1001 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Jenad, Inc. v. Scarsdale


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


23 A.D.2d 784; 258 N.Y.S.2d 777; 1965 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4407



April 19, 1965 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with $ 10 costs and disbursements; plaintiff's motion for summary judgment granted; and the defendants' cross motion denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff land develop challenged an order from the Supreme Court, Westchester County (New York), which denied its motion for summary judgment under former N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 113 and granted a cross motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint filed by defendants, a city and its planning commission. The developer filed an action to recover money paid pursuant to allegedly illegal, null, and void Scarsdale, N.Y., Village Code § 179-1.


OVERVIEW: The developer applied for approval of a subdivision plan. The commission approved the plan, subject to the requirement that the developer deposit with the village a sum for each lot in the subdivision, to be used for park, playground and recreational facilities, in lieu of any land dedication for park, playground and recreational purposes, as provided in § 179-1. The trial court held that even if § 179-1 was illegal the developer was barred from asserting a claim for a refund because of its failure to formally protest the payment or to otherwise indicate that the payment was being made involuntarily. The court held that: (1) § 179-1 was unconstitutional in that it required the payment of a certain sum per lot in a proposed subdivision in lieu of a reservation or dedication of land; (2) the illegal exaction could not be required to be paid by the developer in order to engage in its business of developing land for residential use; and (3) the developer was not estopped from recovering that which was paid under a mistake of law, N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3005.Accordingly, the court reversed the order.


OUTCOME: The court reversed, with costs and disbursements, the order rendered by the trial court, which denied the developer's motion for summary judgment and granted the cross motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint filed by the city and the commission. In the developer's action to recover money paid pursuant to allegedly illegal, null, and void municipal ordinance the court granted the developer's motion and denied the others' cross motion.

 

1002 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Sweeney v. Cannon


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


23 A.D.2d 1; 258 N.Y.S.2d 183; 1965 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4574



March 29, 1965 



DISPOSITION: On defendant's appeal: Judgment and order reversed on the law, without costs; defendant's motion to dismiss the amended complaint granted; and amended complaint dismissed, without costs. No questions of fact were considered.

Cross appeal by plaintiff dismissed as academic, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, the Clerk of the Court of Appeals of the State of New York, sought review of a decision by the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which denied a motion by the clerk to dismiss plaintiff attorney's amended complaint and granted summary judgment in favor of the attorney in his action to have § 467-a of the New York Judiciary Law declared constitutionally invalid. The attorney filed a cross appeal.


OVERVIEW: Section 467-a required all attorneys admitted to practice in the state as of a certain date to register with the clerk and pay a registration fee. On appeal, the court held the statute to be constitutionally valid. The court noted that it was not in a position to weigh the legislature's wisdom for the manner in which it chose to deal with the registration of the attorneys in the state. The court held that the time classification that was the basis of the statute was not unreasonable or arbitrary and, therefore, did violate equal protection or due process. The court also held that the statute did not violate N.Y. Const. art. III, § 22 because that provision only related to general taxes and not to license fees. The court finally held that the statute did not diminish the compensation of judges in violation of art. VI, § 25 because the judges were being treated in their capacities as attorneys.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and dismissed the attorney's amended complaint to declare the statute requiring a license fee constitutionally invalid.


HEADNOTES

Attorneys -- registration -- statute (Judiciary Law, § 467-a) requiring attorneys admitted to practice of law on September 1, 1963 to file certificate of registration and pay $ 15 fee is not unconstitutional.

1. Section 467-a of the Judiciary Law (L. 1963, ch. 204, § 74) provides that: "Every attorney and counsellor-at-law duly licensed and admitted to practice law in this state on the first day of September, nineteen hundred sixty-three, shall, on or before the first day of January, nineteen hundred sixty-four, file with the clerk of the court of appeals a certificate of [***2] registration upon a form which shall be furnished by the clerk, upon application therefor. A fee of fifteen dollars shall accompany the certificate of registration when it is transmitted to the clerk of the court of appeals for filing." This statute is not in violation of the Constitution of the United States or the Constitution of the State of New York.

2. The State has the power to impose a license fee on attorneys as a police regulation or as a revenue measure. ( Adlerstein v. City of New York, 6 N Y 2d 740, distinguished.)

3. The enactment of this statute was a reasonable exercise of the Legislature's power in response to the need for an up-to-date official register of attorneys in order to prevent the unauthorized practice of law. It is not violative of due process.

4. That there is no provision in the statute for keeping the list up-to-date may be a legitimate subject for appropriate legislation in the future, but is no ground for invalidating the statute.

5. The enactment is entitled to a presumption of constitutionality. The classification by the Legislature rests upon a reasonable basis and is not violative of the equal protection provision of the Constitution.  [***3] The Legislature, at this time, chose the simplest means of taking a census or roll call of attorneys presently admitted to practice. The time classification made by the statute is appropriate for that purpose.

6. The provision of the State Constitution (N. Y. Const. art. III, § 22) which reads: "Every law which imposes, continues or revives a tax shall distinctly state the tax and the object to which it is to be applied" refers only to general taxes levied for the general purposes of the State, and not to taxes in the nature of license fees.

7. The statute does not diminish the compensation of Judges in violation of the State Constitution (art. VI, § 25).

 

1003 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Will of Kruger


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, SECOND DEPARTMENT


23 A.D.2d 667; 257 N.Y.S.2d 232; 1965 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4726



March 8, 1965 - Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, daughters of the testator, filed an action in the Surrogate's Court, Richmond County (New York) seeking a judicial construction of the validity of bequests made to respondents, charitable and religious institutions. The charitable institutions sought appellate review of the trial court's order that any gifts exceeding one-half of the father's gross estate passed to the daughters as intestate property.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the court held that the N.Y. Decedent Estate Law § 17 was enacted in accordance with the sound public policy in favor of restricting testamentary dispositions to benevolent, charitable, or religious institutions where a testator was survived by a husband, wife, child, descendant, or parent. The court affirmed the trial court's decision that § 17 required that any gifts to respondents exceeding one-half of the testator's gross estate, less debts, must pass under intestate property laws to the daughters. The court held that the alleged failure of the daughters to perform their filial duties toward their father did not constitute an act of waiver. The court also held that the statute in question was not unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment that the daughters were entitled to a statutory share of their father's estate.

 

1004 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Siegel v. Allen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


23 A.D.2d 520; 255 N.Y.S.2d 336; 1965 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5068



January 12, 1965 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, taxpayers and board of education members, sought review of a judgment entered in the Supreme Court of Albany County (New York) that dismissed their petition under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 to make some capital improvements in its school building to convert an unused basement into a modern and adequate music room.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers and board of education members filed a petition to overturn the education commissioner's denial of their request for building aid, contending that his refusal to grant building aid was arbitrary and capricious and amounted to unconstitutional discrimination. The trial court dismissed their petition. On appeal, the court noted that the education commissioner had acted pursuant to a state master plan for school reorganization, which made certain economic incentives available to those districts that cooperated with the reorganization plan. The plan also allowed the education commissioner to withhold building aid from school districts that did not cooperate with the reorganization plan on the basis that it would impede reorganization. In this case, the taxpayers and board of education members were part of a school district that had rejected reorganization. The court found that the taxpayers and board of education members had failed to show that the education commissioner's decision to deny building aid was arbitrary or capricious or that it amounted to unconstitutional discrimination.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower court's judgment.

 

1005 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Town Board of Poughkeepsie on behalf of Arlington Water Dist. v. Poughkeepsie


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


22 A.D.2d 270; 255 N.Y.S.2d 549; 1964 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 2457



December 21, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Judgment and order reversed on the law and the facts, without costs, and judgment directed to be entered (without costs) which shall contain the following two decretal paragraphs: (1) a paragraph declaring that the fact that plaintiffs were not given notice and opportunity to be heard with respect to the adoption in June, 1961, by the Common Council of the defendant City of Poughkeepsie, of the resolution establishing a new schedule of water rates, effective as of July 1, 1961; and the further fact that the resolution accorded preferential rates to industrial consumers outside the City of Poughkeepsie using in excess of 100,000 cubic feet of water per quarter year, did not render the resolution invalid or unconstitutional; and (2) a paragraph declaring that, as to all the water purchased and delivered on and after July 1, 1961 to the water districts on whose behalf this action was prosecuted, the plaintiff Town Board of the Town of Poughkeepsie is obligated to pay the defendant city therefor [***2] at the increased rates specified in said resolution. The findings of fact implicit or contained in the decision opinion of the Trial Term which may be inconsistent herewith are reversed, and new findings made as indicated in the opinion herewith.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, town and town board acting on behalf of water districts it administered, sought review of a decision of the Supreme Court in Dutchess County (New York), which rejected plaintiffs' claims against defendant city arising out of the city's decision to increase the price for water it sold and delivered to water districts outside the city's territorial boundaries.


OVERVIEW: For many years plaintiffs' water districts had purchased water from the city at a fixed rate. Without notice to plaintiffs, the city increased the water rates. Plaintiffs brought suit claiming that the lack of notice deprived them of property without due process in that they lost the opportunity to be heard with respect to the propriety and validity of the increase and because they had not been able incorporate the increase into their budgeting process. The trial court ruled in favor of the city. On appeal the court reached the same conclusion on the merits but reversed due to the trial court's failure to render its judgment in proper form. The court found nothing in the city's charter nor any other statute which imposed a duty on the city to give water purchasers notice or an opportunity to be heard before increasing water rates. The court further found that, with the possible exception of a reduced rate charged to a university and a hospital, it was not unjust for the city to discriminate by charging lower rates to large industrial users and, even if the city had granted improper preferences, this was not relevant to a dispute between plaintiffs and the city.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and order of the supreme court for the city and directed that judgment be entered declaring that the city's resolution was not unconstitutional and that the town was obligated to pay the city the increased rate for all water purchased and delivered after the effective date of the rate increase.


HEADNOTES

Waters and watercourses -- water supply -- water rates -- defendant city, which has been selling and delivering water to water districts in surrounding area, was not required to give plaintiff Town Board or water district prior notice of intention to increase rates and opportunity to be heard -- no charter or statutory provisions requiring such notice or opportunity -- not unjust discrimination for city to prescribe lower rates for large quantity industrial consumers outside city -- no adjudication made on question whether city had power to grant preferential rate to college and hospital -- consumer may not refuse to pay water bill because preferential rate given to others -- while plaintiffs not entitled to declaratory judgment, complaint not dismissed, but judgment should declare parties' rights.

1. For many years defendant city has been selling and delivering water to water districts in the surrounding area. The rates had [***3] been fixed in 1919. In 1961, when defendant city increased the rates, it was not required to give prior notice and an opportunity to be heard to plaintiff Town Board or the water districts it administers.

2. Neither the charter of the defendant city nor the provisions of any statute made it part of the city's rate-fixing procedure that purchasers of water should be given such notice or opportunity to be heard.

3. The charter provisions enabling the city to establish water rates are not rendered invalid because of the absence of such requirements.

4. While the arrangements under which the water was furnished to the water districts were not formal, they were contractual. Purchasers are presumed to know that the rates may lawfully be changed without notice and without an opportunity to be heard. They contract to purchase water according to the quantity consumed by them and to pay the prevailing rates in existence during the period of consumption.

5. It is not unjust discrimination for defendant city to prescribe lower rates for large quantity industrial consumers outside the city.

6. While the city was without power to grant a preferential rate to a college and a hospital in the [***4] absence of statutory authority, no adjudication should be made here on that question, particularly where the institutions are not parties.

7. A consumer may not refuse to pay a water bill because a preferential rate has been given to other purchasers.

8. While, in this action for a declaratory judgment, plaintiffs are not entitled to a declaration in their favor, the complaint should not have been dismissed. The judgment should declare the rights and other legal relationships of the parties.

 

1006 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Di Paola v. Reilly


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


22 A.D.2d 910; 255 N.Y.S.2d 532; 1964 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 2463



December 21, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed on the law, without costs, and petition dismissed, without costs. 35 Misc 2d 269.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant council members challenged the decision of the Supreme Court, Nassau County (New York), which sustained the petition of respondent board members. The board members' petition sought to declare invalid a resolution of the council terminating the board members' terms of office and for related injunctive relief. The petition was sustained because the resolution was found to have been in direct conflict with N.Y. Gen. City Law § 81.


OVERVIEW: The court held that no questions of fact were presented or considered. The court assumed, without deciding, that the trial court was correct in holding that the city's building zone ordinance was inconsistent with § 81. Nevertheless, the court held that the trial court erred in holding that the invalidity of a portion of the ordinance also invalidated the commencement date fixed for the terms of office of the board members. The court held that the question was whether the legislature, if partial invalidity had been foreseen, would have wished the statute to have been enforced with the invalid part rejected altogether. The court reasoned that the inclusion of a separability clause raised a presumption that the legislature intended the act to have been divisible. The court concluded that the portion of the ordinance that established a commencement date for the terms of office of board members was separable from the invalid portion of the ordinance. Therefore, the court held that the commencement portion of the ordinance was valid.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and dismissed the petition.

 

1007 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Dolan v. Krone


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


22 A.D.2d 234; 254 N.Y.S.2d 702; 1964 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 2494



December 18, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, 17 applicants that took a civil service competitive promotional examination for the post of deputy clerk or assistant deputy clerk of the supreme court, sought review of the decision of the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which dismissed their N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding against respondents, Civil Service Commission members, to obtain credit for an answer given on the examination.


OVERVIEW: The applicants' answers were marked incorrect on one question involving whether the trial court could direct the jury in a criminal proceeding to be discharged before the case was submitted to them if it appeared from testimony that: (1) The facts proved constituted a crime of a higher nature than that charged in the indictment; (2) The court did not have jurisdiction of the crime charged in the indictment; or (3) The facts as charged in the indictment did not constitute a crime. The applicants marked that all three applied. The dispute centered on whether (1) was correct. The court affirmed, finding that while N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 400 supported (1), it had been declared unconstitutional on the ground that it exposed defendants to double jeopardy. The applicants contended that the answers were to be based only on statutory law. The court found that it was implicit from the directions that the questions were not based solely on statutory law. The court found that N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 260 was based on a narrow exception to the law and did not apply to the question. Thus, the correct answer was (2) and (3).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of the commission in the applicants' proceeding to obtain credit for an answer given on the examination for the post of deputy clerk or assistant deputy clerk of the supreme court.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- examination -- correctness of answer -- petitioners, candidates for posts of Deputy Clerk or Assistant Deputy Clerk in Supreme Court, in error in answering question where answer was supported by statute but statute had been declared unconstitutional -- examination not based solely on statute law -- petitioners' answer not supported by isolated and exceptional statutory provision where question called for practices and procedures generally applicable -- Civil Service Commission's "pre-rating appeal" system not arbitrary or capricious.

1. Petitioners who took competitive civil service examinations for the posts of Deputy Clerk or Assistant Deputy Clerk in the Supreme Court were in error when they agreed, in answering one of the questions, that "The court may direct the jury in a criminal proceeding to be discharged before the case is submitted to them if it appears from [***2] the testimony that * * * The facts proved constitute a crime of a higher nature than that charged in the indictment." A statute (Code Crim. Pro., § 400) specifically supported that statement, but it had been declared unconstitutional on the ground that it exposes defendants to double jeopardy. It was implicit in the directions given in the examination that the questions were not based solely on statute law.

2. Under section 260 of the Penal Law which provides that: "A person may be convicted of an attempt to commit a crime, although it appears on the trial that the crime was consummated, unless the court, in its discretion, discharges the jury and directs the defendant to be tried for the crime itself" the jury may be discharged when the facts indicate a crime of a higher nature than that charged in the indictment. Nevertheless, the examination instructions specifically called for the practice and procedures generally applicable to the courts of record in New York State and section 260 is an isolated and exceptional provision and is not indicative of practice and procedures generally applicable.

3. The Civil Service Commission's "pre-rating appeal" system is not arbitrary or capricious

 

1008 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Chusud Realty Corp. v. Kensington


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


22 A.D.2d 895; 255 N.Y.S.2d 411; 1964 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 2567



December 14, 1964 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, a village, its mayor, and its trustees, appealed from a judgment of the Supreme Court, Nassau County (New York), which, inter alia, declared a village zoning ordinance unconstitutional and void insofar as it affected plaintiff owner's property, in the owner's action challenging the constitutionality of the zoning ordinance. The owner cross-appealed from so much of the judgment as limited the owner's recovery of damages to $ 50,000.


OVERVIEW: The owner filed an action to declare void and unconstitutional the zoning ordinance enacted by the village on February 9, 1926, insofar as it affected the owner's property, and for other relief. The ordinance limited development on the property to detached one-family dwellings. On review of the trial court's decision declaring the ordinance unconstitutional, the court noted that the ordinance at issue had been declared invalid in a 1931 decision with respect to a vacant parcel of comparable property situated near the owner's property. The record in the instant case supported the trial court judge's view that the continued development and utilization of properties in the vicinity for apartment houses and other commercial uses made the sale of residences in this area as economically unfeasible for the instant owner as it was in 1931. Thus, the continued application of the would have destroyed the greater part of the value of the subject property and precluded the owner from other proper uses to which the property was reasonably adapted. Also, the trial court did not err in limiting the village's liability for damages by reason of the appeal to $ 50, 000.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment on appeal and on cross-appeal.

 

1009 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Grossman v. Baumgartner


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


22 A.D.2d 100; 254 N.Y.S.2d 335; 1964 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 2682



December 1, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Judgment for plaintiffs reversed, on the law and the facts, without costs and judgment granted to defendants. Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant board appealed an order of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which ruled in favor of plaintiff tattoo operators in an action for declaratory judgment declaring New York City, N.Y., Health Code § 181.15 unconstitutional and enjoining the board from enforcing it.


OVERVIEW: The tattoo operators sought a declaratory judgment declaring New York City, N.Y., Health Code § 181.15 unconstitutional and enjoining the board from enforcing it. The section made it unlawful for any person to tattoo a human being. An exception was made for physicians acting for medical purposes. The operators argued that tattooing was a vocation that could be regulated but not prohibited. The court reversed the trial court and held that the record showed that the prohibition of lay tattooing was an advisable procedure for the security of life and health and that the control of tattooing came well within the field of securing the health of the community. The court determined that it was not the operators who were on trial but the trade they engaged in, and because the practices of the trade endangered the community, they had to suffer the same fate despite their ability to rise above their fellow practitioners.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that had held in favor of the tattoo operators in their action seeking a declaration that the health code section that barred tattooing was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Health -- tattooing -- regulation forbidding tattooing except by doctors is valid exercise of police power against hepatitis -- immaterial that plaintiffs are willing to meet sanitary standards; health regulation is directed against practices of entire trade -- exception for doctors is valid, and anyway is separable.

1. Section 181.15, as amended, of the New York City Health Code, which makes it unlawful to tattoo a human being except for medical purposes by doctors, is authorized by the New York City Charter (§ 558), and is a valid exercise of the police power. The record shows that hepatitis is a serious disease, that there is no known cure, that it is transmitted by injection of the blood products of infected persons, that such transmissions occur [***2] seven times more frequently to persons who have been tattooed than to other persons, that tattooing is often associated with a morbid or abnormal personality, and that it is too much to expect that nonmedical personnel will adhere to sanitary practices needed to provide a reasonable assurance against transmitting infection. There is no constitutional prohibition against outright banning of a practice which is harmful to public health.

2. It is immaterial that the two plaintiffs in this action are able and willing to meet sanitary standards. They are not individually on trial. The health regulation is directed against the practices of the entire trade.

3. The exception for physicians is not too vague; in any case, the exception is separable and cannot affect the validity of the rest of the regulation.

 

1010 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cornish


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


21 A.D.2d 280; 250 N.Y.S.2d 233; 1964 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3618



June 2, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Order, entered on April 2, 1962, denying defendant's motion in the nature of writ of error coram nobis, unanimously affirmed, without prejudice to a motion for resentence, if defendant be so advised, on proper papers asserting facts and supported by corroborative affidavits and public records, together with the facts defendant claims constitute good cause for not having made timely challenge as required by the statute.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the order of the Court of General Sessions, County of New York (New York), which denied his motion for a writ of error coram nobis. Defendant filed the motion seeking a remedy under an amendment to N.Y. Penal Law § 1943 (1964). Almost 30 years previously, he was convicted of robbery in the first degree and sentenced as a multiple felony offender.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of robbery in the first degree. He was sentenced as a multiple felony offender based on prior felony convictions in Pennsylvania. He attacked the sentence on the grounds that the Pennsylvania convictions did not constitute felonies under New York law and that they were unconstitutional. The trial court denied a writ of error coram nobis. Affirming, the court found that it was not the proper remedy under the amendment to § 1943. The court concluded that the statute had a retrospective application and a defendant could challenge the unconstitutionality of predicated convictions when he or she was arraigned as a multiple offender. The court concluded that the proper remedy for a sentencing challenge under the amended statute was a motion for resentencing.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court, which denied a writ of error coram nobis, without prejudice to a motion for resentence.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- multiple offender sentence -- foreign judgment -- statute (L. 1964, ch. 446; Penal Law, § 1943) which provides State remedy on sentence for challenge of prior convictions under Multiple Offender Law on ground that they were rendered in violation of constitutional limitations, should be given retrospective effect -- proper remedy is motion for resentence -- coram nobis proceeding not available -- defendant's allegations are insufficient and conclusory and upon motion for resentence should recite facts supported by affidavits and records.

 [***2] 1. When the present proceeding was instituted, there was no available State remedy to correct a multiple offender sentence predicated upon out-of-State convictions rendered in violation of the constitutional right to counsel. Chapter 446 of the Laws of 1964 amends section 1943 of the Penal Law to provide that, upon arraignment of a defendant as a multiple offender, he may raise the unconstitutionality of any prior conviction relied upon whether rendered in or out of the State. This statute which now provides a State remedy, on sentence, for challenge of prior convictions on the ground that they were rendered in violation of constitutional limitations, should be given retrospective effect.

2. Since the proper remedy is now a motion for resentence, a coram nobis proceeding is not available and, accordingly, the order denying a motion for a writ of error coram nobis is affirmed.

3. Defendant's allegations with regard to his principal contention that prior Pennsylvania convictions, upon which he was sentenced in this State as a fourth felony offender, were rendered in violation of constitutional limitations in that he was not informed of his right to counsel and that he was [***3] not represented by counsel at any stage of the proceedings are insufficient and are conclusory. The order denying the application in coram nobis is without prejudice to a motion for resentence on the same grounds presented in the petition, but such an application should consist of more than conclusory allegations and should recite the facts, supported by available affidavits and records from Pennsylvania.

 

1011 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. De Jesus


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


21 A.D.2d 236; 250 N.Y.S.2d 317; 1964 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3680



May 26, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Appeal unanimously dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State appealed from the order of the Chautauqua County Court (New York) that transferred to the family court defendant's trial on the charge of assault in the second degree.


OVERVIEW: An indictment was filed against defendant, which charged him with assault in the second degree based upon allegations that he cut his wife's face with a razor blade. Upon arraignment in the county court, defendant filed a motion for an order to transfer the proceeding to the family court. The county court granted the motion, and the case was transferred. The State appealed, urging that the family court had no felony jurisdiction, that the county court had no authority to transfer the proceeding to family court, and that the family court could not divest the grand jury of its constitutional power to indict defendant for the alleged felony. The court dismissed the State's appeal on the ground that the county court's order was not a final, appealable order. The court also held that defendant's indictment was not valid because the procedures contained in the Family Court Act were not followed. The court stated that after defendant's surrender to the police, the case should have been transferred to the family court because N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 13, subd. 13 required that proceedings arising from crimes and offenses between spouses originate in the family court.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the State's appeal from the order of the county court that transferred to the family court defendant's trial on the charge of second-degree assault.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Family Court -- jurisdiction -- order of County Court granting motion to transfer proceeding to Family Court is not appealable to Appellate Division -- however, County Court had authority to transfer proceeding to Family Court -- proceedings involving crimes between spouses should originate in Family Court but provision has been made for transfer of proceedings commenced in another court -- fact that defendant had purportedly been "indicted" would not exclude right to transfer -- District Attorney was without power to obtain indictment -- procedure authorized by Family Court Act is not in conflict with constitutional powers of Grand Jury to indict.

1. An order of the County Court granting a motion to transfer a proceeding to Family Court is not appealable to the Appellate Division.

2. The County Court did have authority to transfer the proceeding to the Family Court.

3. Subdivision b of section 13 of article VI of the New York State Constitution provides that the Family [***2] Court shall have jurisdiction of crimes between spouses and that they "shall be originated in * * * family court". Under article 8 of the Family Court Act, the Family Court is given "exclusive original jurisdiction over any proceeding concerning acts which would constitute disorderly conduct or an assault between spouses" (§ 812). While it is intended that proceedings arising because of such acts be originated by the filing of a petition with the Family Court and that there be resort to the procedures of that court in the first instance (§§ 114, 821-827), provision is made in section 813 for the transfer of cases should they be commenced in another court.

4. In the present case the procedures established by the Family Court Act were not followed. The matter should have been transferred to Family Court at the time of the arraignment. Nevertheless, defendant was purportedly indicted in Supreme Court. Thereafter the proceeding was transferred to County Court, and it was not until arraignment in County Court that the transfer to Family Court was ordered. There is, however, specific authority for the transfer to Family Court at this stage of the proceedings (N. Y. Const., art. VI,  [***3] § 19, subd. b).

5. The fact that defendant was "indicted" would not exclude the right to transfer. To prevent a transfer there must be a valid indictment. The Legislature has, as authorized by section 13 (subd. b), determined that an assault between spouses shall not be brought within the category of crimes until and unless a Family Court Judge, having decided that the processes and remedies of his court are inappropriate, has transferred the proceeding to the appropriate court for criminal proceedings. Then the right to indict may arise for the first time. The District Attorney's determination to obtain an indictment was beyond his powers.

6. The procedure authorized by the Family Court Act is not in conflict with the constitutional powers of a Grand Jury to indict.

 

1012 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Singer v. Walker


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


21 A.D.2d 285; 250 N.Y.S.2d 216; 1964 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3682



May 26, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Order, entered on November 21, 1963, unanimously reversed, on the law, without costs, and the motion to vacate service of the summons and complaint denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff sought review of an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term in New York County (New York) that granted a motion to vacate service of the summons and complaint upon defendant foreign corporation.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff filed a personal injury action against the foreign corporation alleging breach of warranty and negligence. The foreign corporation was the manufacturer of a hammer, which broke and injured the plaintiff's minor. The supreme court held that it did not have jurisdiction over the foreign corporation and dismissed the complaint. Plaintiff appealed and the court reversed the supreme court's decision because the foreign corporation sent the mislabeled defective hammer into the New York market and the state had jurisdiction over the a foreign corporation that caused an action to be done there. Although, the tort occurred in Connecticut when the minor was visiting a third party, the court concluded that the tortious act was the circulation in New York of the dangerous instrument mislabeled, and this action was the proximate cause and connected with of the resulting injury. The court determined that the hammer could have broken in New York as easily as it did in Connecticut. The court noted that due process considerations would be more restrictive if a simple dispute over a commercial contract was involved.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the supreme court's order vacating the service of a summons and complaint.


HEADNOTES

Process -- service on nonresidents -- defendant foreign corporation, which circulated in New York defective geologist's hammer manufactured by it, marked unbreakable but which broke, committed tortious act in New York sufficient to subject it to jurisdiction of New York courts ( CPLR 302).

Defendant, foreign corporation which circulated in New York a dangerous instrument, i.e., a geologist's hammer manufactured by it, marked as unbreakable but which broke and caused personal injuries to infant plaintiff, while using it in Connecticut, thereby committed a tortious act in New York within the meaning of 302 (subd. [a], par. 2) of the Civil Practice Law and Rules, sufficient to subject defendant to the jurisdiction of the New York courts and to satisfy the constitutional limitations which require [***2] some contacts with the State. The single act statute does not require the cause of action to arise in New York and so the occurrence of the harm in Connecticut was incidental. The tortious act, the circulation in New York of the mislabeled, dangerous instrument was proximately connected with the acquisition and continued possession by infant plaintiff and his resulting injury.

 

1013 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Harris v. Lindsay


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


21 A.D.2d 102; 248 N.Y.S.2d 691; 1964 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3960



April 23, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Order, entered on February 4, 1964, unanimously reversed on the law, without costs, the petition dismissed, and the relator remanded to the custody of the Warden of the House of Detention for Women. Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State and appellant warden challenged the order of the Supreme Court in New York County (New York), which sustained respondent relator's writ of habeas corpus and released her from the custody of the warden of the women's house of detention.


OVERVIEW: The relator was convicted in the criminal court of New York City for health code violations, and she was sentenced to 90 days' imprisonment in the women's house of detention. She alleged that her commitment was void because an assistant court clerk signed it. The lower court sustained her writ of habeas corpus on the grounds that the commitment did not meet the statutory provisions for the proper mode of commitment. The State and the warden appealed. The court held that the city criminal court had jurisdiction over crimes and violations of the law other than those to be prosecuted by indictment. The chief clerk of the court or his designated assistant clerks were authorized to certify the minutes of the city criminal court. N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 486 applied to the city criminal court, which pertained to commitments for the execution of a judgment entered in any criminal court of the state. The warden only needed the certified copy of the minutes, and no other warrant or authority. The judgment was valid, and the relator's commitment was not void for any purported defects in the certified copy of the judgment of conviction as it appeared the city criminal court' minutes.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order, dismissed the petition for a writ of habeas corpus, and remanded the relator to the warden's custody.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- commitment -- commitment issued and signed by Assistant Court Clerk when relator was convicted in Criminal Court of City of New York and, upon being sentenced, was delivered to Warden of House of Detention for Women of City of New York was proper (cf. Code Crim. Pro., § 486) -- in any event, commitment not invalid where defendant not prejudiced in substantial right (Code Crim. Pro., § 684) -- existence of judgment of conviction can always be shown in justification of detention.

1. Relator was convicted in the Criminal Court of the City of New York and, upon being sentenced, was delivered to the Warden of the House of Detention for Women of the City of New York. The commitment, which was issued and signed by an Assistant Court Clerk, meets the [***2] provisions of statute providing for the proper mode of commitment. It is the judgment of conviction of the Criminal Court which authorizes the detention of defendant for the purpose of serving the sentence imposed. Section 486 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, which is applicable here, provides that "a certified copy of the entry [of the judgment] upon the minutes must be forthwith furnished to the officer whose duty it is to execute the judgment; and no other warrant or authority is necessary to justify or require its execution." The Chief Clerk of the Criminal Court and any Court Clerk thereof would have the power to certify the copy of the minutes of conviction. The powers and duties of the Chief Clerk or a Court Clerk could be performed by a deputy or assistant.

2. In any event, it is expressly provided that departure from the form or mode prescribed by the statute in respect to the proceedings, or an error or mistake therein, will not invalidate the same unless the defendant is prejudiced in a substantial right (Code Crim. Pro., § 684).

3. On the return of a writ of habeas corpus inquiring into the cause of the detention, the existence of the judgment can always be shown [***3] in full justification of the detention.

4. Moreover, now there has been supplied by the signature and certification of the Court Clerk himself due and proper evidence of the judgment of conviction outstanding against relator and, on the basis thereof, relator may properly be remanded to custody.

 

1014 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Gaynor v. Rockefeller


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


21 A.D.2d 92; 248 N.Y.S.2d 792; 1964 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3971; 56 L.R.R.M. 2210; 49 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P51,100



April 21, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Order, entered on or about December 12, 1963, unanimously reversed on the law for the reasons stated in the opinion of this court filed herein, the complaint dismissed, without costs and without prejudice as to any or further action as plaintiffs may be advised to pursue. Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, public officials and labor unions, appealed the denial by the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York) of their cross motions to dismiss respondent black residents' complaint seeking a declaratory judgment and an injunction against them. Respondents appealed the denial of their motion for a preliminary injunction.


OVERVIEW: Respondent black residents brought a class action for a declaratory judgment, an injunction, as well as a taxpayer's action under N.Y. Gen. Mun. § 51, against defendants, public officials, and labor unions. Respondents claimed they were unsuccessful in gaining admittance to defendant unions because of race. The lower court denied them the preliminary injunction, and denied defendants' cross motions for dismissal of the complaint. On appeal, defendants claimed the complaint failed to state a cause of action, and that the court had no jurisdiction of the subject matter. The court concluded that the action was not the proper vehicle. Defendant public officials had no contracts with defendant unions. The contracts were with private firms, none of whom were parties defendant. Defendant unions were also not parties to the contracts in controversy and there was a fatal deficiency of parties defendant. The relief sought by respondents, of judicial supervision of union activities in the manner requested, was not within the scope of judicial competence. The order was reversed on the law and the complaint dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order on the law, dismissed respondents' complaint, without costs and without prejudice as to any or further action as respondents might be advised to pursue.


HEADNOTES

Civil rights -- labor unions -- Negroes, allegedly refused admission to construction unions, sue unions and State and city officials for declaratory judgment and injunction against discrimination (N. Y. Const., art. I, § 11) and for enforcement of laws (Civil Rights Law, §§ 43, 45; Labor Law, § 220-e; Penal Law, § 700; Administrative Code of City of New York, § 343-8.0) and against expenditures of public moneys on construction contracts (General Municipal Law, § 51); complaint dismissed, without prejudice -- contractors not joined as parties defendant; complaint  [***2] insufficient as to State and city officials; close supervision of unions beyond judicial competence -- however, plaintiffs are not limited to NLRB or SCHR procedures, or by labor disputes anti-injunction statutes.

1. In this class action in equity by four Negroes who are citizens of the United States and residents of the State of New York, plaintiffs allege that the defendant unions exercise a practical monopoly of skilled crafts in the construction industry and that said unions maintain discriminatory practices which bar plaintiffs and the class which plaintiffs represent from admittance to their apprentice training programs and memberships and consequently from employment, and that public moneys are being expended on five such construction contracts by the City of New York and on one such contract by the State of New York; wherefore plaintiffs seek (1) a judgment declaring their rights (under N. Y. Const., art. I, § 11; Executive Law, § 296; Penal Law, § 700; and other statutes) and (2) to enjoin said unions from requiring applicants for admittance to have sponsors among current or former members, to enjoin said unions from using their present lists of applicants discriminatorily [***3] obtained and used, to direct said unions to destroy said lists, and to direct said unions, under the supervision of the court, to adopt and use fair tests for admittance to their apprentice training programs; and (3) to enjoin the Governor, the Comptroller, and the Industrial Commissioner of the State of New York from expending public moneys on said State contract and to direct these defendants to enforce the Civil Rights Law ( §§ 43, 45) and the Labor Law ( § 220-e) as to such contract; and (4) to enjoin the Mayor and other officials of the City of New York (under General Municipal Law, § 51) from expending public moneys on said city contracts and on any such new contracts, and to direct said city officials to enforce the provisions of the Administrative Code of the City of New York (§ 343-8.0) as to said contracts. The complaint is dismissed, without prejudice.

2. The unions are not parties to the contracts, and the contractors are not joined as parties defendant. The complaint does not sufficiently show an "illegal official act * * * or * * * waste or injury" (General Municipal Law, § 51), or that the Governor or Mayor or other official has violated any constitutional or statutory [***4] provision. Moreover, the requested extent of judicial supervision of union activities is beyond the scope of judicial competence. Plaintiffs may pursue any or further action, as they may be advised.

3. Plaintiffs' grievances are not within the sole jurisdiction of the State Commission for Human Rights; and particularly not when no proceeding is pending before the commission (Executive Law, § 300). Plaintiffs' grievances are not exclusively within the jurisdiction of the National Labor Relations Board (U. S. Code, tit. 29, § 141 et seq.). This is not a "labor dispute" between employers and employees subject to the anti-injunction statute (Labor Law, §§ 701, 807).

 

1015 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Westchester Motels, Inc. v. Elmsford


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


20 A.D.2d 818; 248 N.Y.S.2d 698; 1964 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4178



March 23, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Order modified by striking out the third decretal paragraph granting the motion of the defendant village to dismiss the complaint, and by substituting therefor a paragraph denying such motion. As so modified, order affirmed, without costs, with leave to the defendants to serve an answer within 20 days after entry of the order hereon.

 

1016 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Balaban v. Rubin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


20 A.D.2d 438; 248 N.Y.S.2d 574; 1964 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4237



March 10, 1964 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed on the law, without costs, and petition dismissed. The findings of fact implicit in the decision of the Special Term are affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent board of education appealed from a judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Kings County (New York), which granted judgment in favor of petitioner parents and annulled a new school zone adopted by the board. The parents of white children living in the disputed area who were scheduled to go to the new school had sought review of the board's determination fixing the zone for that new school.


OVERVIEW: The issue was whether the board had the power to draw the zoning lines in a newly established junior high school so as to prevent segregation within that school at its inception. The lower court held that the board had no such power and that its inclusion of racial balance as a material basis for the board's determination rendered it unlawful under N.Y. Educ. Law § 3201.The court reversed and held that, in drawing attendance lines for a school, it was not only within the power of the board to take into consideration the ethnic composition of the children, but that it was the board's responsibility so to do in order to prevent the creation of a segregated public school. The board had the power to establish school attendance zones; to determine the area that a particular school should serve; and to require the students in that area to attend that school. Moreover, § 3201 was not violated because none of the white children at issue had been excluded from the school because of their race. In addition, the other criteria utilized by the board furnished ample support for the zone, such as easy access from all parts of the zone and the central location of the school within the zone.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the lower court annulling the new school zone adopted by the board and dismissed the parents' petition.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- zoning lines -- integration -- Board of Education of City of New York had power to draw zoning lines with respect to attendance of children in newly established junior high school to prevent segregation in school -- board had right to consider question of race or color as criterion in determining zone and did not violate constitutional or statutory rights of petitioners ( Brown v. Board of Educ., 347 U.S. 483; Brown v. Board of Educ., 349 U.S. 249; Education Law, § 3201) -- board also properly considered distance from home to school, utilization of school space, convenience of transportation, topographic barriers and continuity of instruction.

1. The Board of Education of [***2] the City of New York has the power to draw zoning lines with respect to the attendance of children in a newly established junior high school so as to prevent segregation within that school at its inception. The zone as fixed by the board for the new J. H. S. 275 in the Borough of Brooklyn was proper and lawful. In drawing attendance lines for a school, it is not only within the power of the board to take into consideration the ethnic composition of the children therein but, under the decisions of the Supreme Court of the United States, it is the board's responsibility so to do in order to prevent the creation of a segregated public school.

2. The Assistant Superintendent of Schools, in charge of the school district involved, in February, 1962 proposed a zone which (a) was geographically irregular, (b) placed the school in the approximate corner of a peculiarly shaped area, remote from the zone's northern area, and (c) would result in a school population consisting of 14% white, 52% Negro, and 34% Puerto Rican. The board modified the plan by cutting off the northern area and permitting it to remain in the zone for the existing J. H. S. 263 and shifting the easterly and southwesterly [***3] boundaries. The effect of this shift was to transfer and place within the zone for the new J. H. S. 275 a 12-block area which is the subject of this proceeding. As a result of the change, the children expected to attend J. H. S. 275 as of September, 1963 would initially consist of 35.2% Negro, 33.6% Puerto Rican, and 31.2% others. In promulgating the zone for the new J. H. S. 275, the board admittedly took into consideration the distance from home to school, utilization of school space, convenience of transportation, racial integration of the school, topographic barriers, and continuity of instruction. The Board of Education had the right to consider the question of race or color as one of the criteria in determining the zone for the new J. H. S. 275 in order to prevent segregation, and in doing so it did not violate any of the constitutional or statutory rights of petitioners (cf. Brown v. Board of Educ., 347 U.S. 483; Brown v. Board of Educ., 349 U.S. 294). In addition to the racial criterion, all the other five criteria utilized by the board furnish ample support for the zone fixed by it for the new J. H. S. 275.

3. The zoning for J. H. S. 275 did not violate [***4] section 3201 of the Education Law which provides that "No person shall be refused admission into or be excluded from any public school in the state of New York on account of race, creed, color or national origin." Each child has the right to attend only the public school in the zone or district in which he resides (Education Law, § 3202, subd. 1). This means the school nearest to his home. All of the white children on whose behalf this proceeding was instituted live closer to or no further from J. H. S. 275 than from J. H. S. 285. Therefore, J. H. S. 275 is the school in the district of their residence. Only if these children had been excluded from J. H. S. 275 because of their race or color, would there have been a violation of section 3201 of the Education Law. Section 3201 of the Education Law can mean only that no person on account of race, creed, color or national origin, shall be refused admission to or be excluded from any public school to which he is entitled to go as of right.

4. If section 3201 of the Education Law can be utilized to defeat efforts to desegregate schools, then, in the light of the Brown decisions by the Supreme Court, that statute would have to [***5] be declared unconstitutional.

5. The argument that J. H. S. 275 was zoned to establish a racial quota is untenable. There was no quota system in this case.

6. The zone established did not violate section 40 of the Civil Rights Law. None of the rights or privileges of these white children will be denied them if they attend J. H. S. 275. They will have the same rights or privileges accorded to all other children in that school.

 

1017 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Larkin v. G. P. Putnam's Sons


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


20 A.D.2d 702; 247 N.Y.S.2d 275; 1964 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4300



February 27, 1964 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Judgment was entered dismissing plaintiff city counsel's complaint in an action for an injunction and other relief pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. § 22 regarding the publication, distribution, and sale of a book alleged to be obscene.


OVERVIEW: The question in the instant case was not what the court's preference was with respect to permitting the publication, distribution, and sale of the book in question, but rather whether the statute under consideration, without offending the Constitution of the United States or that of the State of New York, prohibited such publication, distribution, and sale. The court thought it did. The court concluded that the book did come within the proscriptions of N.Y. Crim. Proc. § 22 and that the injunction asked for did not violate the State or Federal Constitutions. In the court's opinion, the book, as a whole, did treat sex in a manner appealing to prurient interest thus coming within the boundaries of any permissible definition of obscenity under the United States Constitution and did meet the more stringent "hard-core pornography" test essential to a finding of obscenity under the New York State statutes. Thus, the court held that the book was "obscene."


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment on the law and the facts and directed that judgment be entered in favor of the city counsel for the prayed for relief.

 

1018 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Essenfeld Bros., Inc. v. Hostetter


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


20 A.D.2d 34; 245 N.Y.S.2d 291; 1963 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 2715



December 12, 1963 



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant New York State Liquor Authority (state) sought review of an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term, New York County (New York), which granted plaintiff alcohol distributors' motion for summary judgment in an action for a permanent injunction and to declare the rights of the alcohol distributors under the New York Alcoholic Beverage Control Law.


OVERVIEW: The alcohol distributors distributed "order kits" for the purchase abroad of alcoholic beverages. The customers mailed the orders and the payments outside the United States, a foreign agent caused each purchase to be packaged separately and shipped to New York City piers, where the individual packages were removed and delivered to the homes of the purchasers. The trial court granted the alcohol distributors' motion for summary judgment. On appeal the court reversed, holding that: (1) the alcohol distributors shipped and brought and caused to be shipped and brought into the state alcoholic beverages not consigned to licensed traffickers of alcoholic beverages contrary to the provisions of N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law § 102(1)(c), (d); (2) it was immaterial that the alcohol distributors may have been the agents of the purchasers because the statute proscribed shipment or bringing into the state except to a licensed trafficker of liquor and did not exclude therefrom proscribed acts performed as agents or in behalf of the purchasers; and (3) the alcohol distributors could not rely on State Liquor Authority Bulletin No. 263 because a bulletin may not serve to vary a statute.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment which granted the alcohol distributors' motion for summary judgment. The court modified the trial court's judgment by declaring that the state's Bulletin No. 359 was in conformity with the law and that the alcohol distributors were prohibited from bringing into the state alcoholic beverages unless they were consigned to a person duly licensed to traffic therein. Otherwise, the complaint was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Intoxicating liquors -- liquor purchased by travelers abroad -- carriers cannot bring into New York alcoholic beverages which were bought and shipped by travelers abroad, unless such beverages are consigned to persons licensed to traffic in such beverages in New York (Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, § 102, subd. 1) -- carriers, as licensees under Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, cannot attack constitutionality of law, nor can they assert any constitutional rights of such purchasers.

Plaintiff corporations are engaged in commercial transportation and they hold permits of the State Liquor Authority to carry alcoholic beverages within the State of New York. Another corporation distributes in New York so-called "order kits" in which it solicits [***2] persons traveling abroad to purchase liquor abroad at low prices, by mailing their order and payment outside the United States and by declaring their purchase to United States customs on their return. Such orders are directed to a Swiss bank, which forwards them to various liquor suppliers in Switzerland and Belgium and makes payment therefor. On receipt of the United States customs forms, a foreign agent of the plaintiffs causes each purchase to be separately packaged and placed with others in large containers. The containers are shipped to New York City piers, whence they are moved to plaintiffs' terminals within New York, and the individual packages are then removed and delivered to the homes of the individual purchasers. The individual purchasers are not licensed to traffic in liquors in the State of New York (Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, § 102, subd. 1, pars. [c], [d], [e]; see, also, Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, §§ 2, 3, subds. 28, 30; § 93, subd. 1; § 102, subd. 1, pars. [a], [b]; §§ 100, 116; U. S. Code, tit. 27, § 121; U. S. Const., 21st Amdt., § 2). Plaintiffs, as licensees under the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, cannot attack the constitutionality [***3] of the law; nor can they assert any constitutional rights of the individual purchasers. A declaratory judgment and injunction in favor of plaintiffs and against the State Liquor Authority is reversed. Judgment is directed declaring that a bulletin issued by the State Liquor Authority is in conformity with the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law ( § 102, subd. 1, par. [c]), and that said section prohibits plaintiffs from bringing and shipping into this State alcoholic beverages unless they are consigned to a person duly licensed under the statute to traffic therein; and otherwise dismissing the complaint.

 

1019 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of McIntosh


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


19 A.D.2d 931; 244 N.Y.S.2d 508; 1963 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 2881



November 21, 1963 



DISPOSITION:  [**1] Accordingly, the determination of the board is modified by reducing the suspension period to four months and, as modified, in all other respects affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner surveyor appealed the determination of respondent Board of Regents (New York), which suspended his license for one year. The charge was a violation of N.Y. Educ. Law § 7210. The Board determined that the surveyor was guilty of fraud and deceit. The surveyor questioned the constitutionality of § 7210 as to the procedural requirements and its indefiniteness.


OVERVIEW: The petitioner was a licensed surveyor. His letterhead stated that he was associated with several engineers and architects. The "associates" listed on his letterhead testified that they had never given him permission to use their names in such manner. The surveyor also, under the guise of the "Associates," rendered a building elevation design for a town hall, which was an engineering job. Based on that evidence, the surveyor's license was suspended for one year for violating § 7210, which prohibited the holder of a license from falsely impersonating a practitioner or practicing under an assumed or fictitious name. The surveyor argued that § 7210 was procedurally unconstitutional because it prescribed, in effect, that the investigation, charge, and trial were all to be directed and heard by the same body, and thus, the Board acted as the accuser and judge, which was a denial of due process. The court rejected the surveyor's argument, holding that it was the Board's responsibility to determine that the motivations for any form of discipline were within the intent of the law. The court did find that the measure of discipline was excessive.


OUTCOME: The court modified the determination of the Board by reducing the suspension period, and as modified, affirmed the determination.

 

1020 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


United States Steel Corp. v. Gerosa


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


19 A.D.2d 313; 241 N.Y.S.2d 321; 1963 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3305



July 9, 1963, Decided



DISPOSITION: Determination annulled, on the law and in the interests of justice, without costs, and the matter remanded to respondent to recompute the tax on an allocation basis, and to consider further the question of penalty (cf. Matter of McCall Corp. v. Gerosa, 2 A D 2d 358).


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer sought review of a determination by made by respondent, the Comptroller of the City of New York, which assessed against the taxpayer a specific sum as privilege taxes due at the general business rate. The Comptroller acted on remand from the Court of Appeals (New York), which held that the Comptroller had incorrectly assessed the taxpayer at the financial business rate.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was a New Jersey holding company with its principal place of business located in the City of New York. Most of its income, for the privilege years in question, consisted of dividends and interest from some 68 controlled subsidiaries. In 1948, 1949, and 1950, it received dividends and interest in the aggregate amount of $ 421 million. The taxpayer successfully challenged an assessment against it as a financial business, but on remand the Comptroller reimposed the same amount, only changing the label to "general business." The taxpayer sought review. The court annulled the determination, remanding for recalculation. The court held that the statute of limitations did not bar the assessment because the Comptroller acted on remand. The Comptroller had jurisdiction to conduct a hearing on the subject. But, as the city's practice was always to allocate receipts by determining which were allocable to the city, the taxpayer was entitled to a redetermination which did that.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the Comptroller's determination, remanding for a recomputation of the tax on an allocation basis and for a reconsideration of the question of penalty.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- New York City General Business and Financial Tax -- review of determination imposing general business tax -- Court of Appeals ruling that holding companies are subject to general business tax, not financial business tax, nullified all prior proceedings herein so that it is as if petitioner did not file return -- therefore, respondent not time-barred from imposing tax on general business tax basis -- since protested tax is imposed on subject matter not previously taxed, it is not time-barred as addition to business tax already levied  [***2] -- identity, on remand, of principal amount and penalty with that found in earlier proceeding indicates mere exchange of labels -- matter remanded for recomputation of tax based on allocation of taxable receipts and, since petitioner had filed timely returns under erroneous classification required by respondent, for reconsideration of question of penalties.

1. Respondent assessed a "Business Tax Deficiency" for the years 1948, 1949 and 1950 against petitioner, a New Jersey holding company with its principal place of business in New York City, basing its assessment in part on a general business basis, determined in relation to pension deficit charges and wire expense charges to subsidiaries, and profit on sale of securities, and in part on a financial business basis, determined by allocating to New York City 12 1/2% of the total dividends and interest received by petitioner from all of its controlled subsidiaries. The business tax deficiency was compromised. The financial business tax deficiency was confirmed at $ 176,767.28, plus interest and penalties. Petitioner instituted a review proceeding, in which it was ultimately held by the Court of Appeals that holding companies were [***3] not intended to be included in the definition of financial business. Upon remand, respondent scheduled a hearing at which petitioner offered no proof respecting the computation of the general business tax but merely challenged respondent's jurisdiction to hold the hearing. Thereafter, respondent made a final determination, containing no findings, and in exactly the total amount previously calculated at and for the financial business tax rate. The present assessment is not time-barred, despite the expiration of more than three years since the filing of the return (Administrative Code of City of New York, ch. 46, § B46-15.0, subd. b). Although petitioner timely filed its return, the return, through respondent's error, was classified, under protest, as a financial business tax. The Court of Appeals, in determining that such tax rate did not apply to holding companies, nullified all prior proceedings and it was as if no return had been filed. However, since the error was respondent's, the matter of imposition of penalties might well be reconsidered.

2. The protested tax is not time-barred as an increase, augmentation or accession to the business tax already levied since it is imposed [***4] on subject matter not previously taxed.

3. The general business tax is required to be imposed upon receipts received in and/or allocable to the city (Administrative Code, § B46-2.0). Upon remand, respondent made no independent determination or allocation of taxable receipts, resting, instead, upon a stipulation executed prior to the final determination which preceded the earlier article 78 proceeding and provided for the amount of tax if liability were finally determined to be that imposed by the business tax rates, without allocation. However, no such determination was made in either review proceeding. Moreover, the identity, on remand, of the principal amount and penalty with that found in the earlier proceeding, indicates that there was at most an exchange of labels. Accordingly, the matter is remanded for recomputation of the tax on an allocation basis, and for further consideration of the question of penalty.

 

1021 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


McCanless v. Brieant


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


19 A.D.2d 736; 242 N.Y.S.2d 841; 1963 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3323



July 8, 1963 



DISPOSITION: As so modified, order affirmed, with $ 50 costs and disbursements to petitioner as against the respondents comprising the Town Council; and matter [***2] remitted to the Special Term for further proceedings against the Town Council not inconsistent herewith.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, a classified civil service employee, sought review of an order from the Supreme Court, Westchester County (New York), which granted without a hearing respondents', town council and board of assessors, respective motions to dismiss the civil service employee's petition for reinstatement as insufficient in law.


OVERVIEW: In a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, the civil service employee filed a petition to direct the town council to reinstate her as senior clerk to the board of assessors, or, in the alternative, to appoint her to a newly created position. The trial court granted respondents' respective motions to dismiss the civil service employee's petition for reinstatement as insufficient in law. On appeal, the civil service employee alleged that there was such a similarity between the two positions as to entitle her to reinstatement to the old position or to appointment to the new position. The court modified the order dismissing the civil service employee's petition as to all respondents, except the town council, and remitted to the trial court for further proceedings against the town council. The court held that the civil service employee's petition sufficiently alleged a claim against the town counsel on the issue of whether the duties of the abolished position and the newly created position were sufficiently similar.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order dismissing the civil service employee's petition as to all respondents, except the town council, and remitted to the trial court for further proceedings against the town council.

 

1022 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Aronson v. McNeill


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


19 A.D.2d 731; 242 N.Y.S.2d 427; 1963 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3420



July 1, 1963 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant attorney sought review of a decision from the Supreme Court, Duchess County (New York), which dismissed the attorney's habeas corpus action on behalf of mental patients at a hospital.


OVERVIEW: The Attorney General of the State of New York filed a statement indicating that a finding that N.Y. Correct. Law § 412 was unconstitutional affected 57 patients who had been committed to Matteawan State hospital pursuant to that statute. An attorney then filed a habeas corpus action in the trial court on behalf of those patients. The trial court dismissed the action and the attorney sought review. On appeal, the court determined that although the failure to furnish a prior hearing to those patients transferred pursuant to § 412 was arbitrarily discriminatory and constituted a denial of the equal protection of the laws, it was constrained to affirm the order dismissing the attorney's action because the statute had been previously found to be constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order dismissing the habeas corpus action.

 

1023 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wilson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


18 A.D.2d 424; 239 N.Y.S.2d 900; 1963 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3790



May 9, 1963 



DISPOSITION: Order entered on October 30, 1962 denying defendant's application for a writ of error coram nobis, unanimously affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order from the Supreme Court (New York), which denied, without a hearing, defendant's motion for a writ of error coram nobis. Defendant claimed that he was entitled to a hearing because a prior, out-of-state conviction, upon which he was sentenced as a second offender, was rendered in violation of constitutional limitations.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was tried and convicted in New York of attempted murder. A district attorney filed an information that charged defendant with having been previously convicted of murder in Florida. Defendant admitted the truth of the information, and he was sentenced as a second felony offender. Defendant moved to vacate his New York conviction and sentence on the basis that he was not represented by counsel or advised of his right to counsel when he was arraigned on the Florida charge. The trial court denied defendant's motion. On appeal, the court recognized that: (1) defendant should have been advised of his right to counsel; and (2) the availability of the remedy of coram nobis was determined exclusively by state law and not federal law. The court found that coram nobis was not a proper remedy for purposes of discrediting a prior, out-of-state conviction. Because the case involved the lawfulness of defendant's detention, the court conducted a thorough review of whether any other remedies existed for defendant. The court held that the remedies of a motion for resentence or habeas corpus were possibly available.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's order that denied defendant's motion in the nature of a writ of error coram nobis.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- coram nobis -- multiple offender -- coram nobis does not lie to vacate New York conviction and sentence as second felony offender based on prior conviction in Florida where argument made that defendant was not represented by counsel in Florida -- possibilities of relief by motion to dismiss information where motion to resentence or in habeas corpus proceeding discussed.

1. Defendant was convicted in New York of attempted murder in the second degree and was sentenced as a second felony offender when he admitted the truth of an information charging him with having previously been convicted in Florida of murder in the first degree. His application for a writ of error coram nobis to vacate the New York conviction and sentence on the ground that at the time of his arraignment in Florida he had not been represented by counsel, and had not been advised [***2] that he could retain counsel or have counsel assigned to him, was properly denied without a hearing. The writ of error coram nobis does not lie to discredit a prior out-of-State conviction, even though the subsequent sentence in this State was measured by the fact of the prior conviction ( People v. McCullough, 300 N. Y. 107).

2. It may be that defendant could have moved to dismiss the information on the ground that the prior conviction was void. But there would still be a question whether defendant, having failed to make such a motion, waived his rights, and coram nobis will not lie to determine the issue of waiver or of the invalidity of the prior Florida conviction.
