3. It cannot be said conclusively that defendant does not have a remedy by way of a motion to resentence.

4. It may be that the scope of the remedy of habeas corpus would be extended.

5. None of the remedies alternative to coram nobis clearly provide a procedure for obtaining relief by defendant, but neither are all such avenues of relief clearly foreclosed.

 

1024 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ulisano


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


18 A.D.2d 432; 239 N.Y.S.2d 983; 1963 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3792



May 9, 1963 



DISPOSITION: Modified.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment from the Schenectady County Court (New York), which convicted him of and sentenced him for the crimes of operating a policy business in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 974-a, possession of policy slips in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 975, book-making in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 986, and possession of book-making records in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 986-b.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's conviction for operating a policy establishment, as well as on the other counts, was based upon his confession, which was not the result of psychological coercion as alleged by defendant, but was voluntarily given. As such the confession was properly admitted and the sole question was whether that confession was sufficiently corroborated by additional proof so as to sustain the convictions. The crime of operating a policy establishment, pursuant to N.Y. Penal Code § 974-a, had a two-part body, the establishment and using the establishment for the purpose of there receiving in any one day written records of over 100 plays. The documentary evidence contained in the envelope established the second part. However, there was absolutely no independent evidence that defendant kept an establishment for the purpose of receiving policy plays or bets. The only proof, other than defendant's own written and oral confessions, of an establishment was the statement made by another man in defendant's presence that defendant had given him the envelopes at the establishment. Because the body of the crime was not independently established, defendant was improperly convicted.


OUTCOME: Defendant's conviction for operating a policy business was reversed and that count in the indictment was dismissed. Defendant's convictions and sentences for the remaining three counts were modified and defendant was sentenced on each count for a period of six months, with the sentences running concurrently.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- policy -- defendant improperly convicted of violation of section 974-a of Penal Law -- confession not properly corroborated (Code Crim. Pro., § 395) -- no independent evidence that defendant kept establishment for purpose of receiving policy plays or bets -- statute not unconstitutional -- conviction of other three counts proper.

1. Defendant was convicted of (a) operating a policy business in violation of section 974-a of the Penal Law, (b) possession of policy slips in violation of section 975, (c) book-making in violation of section 986, and (d) possession of book-making records in violation of section 986-b. Section 974-a of the Penal Law provides that "Any person who knowingly keeps, occupies or uses a place, building, room or establishment * * * for the purpose of receiving in any one day * * * written records of more than one hundred plays or bets made over any period of time in what [***2] is commonly called 'policy' or 'the numbers game' * * * shall be guilty of a felony". Defendant was improperly convicted under this section. His confession was not properly corroborated (Code Crim. Pro., § 395). There is no independent evidence that defendant kept an establishment for the purpose of receiving policy plays or bets.

2. Although not necessary to the decision, the court determines that the section is not unconstitutional but is sufficiently definite.

3. Defendant was properly convicted on the other three counts.

4. In sentencing defendant the County Court was primarily considering the felony conviction and, since that is reversed and dismissed, the sentences as to the other three counts should be modified and defendant sentenced on each count to the Schenectady County Jail for a period of six months, the sentences to run concurrently with credit for any time already served.

 

1025 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Wa-Wa-Yanda, Inc. v. Dickerson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


18 A.D.2d 251; 239 N.Y.S.2d 473; 1963 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3978



April 8, 1963 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant town appealed an order of the Supreme Court in Suffolk County (New York) that granted judgment to plaintiff lessee in lessee's action to compel the town to issue a permit for the installation and use of gas tanks on property it leased from the town. The trial court held that the lessee was entitled to a mandamus order, in part, because the town's amended zoning ordinance deprived the lessee of its contractual rights under the lease.


OVERVIEW: The town leased property to the lessee for the operation of a marina. Later, the town enacted an ordinance amending the zoning of the property to a classification that did not allow for the sale of gasoline on the property. The lessee filed suit when the town building inspector refused to issue a permit allowing the lessee to install gasoline tanks and other equipment for the sale of gasoline. On appeal, the court affirmed because it held that a town, acting in its government capacity could not impair an existing lease contract. The court found that the U.S. Const. art. I, § 10 prohibited the enactment of any law impairing the obligations of contracts except in the event of an emergency in which the public welfare required it, and the town had not shown any emergency to justify its ordinance. Thus, the towns refusal of the permit was beyond its police power. The court also affirmed the decision based on the trial court's reasoning that the zoning amendment was a confiscation of the lessee's interest because the greater part of the lease's value was destroyed when it could no longer be used for the purpose intended by the parties.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court that the lessee was entitled to a mandamus order forcing the town's building inspector to issue a permit for the installation of gasoline tanks and related equipment for the sale of gasoline.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- after town in its proprietary capacity leased land to corporation, town amended zoning resolution so as to prohibit major use allowed in lease; as to corporation, such amendment is unconstitutional and void, since it impairs obligation of contract and confiscates leasehold's value.

A town owned an island in its proprietary capacity and leased it to a corporation for 30 years to be used by the lessee for a yacht basin, hotel, bar and restaurant, and for the sale of gasoline; and if gasoline were rationed in case of war, the lessee could either cancel the whole lease or reduce the rent by 90%. Thereafter and during the term of [***2] the lease, and without any showing of emergency which might justify such an exercise of the police power, the town in its governmental capacity amended its zoning resolution so as to place these premises in a different zone and so as to allow in such a zone only certain uses which uses would preclude any sale of gasoline. As applied to this lessee, such zoning amendment was unconstitutional and void, for either of two reasons: (1) it effected a confiscation and destruction of the value of the leasehold interest; (2) it impaired the obligation of the leasehold contract. Accordingly, Special Term properly directed the town's Building Inspector to permit the corporation to install gasoline tanks and pumps and related equipment in accordance with plans and specifications filed by the corporation in the office of said Building Inspector.

 

1026 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Board of Education v. Miles


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


18 A.D.2d 87; 238 N.Y.S.2d 766; 1963 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4153



March 14, 1963 



DISPOSITION: Judgment for the plaintiff, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff board of education, the owner of property that had been conveyed subject to a proviso that it could only be used for school purposes, submitted a controversy to the court. Defendants, the original grantor's heirs, argued that N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 345, which provided for the extinguishment of certain future interests unless they were recorded within a certain period, was unconstitutional in retroactive application.


OVERVIEW: The original deed conveyed the land to a school and contained a proviso that the land would revert to the grantor or his heirs if the land ceased to be used for school purposes. When the property ceased be used for a school, the original grantor's heirs recorded a declaration of intention to preserve restrictions on the use of the land. The court held that N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 345 was a valid exercise of legislative power. Thus, the heirs' rights were extinguished since the filing of the declaration was over six months after the expiration of the time for recording such an intention fixed by the statute. The language of the deed created either a fee simple subject to a condition subsequent or a fee simple determinable. These future interests had been characterized as bare possibilities. The court found that it was not an impairment of contract or a denial of due process to require a man who owned so tenuous an interest to put it down in a public record within the reasonable time specified in the statute.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment for the board of education, without costs.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- validity of statute extinguishing unrecorded future contingent interests -- provision (Real Property Law, § 345, added by L. 1958, ch. 865) for extinguishing condition subsequent or special limitation on land use, along with resulting right of entry or possibility of reverter, unless possessor thereof within stated time recorded declaration of intent to preserve such future interest, was valid exercise of legislative power and retroactive application thereof to bar contingent interests of grantor's heirs to lands conveyed to school trustees in 1863 for school use only neither impaired contract nor denied due process.

1. A grant of land in 1863 to the trustees of an academy, the predecessors of plaintiff Board of Education, contained a provision that it should remain effective while the premises "shall be used for the purpose of an Academy and no other" but "otherwise it shall become Void and the premises herein conveyed shall revert to [the grantor] and to his heirs." The property was used for school purposes until April [***2] 1, 1962 when the board discontinued such use. Defendants, as sole heirs of the grantor, recorded a declaration of intention to preserve restrictions on April 13, more than six months after the expiration of the time allowed for such recording by section 345 of the Real Property Law. Section 345 (added by L. 1958, ch. 865) provided for the extinguishment of a previously existing, as well as a future, condition subsequent or special limitation on the use of land, along with the resulting right of entry or possibility of reverter, unless the party possessing such future interest recorded a declaration of intention to preserve it, within a stated time, which for such interests created before September 1, 1931 ended September 1, 1961, three years after the effective date of the statute. Such recording requirement was a valid exercise of legislative power and defendants' failure to record timely extinguished their contingent interest in the land.

2. Although such future interests have been characterized as bare possibilities and their transferability had been in doubt, the statute (Real Property Law, § 59, as amd. by L. 1962, ch. 146, eff. Sept. 1, 1962) settled that question by making [***3] such interests descendible, devisable and alienable. However such alienability did not necessarily conclude the question of these rights' being constitutionally protected which must be tested out on the rationality of the need for public regulation of such interests in the general welfare. The right so to regulate and, under certain reasonable conditions, to extinguish depends in turn upon the nature of the thing regulated and extinguished. The loose-end nature of these contingent, future interests, allowing the owners thereof to sit by for generations without showing any interest whatever in them, while the grantor's heirs or distributees spread out to evolve a multitudinous ownership, left titles doubtful, uncertain and confused and has been a source of marked difficulty in administering New York law. Regulation of this kind of title by requiring that any intent to rely thereon be recorded was in the public interest and was a reasonable and salutory public control of the use of a peculiar form of property which, if unregulated, could adversely affect the free alienability and development of land.

3. It was neither the impairment of contract nor a denial of due process to require [***4] the owner of so tenuous and troublesome an interest to put it down in a public record.

4. The recording provisions of section 345, including its retroactive application, are constitutionally valid. So far as anything in the case of Varick's Executors v. Briggs (22 Wend. 543), decided by the Court of Errors in 1839, is to the contrary, the doctrine of that case is opposed by the great weight of authority; has been ignored by the State's lower courts; has never been followed by the Court of Appeals, and has been expressly questioned by Judges thereof. (The historical development of the Varick's Executors case doctrine traced and its treatment in subsequent State and Federal decisions reviewed.)

5. That defendants' rights did not mature until the condition occurred -- when the use for school purposes ceased on April 1, 1962 -- is not controlling. The right was created before September 1, 1931 and the statute required recording in such case by September 1, 1961.

 

1027 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Kaskoff v. Anderson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


18 A.D.2d 192; 238 N.Y.S.2d 649; 1963 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4168



March 13, 1963 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, a driver and the city, challenged an order of the Supreme Court, Sullivan County (New York), which entered judgment for plaintiff victim in the victim's action for damages for injuries suffered as a result of an automobile accident.


OVERVIEW: A sharp factual difference existed between the versions of the accident as related by the driver and the victim. The victim testified that she attempted to make a left-hand turn, turned partially, and waited for another car passing in the opposite direction. As she waited, she saw headlights approaching from the rear. The driver testified that she did not see the victim's car until a few seconds before the impact, and that the victim's car was moving from the right to the left. The trial court entered judgement for the victim. On appeal, defendants claimed that it was error for the trial court to charge the jury on the doctrine of last clear chance, which required the victim to be in a perilous situation of which the driver had actual knowledge. However, even if the charge were erroneous, reversal was not required. Indeed, immediately after discussing the general doctrine of last clear chance and its very limited general operation, the trial court in effect substantially swept it out of consideration by saying that if the victim were guilty of negligence, which contributed in the slightest degree, the verdict "must be" for defendants.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment entered in favor of the victim.


HEADNOTES

Negligence -- last clear chance -- in action to recover for injuries sustained by plaintiff as result of collision of automobiles, Trial Judge submitted doctrine of last clear chance as one alternative open to jury -- drawing that inference from conflicting proof as to how accident occurred which is most favorable to such charge, it would be possible for jury to find that plaintiff's automobile was stopped under perilous conditions of location and traffic, that such act of standing and waiting was negligent, and that plaintiff's automobile was in such location long enough to be seen and was in fact seen by defendant operator in time to avoid collision -- even if charge was error, it was not so substantial as to require reversal.

1. Plaintiff's automobile was struck on the left side by an automobile operated by one of defendants. Both automobiles had been proceeding northerly on a street wide enough for two lanes of traffic in each direction. In this action to [***2] recover for the personal injuries sustained by plaintiff as a result of this accident, there was a sharp factual difference between the versions of the accident given by the parties. In his charge the Trial Judge submitted the doctrine of last clear chance as one alternative open to the jury. Drawing that inference from the proof as to how the accident occurred which is most favorable to the charge as to the doctrine of last clear chance, it would be possible for the jury to find that plaintiff's automobile was stopped at an angle partly away from the curb, in the lane of traffic, waiting under perilous conditions of location and traffic; that such act of standing and waiting was so perilous as to be negligent, and that plaintiff's automobile was in such a location long enough to be seen and was in fact seen by defendant operator in time to avoid the collision.

2. Even if the charge as to the doctrine of last clear chance was error, it was not so substantial as to require a reversal. The Trial Judge submitted the doctrine and its limited operation in general terms, without specifically tying it into the facts of this case and, immediately after this submission, substantially swept [***3] it out of consideration by charging that the verdict must be one of no cause of action if the jury found that plaintiff, at the time and place in question, was guilty of negligence contributing in the slightest degree to the injuries allegedly sustained by her.

 

1028 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Courtesy Sandwich Shop, Inc. v. Port of New York Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


17 A.D.2d 590; 237 N.Y.S.2d 820; 1963 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4346



February 19, 1963 



DISPOSITION: Orders, entered on July 26, 1962 and July 17, 1962 reversed, on the law, with $ 20 costs and disbursements to the appellants. A temporary injunction restraining the condemnation of the tube and tube properties should issue; the Port Authority may not be permitted to condemn or be given possession of the properties involved, and the cross motion of the petitioners to dismiss the condemnation [***2] proceedings granted.

Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowners sought review of two decisions of the Supreme Court at Special Term in New York County (New York), which denied the landowners' motion for a temporary injunction restraining respondents, a port authority and others, from proceeding under Chapter 209 of the Laws of 1963 with the condemnation of property in lower Manhattan and granted condemnation and put the port authority into possession of the property.


OVERVIEW: Chapter 209 of the Laws of 1962 authorized the port authority to acquire, through condemnation, the Hudson Tubes and to condemn 13 blocks in lower Manhattan for the purpose of developing a project known as the "world trade center." The landowners brought suit in which they claimed that the statute was unconstitutional and sought an injunction prohibiting condemnation. The trial court denied the injunction and, in a second action brought by a subsidiary of the port authority, granted condemnation. The landowners appealed and the court reversed. The court found that the condemnation of the tubes and the creation of the world trade center was a unified project, and thus if one part of the statute were declared unconstitutional, then the entire statute was unconstitutional. The court recognized that the port authority had the power to condemn for a public purpose. But the court found that the creation of the world trade center was not for a public purpose because the statute authorized the world trade center to have been used primarily to generate revenue to cover the expenses of the remainder of the project. Thus, the court held the statute unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court reversed a decision that refused to grant a restraining order against and granted condemnation to the port authority pursuant to a statute that permitted the condemnation of the landowners' land. The court held the statute unconstitutional, granted a temporary restraining order prohibiting condemnation, and dismissed the condemnation proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Eminent domain -- private use -- portion of statute (L. 1962, ch. 209) authorizing Port of New York Authority to condemn 13 city block area for "world trade center" was unconstitutional because it permitted private use of condemned property "primarily for revenue" -- remainder of statute, including authorizing Port Authority to condemn Hudson Tubes and appurtenant properties, likewise fell inasmuch as severability clause of statute contained limitation clearly showing intent of New York and New Jersey Legislatures in passing concurrent legislation that trade center and tubes projects were to be considered as indivisible unit -- courts should have decided question of constitutionality of trade center plan before granting condemnation of tube properties.

1. That portion of a statute (L. 1962, ch. 209), authorizing the Port of New York Authority to condemn a 13 city block area in lower Manhattan for the purpose of developing a "world trade center", permitted the use of such areas therein that may "not be devoted to purposes of the port development project other than the production of incidental revenue available for the expenses [***3] of all or part of the port development project". Although creation of a world trade center in concept is a public purpose, such portion of the statute not only authorized condemnation of private property for public purposes, but also permitted condemnation for improperly exercised nonpublic purposes -- the use of the property "primarily for revenue" -- and, accordingly, must be declared unconstitutional.

2. Moreover, the Legislature, in authorizing the Port Authority to construct customs houses and stores, foreign trade zones and other facilities with clearly public purposes, not only failed to limit such authorization to such type of building, but expressly permitted the Authority to erect and use warehouses for functions incident to the exchange, buying and selling of commodities and other property in world trade and commerce. Exercising such a broad power would make this project in reality a real estate development inasmuch as scarcely any enterprise or business in the city would be excluded from the area although devoted exclusively to private purposes. Such powers granted by the statute are so broad as to mandate a finding of unconstitutionality.

3. Furthermore, because of [***4] such invalidity of that portion of the statute authorizing the world trade center, the entire statute must likewise fall, including that part authorizing the Port Authority to acquire by condemnation the Hudson Tubes and appurtenant properties. The operation of the tubes undoubtedly would constitute a public purpose and buildings presently erected over the existing terminal could properly be condemned in order to improve existing facilities or to construct a new terminal, including buildings that might yield incidental revenues. However the severability clause (§ 18) of the statute, providing that the invalidity of any portion thereof should not affect the validity of the remainder, also contained the limiting provision: "so long as the * * * remainder of the act shall nonetheless permit the effectuation, as a unified project, of the Hudson tubes, Hudson tube extensions and the world trade center". The Legislature of New York and that of New Jersey (which enacted concurrent legislation) clearly intended thereby that the Hudson Tubes project and the world trade center project be considered as a unit and stand or fall together, and the courts would be invading the legislative function [***5] if they allowed the residue of the statute to remain. Accordingly, the trade center phase of the statute being invalid, the Port Authority may not be permitted to take over the tubes, and may not go forward with a condemnation proceeding in connection with the tubes project.

4. It was error for the court to refuse to consider and pass on the constitutionality of the world trade center authorization before granting the petition for an order of condemnation of the tube properties. Likewise, in an action for a declaratory judgment of the statute's unconstitutionality and invalidity for other reasons, it was error for the court to fail to decide that constitutional question before denying a motion by persons interested in the tube properties for a temporary injunction restraining the condemnation of such properties. The severability clause, making the tubes and the trade center a nondivisible project, in effect required that decision as to the validity of the trade center be made at the time when the first step effectuating the statutory purpose was taken. Otherwise a subsequent finding of the trade center's invalidity might leave the Port Authority with an advanced or completed tubes [***6] project without the possibility of effectuating the trade center -- a result expressly prohibited by the Legislature. Moreover, the parties whose properties might be condemned might not have sufficient opportunity, before an actual takeover, to present the question as to whether a public use was contemplated. Such contingency may be avoided by present consideration of the validity of the trade center project as written.

 

1029 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Trippe v. Port of New York Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


17 A.D.2d 472; 236 N.Y.S.2d 312; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6236



December 24, 1962 



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, airport and airlines, sought review of the decision of the Supreme Court, Queens County (New York), which denied defendant's motion to strike from the first cause of action of the complaint all the allegations relating to claims for an alleged "taking" of plaintiff homeowners' properties in the homeowners' action for nuisance, trespass, and for the "taking" of the air easements and space over and upon their properties.


OVERVIEW: The homeowners filed a complaint against the airport and the airlines for nuisance, trespass, and for the "taking" of the air easements and space over and upon their properties. The airport filed a motion to strike those portions of the first cause of action that sought compensation for claims that accrued prior one year before the commencement of the action. The trial court granted the motion to the extent of striking out those allegations relating to claims in nuisance and trespass, but denied the motion as to the allegations relating to the taking. The trial court held that the airport was not immune to an action pursuant to the constitutional guarantee of due compensation for the taking of property, and that the suability statute was inapplicable. The court affirmed and held that based upon the alleged unlawful taking, the homeowners were free to seek relief against the airport by any other appropriate proceeding or action wherein their rights might be enforced, including a proceeding to compel the airport to condemn the subject property rights, or an action for damages. The court held that there was no immunity because of the constitutional requirement of just compensation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's denial of the airport's motion to strike the claims relating to the alleged taking of the air easements and space over and upon the homeowners' properties that arose over one year prior to the commencement of the action.


HEADNOTES

Eminent domain -- taking of air easements and space -- claims against Port of New York Authority, based on alleged "taking" of air easements and space above properties of plaintiffs, are not barred by one-year limitation contained in chapter 301 (§ 7) of Laws of 1950 -- by its express language this chapter is applicable only to suits which were previously subject to plea of sovereign immunity -- at no time prior to enactment thereof did Port Authority have sovereign immunity from claim based upon alleged unconstitutional taking of property for public use without just compensation.

On December 14, 1961 property owners in a community near Idlewild Airport commenced a suit seeking, among other things,  [***2] damages from the Port of New York Authority for the "taking" since 1947 of the air easements and space over and above their properties. Those claims based on an alleged "taking" which accrued between 1947 and December 14, 1960 are not barred by the one-year limitation contained in chapter 301 (§ 7) of the Laws of 1950 which provides that the States of New York and New Jersey "consent" to suits against the Port of New York Authority "upon the condition that any suit * * * prosecuted or maintained under this act shall be commenced within one year after the cause of action therefor shall have accrued". By its express language chapter 301 of the Laws of 1950 is applicable only to suits which were previously subject to the plea of sovereign immunity. At no time prior to the enactment thereof did the Port Authority have sovereign immunity from a claim based upon an alleged unconstitutional taking of property for public use without just compensation. Accordingly, that statute is inapplicable to plaintiffs' claims based on a taking.

 

1030 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Automobile Transporters Welfare Fund


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


17 A.D.2d 448; 235 N.Y.S.2d 702; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6290; 52 L.R.R.M. 2238



December 20, 1962 



DISPOSITION: Judgment and order granting judgment in favor of defendants unanimously reversed, on the law, with costs to plaintiff-appellant, plaintiff's motion for judgment on the pleadings granted, with $ 10 costs and defendants' cross motion for judgment on the pleadings denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff State sought review of the decision of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York) granting defendant out-of-state union welfare fund's motion for judgment on the pleadings in plaintiff's action to impose the cost of its examination of defendants' fund.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff State filed suit to recover from defendants the costs of an audit and examination of defendants' interstate union-employer welfare fund. Defendants claimed that the fund, with its sole and principal office located out of state, was exempt from state regulation and examination under federal law. The parties filed cross-motions for judgment on the pleadings. The trial court granted defendants' motion. On appeal, the court reversed the judgment entered in favor of defendants and granted judgment on the pleadings in favor of plaintiff. While federal law prohibited the States from requiring duplication of report-making required of welfare funds, all other State regulation was expressly preserved under federal and state law.


OUTCOME: Judgment in favor defendants was reversed and plaintiff's motion for judgment on the pleadings was granted. Plaintiff State was empowered under state and federal law to regulate and conduct an audit and examination of defendant out-of-state welfare fund.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- audit of employer-union welfare fund -- Insurance Department had authority to audit defendant welfare fund, created by trust indenture between employers and labor unions, and charge expenses of examination to such fund -- State legislation (Insurance Law, art. III-A) includes welfare funds under State supervision -- Federal statutes do not prohibit such audit and charge -- no showing of unconstitutionality.

1. Defendant welfare fund, created by a trust indenture in collective bargaining between employers and labor unions,  [***2] and having its sole and principal office in Detroit, Michigan, is jointly maintained by the employers and unions, and provides health and welfare benefits for the employees. Approximately 3% of the covered employees are residents of New York. The State of New York, through its Insurance Department, audits the books, records and affairs of the fund which, pursuant to State statute (Insurance Law, art. III-A, § 37 et seq.) is registered with the Superintendent of Insurance. In this action in which the State seeks to recover the costs of such audit made in 1958, the motion by the state judgment on the pleadings should be granted.

2. While section 466 of the Insurance Law exempts certain labor union organizations and operations from the application of the Insurance Law, article III-A of the Insurance Law provides for supervision of such welfare funds and that expenses of such examinations shall be borne by the examined funds. The State legislation does not exempt from, but, on the contrary, includes welfare funds under State supervision.

3. The Federal statutes do not pre-empt the regulation of this welfare fund to the extent that the State is excluded from exercising its authority [***3] in auditing the books and records of the fund and imposing the cost thereof on the examined fund. The Federal statute, (U. S. Code, tit. 29, § 301 et seq.) precludes, rather than extends, pre-emption, by its express terms, except in the narrow field of report-making, and disclosure of the character specified in the Federal statute.

4. Whether welfare plans fit within the category of insurance is not essential to the determination because, in the Federal statute, continued power in the State to regulate welfare plans is recognized expressly. Moreover, the fund operates an employee benefit plan and comes within the provisions of article III-A of the Insurance Law.

5. The State has the power to protect its residents in dealing with interstate organizations such as defendant fund.

6. Article III-A of the Insurance Law is applicable exclusively to bilateral funds (maintained jointly by employers and unions), and unilateral funds (maintained only by employers) are exempted from its application. The burden of disputing the distinction and showing unreasonable discrimination is on the one attacking, the constitutionality of the statute, and that showing has not been made.

 People  [***4] v. Automobile Transporters Welfare Fund, 34 Misc 2d 907, reversed.

 

1031 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Mishkin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


17 A.D.2d 243; 234 N.Y.S.2d 342; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6857



November 27, 1962 



DISPOSITION: Modified.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged his convictions from the Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York (New York) for unlawfully possessing obscene books with intent to sell, unlawfully publishing obscene books, and hiring others to prepare obscene books in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 1141; and for failing to disclose the publisher's name and address on the books in violation of N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 330.


OVERVIEW: Defendant submitted several specifications of error regarding his convictions for multiple counts of possession and publication of obscene books and for hiring others to prepare them, but the court found nothing prejudicial. However, the court found N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 330 unconstitutional and defendant's 32 violations of that statute unsupportable. The court opined that no grounds for the resulting restriction of free expression could be found in the statute or otherwise established. Although the State suggested that the statute's application could be limited to obscene publications, the court concluded that the statute was not limited in that way and there was no evidence that the legislative purpose was to do so.


OUTCOME: The court modified defendant's conviction by deleting the 32 counts for failing to print the publisher's name and address on the books he printed. The law requiring the disclosure was declared unconstitutional. Defendant's convictions for possessing obscene books with intent to sell, publishing obscene books, and hiring others to prepare obscene books were affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- names and address of publisher in publications -- section 330 (subd. 2) of General Business Law, which provides that publications shall have conspicuously printed name and address of publisher or printer, unconstitutional.

Section 330 (subd. 2) of the General Business Law, which provides that every publication printed after September 1, 1956 (other than newspapers, magazines or other periodicals for which separate provision is made) and published in this State shall have conspicuously printed in certain specified places the name and address of the publisher or printer is unconstitutional.

 

1032 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Shpritzer v. Lang


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


17 A.D.2d 285; 234 N.Y.S.2d 285; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6861



November 27, 1962 



DISPOSITION: Modified.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent Civil Service Commission of the City of New York appealed from the order of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which granted, to the extent of directing a trial on the issue, petitioner policewoman's application, under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78, for judicial review of the Commission's refusal to permit the policewoman to compete in an examination for promotion.


OVERVIEW: The Commission denied the policewoman's application to take an examination for promotion and denied her appeal. The policewoman filed the petition for judicial review, which the trial court granted to the extent of directing a trial. On appeal, the court modified and affirmed. The court found that under N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law art. 4, the Commission could have limited eligibility to take an examination to one sex when the duties of the position related to the care or custody of persons of the same sex or the work required sex selection. The court found that promotions were to based on seniority, merit, and superior capacity under New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 434a-13.0. The court interpreted § 434a-2.0(d), stating that there was only one rank and grade of women police officers who would have been known as policewomen, as abolishing the distinctions between classes of female officers rather than as prohibiting promotions for policewomen. The court found there was no statutory prohibition to policewomen taking promotional examinations and that such an interpretation was an abuse of the Commission's discretion.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order of the trial court, which granted the policewoman's application for judicial review to the extent of directing a trial, and ordered that her motion should be granted in its entirety, and so modified, affirmed the order.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- eligibility to compete in promotion examinations -- denial to policewomen of eligibility to compete in examinations for promotion to position of police sergeant unwarranted and abuse of discretion.

1. The provision of subdivision d of section 434a-2.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York that there shall be "but one rank and grade of women police officers in the uniformed force of the department and they shall be known as policewomen" does not make policewomen ineligible to compete in examinations for promotion to the position of police sergeant.

2. Since there is no prohibition in statute or rule against the eligibility of policewomen to take such examinations [***2] and nothing in the broad definition of the duties of sergeant, as set forth in the rules and procedures of the Police Department, which is clearly impossible of performance by policewomen because of their sex, the denial of such eligibility is unwarranted and constitutes an abuse of discretion.

 

1033 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Farmingdale


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, SECOND DEPARTMENT


17 A.D.2d 655; 230 N.Y.S.2d 863; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8585



July 9, 1962 - Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a proceeding to annul a determination of respondent planning commission, which disapproved a rezoning resolution of petitioner village, and for a judgment to declare the determination to be illegal and beyond the commission's jurisdiction, the parties cross appealed the order of the Supreme Court, Nassau County (New York), which declared that no submission to the commission and its clerk was made as required by law.


OVERVIEW: The planning commission disproved the village's zoning amendment. The village brought a proceeding to annul the determination and for a judgment to declare the determination illegal and beyond the commission's jurisdiction. The court declared that no submission to the commission and its clerk was made as required by the Nassau County Charter, Nassau County, N.Y. County Law §1608, and made the submission. The parties cross appealed. The court modified the order by striking out the provision declaring that no submission was made and dismissed the proceeding because the disapproval of the village zoning amendment was a valid determination made in conformity with the Nassau County Charter. Specifically, because there was one vacancy, the disapproval was accomplished by four members of the five-member commission. As long as the lawfully required proportion of the whole number exercised the authority or the duty for which the commission was created, a vacancy did not per se render the commission powerless to perform its obligation.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order by striking out the provision that declared that no submission was made and that made the submission, and substituted a provision dismissing the proceeding.

 

1034 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York C. R. Co. v. Lefkowitz


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, SECOND DEPARTMENT


17 A.D.2d 638; 230 N.Y.S.2d 678; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8678



July 2, 1962 - Decided

 

1035 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Babcock v. Jackson


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FOURTH DEPARTMENT


17 A.D.2d 694; 230 N.Y.S.2d 114; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8728



July 2, 1962 - Decided

 

1036 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Chiropractic Asso. of New York v. Hilleboe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


16 A.D.2d 285; 228 N.Y.S.2d 358; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9956



May 4, 1962, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, chiropractic association and others, sought review of a judgment of the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York) in favor of respondent, health commissioner, in an action seeking to have N.Y. Sanitary Code ch. XVI, reg. 19 declared unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Sanitary Code ch. XVI, reg. 19 provided that only certain licensed medical professionals could administer radiation or X-rays to humans. The chiropractic association, desirous to have its members be allowed to perform X-rays on its patients, commenced the instant action to have the statute declared unconstitutional. They argued that the regulation was discriminatory against chiropractors and denied them equal protection of the laws. They also argued that the regulation deprived chiropractors of their right to pursue their calling and deprived them of the use of their lawfully acquired X-ray equipment without due process of law. The trial court entered a judgment for the health commissioner. On appeal, the court found that the promulgators of the regulation were clearly entitled to find that medical knowledge and diagnostic skill were essential to evaluate the necessity of X-ray procedures in any particular case and to weigh the attendant risk as against the possible benefit to be derived. The technical education, training and skill of chiropractors were, in general, substantially deficient in these vital areas of knowledge and judgment.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment in favor of the health commissioner in an action brought by the chiropractic association and others seeking to have a state statute that limited the class of persons who could administer radiation to humans declared unconstitutional. The court held that the statute was constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Physicians and surgeons -- chiropractors -- X rays -- New York State Sanitary Code (ch. XVI, reg. 19) prohibits application of radiation to human being by those not licensed to practice medicine, dentistry, podiatry or osteopathy but does not prohibit use of radiation by technician, nurse or other person under direction or order of persons so licensed -- complaint in action by members of chiropractic association for judgment declaring said regulation unconstitutional and restraining its enforcement, properly dismissed -- record indicates chiropractors deficient in necessary technical education, training and skill -- responsibility properly delegated to those whose necessary technical education, knowledge and skill had been determined and certified.

1. Regulation 19 of chapter XVI of the New York State Sanitary Code provides that: "No person shall apply radiation to a human being unless such person is licensed [***2] or otherwise authorized to practice medicine, dentistry, podiatry or osteopathy", and that "This regulation shall not prohibit the use of radiation by a technician, nurse or other person, if such use is directed or ordered by a person licensed or authorized to practice medicine, dentistry, podiatry or osteopathy". The complaint in an action brought to have this regulation declared unconstitutional and to restrain its enforcement was properly dismissed. The promulgators of the regulation were entitled to find that medical knowledge and diagnostic skill are essential to evaluate the necessity of X-ray procedures and to weigh the risk as against the possible benefit to be derived. The record indicates that the technical education, training and skill of chiropractors are, in general, substantially deficient in these areas of knowledge and judgment. Further, it is doubtful whether technical knowledge in the requisite degree, if possessed by a particular chiropractor, could be applied to the problem posed by spinal X ray without thereby constituting an unlawful invasion of the field of medical practice. Such relevant issues as arose with respect to the knowledge, competence and skill [***3] of chiropractors, as such, in the particular areas of judgment and decision involved were properly resolved against appellants -- members of the Chiropractic Association of New York. These findings serve to negate any suggestion that chiropractors, as such, are possessed of such knowledge and skill as to render arbitrary their exclusion from the class of practitioners of named professions authorized to apply radiation to human beings or to direct or order its application.

2. Plaintiffs state that they "do not contend that a proper regulation may not be promulgated dealing with the taking of X-rays of human beings, nor that, if improperly taken, such an operation is not attended by a certain amount of danger to the subject of the operation." In seeking to combat that danger, the Public Health Council could and did recognize the initial necessity of technical knowledge and skill to determine, in each case, the advisability of X-ray procedure, in the light of the clinical evidence at hand, the attendant risk and possible effects, and thereupon, in the event X ray should be indicated, to direct the method, nature and number of exposures, and thus, in effect, prescribe the quantity of [***4] radiation to be applied. The promulgators of the regulation committed an effective degree of responsibility and control to those most competent to exercise it by providing that only those licensed to practice medicine or one of the other professions named, and whose highly technical education, knowledge and skill had thus been determined and certified, should apply radiation, or direct its application, to a human being.

 

1037 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Armondi v. Johnson


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


16 A.D.2d 712; 226 N.Y.S.2d 714; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10318



April 13, 1962 - Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant driver challenged a judgment of the Chenango County Court (New York), which awarded damages to respondent driver for property damage and dismissed appellant's counterclaim arising from an automobile collision.


OVERVIEW: The parties collided when respondent backed into the road from between eight-foot snow banks bordering his driveway and appellant skidded into the rear of respondent's car. The trial court awarded damages to respondent and dismissed appellant's counterclaim. On appeal, appellant alleged reversible error by the trial judge in the verbatim charge of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 56(1) to the jury, which had been declared unconstitutional prior to the date of the accident. Reversing, the court held that prejudice existed because by charging the provisions involved, the jury could have found appellant negligent on the mere fact that he was unable to prevent his car from colliding with respondent's car, no matter what the circumstances happened to be. The court found that it was prejudicial as indicated by the statement of the jury foreman that the jury believed that appellant was negligent in not having his car under control.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment and ordered a new trial.

 

1038 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Fifth Ave. Coach Lines, Inc. v. New York


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FIRST DEPARTMENT


15 A.D.2d 917; 225 N.Y.S.2d 976; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10655



March 30, 1962 - Decided

 

1039 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Huie v. Riehle


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, SECOND DEPARTMENT


15 A.D.2d 931; 226 N.Y.S.2d 295; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11024



March 12, 1962 - Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant claimants sought review of an order of the Supreme Court, Orange County (New York), denying their motion to direct the Commissioners of Appraisal to accept their claims against respondent Board of Water Supply of the City of New York for damages for the taking of their property for the purpose of diverting and providing a water supply for the city's use.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the claimants argued that the notice provisions of the Water Supply Act, New York City, N.Y., R. tit. K, were unconstitutional. The court ruled, however, that the notice provisions were constitutional. The court also ruled that the claimants' failure to file a claim for damages for condemnation within three years barred their right to compensation. Additionally, the court determined that there was no basis for finding that the board was estopped from pleading the three-year statute of limitations as a defense to the claims. In reaching this conclusion, the court emphasized that the notices, the taking map, the posting, and the condemnation petition were not defective. Moreover, the court observed that there was no statutory limitation for the completion of a massive project such as the one involved in these consolidated cases.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's order denying the claimants' motion.

 

1040 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Gulest Associates, Inc. v. Newburgh


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


15 A.D.2d 815; 225 N.Y.S.2d 538; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11247



February 26, 1962 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with $ 10 costs and disbursements.

 

1041 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Utica Daw's Drug Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


16 A.D.2d 12; 225 N.Y.S.2d 128; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11297; 4 A.L.R.3d 393



February 22, 1962, Decided



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a discount house, appealed from a judgment of the Oneida County Court (New York), which convicted defendant of making unlawful sales on Sunday in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 2147.


OVERVIEW: Defendant maintained a drugstore that operated under a policy of selling at reduced prices, generally characteristic of stores known as discount houses. Defendant was convicted under the Sunday statute on the ground that it unlawfully sold and exposed for sale certain property in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 2147. Defendant maintained that public authorities intentionally discriminated against it and other discount houses and allowed others outside the class to continue to sell forbidden items in violation of the Sunday law without molestation. The court reversed the conviction and granted a new trial. It was defendant's burden to establish conscious, intentional discrimination, and if it succeeded in sustaining that burden, defendant was entitled to a dismissal of the prosecution as a matter of law. While the trial court recognized the validity of the defense, it prevented defendant from introducing material evidence that would have tended to support the defense. Further, the court stated that the claim of discriminatory enforcement should not have been treated as a defense, but as an application to dismiss or quash the prosecution on constitutional grounds.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's conviction for violation of the Sunday statute and granted defendant a new trial. The court directed that the court below, prior to the commencement of the new trial, entertain an application by defendant to dismiss or quash the prosecution upon the grounds set forth by it in its offers of proof during the first trial.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sale on Sunday -- discriminatory enforcement -- judgment convicting defendant, operator of drugstore, of violation of section 2147 of Penal Law on charge that it unlawfully sold property on Sunday reversed where trial court prevented defendant from introducing material evidence supporting its defense that public authorities discriminated against its "cut-rate" type of operation in enforcement of statute -- on new trial, matter of discriminatory enforcement should not be submitted to jury but should be decided by court on application to dismiss or quash prosecution.

1. Defendant, operator of a drugstore, was convicted of violating section 2147 of the Penal Law upon a charge that it unlawfully sold certain property on a Sunday. Defendant did not contest the charge but contended that the prosecution was part of a discriminatory design aimed at defendant and others engaged in the "cut-rate"  [***2] type of operation in which defendant was engaged, and that the public authorities intentionally discriminated against that class and allowed others outside that class to continue to sell the forbidden items in violation of the law without molestation. The trial court, with the acquiescence of the District Attorney, held that defendant's contention, if established, would constitute a good defense and it submitted the case to the jury, leaving the question to the jury to decide whether defendant's proof established a clear and intentional discrimination against defendant and those in the same class. Upon the theory upon which the case was tried and submitted, the judgment of conviction must be reversed since the trial court prevented defendant from introducing material evidence which would have tended to support the defense. The court held that the evidence was irrelevant since nonenforcement of itself is not sufficient to establish discrimination. While it is true that nonenforcement is insufficient of itself to establish discrimination, proof of nonenforcement is admissible in evidence where defendant alleges that there has been intentional discrimination.

2. However, the claim [***3] of discriminatory enforcement should not be treated as a defense to the criminal charge, to be tried before the jury and submitted to it for decision, but should be treated as an application to the court for a dismissal or quashing of the prosecution upon constitutional grounds. Insofar as a question of fact may be involved, the court should take the evidence in the absence of the jury and should decide the question itself. If the court finds that there was an intentional discrimination, it should quash the prosecution, not because defendant is not guilty of the crime charged, but because the court, as an agency of government, should not lend itself to a prosecution, the maintenance of which would violate the constitutional rights of the defendant.

3. A new trial is granted. The court should, prior to the commencement of the new trial, entertain an application by defendant to dismiss or quash the prosecution upon the grounds set forth by it in its offers of proof on the first trial.

 

1042 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Pennsylvania R. Co. v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


15 A.D.2d 269; 223 N.Y.S.2d 541; 1962 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12095



January 11, 1962 



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff railroad development corporations challenged a decision from the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which granted defendant State of New York's motion to declare N.Y. R.R. Law ch. 386 (1958) constitutional and valid in the corporations' action to declare that ch. 386 unconstitutionally impaired the obligation of their contracts with the state.


OVERVIEW: Under N.Y. R.R. Law § 307 (1954), the corporations were authorized to make emergency changes in their passenger fares without prior approval by the Public Service Commission whenever they determined that their revenues would have been inadequate during the following 12-month period to meet the expenditures authorized by N.Y. R.R. Law § 306 (1954). Such changes were subject to review by the Public Service Commission. However, N.Y. R.R. Law ch. 386 (1958) amended N.Y. R.R. Law § 307 (1954) and required advance approval of the Public Service Commission before changes in existing fares became effective. The corporations filed an action against the state to have N.Y. R.R. Law ch. 386 (1958) declared unconstitutional because it impaired the obligation of their contracts with the state. The trial court declared that ch. 386 was constitutional and valid. The court affirmed. The court held that N.Y. R.R. Law ch. 824 (1954) was a general law that was not open to contract with the corporations. Chapter 824 did not bind the state, did not suggest any contractual obligations on the part of the state, and did not waive the state's powers to alter any corporate privileges.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's decision in favor of the state in the corporations' action to declare that a state statute unconstitutionally impaired the obligation of their contracts with the state.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- impairment of contracts -- chapter 824 of Laws of 1954 provided that railroad redevelopment corporations might make emergency changes in passenger fares without prior approval by Public Service Commission but subject to later review by Public Service Commission -- chapter 386 of Laws of 1958 requiring advance approval by Public Service Commission of changes in fares does not unconstitutionally impair obligation of contract between railroads and State.

1. Article 7 ( §§ 300-313) of the Railroad Law, enacted in 1954 (L. 1954, ch. 824), provided that certain domestic railroad corporations which could meet the conditions set forth in the act might qualify as a railroad redevelopment corporation. After qualifying, the corporation's existence, subject to stated exceptions, would continue for a 12-year period. (§ [***2] 303). Under section 307 of the law, a railroad redevelopment corporation was authorized to make emergency changes in its passenger fares without prior approval by the Public Service Commission whenever it determined that its revenues would be inadequate during the following 12-month period to meet the expenditures authorized by section 306. Such changes were, nevertheless, subject to review by the Public Service Commission. Section 307 was amended by chapter 386 of the Laws of 1958 to require advance approval of the Public Service Commission before changes in existing fares could become effective. Chapter 386 of the Laws of 1958 does not unconstitutionally impair the obligation of a contract between plaintiffs and the State. There is nothing in the act itself (L. 1954, ch 824) which binds the State, or suggests any contractual obligations on the part of the State, or that the State waived its powers to alter any corporate privileges therein granted.

2. Moreover, assuming a contractual plan for the 1954 legislation, the State reserved the power to alter it under the "reserved power" found in section 1 of article X of the New York State Constitution.

3. Article 7 of the Railroad [***3] Law is a general law and not a private or local enactment. The fact that only one corporation, at the moment may meet the qualifying requirements, does not alter the type of legislation which encompasses any corporation which now or later may meet those requirements.

 

1043 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lanza v. Wagner


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


15 A.D.2d 552; 222 N.Y.S.2d 1019; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6962



December 20, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Orders and judgment affirmed, without costs.

 

1044 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Jewish Center of Mt. Vernon, Inc. v. Mt. Eden Cemetery Asso.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


15 A.D.2d 94; 222 N.Y.S.2d 644; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7207



December 11, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Order and judgment reversed, without costs; plaintiff's motion denied; and defendant's cross motion granted and complaint dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant cemetery challenged the judgment of the Supreme Court of Westchester County (New York), which granted a motion by plaintiff plot owner for judgment on the pleadings in the plot owner's action for a declaratory judgment to bind the agreement between the parties in regard to services rendered by the cemetery. Intervenor cemetery board also challenged the order.


OVERVIEW: The plot owner purchased certain burial rights and sought to bind the parties' agreement in regard to the maintenance of the cemetery grounds. Specifically, the plot owner argued that the cemetery refused to perform the specified services at the agreed prices and increased the agreed upon prices. The court reversed the judgment because the plot owner merely had the right of interment and the right to erect suitable monuments and to care for the plot. The plot owner was no different than any other large organization granting similar burial and funeral benefits to its members. The court noted that the cemetery could not charge either too little or too much for services to be rendered and it could not discriminate between lot owners by imposing burdens upon one that others should properly bear. However, because the plot owner did not contend that the increased charges were unreasonable, their imposition did not represent an abuse of power.


OUTCOME: The judgment in favor of the plot was reversed.


HEADNOTES

Cemeteries -- charges by cemetery corporations -- section 71 of Membership Corporations Law, providing that such law is inapplicable to religious corporation, does not exempt from provisions thereof religious corporation which merely holds plots in cemetery owned by unrelated cemetery corporation, as distinct from owning such plots -- law is not unconstitutional in authorizing approval by Cemetery Board of charges in excess of those fixed by existing contract where increases are reasonable and related to actual cost incurred by cemetery in rendering its services.

1. Plaintiff, a religious corporation owning burial rights in a plot located in defendant's cemetery, entered into an agreement with defendant, a [***2] membership corporation, in 1939. This agreement established fixed charges for grave openings and special care to be rendered by defendant. Intervening defendant, the Cemetery Board, pursuant to 1949 amendments to the Membership Corporations Law (L. 1949, ch. 533, as amd.), subsequently granted defendant the right to increase charges for these services, the increases becoming effective when approved by intervenor (§ 82). Plaintiff's allegation that its organization under the Religious Corporations Law makes it expressly exempt from the provisions of the Membership Corporations Law, section 71 thereof providing that such law does not apply to a religious corporation, cannot be sustained in the light of the intent of the statute as gleaned from other provisions therein and from its history, which make it clear that the exemption is inapplicable to religious corporations which merely hold plots in a cemetery owned by an unrelated cemetery corporation, as distinct from owning them. Accordingly, plaintiff's contract with defendant is subject to regulation under the Membership Corporations Law and to the changes in charges approved by intervenor.

2. The stated purpose of article IX [***3] of the Membership Corporations Law, authorizing the Cemetery Board to regulate cemeteries, is to prevent them from falling into disrepair and becoming a burden on the community. Accordingly, the law is not unconstitutional in authorizing approval of charges in excess of those fixed by earlier agreement where such increases are reasonable and related to the actual cost incurred by the cemetery in rendering its services.

 

1045 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Klein v. Yonkers


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


14 A.D.2d 885; 218 N.Y.S.2d 537; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8134



November 6, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Order and judgment affirmed, without costs.

 

1046 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Fischer v. Post-Standard Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


14 A.D.2d 130; 217 N.Y.S.2d 947; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9353



August 1, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with $ 10 costs to respondent.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant publisher challenged an order from the Supreme Court, Franklin County (New York), which denying the publisher's motion to dismiss the complaint filed by respondent district attorney alleging defamation.


OVERVIEW: The publisher printed an article describing the circumstances surrounding a pretrial hearing of a criminal defendant accused of killing a New York police officer. The press and the public were excluded in accordance with N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. 203. The publisher used the expression "Star Chamber," alleged police brutality, and used the phrase "iron curtain" in the article. The attorney argued that the article falsely insinuated that he violated the criminal defendant's constitutional rights, causing injury to the attorney's professional reputation. On appeal, the court found that the trial court properly denied the publisher's motion to dismiss. The court determined that whether the article contained defamatory statements was a question for the jury and not for the trial court because the application or meaning of the words in the article was ambiguous and the sense in which they were used was uncertain. The court concluded, however, that the article was capable of a construction upon which the publisher could have been found liable in defamation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.


HEADNOTES

Libel and slander -- libel -- owner and publisher of newspaper published article about plaintiff District Attorney captioned "D A Pulls 'Star Chamber' Hearing in Slaying" and mentioned police brutality and "iron curtain" -- no special damages alleged -- publication susceptible of defamatory meaning -- motion to dismiss complaint properly denied.

Respondent is the District Attorney of Franklin County and a member of the New York Bar. Appellant, the owner and publisher of a newspaper, published an article captioned "D A Pulls 'Star Chamber' Hearing in Slaying". The article described the circumstances surrounding the pretrial hearing of a St. Regis Indian accused of killing a State Trooper from which the press and public were legally excluded in accordance with section 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. In addition to the expression "Star Chamber", police brutality was charged and the phrase "iron curtain" was also used in describing the [***2] exclusion of the press and public from the hearing. Respondent alleges that the article falsely insinuates that he violated the accused's constitutional rights and by so doing injured his professional reputation. The public's understanding of the meaning of the term "Star Chamber" is something quite different than merely a secret or closed meeting. A charge that respondent deprived the accused of his constitutional rights would clearly be actionable. The expressions "Star Chamber", police brutality and "iron curtain" conveying the same meaning would be no less libelous. Since no special damages are alleged, the test to be applied is whether the article, as a matter of law, can be found to be without defamatory import. It cannot be said, that, as used in the instant article, a reasonable man could not conceive that a "Star Chamber" hearing imported an oppressive affair in derogation of the accused's rights. This publication is susceptible of defamatory meaning.

 

1047 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Schroeder v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


14 A.D.2d 183; 217 N.Y.S.2d 975; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9364



August 1, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Order and judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action to enjoin appellee nearby landowner from diverting a river away from appellant riparian landowner's property, the riparian landowner sought review of a judgment from the Supreme Court (New York), which granted a motion by the nearby landowner for judgment on the pleadings dismissing the complaint and denied a cross motion by the riparian landowner for judgment on the pleadings and to strike out defenses contained in the answer.


OVERVIEW: The nearby landowner commenced a proceeding to acquire the right to divert a river that flowed through the riparian landowner's property. The riparian landowner filed an action to enjoin the diversion. The trial court granted the nearby landowner's motion for judgment on the pleadings dismissing the complaint. The court affirmed the trial court's judgment. First, the nearby landowner complied with the notice requirements set out in New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § K41-8.0 by publishing notice of the proposed diversion and by posting notices of the diversion near the riparian landowner's property. Second, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § K41-8.0 did not violate N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6 or U.S. Const. amend XIV, XV because constructive notice was sufficient, as it was reasonably probable to have apprised the riparian landowner of the proceeding, and as such, gave him an opportunity to be heard. Finally, the riparian landowner's claim was barred because it was not filed within three years of the filing of the Commissioner's oath or the diversion, as required by New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § K41-8.0.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment, which granted a motion by the nearby landowner for judgment on the pleadings dismissing the complaint and denied a cross motion by the riparian landowner for judgment on the pleadings and to strike out defenses contained in the answer.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- notice of diversion of river -- constructive notice requirements of section K41-8.0 of Administrative Code of City of New York where city desired to acquire right to divert river do not violate New York Constitution (art. I, § 6) and Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments of United States Constitution.

The City of New York commenced a proceeding to acquire the right to divert the Neversink River in Orange County and gave the notice required by section K41-8.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York which did not require written notice. The constructive notice requirements of section K41-8.0 do not violate section 6 of article I of the New York Constitution and the Fifth Amendment and the Fourteenth Amendment (§ 1) of the United States Constitution.  [***2] The constructive notice is constitutionally adequate. Under the statute plaintiff had three years from the filing of the oaths of the Commissioners or from the diversion, whichever was later, in which to file her claim. The publications, posting and the visible effect of the diversion proceedings on the Neversink River over a three-year period constituted sufficient notice to meet the requirements of the New York and Federal Constitutions.

 

1048 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Schwartz v. Compania Azucarera Vertientes-Camaguey De Cuba


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


14 A.D.2d 582; 217 N.Y.S.2d 711; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9481



July 17, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Order, insofar, as appealed from, modified by striking out the second decretal paragraph which strikes out both the first and second defenses contained in the corporation's answer; and by substituting therefor a paragraph denying plaintiff's motion to strike out the corporation's first defense that it has not ceased to do business, and granting plaintiff's motion to strike out the corporation's second defense that the statute (Civ. Prac. Act, § 977-b) as applied to it is unconstitutional. As so modified, the order is affirmed, without costs.

 

1049 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Wiltwyck School for Boys, Inc. v. Hill


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


14 A.D.2d 198; 219 N.Y.S.2d 161; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9488



July 14, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Orders affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a zoning appeal, appellant charity sought review of the judgment of the Supreme Court, Westchester County (New York), which affirmed respondent zoning board's denial of appellant's application to build a facility in a residential area.


OVERVIEW: Appellant charity applied to build a school for boys on land in a residential area. Schools were among the authorized uses under the zoning ordinance. Respondent zoning board denied the application, finding that the proposed facility was for the treatment and rehabilitation of delinquent or maladjusted boys and was not a school within the meaning of the zoning ordinance. Appellant brought action. The trial court affirmed respondent's decision and appellant sought review. The court affirmed the trial court's ruling. Respondent's finding on the nature of the proposed facility was not arbitrary or capricious and the interpretation of the zoning ordinance was proper. The court held that respondent's ruling was neither invalid nor a violation of appellant's constitutional rights.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment. Respondent zoning board's determination that appellant charity's proposed facility for delinquent or maladjusted boys was not a school within the meaning of the zoning ordinance was not arbitrary or capricious.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- schools -- proof before Zoning Board  [***2] of Appeals of Town of Yorktown sufficient to sustain finding that petitioner's purpose was treatment and rehabilitation of delinquent or maladjusted boys and that it therefore did not qualify as school within meaning and intent of Zoning Ordinance -- building inspector's decision denying permit properly affirmed.

1. The proof before respondents constituting the Zoning Board of Appeals of the Town of Yorktown was sufficient to sustain their finding that petitioner's purpose was the treatment and rehabilitation of delinquent or maladjusted boys, and that it therefore did not qualify as a school within the meaning and intent of the Zoning Ordinance. Their determination as to the nature of petitioner's activities was not arbitrary or capricious, and their construction of the Zoning Ordinance was proper.

2. The fact that petitioner is subject to supervision by the State and the fact that the proposed site had been approved by a State agency do not render their determination either invalid or in violation of petitioner's constitutional rights.

3. The building inspector's decision denying a permit was properly affirmed. Petitioner failed to sustain the burden of proving the invalidity [***3] of the ordinance and the amendments thereto. The proof established that the ordinance as amended was a legitimate exercise of the police power of the town and promoted the general welfare of the community. The ordinance does not violate petitioner's constitutional rights or conflict with State law or policy.

 

1050 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Siegal v. Dros


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


14 A.D.2d 66; 217 N.Y.S.2d 417; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9556



July 6, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Order entered on February 26, 1959, sustaining a writ of habeas corpus and discharging the relator, unanimously reversed, on the law, and the writ dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State challenged an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which granted respondent owner's petition for a writ of habeas corpus to secure his release from jail after he was convicted for violations of N.Y. Mult. Dwell. Law §§ D26-3.1, D26-8.0.


OVERVIEW: The owner was charged with failing to register his tenement building with the city as required by § D26-3.1 and with violating § D26-8.0 by failing to cure building violations. He was convicted of both charges in a magistrate court. The owner filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus to secure his release from jail. The trial court granted the petition, holding that the magistrate court lacked jurisdiction over the § D26-8.0 charge because an affiant did not swear to the information. On appeal, the court reversed the trial court's order and dismissed the petition.
