The court held that the owner's proper remedy was a direct appeal of the convictions, a motion to vacate the judgment of the magistrate court, or a motion for a new trial. The court determined that § D26-3.1 was constitutional because it was reasonably related to the legitimate government purpose of enforcing the laws governing multiple dwellings. The court ruled that the information improperly charged the owner with violating § D26-8.0, which set the penalties for violations of the New York Multiple Dwelling Code, but that the error was not a sufficient ground for a writ of habeas corpus.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's order granting the owner's petition for a writ of habeas corpus to secure his release from jail. The court dismissed the owner's petition.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- failure properly to register ownership of building and to cure building violations -- violation of Multiple Dwelling Code (§ D26-3.1) is offense over which Magistrate's Court has jurisdiction -- relator was sufficiently apprised of charge against him and participated fully in trial -- sentence imposed did not exceed maximum specified for first offense under Multiple Dwelling Code -- sentencing court having had jurisdiction, habeas corpus is not proper remedy to challenge its decisions.

1. Relator was convicted in Magistrate's Court of failure properly to register ownership of a tenement building (Multiple Dwelling Code, § D26-3.1) and failure to cure specific building violations (Multiple Dwelling Law, § 80). The complaint which instituted his [***2] prosecution was signed, but not sworn to, by the Building Inspector who discovered and reported the alleged violations. Relator's challenge to the court's jurisdiction on the ground that this complaint was not sworn to by the complainant was overruled during the trial. Upon his conviction he was sentenced to pay a fine of $ 500, in default thereof, to 30 days' imprisonment. A violation of the Multiple Dwelling Code is an offense only (§ D26-8.0) and one over which the Magistrate's Court has jurisdiction ( N. Y. City Crim. Cts. Act, § 100). The complaint as drawn was adequate to apprise relator of the charge against him and he participated fully in the trial. The penalty imposed upon him coincided with the maximum penalty imposable for a first offense under the Multiple Dwelling Code. Accordingly, the Magistrate had jurisdiction of the subject matter and of the relator and did not exceed it in rendering his judgment.

2. The Magistrate's Court having had jurisdiction, a writ of habeas corpus does not lie to challenge its decisions on questions raised during the trial, litigated therein, and decided adversely to relator, including that concerning the alleged defect in the complaint [***3] filed.

 

1051 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Finocchairo v. Kelly


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


14 A.D.2d 503; 218 N.Y.S.2d 132; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9712



June 30, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Determination annulled on the law and respondent directed to restore petitioner's license, with $ 50 costs and disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner motorist sought review of an order from respondent Commissioner of Motor Vehicles of the State of New York, which revoked his driver's license.


OVERVIEW: The motorist was arrested under the charge of driving while intoxicated. He told the officer that he would submit to a blood test if his attorney so advised him. The court found that under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 71(a), the motorist should have been given an opportunity to consult with an attorney before he submitted to the blood test. He was entitled to obtain confirmation from his attorney of his asserted duty to submit to the test. The court did note the test had to be taken promptly to be effective and an unreasonable delay did not need to be countenanced. There was nothing to show that the motorist's attorney could not have been reached promptly by telephone. The license revocation was not based upon the driving while intoxicated charge but upon the alleged refusal to take the blood test. The motorist's request to consult with an attorney was not a basis for the revocation of his driver's license.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the Commissioner that revoked the driver's license of the motorist.

 

1052 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Di Prima v. Wagner


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


14 A.D.2d 36; 215 N.Y.S.2d 705; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10645



May 23, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Judgment and order unanimously modified, on the law, so as to strike therefrom the last decretal paragraph in both the order and judgment and substituting in place thereof a declaration that the provisions of paragraph (e) of subdivision 4 and subdivision 3 of section 20 of the City Home Rule Law are valid and, as so modified, the judgment and order are affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer, defendant public officials, and intervenor attorney general cross appealed the order and judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term, New York County (New York), which denied the taxpayer's motion for a temporary injunction to prevent the application of N.Y. City Home Rule Law § 20 (1961), denied defendants' cross motion to dismiss the complaint, and declared that § 20 was in part unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Section 20 provided for the appointment by the mayor of a commission to draw up a proposed charter for the city and for the payment of the expenses of the commission by the city. The taxpayer sought to have § 20 declared unconstitutional and to prevent the public officials from incurring any liabilities or using any municipal funds for the purposes of the statute. The trial court found that the statute was constitutional but that certain sections were unconstitutional, but, because the unconstitutional sections were separable, they did not destroy the valid provisions of the statute. The court agreed with the trial court that defendants could validly collect taxes but it found that the provisions in question were constitutional. Section 20 did not violate the state constitution because it was not a local law and, as a general law, it did not have to be passed in accord with the provisions for enactment of local laws by the state legislature. Also, the delegation of authority to the mayor to approve the commission's expenses was a lawful delegation of legislative power.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed, as modified, the order and judgment of the trial court. The court modified the judgment to hold that the statute was in all respects constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- New York City Charter -- act of Legislature (L. 1961, ch. 87), amending section 20 of City Home Rule Law to provide additional method by which city could adopt new charter, is general law and not local law and not in violation of New York State Constitution (art. IX, §  [***2] 11) -- Legislature had power to give Mayor discretion to approve expenses of charter commission and make expenses charge upon city, and also to provide that, when charter was promulgated in accord with such amendment, no other proposed charter might be submitted at same election -- statute in all respects constitutional.

1. An act of the Legislature (L. 1961, ch. 87) amending section 20 of the City Home Rule Law to provide an additional method beyond the three methods formerly contained in section 20 of the City Home Rule Law by which the city could adopt a new charter, is a general law and not a local law and is, consequently, not in violation of section 11 of article IX of the New York State Constitution.

2. An allegation in the complaint that the law, while in terms referring to all cities, is meant to apply to the City of New York only and is in fact a local law, is a conclusion as to a matter of statutory interpretation, and raises no evidentiary issue.

3. The Legislature had the power to give the Mayor discretion to approve the expenses of a charter commission and, when so approved, make these expenses a charge upon the city.

4. Special Term declared unconstitutional and [***3] inoperative the provisions of the statute providing that, where a proposed new charter promulgated in accord with the amendment is submitted to the electorate for approval or disapproval, no other proposed charter may be submitted at the same election. Provision is also made against the submission of another proposed charter in the guise of amendments to existing local laws. Those provisions are not unconstitutional. The granting of city charters is a legislative function which was originally exercised by the Legislature itself. By virtue of a constitutional home rule amendment (art. IX, § 11), the Legislature was given the power to delegate to cities the right to adopt a charter by local law. If the amendment amounts to a withdrawal of power, it is authorized. The Legislature could withdraw all powers given in respect to charters or charter revision in section 20 of the Home Rule Law.

5. The statute is in all respects constitutional.

 

1053 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York v. Sanford


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


13 A.D.2d 259; 215 N.Y.S.2d 411; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10652



May 23, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Orders affirmed, with $ 10 costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, members of the board of assessors of a village, appealed from orders of the Supreme Court, Delaware County (New York), which struck certain defenses as a sham, frivolous, and insufficient in law, and which granted respondent city's application thereby reducing the assessment upon the city's sewage disposal system within the village.


OVERVIEW: The city owned real property in the village that it used for sewage disposal purposes. The city and the village entered into a contract that provided that the disposal plant would be exempt from taxation for a period of 10 years, and that the lands upon which the plant was situated could not be assessed in excess of $ 25,000 for that period. The board of assessors of the village assessed a tax on the sewage disposal system of $ 378,651. The city brought an action to review the assessment. The board of assessors argued that the agreement was not binding, that it was ultra vires and unconstitutional, and that the city's breach of other agreements justified rescission of the tax exemption. The court held that: (1) N.Y. Tax Law §4, subd. 16-a provided for the tax exemption of a sewage disposal plant or system if the municipal corporation in which it was located agreed to the exemption in writing; (2) a tax exemption authorized by statute was not revocable; it was binding; (3) once the village consented to the tax exemption, the legislation took effect; (4) the village could not revoke the tax exemption; and (5) the trial court properly struck certain defenses raised by the village.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the orders of the trial court, with costs.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- exemption -- contract between City of New York and Village of Margaretville, executed pursuant to section 406 (subd. 3) of Real Property Tax Law and granting exemption to City of New York's sewage disposal system in village, is valid and binding and is not revocable by village.

1. The City of New York constructed a sewage disposal system in the Village of Margaretville, and on September 23, 1958 the city and the Village Board executed a contract whereby the village agreed that the disposal plant and system would be exempt from taxation for a period of 10 years. The agreement provided also that the lands upon which the plant was situated would not be assessed in excess of $ 25,000 for such period. The sewage disposal plant would ordinarily be taxable [***2] property (Real Property Tax Law, § 300). However, section 406 (subd. 3) of the Real Property Tax Law provided that: "Real property owned by a municipal corporation not within its corporate limits while used as a sewage disposal plant or system, including necessary connections and appurtenances, shall be wholly or partially exempt from taxation and exempt from special ad valorem levies and special assessments to the extent provided in section four hundred ninety of this chapter, by any municipal corporation in which located, provided the governing board thereof shall so agree in writing." Pursuant to the intention of the statute, the contract is binding on the village. The period of 10 years is within the bounds of propriety where the enabling statute contained no limitations of the term. There appears to be a mutuality of consideration but, since the agreement was executed pursuant to expressed legislative intent, it is not important whether the village received a consideration. The agreement was a legislative act by the Village Board which carried into effect a tax exemption authorized by the Legislature by virtue of a constitutional statute. The exemption is not revocable [***3] -- it is binding.

2. The contention of the village that the agreement was integrated with two other agreements so that a breach of those agreements affects this one is without merit. There is no reference to these agreements in the subject agreement.

3. Accordingly, the court properly gave effect to the exemption agreement and reduced the assessment on the sewage disposal system.

 

1054 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Brunacini v. Loomis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


12 A.D.2d 298; 211 N.Y.S.2d 371; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12585



February 16, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Order unanimously reversed and petition dismissed, without costs of this appeal to any party.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, the members of a Town Board, sought review of the decision of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Chautauqua County (New York), which vacated a determination of the Board that denied petitioner applicant's request for a junk dealer's license, and directed that the Board issue the license to the applicant as requested.


OVERVIEW: The Board contended that the trial court erred in overturning their denial of the applicant's request for a license and ordering that the license be issued, arguing that N.Y. Town Law § 137 provided that the Town Clerk could refuse a license to any person who, in his judgment, was an undesirable person or incapable of properly conducting the trade or business desired. The court overturned the trial court's ruling. In so holding, the court found that: (1) N.Y. Town Law § 137 provided guidance to the licensor, and therein contained an implied delegation of power to withhold a license for good cause; (2) a finding having been made that the applicant was a person unfit to be granted a license the scope of judicial inquiry was limited to the question of whether there was substantial evidence in the record to support the determination, or whether, on the other hand, the action was tantamount to an arbitrary or capricious abuse of discretion; and (3) there was substantial evidence to support the determination that petitioner was an unfit person to possess a license and the denial of the application was neither arbitrary nor capricious.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's ruling and dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

Licenses -- municipal corporations -- junk business -- section 137 of Town Law which provides that Town Clerk may refuse license for junk business to "undesirable person" or one "incapable of properly conducting the trade or business desired" not unconstitutional -- "undesirable person" not too ambiguous -- where no standards necessary, vague or indefinite standards are not unconstitutional -- finding that petitioner was unfit for license is supported by substantial evidence.

1. Section 137 of the Town Law sets forth procedures for the issuance of licenses for the junk business, and provides that the Town Clerk "may also refuse a license to any person who in his judgment shall be an undesirable person or incapable of properly conducting the trade or business [***2] desired." In a proceeding to compel issuance of a license, Special Term should not have declared this provision unconstitutional upon the ground that the phrase "undesirable person" is too "vague, uncertain, ambiguous and illusory to furnish any proper standard."

2. The provision in section 137 of the Town Law that a license may be denied an undesirable person or one incapable of properly conducting the business furnishes some guidance to the licensor. If, however, there is an implied delegation of power to withhold a license for good cause in the absence of any standards in the statute defining good cause (cf. Matter of Barton Trucking Corp. v. O'Connell, 7 N Y 2d 299), the enactment may not be struck down because the standards expressly stated are vague. In other words, if "fitness" may be passed upon by implication, vague or indefinite standards are better than none, and, in any event, none is required.

3. The finding that petitioner was a person unfit to be granted a license is supported by substantial evidence. The licensing body found that the applicant had made a false statement under oath in a prior court proceeding involving this license and in addition had refused [***3] to testify and offer any exculpatory proof with regard to the alleged perjurious statements.

 

1055 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rockwell v. Morris


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


12 A.D.2d 272; 211 N.Y.S.2d 25; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12687



February 14, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Order entered on August 30, 1960, denying petitioner's application for an order directing the Commissioner of Parks of the City of New York to issue a permit to the petitioner to speak in Union Square Park and dismissing the petition, reversed, on the law, without costs, and the petition granted to the extent of remanding the matter to the Commissioner for the purpose of allowing petitioner to file a new application for a permit and for the Commissioner to proceed thereon in accordance with the opinion of Breitel, J. P., filed herein. The intervenor, Department of New York Jewish War Veterans of the United States, Inc., is stricken as a party respondent in this proceeding and the caption of this proceeding is hereby amended by deleting and striking the name of said intervenor as a party hereto.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant applicant sought review of an order by the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which denied the applicant's request for an order directing respondent Commissioner of Parks of the City of New York to issue a permit to the applicant to speak in a park.


OVERVIEW: The applicant contended the commissioner did not comply with New York City, N.Y., Rules of the City of New York, tit. 15, § 21-a, and that, if he had such power under §21-a, it was void for unconstitutionality. The court reversed, granted the petition in part, and held that (1) the record did not support the grounds assigned by the commissioner for his action; (2) the commissioner did not follow § 21-a; (3) there was no power in government under the state constitution to exercise prior restraint of the expression of views, unless it was demonstrable on a record that such expression would have immediately and irreparably created injury to the public weal; (4) while there might not have been a prior restraint on the expression of views, but for the narrowest of exceptions, there might have been complete responsibility for the content of such expression; and (5) because of the important public issue involved and the future significance of the constitutional questions raised, and also because the commissioner failed to provide the applicant with an alternative time and place for his speech, the N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 proceeding had not been rendered moot.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order dismissing the applicant's petition, and granted the petition to the extent of remanding the matter to the commissioner for the purpose of allowing the applicant to file a new application for a permit and for the commissioner to proceed thereon in accordance with the opinion of the court.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- freedom  [***2] of speech -- application for permit to speak insufficient to support conclusion that speech would create serious disorders -- failure to serve reply in judicial proceeding not prejudicial -- Department of Parks rule constitutional -- denial of application without setting alternative time and place error -- prior restraint of expression without showing of immediate and irreparable injury not constitutional -- date requested in application does not render proceeding moot.

1. Petitioner, a self-styled American Nazi and, reputedly, a rabid racist, applied to the Commissioner of Parks for a permit to use Union Square Park to make a public political speech on July 4, 1960. In August, 1960, after respondent Commissioner had denied the application without offering an alternative time or place, petitioner instituted a proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act to review the determination. Since the Commissioner had before him only the application of petitioner, there was no competent record upon which to conclude that petitioner's speech was likely to create serious disorders.

2. A rule of the Department of Parks which provides that, if a permit is denied for any but commercial [***3] or private uses, an alternative suitable location and date must be offered to the applicant does not authorize censorship of speech content and is constitutional.

3. The Commissioner erred in denying the application without offering to petitioner an alternative time or place as he was required to do under the regulation of the department.

4. Petitioner is not prejudiced by his failure to serve a reply in the judicial proceedings.

5. There is no power in the government constitutionally to exercise prior restraint of the expression of views unless the record supports the conclusion that such expression will immediately and irreparably injure the public.

6. Because of the important public issue involved and also because the Commissioner failed to provide petitioner with an alternative time and place for his speech, the proceeding is not rendered moot merely because the date requested by petitioner has passed.

7. Since intervenor conceded that, except as an organized group in the public generally, it had no legal interest in this litigation, the court on its own motion should strike intervenor as a party to the proceeding.

8. The matter should be remanded to the Commissioner for [***4] the purpose of allowing petitioner to file a new application for a permit and for the Commissioner to proceed thereon in accordance with the opinion.

 

1056 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York State Thruway Authority v. Ashley Motor Court, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


12 A.D.2d 223; 210 N.Y.S.2d 193; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13048



January 24, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of the judgment by the Supreme Court (New York) in favor of plaintiff, New York State Thruway Authority (authority), in an action to prohibit defendant from maintaining a sign within 500 feet of the nearest edge of the thruway pavement unless a written permit had been granted by the authority pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 361-a.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended § 361-a violated the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the Federal Constitution and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6 by arbitrarily prohibiting some but not all advertising and retroactively deprived defendant of a vested right. In affirming, the court held the authority had the power to regulate advertising to provide maximum visibility, to prevent confusion with regard to traffic lights, signs, or signals, to preserve and enhance the thruway's natural scenic beauty, and to promote safety, comfort, and well-being of the users of the thruway. The court found the sign was originally placed on defendant's property, then relocated on the request of the Department of Public Works. Relocation was the same as erecting and the sign was within 500 feet of the thruway pavement, and defendant did not have a permit. The court held the rules were not arbitrary because if a permit was refused the authority had to state specifically the reasons for its refusal and defendant never made an application. The court finally held the restriction was in the interest of the welfare of the general public and was not considered a taking of property.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of the authority in its action to prohibit defendant from maintaining a sign within 500 feet of the nearest edge of the thruway pavement without a permit.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- billboards near Thruway -- statute (Public Authorities Law, § 361-a) prohibiting erection or maintenance of any advertising devices within 500 feet of Thruway without permit from Thruway Authority was valid exercise of State's police power and did not violate equal protection or due process clauses of Federal or State Constitutions.

1. Section 361-a of the Public Authorities Law prohibited the erection or maintenance of any advertising device within 500 feet of the pavement of the New York State Thruway without a written permit therefor from the Thruway Authority. Enactment of the statute was justified as an exercise of the State's police power by the necessity of providing reasonable precautions to insure the safety and comfort of travelers on this high-speed, controlled access, express highway specially designed and constructed for the greatest possible visibility. Moreover, the statute did not arbitrarily prohibit [***2] some but not all advertising and, therefore, did not violate the equal protection clause of the Federal Constitution (14th Amdt.) or the State Constitution (art. I, § 6). Accordingly, defendants were properly restrained from maintaining an advertising sign on their premises within 500 feet of the Thruway pavement without the permit required by the statute.

2. The statute did not retroactively deprive defendants of a vested right without due process of law inasmuch as their sign was erected after the effective date of the statute. Relocating is the same as erecting, and defendants' sign, although originally erected on the same premises in 1937, was then in another location and was relocated in 1958 when the State acquired title to the original location for highway purposes, and the wording of the sign had been changed from its original form. Accordingly it was properly determined to be a new and different sign. In any event, subdivision 1 of section 361-a applied not only to the erection but to the maintenance of advertising devices, and defendants were enjoined from maintaining their sign without obtaining the permit required by the section.

3. Due process demands that laws [***3] enacted pursuant to the police power be reasonable and not arbitrary, but section 361-a was not arbitrary on the claimed ground that subdivision 7 thereof gave the Thruway Authority the right to make exceptions excluding from coverage under the section advertising devices which it found do not interefere with Thruway safety or contravene enumerated standards, or on the claimed ground that article 5 of the Thruway Authority's rules and regulations defined certain exempt areas where advertising signs may be erected. The intent and purpose of the statute and the regulations was not to deny the right to have signs within the prescribed area, but to require the obtaining of a permit so as to regulate the use and maintenance of signs erected thereon.

4. The determination as to the right to erect and maintain any sign within 500 feet of the Thruway is not made until after a permit has been applied for, and if the Authority denied an application for such permit, it would be required to state specifically its reasons for such denial. Defendants, who have made no such application for a permit, and who have offered no proof of signs in exempt areas or as to other claimed discrimination to [***4] sustain the burden of proof that they have in attacking the constitutionality of a statute, have no reason to claim discrimination.

 

1057 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Douglas


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


12 A.D.2d 194; 209 N.Y.S.2d 734; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13157



January 17, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Order of the Special County Judge modified to the extent that the demurrer is allowed, upon the ground that the indictment was insufficient, and the case resubmitted to another Grand Jury, and as modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State sought review of a judgment from the County Court of St. Lawrence County (New York), which dismissed an indictment charging defendants with selling obscene magazines in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 1141.


OVERVIEW: The trial judge dismissed the indictment on the ground that N.Y. Penal Law 1141(1) was unconstitutional, being contrary to the letter and spirit of U.S. Const. amend. 14 and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8. On appeal, the State argued that the trial court erred in dismissing the indictment. Upon review, the court found the State's argument without merit. The order dismissing the indictment required affirmance not because of the unconstitutionality of N.Y. Penal Law § 1141, but because of the insufficiency of the indictment. The indictment was insufficient in that it failed to allege knowledge on the part of defendants. The various counts of the indictment stated that defendants sold obscene magazines. Such action was not a crime unless the magazines were sold with knowledge, actual or constructive, that they were obscene.


OUTCOME: The order of the trial court was modified to the extent that the demurrer was allowed upon the ground that the indictment was insufficient, the case was resubmitted to another grand jury, and as modified, the judgment was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sale of obscene magazines -- section 1141 (subd. 1) of Penal Law, rendering person who sells obscene magazine guilty of misdemeanor, construed as requiring scienter -- as so construed, statute not unconstitutional -- indictment insufficient in failing to allege knowledge on part of defendants.

1. Subdivision 1 of section 1141 of the Penal Law provides that: "A person who sells * * * distributes * * * any obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy, indecent, sadistic, masochistic or disgusting * * * magazine * * * [is] guilty of a misdemeanor". The statute is construed as requiring scienter. As so construed it is not unconstitutional (cf. Smith v. California, 361 U.S. 147).

2. The indictment, which charged a violation of section 1141 of the [***2] Penal Law, is insufficient in failing to allege knowledge on the part of defendants. The matter should be resubmitted to another Grand Jury.

 

1058 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Loblaw, Inc. v. New York State Board of Pharmacy


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


12 A.D.2d 180; 210 N.Y.S.2d 709; 1961 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13278



January 12, 1961 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed on the law, without costs of this appeal to any party and judgment directed in favor of the defendants.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, the New York State Board of Pharmacy and others, sought review of a judgment from the Supreme Court at Special Term, Erie County (New York), which granted a motion by plaintiff corporation for summary judgment and determined that the corporation had the right to sell Bayer Aspirin Tablets through unlicensed employees in its retail stores, for which the corporation did not have registration certificates.


OVERVIEW: The corporation sold the tablets in its retail stores without complying with certain provisions of the New York Education Law regulating the sale of drugs. The corporation claimed, and the trial court found, that such tablets were "proprietary medicines" and, as such, were exempt from the application of N.Y. Educ. Law art. 137. The corporation also contended that any attempt to interfere with the free and unlicensed sale of the tablets was unreasonable, arbitrary, discriminatory, and unconstitutional. The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of the corporation, and defendants appealed. The court reversed, holding that Bayer Aspirin Tablets were not so distinctively or exclusively attributable to their producers as to be regarded as specially the maker's own kind of medicine, and thus were not "proprietary medicines" excepted from N.Y. Educ. Law art. 137 by N.Y. Educ. Law § 6816(2)(c). The court concluded that restricting the sale of such tablets, even though they may have been harmless, to registered pharmacists, was a valid exercise of the State's police power, under which all pharmacists were treated alike and all general retailers were treated alike.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment, which had been entered in favor of the corporation, and thereby granted judgment in favor of defendants against the corporation.


HEADNOTES

Drugs and druggists -- proprietary medicines -- Bayer Aspirin Tablets are drugs but not proprietary medicines (Education Law, § 6816, subd. 2) -- accordingly, article 137 of Education Law, which regulates sale and distribution of drugs, is applicable -- judgment determining that plaintiff has right to sell Bayer Aspirin Tablets through unlicensed employees in its retail stores, for which plaintiff does not have registration certificates as pharmacies, reversed.

1. Article 137 of the Education Law regulates the sale and distribution of drugs in the State of New York. Section 6816 (subd. 2) provides that: "Except as to the [***2] labeling of poison and to adulterating, misbranding and substituting", article 137 shall not apply "(c) To the sale of proprietary medicines except those proprietary medicines which are poisonous, deleterious and/or habit forming." Bayer Aspirin Tablets are admittedly drugs. However, they are not proprietary medicines.

2. The question whether they are "poisonous, deleterious and/or habit forming" is not reached.

3. Restricting the sale of Bayer Aspirin Tablets to licensed pharmacies (Education Law, art. 137, § 6805) is a valid exercise of the State's police power, even if the tablets be harmless.

4. A judgment determining that plaintiff has a right to sell Bayer Aspirin Tablets through unlicensed employees in its retail supermarkets, for which plaintiff does not have registration certificates as pharmacies, is reversed.

 

1059 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Waterman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


12 A.D.2d 84; 208 N.Y.S.2d 596; 1960 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6370



December 20, 1960 



DISPOSITION: Judgments of conviction reversed, upon the law only, the facts having been considered, and a new trial ordered.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed their convictions in the Bronx County Court (New York) for the crimes of robbery in the first degree, grand larceny in the second degree, and assault in the second degree.


OVERVIEW: A victim was robbed by three individuals, including defendants. One of the robbers was apprehended immediately following the crime. He implicated defendants in the crime but the indictment against the apprehended individual listed his codefendant under fictitious designations. A detective questioned one defendant while he was incarcerated and again while he was at the courthouse. The detective testified that he gave a full confession each time but there were no notes of the confession. The detective never informed defendant of his right to counsel or asked if defendant had retained counsel. The court held that the questioning of defendant while he was in custody, was a suspect in the crime, and was without counsel was a violation of his constitutional rights. The court held that the admission of defendant's confession at trial required the reversal of the remaining defendant's conviction because the admission of such confession redounded to the prejudice of this defendant.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgments of conviction and ordered a new trial.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- confessions -- testimony of detective that after defendants were indicted one defendant made complete oral confessions to him when questioned without counsel was improperly admitted at defendants' trial; principles of People v. Di Biasi (7 N Y 2d 544) held to control and require reversal of convictions of both defendants.

1. Defendants were convicted of robbery, first degree, grand larceny, second degree, and assault, second degree, upon an indictment returned February 24, 1959, which originally denoted defendants by fictitious names. Upon their trial a detective testified that he had questioned defendant Waterman on June 17, 1959, while he was incarcerated in the Tombs, and on June 29, 1959 at the county courthouse, and that defendant had made a complete confession on each occasion. Such testimony [***2] was improperly admitted into evidence. Although it is not clear when defendants' real names were substituted in the indictment, there is no doubt that the defendant Waterman was in fact an accused at the time he was questioned. At that time he was without counsel and was not asked by the detective if he had retained or had been assigned counsel. However, the fact that he was without counsel when questioned by one who knew that he was an accused should not deprive him of the benefit of the principle of People v. Di Biasi (7 N Y 2d 544) which applies to require reversal of defendant's conviction. Although this limits section 395 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, and appears to be contrary to the general principle governing admissibility of confessions -- that no one will voluntarily make an admission against interest -- the circumstances under which the alleged confession was obtained may, upon further evidence, show it to have been involuntary, inasmuch as the detective stated that the defendant Waterman did not solicit his visit or declare any intent or wish to make a statement prior thereto. The mere fact that he was in custody at the time of the alleged confession would [***3] not prevent its admission, but the fact that he was then known by his interrogator to be an accused, together with other circumstances existing, required reversal of his conviction.

2. The error committed by receiving such confession into evidence redounded to the prejudice of the codefendant Devine as well and required reversal of his conviction also. Moreover, the limiting effect of Waterman's confession was not sufficiently delineated by the court as to Devine in view of the prosecutor's continued references thereto.

 

1060 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lanvin Parfums, Inc. v. Le Dans, Ltd.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


12 A.D.2d 104; 208 N.Y.S.2d 675; 1960 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6375; 128 U.S.P.Q. (BNA) 208



December 20, 1960 



DISPOSITION: Order, entered on March 4, 1960, denying defendants-appellants' motion, pursuant to rule 106 of the Rules of Civil Practice, to dismiss the complaint for insufficiency, as to each of them, reversed, on the law, with $ 20 costs and disbursements to appellants, and the motion to dismiss the complaint for legal insufficiency granted, with $ 10 costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, rebottlers and principal officers, sought review of an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which dismissed their motion to dismiss plaintiff corporation's complaint for legal insufficiency under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 106.


OVERVIEW: The corporations filed a civil action against the rebottlers and principal officers, alleging that the rebottling and resale of its trademarked products were illegal although the new bottles and the labels which they bore made complete disclosure of the fact of rebottling. The corporation sought an injunction and damages against the rebottlers and their principal officers. The supreme court denied the rebottlers and principal officers' N.Y. C.P.L.R. 106 motion to dismiss the complaint for legal insufficiency, holding that N.Y. Penal Law § 2354(6) prohibited the resale of any trademarked product, represented to be the product of the manufacturer, except in its original container. On appeal, the court reversed the order denying the rebottlers and principal officers' motion to dismiss. The court ruled that the complaint failed to allege any cause of action against any of the rebottlers or principal officers. The court granted their motion and dismissed the complaint with costs.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the dismissal of the rebottlers and principal officers' motion to dismiss the corporation's complaint for insufficiency. The court granted the motion with $ 10 costs.


HEADNOTES

Trade-marks, trade names and unfair competition -- resale of rebottled trade-marked products -- defendants' rebottling and resale of trade-marked toilet waters imported by plaintiff was not violation of Penal Law ( § 2354, subd. 6), in absence of misstatement, fraud or deception, where new bottles and labels clearly disclosed rebottling and lack of connection between rebottler and plaintiff or manufacturer; plaintiff not damaged so as to warrant injunction against defendants' rebottling and resale; controlling stockholders not personally responsible  [***2] for every corporate act.

1. Defendant corporations purchased trade-marked toilet waters packaged by plaintiff (which imported them from France as perfumes or perfume extracts) and rebottled or repackaged them in smaller containers which were sold at correspondingly reduced prices under labels which identified the contents as plaintiff's products, but also stated that rebottling had been done by defendant corporations which were wholly independent of plaintiff. Such rebottling and resale, with complete disclosure of the facts of rebottling and of no connection between the rebottler and plaintiff or the manufacturer, and with no misstatement of any fact to the deception of a purchaser, did not constitute a violation of subdivision 6 of section 2354 of the Penal Law, although the literal language of the statute made it a misdemeanor to sell trade-marked goods except "in the original package, box or bottle and under the labels, marks or names placed thereon by the manufacturer who is entitled to use such marks" and the statute contained no qualification expressly related to the element of fraud or deception. Statutes are not to be read so literally as to kill their meaning, intent,  [***3] purpose or the beneficial ends for which they were designed, and it has been uniformly held that this is a fraud statute requiring misrepresentation, tacit or expressed, before there could be a violation. Moreover, it is a criminal statute which if applied to the acts of defendants would penalize their disclosure of the truth and produce utterly intolerable results. Indeed, such a literal interpretation of the statute, which refers only to the "manufacturer" who is entitled to use the trade names, would cause difficulty to plaintiff which itself is not the manufacturer, but an importer and rebottler.

2. If the statute were interpreted as condemning activity in the absence of fraud, there would be a serious question of its constitutional validity. However, the constitutional issues may be avoided and the constitutional limits of the legislation need not be explored in view of the controlling interpretations of the statute. Although the mere potentiality for fraud, as distinguished from the actuality of fraud, may allow exercise of the police power to restrict commercial activity, the power to legislate is less in an area of mere potentiality for fraud as compared with actual fraud.  [***4] Moreover, requiring statutes to be literally construed as long as such construction does not violate a constitution is a primitive literalism which does not necessarily yield intention. The fact is that intent is not discovered by literal reading of abstracted words, but by interpretation in context and circumstances. In any event there is a positive obligation to avoid stretching the statutory language in unnecessary violation of precedents and to the disruption of commerce.

3. Injunction will not lie merely to prevent a crime, although it is available if the criminal act causes damage or impairs a property right. But inasmuch as the application of this criminal statute to defendants would involve an extension of protectible interests in trade-marks not even recognized under Federal law, such trade-mark rights do not extend to resale in the absence of deception, and plaintiff, therefore, has no property or equivalent right to protect, and consequently was not entitled to the injunction it sought to restrain defendants' rebottling and resale.

4. The complaint was defective as to the individual defendants. Merely to say that an individual is the owner of stock of a corporation [***5] and controls its activities does not imply that he is responsible for every act of the corporation. Accordingly, the complaint, which fails to allege any cause of action against any of the defendants, should have been dismissed for legal insufficiency.

 

1061 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hotel Armstrong, Inc. v. Temporary State Housing Rent Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


11 A.D.2d 395; 207 N.Y.S.2d 358; 1960 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6954



November 22, 1960 



DISPOSITION: Order and judgment (one paper) denying defendants' and intervenor's motions for summary judgment and granting plaintiff such summary judgment, unanimously reversed, on the law, the defendants' and intervenor's motions granted, and plaintiff's motion denied, with costs to defendants-appellants and intervenor-appellant. Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, Temporary State Housing Rent Commission and others, challenged an order and judgment from the Supreme Court at Special Term, New York County (New York) which denied motions by defendants for summary judgment and for judgment on the pleadings, granted a cross motion by plaintiff hotel owner for summary judgment and judgment on the pleadings, and held that the premises were not subject to rent control.


OVERVIEW: The owner of housing accommodations styled as a hotel sought a declaratory judgment that the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission was without power to regulate the rents charged by it. It asserted that the 1959 amendments to the controlling statute (L. 1959, ch. 695), under which the Rent Commission acted, were not applicable, and that, in any event, the amendments were unconstitutional. On cross motions for summary judgment, the lower court granted judgment in favor of the owner, holding that the amendments were limited to revesting rent control in the Rent Commission only regarding purported hotels whose rents had been regulated by the Rent Commission at some prior time. The appellate court reversed, holding that the 1959 amendments were applicable to the premises and there was no constitutional infirmity. The amendments were applicable to housing accommodations styled as hotels that did not satisfy the definition of hotels in the statute, even though such housing accommodations had not been subject to rent control since 1950. Also, the 1959 amendments in conferring power upon the Rent Commission to fix rents contained sufficient legislative standards and were valid.


OUTCOME: The order and judgment denying the motion for summary judgment by defendants and granting the hotel owner summary judgment was reversed. .


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant -- rent regulation -- applicability of State Residential Rent Law (L. 1946, ch. 274, as amd. by  [***2] L. 1959, ch. 695) to premises formerly exempt or decontrolled as "hotel" -- 1959 amendments to State Residential Rent Law (§ 2, subd. 2, par. [b]) applied to authorize fixing maximum rents for premises theretofore exempt or decontrolled as "hotel"; amendment (§ 4, subd. 2-b), when read together with following subdivision 3, contained sufficient legislative standards for commission in fixing maximum rents and was, therefore, valid.

1. Both the language of the 1959 amendments to the State Residential Rent Law (L. 1946, ch. 274, as amd. by L. 1959, ch. 695) and the report to the Legislature by the Temporary State Commission to Study Rents and Rental Conditions preceding enactment of the amendments make it evident that they had the intent and effect of vesting in the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission control of rents in purported hotels which no longer qualify as such, whether or not they had at some prior time been properly classified as hotels and, therefore, exempt or decontrolled under the statute and not subject to rent control since 1950. In order to be excluded from regulation (State Residential Rent Law, § 2, subd. 2, par. [b]) a hotel must have been within the [***3] statutory definition of such not only on March 1, 1950, but also at the present time. Accordingly, the 1959 amendments apply to housing accommodations called hotels which no longer satisfy the statutory definition thereof even though they once were properly so classified and, therefore, have not been subject to rent control since 1950.

2. Subdivision 2-b of section 4 of the statute (added by L. 1959, ch. 695) provided for regulations by the commission for the establishment, adjustment and modification of maximum rents in rooming houses, including the erstwhile "hotels" which, as stated in the legislative report, have deteriorated "into rooming houses or worse". The subdivision provided that such regulations were to be promulgated by the commission "having regard for any factors bearing on the equities involved, consistent with the purposes of this act". If read in isolation, this would give the commission power to fix maximum rents based only on equitable factors and might well be invalid as containing insufficient legislative standards. However, the subdivision was made part of section 4 of the act which also contains, immediately thereafter, subdivision 3 providing that the [***4] commission should fix minimum rents "having regard to the maximum rents for comparable housing accommodations" as well as equitable factors consistent with the purposes of the act. If these subdivisions are read together, there are sufficient legislative standards to guide the commission, and the statutes are entitled to a presumption of validity and to that construction, if available, which will support constitutionality. Accordingly, if the subdivision is read to require the commission to consider maximum rents for comparable housing accommodations and only then to adjust by equitable factors, it is invulnerable to attack. Such construction of the statute has, in fact, been continuously followed by the Rent Commission (State Rent and Eviction Regulations, § 36), whose administrative interpretation of the statute was entitled to the greatest weight.

 

1062 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Schwartz v. Compania Azucarera Vertientes-Camaguey De Cuba


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


12 A.D.2d 506; 207 N.Y.S.2d 288; 1960 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7120



November 14, 1960 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant foreign corporation sought review of the judgment of the Supreme Court, Kings County (New York), which denied its motion for alternative relief from an order appointing respondent receiver in respondent stockholder's action for the appointment of a receiver.


OVERVIEW: The stockholder filed an action for the appointment of a receiver over the foreign corporation's assets that were in the state. The stockholder alleged that the foreign corporation had been nationalized by the Cuban government and had ceased doing business. The court found that the stockholder sought the appointment of a receiver asserting that service of the summons could not be effected with due diligence. The trial court denied the foreign corporation's motion for alternative relief from the trial court's order appointing a receiver finding that the issues presented could only be decided after a trial. On appeal, the court affirmed finding that although the appointment of a receiver was not mandatory, it was not an abuse of discretion for the trial court to appoint a receiver. The court found that there was at least a question of fact as to whether the foreign corporation had ceased doing business. The court found that it was unclear whether the foreign corporation had been conducting business in the state sufficient to subject it to service of process.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

1063 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Finkelstein


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


12 A.D.2d 457; 207 N.Y.S.2d 389; 1960 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7129



November 10, 1960 



DISPOSITION:  [**1] Judgments of conviction unanimously affirmed.

 

1064 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bareika


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


11 A.D.2d 292; 203 N.Y.S.2d 355; 1960 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8395



July 27, 1960 



DISPOSITION: Motion granted and indictment dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion with the court to dismiss the indictment that the People of the State of New York filed against them for allegedly violating N.Y. Penal Law § 580.


OVERVIEW: A town superintendent advertised for bids for the town to buy a snowplow. The town officials agreed that the superintendent should buy the equipment. The indictment concerned three bids for the snowplow. The superintendent of the town when testifying before the grand jury stated that he had requested three bids although the specifications were drafted so that only the exclusive distributor's equipment could qualify for the bid. Defendant, the exclusive distributor of the equipment in the county, asked two of the other defendants, the manufacturer of the equipment and the distributor in an adjacent territory, to submit bids. The State did not present any evidence that the lowest bid was improper or that it failed to meet specifications. The court dismissed the indictment. The court held that it was an error of judgment to submit accommodation bids at the request of the exclusive distributor, but it found no evidence showing a criminal intent on the part of the defendants to deceive public officials.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the indictment.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- conspiracy -- indictment charging conspiracy to obstruct justice or due administration of law dismissed -- conduct of defendant, who was exclusive distributor for equipment desired by town, in securing manufacturer of equipment and distributor in adjacent territory to submit bids along with said defendant's bid, pursuant to request of Superintendent of Highways that three bids be submitted, not evidence of criminal intent or unlawful conspiracy.

Defendants were indicted for conspiracy (Penal Law § 580). The Town Board of the Town of Woodstock adopted a resolution for the standardization of equipment, materials and supplies, pursuant to subdivision 5 of section 103 of the General Municipal Law, and authorized the Superintendent of Highways to advertise for bids for "one Walter four-wheel positive drive snow plow". The Superintendent requested three bids although the specifications were so drafted that Walter equipment alone could qualify. Defendant Bareika was the exclusive distributor [***2] for Walter equipment in the county, and requested defendant Walter Motor Truck Company, manufacturer of the equipment, and defendant Rand-MacMurray, Inc., distributor in an adjacent territory, to submit bids. Admittedly, the two bids, other than that of Bareika, were at the request of and for the accommodation of defendant Bareika but that does not imply there was any criminal rigging or collusion or effort on the part of defendants to conceal what they were doing. Such conduct cannot be considered as evidence of criminal intent by those two bidders to commit unlawful, willful and corrupt acts constituting a conspiracy between them and Bareika. As to Bareika, his intent and purpose was solely to satisfy the requirements of the Town Superintendent. The acts of defendants did not obstruct justice or the due administration of the law -- section 103 of the General Municipal Law. That statute did not require three bids. The indictment should be dismissed.

 

1065 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Blaikie


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


11 A.D.2d 196; 202 N.Y.S.2d 659; 1960 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8650



July 5, 1960 



DISPOSITION: Application pursuant to section 111 of the Finance Law for permission to commence and maintain a taxpayer's action for an injunction against Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., and any other harness racing tracks which may have diverted certain revenues of the State of New York, and the State Harness Racing Commission, denied without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, a taxpayer, filed an application under N.Y. State Fin. Law § 111 for permission to commence and maintain a taxpayer's action for an injunction against respondents, the State Harness Racing Commission, a harness racetrack, and any other harness racing tracks which may have diverted certain revenues of the State of New York.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer made an application for permission to institute and maintain an action, pursuant to the provisions of N.Y. State Fin. Law § 111against the harness racetrack and the State Harness Racing Commission. He sought an order restraining the racetrack from reimbursing itself from the construction account used to make capital improvements to its track, and a declaratory judgment adjudicating as unconstitutional in its entirety that portion of the N.Y. Rac. Pari-Mut. Wag. & Breed Law § 45-a, which authorized harness racing tracks to reimburse themselves for capital improvements. The court held that the taxpayer had no standing to challenge the constitutionality of § 45-a generally, and did not challenge it specifically on constitutional grounds as violative of N.Y. Const. art. V, § 1, so he could not have sued to declare the statute unconstitutional. On his second major contention, that the fund held by the track in its construction account could not have been paid out without the state comptroller's audit, the court ruled that the funds in the construction account were not moneys of the state.


OUTCOME: The court denied the application of the taxpayer, without costs.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law -- construction account -- application, pursuant to section 111 of State Finance Law for permission to commence and maintain taxpayer's action to enjoin race track from reimbursing itself from "construction account" (Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law, § 45-a, subd. 5), for judgment declaring unconstitutional law which authorizes race tracks to reimburse themselves for capital improvements, and for adjudication that funds in construction account constitute moneys and property of State of New York, denied.

 [***2] Subdivision 5 of section 45-a of the Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law (L. 1956, ch. 837) provided for the establishment of a "construction account" by race tracks, with the approval of the State Harness Racing Commission, from which the race tracks would be reimbursed for the expenses of capital improvements. Petitioner applied, pursuant to section 111 of the State Finance Law, for permission to commence and maintain a taxpayer's action for an injunction against Roosevelt Raceway, Inc. and other harness racing tracks and the State Harness Racing Commission. He proposed to seek the following relief: (1) an order restraining Roosevelt from reimbursing itself (without the warrant of the Comptroller of the State of New York) from the construction account; (2) a declaratory judgment adjudicating as unconstitutional in its entirety that portion of the Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law which authorizes harness racing tracks to reimburse themselves for capital improvements, and (3) an adjudication that all sums previously received and paid by Roosevelt to itself and those funds still remaining in its construction account constitute moneys and property of the State of New York. The application is denied.

 

1066 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Roosevelt Raceway, Inc. v. Monaghan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


11 A.D.2d 206; 202 N.Y.S.2d 646; 1960 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8651



July 5, 1960 



DISPOSITION: Order appealed from affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent Harness Racing Commission appealed an order of the Supreme Court of New York County (New York), which granted the application of petitioner raceway for an order pursuant N.Y. R. Civ. Prac. 78 and directed that the raceway's construction account be credited with $ 1,404,664.63, constituting the federal tax paid on sums previously transferred to the raceway's general funds.


OVERVIEW: The Commission contended that section 45-a of the Pari-Mutual Revenue Law, 1956 N.Y. Laws ch. 837, was unconstitutional and violative of N.Y. Const. art. VII, §§ 7, 8. The court disagreed, holding that: (1) § 7 provided that no money could be paid out of the state treasury except in pursuance of an appropriation by law; (2) § 8 provided that state money could not be given or loaned to or in aid of any private corporation or association; (3) the funds in the raceway's construction account were not money of the state nor money under its control; (4) because the moneys the subject matter of the proceeding were not in the state treasury, nor state funds, nor under its management, they did not come within the interdiction of §§ 7 and 8; (5) title to these funds was always in the track; and (6) the capital improvement raceway track was entitled to receive from its construction account a sum of money, net after federal income taxes paid thereon, equal to the cost of the improvements approved by the Commission.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order granting the raceway's application and directing that the raceway's construction account be credited with the amount of federal tax paid on sums previously transferred to the raceway's general funds.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law -- construction account -- funds in construction account of raceway (Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law, § 45-a, subd. 5) are not "money of the State" nor "money under its control" and do not come within prohibitions of constitutional provisions (N. Y. Const., art. VII, §§ 7, 8) -- title to funds is in race track -- application for order directing that construction account be credited with tax paid to United States on sum previously transferred to race track's general funds, properly granted.

1. Funds in the construction account of petitioner (Pari-Mutuel [***2] Revenue Law, § 45-a, subd. 5 [L. 1956, ch. 837]) are not "money of the State" nor "money under its control" (N. Y. Const., art. VII, §§ 7, 8) and they do not come within the prohibitions of those constitutional provisions.

2. Title is always in the race track and is not in "a state of suspension".

3. The law (L. 1956, ch. 837) provides in clear and unmistakable language that a track is entitled to receive from its construction account a sum of money, net after Federal income taxes paid thereon, equal to the cost of the improvements approved by the State Harness Racing Commission. The court at Special Term therefore construed the law correctly in that regard in granting an application for an order directing that petitioner's construction account be credited with the amount constituting the tax paid to the United States on the sum previously transferred to petitioner's general funds and directing future similar Federal income tax payments.

 

1067 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of The Second Additional Grand Jury


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


10 A.D.2d 425; 202 N.Y.S.2d 26; 1960 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10123



May 9, 1960 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, who were all attorneys, sought review of an order from the County Court, Kings County (New York), which adjudged each defendant guilty of criminal contempt of court pursuant to N.Y. Jud. Law § 750, subd. A, para. 5. Defendants had been adjudged guilty for their failure to answer questions before a certain grand jury.


OVERVIEW: The subjects of the grand jury's investigation were whether there had been any unlawful solicitation of legal business in violation of N.Y. Penal Law art. 24 and the existence of a conspiracy to violate that statute. When subpoenaed and sworn before the grand jury, defendants were advised of the purpose and scope of the investigation, and were additionally advised that the grand jury was prepared to issue them immunity permitted by N.Y. Penal Law § 2447. Each defendant refused to answer the propounded questions and was subsequently adjudged guilty of criminal contempt. In affirming, the court noted that defendants were not prospective defendants or targets of the grand jury's investigation. Statutory immunity having been granted them as witnesses, with such immunity being as broad as that guaranteed by N.Y Const. art. I, § 6, defendants were compelled to testify. Furthermore, there was no constitutional deficiency in the application of N.Y. Penal Law § 2447 in the instant case. Therefore, because defendants were compelled to testify on matters relevant to the grand jury's inquiry, their refusal to do so, in the face of being advised of their immunity, constituted contempt.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the county court's order.


HEADNOTES

Witnesses -- immunity and contempt -- two attorneys properly adjudged in contempt for refusal, after immunity, to answer question relevant to Grand Jury inquiry into conspiracies to solicit law business.

1. Two attorneys who had received from a Grand Jury full statutory immunity from prosecution (Penal Law, §§ 584, 2447) and who had been advised that such immunity had been conferred upon them, and who still refused to answer a proper question (Judiciary Law, § 750, subd. A, par. 5) in the Grand Jury's inquiry into unlawful solicitation of legal business (Penal Law, art. 24) and into criminal conspiracies among attorneys and others to violate said article (Penal Law, art. 54), were properly adjudged in criminal contempt.

2. Though possibly conspirators with others, the immune witnesses themselves cannot be said to [***2] be prospective defendants (N. Y. Const., art. I, § 6).

3. Whether or not immunity can be conferred (under Penal Law, § 2447) against prosecution for unlawful solicitation of legal business (Penal Law, art. 24) is an academic question at this time; at this time the witnesses have refused to answer a question which is relevant to the inquiry into conspiracy (Penal Law, art. 54, § 584) to violate article 24 of the Penal Law. So long as questions put to witnesses are relevant to inquiry into criminal conspiracy, immunity has been conferred, and the witnesses have been so advised, and they must answer.

 

1068 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wilson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


10 A.D.2d 297; 200 N.Y.S.2d 792; 1960 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10576



April 18, 1960 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously affirmed. No separate appeal lies from the intermediate orders, which have been reviewed on the appeal from the judgment of conviction.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the County Court, Queens County (New York), which convicted him of attempted robbery in the third degree.


OVERVIEW: The court reversed a judgment rendered by the trial court, which convicted defendant, and dismissed the indictment. Defendant was again indicted, and his motion to dismiss the indictment on the ground that he had been denied his constitutional right to a speedy trial was denied. He was again convicted. The court determined that an accused could be prosecuted for a felony even though an indictment may have been dismissed for want of, or delay in, prosecution. The court explained that the right to a dismissal, if an indictment was not promptly found, and the right to a speedy trial after indictment, were provided by statute, so they were only guaranteed to defendants against whom criminal prosecutions were pending and did not restrict the right of the State to commence criminal prosecutions within the time limited by law. The court noted that defendant's reindictment and subsequent prosecution were expressly authorized by law and there was nothing unconstitutional in the statutes, which authorized them. The court concluded that the U.S. Const. amend. VI right to a speedy trial applied to the United States courts alone and did not restrict the powers of the State governments.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- right to speedy trial -- section 673 of Code of Criminal Procedure, which provides that dismissal of prior action because of denial of right to speedy trial is not bar to another prosecution for same offense, if offense charged is felony, not unconstitutional.

Section 673 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, which provides that dismissal of a prior action because of the denial of the right to a speedy trial is not a bar to another prosecution for the same offense, if the offense charged is a felony, is not unconstitutional. Accordingly, defendant, whose prior conviction upon his plea of guilty of attempted robbery in the third degree was reversed and his indictment dismissed because he had been denied his right of a speedy trial, was properly convicted,  [***2] upon his plea of guilty, of attempted robbery in the third degree upon a subsequent indictment.

 

1069 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Namro Holding Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


10 A.D.2d 702; 198 N.Y.S.2d 56; 1960 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10883



March 29, 1960 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment of conviction affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Court of Special Sessions (New York), convicting him of knowingly failing and neglecting to comply with a notice of violation for failure to properly maintain horizontal exits on various floors in a building under his control.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of knowingly failing and neglecting to comply with a notice of violation for failure to properly maintain horizontal exits on various floors in a building under his control. Defendant appealed, arguing that the notice of violation was improperly vague. The court ruled that the propriety of a notice of violation could not be collaterally reviewed in the criminal prosecution for its disobedience. The court affirmed the judgment convicting defendant, concluding that vagueness of the regulation upon which the notice of violation depended and the difficulty of finding it in the statutory labyrinth became immaterial when defendant disobeyed its directions and did not follow the proper procedure by appeal to test its efficacy.


OUTCOME: The judgment convicting defendant was affirmed.

 

1070 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Betty-June School, Inc. v. Young


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


10 A.D.2d 648; 197 N.Y.S.2d 760; 1960 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11580



February 29, 1960 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants schools incorporated under N.Y. Educ. Law §§ 216, 217 challenged an order of the trial court (New York), which only granted a partial temporary restraining order against appellees, the manager of a town's building department and others in their action to declare unconstitutional Hempstead, N.Y., Building Code art. 19 and Hempstead, N.Y., Building Zone Ordinance art. 16.


OVERVIEW: The schools filed an action seeking a declaratory judgment that Hempstead, N.Y., Building Code art. 19 and Hempstead, N.Y., Building Zone Ordinance art. 16 were unconstitutional. The trial court granted the schools' motion only as to certain provisions of Hempstead, N.Y., Building Code art. 19, involving provisions requiring the erection of a six-foot fence along certain boundaries of school premises and prohibiting the use of basements for classrooms unless certain conditions were met. The trial court denied a request for a temporary injunction as to the requirement that an annually renewable permit had to be obtained in order to lawfully operate any premises for a "private school" and that such premises were subject to setback restrictions and restrictions limiting the number of students proportionately to square feet of "classroom area" and "cleared outdoor activity area." The court held that there were serious questions regarding the constitutionality of the municipal legislation and the interpretation given them. Possible discrimination between public and private schools was involved so it was advisable to preserve the status quo pending determination of the issues at trial.


OUTCOME: The court modified the trial court's decision and granted a temporary injunction on all issues.

 

1071 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Tarrant v. Roslyn


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


10 A.D.2d 37; 197 N.Y.S.2d 317; 1960 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11630



February 23, 1960 



DISPOSITION: Judgment insofar as appealed from unanimously affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant village challenged an order of the Supreme Court in Nassau County (New York), upon a decision of the court at Special Term, which entered judgment in favor of appellee owners and declared that certain real property could be used for apartment house purposes.


OVERVIEW: The Village Board of Appeals granted the owners' application for a variance so as to extend the apartment district use to the portion of their property situated in the residence "B" district. Later the Building inspector rejected the application for a building permit, claiming that the villages' amendment rendered the variance invalid. The special term held that the village failed to file a timely appeal. The court affirmed, finding that (1) the Board had jurisdiction to grant the variance, its determination was reviewable by a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, the village failed to appeal, and the time to appeal had long since passed; (2) there was ample proof in the record to sustain the determination of the special term that the rezoned property was unfit for one-family residential use; and (3) the owners' proof of that fact met their burden of showing that the amendment, as it pertained to their property, was so unreasonable and arbitrary as to constitute an invasion of property rights contrary to constitutional due process and, as such, was invalid, illegal, and void.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- variance -- since action of Village Board of Appeals granting variance to extend apartment district use to portion of respondents' property situated in residence district was not reviewed within time and in manner prescribed by section 179-b of Village Law, village and officers thereof barred from asserting that determination of board was invalid -- property unfit for one-family residential use and to place it in residence district would constitute unconstitutional invasion of property rights.

1. The Village Board of Appeals, on application of respondents, granted a variance to extend an apartment district use to a portion of respondents' property situated in a residence "B" district. The court at Special Term properly determined that, since the action of the Board [***2] of Appeals had not been reviewed within the time and in the manner prescribed by section 179-b of the Village Law, appellants, consisting of the village and officers thereof, could not assert for the first time in the present action that the determination of the Board of Appeals was invalid. It must be conclusively presumed in this action that the board acted according to law.

2. The evidence sustains the determination of the court at Special Term that the property rezoned for apartment house use was unfit for one-family residential use.

3. When that fact was established the burden was met of showing that a subsequent amendment placing that area in a residence "B" district constituted an invasion of property rights contrary to constitutional due process.

 

1072 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Coates


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


8 A.D.2d 444; 188 N.Y.S.2d 400; 1959 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7608



July 9, 1959 



DISPOSITION: Order [entered Sept. 11, 1957] reversed, with $ 10 costs and disbursements and application granted, with $ 10 costs.

Order [entered March 28, 1958] affirmed, without costs of this appeal to either party.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner patient sought review of an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which denied her application for a jury trial and dismissed the proceeding. She sought review of an order by the Court of Appeals, which affirmed the trial court's dismissal of her motion for an order declaring N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law §§ 74 and 76 unconstitutional. Respondent attorney general filed a motion to dismiss the appeals.


OVERVIEW: The hospital filed a certificate about 16 days after the commitment order was made. Approximately 60 days after the order was made, the patient sought a jury trial. The trial court held that the period of 30 days provided in N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 76 had run. The patient appealed the trial court's order denying her motion to vacate the commitment order. The court of appeals dismissed. The hospital was entitled to the full period of 60 days to observe and treat the patient. The court held that the period of 30 days within which a judicial review may be sought did not commence until the expiration of the 60 days from the date of the making of the commitment order. The application for a jury trial as to the issue of mental illness was timely because it was commenced within the period of 90 days after the making of the commitment order. The court held that the patient's request for a jury trial should have been granted. The court held that the constitutionality challenge to N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law §§ 74 and 76 was properly denied. Although the patient was discharged from custody, the court denied the motion to dismiss the appeals because the patient was denied her right to a jury trial.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's order denying the patient's application for a jury trial and awarded costs to the patient.
