The court affirmed the court of appeal's order certifying the patient to the state hospital and denying her motion. The court denied the attorney general's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Insane and other incompetent persons -- jury trial of insanity -- time limitation -- Mental Hygiene Law ( § 74, subd. 7; § 76) provides that, where alleged mentally ill person has been certified to and confined in mental institution, certificate  [***2] may be filed within 60 days from date of commitment order whereupon order shall become final, and that review may be had within 30 days after making of order -- certificate filed 16 days after making of order but no notice of such filing was given -- application for hearing and jury trial timely made, in absence of notice, where made approximately 60 days after order -- under circumstances, 30-day period does not commence to run until expiration of 60 days from date of making of commitment order -- issues presented such as to require decision although moot or academic.

1. Section 74 of the Mental Hygiene Law provides that an alleged mentally ill person may be certified to and confined in an institution upon an order made by certain named judicial officers upon a certificate of two examining physicians, accompanied by a petition therefor. In the absence of a preliminary hearing, the judge, upon finding that the person requires care and treatment, may order his commitment for a period not exceeding 60 days for the purpose of observation and treatment. Subdivision 7 of section 74 authorizes certain named officials of the institution, upon a finding that continued care and treatment [***3] is required, to file a certificate to that effect in the office of the County Clerk at any time prior to the expiration of 60 days from the date of the commitment order and, upon the filing of such certificate, the order shall become final. Section 76 of the Mental Hygiene Law provides that a rehearing and review of the proceedings may be had "within thirty days after the making of such order". On April 17, 1957 petitioner was committed to the Rochester State Hospital by an order of a County Judge. Sixteen days after the order was made, the certificate was filed but no notice of such filing was given. Approximately 60 days after the order was made, petitioner sought a rehearing and jury trial as provided in section 76 of the Mental Hygiene Law. The application was timely.

2. It is not necessary to hold in this case that the hospital must give notice of the determination that the temporary confinement of an alleged mentally ill person has become final. It is sufficient to hold that, in the absence of such notice, the period of 30 days within which a judicial review may be sought does not commence to run until the expiration of 60 days from the date of the making of the commitment [***4] order. The application herein for a jury trial as to the issue of mental illness was timely inasmuch as it was commenced within the period of 90 days after the making of the commitment order, and the request for a jury trial should have been granted.

3. The right to a jury trial to decide the question of insanity is a constitutional right.

4. Petitioner is entitled to the remedy in the present action even though the remedy of habeas corpus is available to one in custody (Mental Hygiene Law, § 204).

5. It is alleged in the moving papers that petitioner was discharged from custody on May 21, 1958. An appellate court usually declines to decide questions which have become moot or academic but the courts will entertain moot or academic questions where the question is of major importance and will arise again and again and invites immediate decision. The issues presented in these appeals are such as to require decision.

 

1073 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Niagara Mohawk Power Corp. v. Fulton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


8 A.D.2d 523; 188 N.Y.S.2d 717; 1959 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7616



July 9, 1959 



DISPOSITION: Order insofar as appealed from reversed, without costs of this appeal to any party and matter remitted to the Oswego Special Term for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Intervenor neighbors challenged the Supreme Court at Special Term in Oswego County (New York) order directing respondents, city and zoning board, to issue a building permit to petitioner substation owner for construction of a substation. The neighbors asserted that there was insufficient evidence that it was reasonably necessary to build the substation at the chosen site.


OVERVIEW: The substation owner initiated a proceeding under art. 78 of the New York Civil Practice Act seeking a zoning variance and an order to compel respondents to issue a permit for construction of a substation at a proposed site. The neighbors of the proposed site intervened. The trial court upheld the zoning board's denial of the variance, but granted an order in the nature of mandamus directing respondents to issue a building permit. This was done without any hearing on the permit issue, but based on the testimony before the board in the variance proceeding. The neighbors appealed the issuance of the permit, asserting there was insufficient evidence to support it. The court reversed, ruling that while the proof before the board was sufficient to establish the necessity for the substation to be built, it was not adequate to show necessity for its construction at the specific site selected. Proof that the chosen site was "ideal" was not enough. There was no evidence that any consideration had been given to the availability of other sites and to their relative degree of detriment to neighboring properties compared to their advantages from the standpoints of safety and efficiency.


OUTCOME: The court reversed, with costs, the order directing respondents to issue a building permit to the substation owner, and remitted for further proceedings to determine the reasonable necessity for the site selected.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- permit to build electrical substation -- improper to grant order in nature of mandamus directing issuance of permit to build electrical substation without regard to provisions of zoning ordinance, without hearing and on basis of evidence given at hearing before Board of Zoning Appeals in proceeding for variance -- evidence not properly before court in mandamus proceeding -- moreover, evidence in variance proceeding not sufficient to warrant granting of order sought by petitioner.

1. The petitioner brought an article 78 proceeding to annul the denial by the Board of Zoning Appeals of the City of Fulton of an application for a variance to enable it to build an electrical substation in a residential [***2] district or, in the alternative, for an order directing the city to issue a permit authorizing petitioner to build the substation without regard to the provisions of the zoning ordinance. The court at Special Term confirmed the determination of the Zoning Board of Appeals denying the variance but granted an order in the nature of mandamus directing the issuance of a building permit without holding any hearing but upon the basis of testimony given at the hearing before the board in the variance proceeding. The evidence before the board in the variance proceeding was not properly before the court in connection with the proceeding in the nature of mandamus. The court should have required petitioner to present proof before the court in support of its contention, and should have given intervenors an opportunity to cross-examine the witnesses for the petitioner and to offer countervailing proof.

2. Upon a proper factual demonstration of public necessity, petitioner would be entitled to a declaration that the ordinance was void insofar as it prevented petitioner from erecting a structure which was reasonably necessary to enable it to perform its public duties under the statutes.

3. Even [***3] if it could be said that the intervenors had impliedly agreed to have the mandamus aspect of the proceeding decided upon the basis of the evidence produced in the variance proceeding, the evidence was not sufficient to warrant the granting of the relief sought by petitioner. The proof was not sufficient to demonstrate that it was necessary for petitioner to build its substation upon the particular site which it had selected. No proof was offered by petitioner of the unavailability of other sites which might cause less disruption of the community zoning plan or less detriment to neighboring property.

 

1074 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York Automatic Canteen Corp. v. Joseph


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


8 A.D.2d 385; 188 N.Y.S.2d 119; 1959 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7774



June 25, 1959 



DISPOSITION: Determination confirmed and the proceeding dismissed, with $ 20 costs and disbursements to the respondent.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer sought a refund for city sales taxes paid. Respondent, Comptroller of the City of New York (comptroller), denied the claim for a refund and the New York Supreme Court at Special Term, New York County, affirmed the comptroller's judgment. The taxpayer appealed.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer operated vending machines and did not collect sales taxes on its sales. The taxpayer argued that New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § N41, precluded the imposition of responsibility for taxes it could not collect, and equated its liability with the purchaser's obligation to pay the tax levied. The court disagreed, holding that the vendor was under a duty to pay the tax whether collected from the purchaser or not. The court held that it would have been a distortion of the purpose of the below minimum provision of the tax law to conclude that it eliminated the payment of all sales taxes by the vendor, not collected from vendees. Because the comptroller was given the power to permit the vendor to waive the collection of the tax from purchasers on below minimum sales, and thus absorb it, it did not follow that included was the power to grant complete exemption to a vendor from liability for the tax. The comptroller's regulation enacted under § N41, was in all respects, reasonable and valid, especially since any attempt to collect a tax of less than one penny on individual sales presented manifold problems.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the comptroller's decision.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- sales tax -- failure to collect sales tax -- petitioner, engaged in selling merchandise through automatic vending machines for 1 cent or 5 cents, did not charge or collect sales taxes -- regulation of Comptroller of City of New York required collection of tax on purchases of 17 cents or more but required every vendor to pay total tax due, including tax on sales below 17 cents -- petitioner not entitled to refund of sales taxes paid on such sales -- tax not discriminatory -- petitioner not deprived of equal protection of law -- regulation reasonable and valid -- vendor must pay tax whether collected from purchaser or not.

1. Petitioner [***2] was engaged in the business of selling candy, gum, crackers and nuts, at retail, through automatic vending machines for either 1 cent or 5 cents. Petitioner did not charge or collect sales taxes on the merchandise. Pursuant to authority granted by statute (Administrative Code of City of New York, § N41-3.0), the Comptroller of the City of New York adopted a regulation requiring the collection of 1 cent for purchases of 17 cents to 66 cents, and 2 cents on purchases from 67 cents to $ 1.16, but also providing that no vendor was exempt from the payment of the tax on sales of 16 cents or less, that every vendor must pay the total tax due and in no event might the tax be less than 2% of the amount of the vendor's taxable sales, including sales of 16 cents or less (cf. Administrative Code of City of New York, § N41, as amd. by Local Laws, 1946, No. 17). Petitioner is not entitled to a refund of the taxes paid.

2. The tax applies equally to all vendors and is not discriminatory.

3. The fact that other vendors, who make sales above as well as below minimum, are more easily able to pass the tax on to their vendees does not deprive petitioner of the equal protection of the law.

4. The [***3] vendor must pay the tax whether it is collected from the purchaser or not. The power given the Comptroller to permit the vendor to waive the collection of the tax from purchasers on below minimum sales does not include the power to grant complete exemption to a vendor from liability for the tax.

5. The regulation is in all respects reasonable and valid.

 

1075 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Scarpati v. Feriola


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


8 A.D.2d 111; 186 N.Y.S.2d 927; 1959 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8532



May 18, 1959 



DISPOSITION: Proceeding dismissed, with $ 50 costs and disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowners sought review of a determination of respondent Zoning Board of Appeals of the City of Yonkers (New York) confirming renewal of a building permit.


OVERVIEW: The building permit was issued permitting a building in contravention of a subsequent zoning ordinance. The board confirmed the renewal of the permit after the landowners had enjoined the building for a time. The final judicial determination in the landowners' previous action found that the building permit had been legally issued and that construction had commenced within the time limited by the zoning ordinance. The permit had expired before the building was completed in part due to the landowners' action. The board held that the permit was properly renewed. Dismissing the proceeding, the court held that the board had the power to vary the provisions of the zoning ordinance by granting an extension of time within which to complete the construction and that its power was properly exercised. The court further found that any other result would have been inequitable and unjust because the building had been completed and completely occupied as a cooperative apartment house while the action was pending.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the landowners' action to review the board's determination confirming renewal of a building permit.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- building permits -- extension of time -- Zoning Board of Appeals of City of Yonkers properly upheld action of Superintendent of Buildings in indorsing renewal on original permit to build apartment house -- no necessity for renewal since permit did not expire by limitation contained in building code -- board had power to vary provisions of zoning ordinance by granting extension of time under ordinance and under General City Law ( § 81, subd. 4) -- owners demonstrated practical difficulties and unnecessary hardship in carrying out conditions imposed by ordinance in that time limitations were not complied with because of litigation instituted and carried  [***2] on by four of present petitioners -- insofar as Matter of Glass v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals of City of Yonkers (5 A D 2d 991) denied petition to extend time limits, it is overruled -- requirements where use ordinance involved not applicable to time variance.

1. On July 6, 1953 the owners of a parcel of land in the City of Yonkers filed plans for the erection of an apartment building. The zoning ordinance then in effect placed this property in an "A-2" district, wherein high density apartment houses were a permitted use. A new zoning ordinance, effective November 15, 1953, changed the district in which the property is located to "MG", wherein the proposed use is not permissible. However, the new ordinance provided that nothing contained therein should require any change in the plans, construction or designated use of a building for which the completed plans had theretofore been filed, if (a) construction was commenced within 210 days of the date of the permit, (b) the ground-story framework, including the second tier of beams, was completed within one year of the date of the permit, and (c) the entire building was completed within two years from the date of permit. On November [***3] 30, 1953 a permit for the erection of the building was issued by the Superintendent of Buildings of the City of Yonkers. In April, 1954 construction was begun. On June 7, 1954 four of the present petitioners and others, owners of nearby property, instituted an action against the City of Yonkers and others to restrain construction on the grounds that (a) construction contravened the applicable provisions of the 1953 zoning ordinance, and (b) 1954 amendments extending the time for commencement of construction were unconstitutional. A judgment enjoining further construction of the building was reversed by the Appellate Division and that reversal was affirmed by the Court of Appeals on June 14, 1957. ( Seltzer v. City of Yonkers, 1 N Y 2d 782.) On September 12, 1957 the time to make application to the United States Supreme Court for review expired. Accordingly, a final judicial determination had been made that the building permit of November 30, 1953 was legally issued and that construction thereunder was legally commenced within the time limited by the zoning ordinance. On October 17, 1957 the Superintendent of Buildings indorsed on the original permit a renewal thereof.  [***4] Petitioners appealed to the Zoning Board of Appeals of the City of Yonkers from this decision and the board held that the action of the Superintendent was proper. The present proceeding to annul the determination of the board should be dismissed.

2. The Building Code of the City of Yonkers provides that a building permit expires by limitation if no work is commenced thereunder within one year from the time of issuance. Here construction was commenced in April, 1954, which was within one year from the time of issuance of the permit on November 30, 1953. Therefore, the permit did not expire by reason of the limitation contained in the building code and there was no necessity for its renewal.

3. Assuming that, as petitioners argue, there was no necessity for renewal, the proceeding should be dismissed because petitioners' appeal to the board fails. There was nothing from which they could appeal. Assuming, on the other hand, that the renewal amounted to no more than a determination that the original permit had not expired, the proceeding should be dismissed because concededly the renewal on that ground would be proper. If, again, the original permit had expired by reason of the [***5] limitation contained in the zoning ordinance and there is no power to vary those time limitations, this proceeding must be dismissed because the question may not be determined by the Superintendent nor by the board nor by the court in an article 78 proceeding.

4. However, the proceeding should be dismissed because the board had the power to vary the provisions of the zoning ordinance by granting an extension of time within which to complete the construction and its power was properly exercised under the circumstances here disclosed. Subdivision 4 of section 81 of the General City Law grants a board of appeals power, in passing on appeals, to vary or modify the application of any of the regulations or provisions of a zoning ordinance relating to the construction of buildings where there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardship in the way of carrying out the strict letter of any such ordinance. The board had the power to modify not only under that statute but also under the ordinance in question.

5. The owners demonstrated practical difficulties and unnecessary hardship in the way of carrying out the time conditions imposed by the ordinance. The time limitations were not [***6] complied with solely because of the prior litigation instituted by four of the present petitioners and by petitioners' appeal to the board here under review.

6. Insofar as Matter of Glass v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals of City of Yonkers (5 A D 2d 991) held that there was no power to extend the time limits contained in the zoning ordinance, it is overruled.

7. It has been held that requirements where a use variance is involved do not apply to an area variance ( Matter of Village of Bronxville v. Francis, 1 A D 2d 236, affd. 1 N Y 2d 839). Neither do these requirements apply to a time variance.

8. To fail to dismiss the petition under the circumstances of this case would be harsh, inequitable and unjust.

 

1076 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Exempt Firemen's Asso. v. New Rochelle


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, SECOND DEPARTMENT


8 A.D.2d 634; 185 N.Y.S.2d 903; 1959 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8942



April 27, 1959 - Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city firemen's association filed an action against respondents, a city and a representative of paid firemen, to recover tax moneys for a certain year which were paid to the city treasurer, instead of to the association. A trial court (New York), denied the association's motion for summary judgment, granted respondents' motion for summary judgment, and dismissed the action. The association appealed.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to 1903 N.Y. Laws 485, § 6, the association was entitled to receive payment of tax moneys collected on the business of foreign fire insurance companies doing business within the city. By 1910 N.Y. Laws 559, which enacted a new charter for the city, 1903 N.Y. Laws 485, § 6 was repealed. Despite the 1910 repeal, the tax moneys were paid to the association until 1957, when the taxes were paid to the city for the first time. The association filed an action seeking, among other things, to recover the tax moneys for 1957. The trial court granted summary judgment for respondents dismissing the action. The court reversed the judgment and granted summary judgment for the association. The title of the 1910 act expressed as its only purpose the enactment of the new charter, whereas the substance of the act embraced not only the new charter, but also repealed 1903 N.Y. Laws 485, § 6. Thus, the 1910 act violated N.Y. Const. art. III, § 15 because it embraced more than one subject and the second subject was not expressed in the title. Hence, the 1910 act was unconstitutional insofar as it attempted to repeal the association's right to receive the tax moneys.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment and granted the association's motion for summary judgment.

 

1077 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Steuding


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


7 A.D.2d 566; 185 N.Y.S.2d 34; 1959 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8962



April 23, 1959 



DISPOSITION: Motion granted and indictment dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss an indictment against him.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted by a grand jury for conspiring to bribe public officers. He filed a motion to dismiss the indictment on the ground that he obtained immunity when he appeared before the grand jury under the compulsion of a subpoena, refused to sign a waiver of immunity, and was then examined concerning the matters for which he was thereafter indicted. The court noted that some of the testimony defendant gave furnished at least a link in the chain of evidence supporting the indictment. Defendant claimed no privilege and made no effort to comply with N.Y. Penal Law § 2447 by asserting any privilege against self incrimination. The court noted that as a result of § 2447, a prospective defendant was not left free and untrammeled to rely on the protection afforded him by the Constitution. He was required to assert the privilege, which should not have been required from a prospective defendant. Section 2447 was unconstitutional insofar as it provided immunity could only be conferred by complying with its provisions.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion and dismissed the indictment.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- immunity -- section 2447 of Penal Law provides that immunity shall not be conferred except in accord with its provisions and that, if immunity is to be obtained, prospective defendant must first assert his privilege and if he is directed to answer by competent authority be obtains immunity for any incriminating testimony -- statute is unconstitutional insofar as it provides that compliance with its provisions is only manner in which immunity may be conferred -- indictment dismissed against defendant who refused to sign waiver of immunity before Grand Jury and was examined concerning matters for which he was thereafter indicted.

Defendant was indicted for the crime of conspiring to bribe public officers in violation of section 378 of the Penal Law and of giving an officer bribes in violation of section 1822 of the Penal Law. He appeared before the Grand Jury pursuant to a subpoena, refused to sign a waiver of immunity, and was then examined concerning the matters for which he was thereafter indicted. Section 2447 of the Penal Law provides [***2] that immunity shall not be conferred except in accordance with the provisions of that statute. It provides that, if immunity is to be obtained, a prospective defendant must first assert his privilege and, if he is directed to answer by a competent authority, he obtains immunity for any incriminating testimony he may give. Defendant claimed no privilege so far as the evidence here concerned is involved and made no effort to comply with section 2447 by asserting any privilege against self incrimination. The constitutional prohibition merely prohibits compelling any person to be a witness against himself. It is beyond the power of the Legislature to impair this constitutional restraint in any degree. As a result of the statutory provision, a prospective defendant is not left free to rely on the protection afforded him by the Constitution. He is required to assert a privilege. The indictment should be dismissed on the ground that defendant obtained immunity and that section 2447 of the Penal Law is unconstitutional insofar as it provides that compliance with its provisions is the only manner in which immunity may be conferred.

 

1078 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


L. C. L. Corp. v. State Tax Com.


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


8 A.D.2d 658; 184 N.Y.S.2d 940; 1959 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9030



April 23, 1959 - Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner corporation appealed a final determination of the New York Tax Commission, which sustained franchise taxes assessed against the corporation.


OVERVIEW: Franchise taxes were assessed against the corporation, a Delaware corporation. Its principal and only office and place of business was in New York City. The corporation conceded that it came squarely within the language of N.Y. Tax Law § 210, but inasmuch as it asserted that a substantial portion of its income was derived from outside the state, it claimed the quoted portion of the statute was unconstitutional in its application to the corporation. So far as it appeared from the record, the corporation was engaged in New York in the business of leasing shipping containers and derived its income therefrom. There was no multiple taxation present and no present conceivable risk of multiple taxation.


OUTCOME: The determination was confirmed.

 

1079 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Tenny v. Sainsbury


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


7 A.D.2d 514; 184 N.Y.S.2d 185; 1959 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9264



April 8, 1959 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with $ 10 costs and disbursements and relief granted in accordance with the opinion, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner milk dealer appealed the order of the Supreme Court in Ontario County (New York), which dismissed the dealer's request that respondent city health officer be required to issue a permit to the dealer. In the alternative, the dealer requested that the health officer perform her duties under the N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 258-j and the New York State Sanitary Code.


OVERVIEW: Canandaigua, N.Y., Bd. Health & Pub. Safety, Res. (Sept. 18, 1929) required that all pasteurized milk offered for sale in the city be pasteurized in the city. The dealer's milk was pasteurized outside of the city. The lower court dismissed the dealer's petition that sought to require the city to issue the dealer a permit to sell milk and the other relief sought by the dealer, and the court reversed. The court held that N.Y. State Sanit. Code ch. III, reg. 4 prohibited supplementary regulations by municipalities pertaining to milk processing and handling. The court further ruled that the city's resolution was unreasonable, discriminatory, and unconstitutional because the state strictly inspected milk plants, and there was no health justification requiring that the pasteurization of the milk occur within the city. Thus, the dealer was entitled to have his request for a milk permit processed.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower court's order and remitted the matter to the city health officer to process the dealer's request for a permit and to disregard the city's resolution dealing with the pasteurization of milk.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- milk control -- resolution of Board of Health and Public Safety of City of Canandaigua that "all pasteurized milk offered for sale in the city of Canandaigua, must be pasteurized in the city of Canandaigua" is in violation of State Sanitary Code and invalid -- State has pre-empted field -- prohibition against local regulation not merely prospective -- even if local authorities still had power to adopt supplementary  [***2] regulations relating to milk plants, this regulation would be unreasonable exercise of power.

1. The Board of Health and Public Safety of the City of Canandaigua on September 18, 1929, adopted a resolution reading as follows: "Resolved, that commencing at the present date, all pasteurized milk offered for sale in the city of Canandaigua, must be pasteurized in the city of Canandaigua". Respondent, Health Officer of the City of Canandaigua, refused to issue a permit to petitioner to sell milk in Canandaigua which had been pasteurized outside of Canandaigua. An order of the court at Special Term dismissing the petition for an order directing that a permit be issued is reversed and the matter is remitted to respondent Health Officer of the City of Canandaigua with directions to take such proceedings as she may be authorized or required to take under the Agriculture and Markets Law and the Sanitary Code in passing upon the petitioner's application, disregarding, however, the provisions of the 1929 resolution of the Board of Health and Public Safety of the City of Canandaigua ( Lang's Creamery v. City of Niagara Falls, 224 App. Div. 483, 251 N. Y. 343, distinguished).

2.  [***3] The 1929 resolution of the City of Canandaigua is in direct violation of the State Sanitary Code in undertaking to regulate the location of milk processing plants. The State has effectively pre-empted the field.

3. The amendments to the Sanitary Code prohibiting this type of local regulation are not merely prospective in operation.

4. Even if the local authorities still had the power under the Sanitary Code to adopt supplementary regulations relating to milk plants, the adoption of the regulation here in controversy would be an unreasonable exercise of the power. The reasoning of Lang's Creamery v. City of Niagara Falls (224 App. Div. 483, 251 N. Y. 343) is no longer controlling. In view of the provisions under which all milk plants in the State are now subjected to inspection and the licensing by appropriate health authorities, it is arbitrary and unreasonable and bears no substantial relation to the protection of public health, safety or welfare, for the local authorities of a particular municipality to insist that no milk be sold therein unless it is processed in a plant located within the municipality.

 

1080 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Oswego Transp. Lines, Inc. v. Feinberg


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


7 A.D.2d 268; 181 N.Y.S.2d 1007; 1959 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9979



February 5, 1959 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with $ 50 costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner transferee sought review from an order of the Supreme Court of Albany County (New York), which confirmed orders of respondent commission and dismissed a petition to review, correct or modify said orders in an action regarding a condition imposed by the commission on the transferee's ability to engage in interstate commerce.


OVERVIEW: A holder of a certificate of convenience and necessity desired to transfer the certificate to the transferee. The commission imposed a condition upon its approval of the transfer for a motor freight route entirely within the State of New York. The condition imposed, in effect, was that the transferee as the new holder of the certificate of convenience and necessity would not engage under the authority of that certificate in interstate commerce within the state. The commission sought to prevent the transferor from making two transportation operations open up where one existed before unless there was a further consideration of the basic questions of convenience and necessity. A supreme court confirmed the order of the commission, and the transferee appealed. The court affirmed because it was not demonstrated that the commission's decision was either arbitrary or unreasonable. The court ruled that in undertaking to exercise its constitutional power over interstate commerce in this field Congress delegated to the commission jurisdiction to pass on the certification of convenience and necessity for the motor transportation of goods in interstate commerce entirely within New York.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order.


HEADNOTES

Public utilities -- Public Service Commission -- powers of commission -- petitioner's transferor held Interstate Commerce Commission certificate for interstate operation entirely within New York and also Public Service Commission certificate for operation within New York -- Insterstate Commerce Commission conditioned approval of transfer of Interstate Commerce Commission certification upon agreement of transferor not to conduct operations in interstate commerce by virtue of Public Service Commission certificate -- in approving transfer of Public Service Commission certificate commission had power to impose condition that transferee shall not engage under authority of that certificate in interstate commerce within New York -- Congress delegated to New York Public Service Commission jurisdiction to pass on certification of convenience and necessity for transportation  [***2] of goods in insterstate commerce entirely within New York (Motor Carrier Act, § 206, subd. [a]; U. S. Code, tit. 49, § 306, subd. [a]).

1. The predecessor of petitioner's transferor had obtained an Interstate Commerce Commission certificate of convenience and necessity for a route within the State of New York in 1935, when such certificate first was needed because of the Congressional enactment that year of the Motor Carrier Act. The certificate was issued by the Interstate Commerce Commission for an interstate operation entirely within New York rather than by the Public Service Commission because New York had not yet established any authority over this kind of operation within the State. In 1938 article 3-B of the Public Service Law was enacted, and the Public Service Commission issued a certificate for the route in 1938 after the enactment of the New York statute, but the 1935 Interstate Commerce Commission certificate continued in effect and the operator had possession of two official papers based on convenience and necessity for the same route. After the enactment of the 1938 statute, the Public Service Commission certificate would have contemplated both interstate [***3] and intrastate operation. In 1948 both certificates were transferred to petitioner's transferor. He sold the two certificates to different parties. The Interstate Commerce Commission conditioned its approval of the transfer of the Federal certificate by providing that the transferor should not conduct operations in interstate commerce "by virtue of the possession of any intrastate certificate now held by him". Nevertheless, he contracted to sell the Public Service Commission certificate to petitioner. In approving the transfer, the Public Service Commission had the power to impose a condition that petitioner shall not engage, under the authority of that certificate, in interstate commerce within New York. The effect is that the certificates cannot be used to create two operations in interstate commerce by the device of separate transfers where there has been a single operation authorized and contemplated by both public agencies.

2. Congress has delegated to the New York Public Service Commission jurisdiction to pass on the certification of convenience and necessity for the motor transportation of goods in interstate commerce entirely within New York (Motor Carrier Act, § 206,  [***4] subd. [a]; U. S. Code, tit. 49, § 306, subd. [a]). The Public Service Commission has the power to consider the consequences to interstate commerce of its certificates of convenience and necessity.

 

1081 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Baker v. Niagara Mohawk Power Corp.


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


7 A.D.2d 788; 180 N.Y.S.2d 850; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3710



December 30, 1958 - Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employer sought review of a determination by respondent Workers' Compensation Board (New York), which awarded death benefits to respondent widow and children.


OVERVIEW: The decedent fell several stories while he was at his employment and the employer argued that it had overcome by substantial evidence the presumption against suicide that was created by N.Y. Work. Comp. Law § 21. The employer also questioned the Board's review of the case on its own motion and setting aside the decisions of the referee and the board panel. On review the court found no reversible error. There was a water cooler next to the railing and there was testimony to the effect that employees occasionally sat on the railing. Medical opinion was divided as to whether decedent committed suicide. The rationale of the Board's decision was that nothing in the record contradicted the possibility that the decedent leaned over the railing, or sat on it, and accidentally fell to his death. Moreover, there was no evidence of a strong motive for suicide, and any inference to be drawn from a possible recurrence of the decedent's mental illness was negated by the fact that his fellow employees failed to notice anything unusual in his behavior.


OUTCOME: The court unanimously affirmed the Board's award.

 

1082 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Commission of Investigation by Lane v. Lombardozzi


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


7 A.D.2d 48; 180 N.Y.S.2d 496; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3911



December 9, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Orders unanimously affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant witnesses sought review of two orders of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which granted applications by respondent investigative commission (commission) for warrants which committed each witness to jail for their refusal to answer certain questions at hearings that were conducted by the commission.


OVERVIEW: The commission subpoenaed the witnesses and commanded them to appear at a public hearing. The commission conferred immunity from prosecution by state authorities upon each witness in accordance with N.Y. Penal Law § 2447. The witnesses refused to answer the questions. Upon the application of the commission, the witnesses were jailed for their refusal to respond to the questions. The witnesses appealed. Upon review, the court affirmed the orders, holding that immunity was properly conferred upon each witness. The court held that (1) pursuant to its legislative power, as provided in N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1, the legislature was vested with the power to enact the statute which created the commission, (2) the grant of immunity was absolute and was coextensive with their privilege against self incrimination, (3) the fact that the witnesses might have been potentially exposed to federal prosecution did not render the immunity invalid, (4) the commission did not pursue the wrong remedy in bringing the proceedings pursuant to the N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 406, and (5) the decisions were properly made pursuant to § 406 after hearings that met the requirements of due process.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the orders which granted the applications of the commission for warrants to commit the witnesses to jail for their refusal to answer questions at a hearing.


HEADNOTES

Witnesses -- immunity -- persons, who refused to answer pertinent questions at hearings conducted by Commission of Investigation of State of New York after having been granted immunity in accord with statutes (L. 1958, ch. 989, § 7; Penal Law, § 2447), properly committed to jail -- chapter 989 of Laws of 1958 creating commission not unconstitutional -- commission is "temporary" commission created for "special purposes" (N. Y. Const., art. V, § 3) -- complete immunity coextensive  [***2] with privilege against self incrimination (N. Y. Const., art. I, § 6) was granted -- commission not required to disclose communications had with Attorney-General and District Attorneys in accord with statute (L. 1958, ch. 989, § 7) -- immunity not invalid because it does not protect against Federal prosecutions -- commission properly pursued coercive remedy under section 406 of Civil Practice Act rather than punitive remedy under Judiciary Law (art. 19) -- summary action against five of witnesses violated no right -- none of witnesses was denied due process.

1. Subpoenas were issued by Commission of Investigation of the State of New York commanding appellants to appear at a public hearing being conducted by the commission. At the first hearing, the chairman announced that it was being held in connection with a certain meeting in November, 1957, at the residence of one Joseph Barbara in Tioga County. The purposes of the hearing were stated to be "Whether the crimes of conspiracy, violation of section 340 of the General Business Law which pertains to monopoly or restraint of trade statutes, bribery of public officials or any other crimes were committed or planned at this meeting."  [***3] Each appellant appeared before the commission and was asked a series of questions, each of which would have been relevant to one of the subjects of the investigation as stated in each subpoena to be "the organization, purposes and participants of, and discussions had and decisions made at" the meeting in Tioga County. Each appellant refused to answer all questions, basing such refusal on the privilege against self incrimation and other grounds. Following such refusal, the members of the commission, according to statutory authority (L. 1958, ch. 989, § 7), conferred immunity upon each appellant in accord with section 2447 of the Penal Law. Each witness was then informed that he had immunity "from prosecution by the New York State authorities on account of any transaction, matter or thing of a criminal nature which may be revealed by your truthful and responsive answers to the particular questions which this Commission * * * may now direct you to answer." Again each witness refused to answer the questions. All of the appellants were properly committed to jail for refusal to answer the questions.

2. Chapter 989 of the Laws of 1958 creating the commission is not unconstitutional.  [***4] Section 2 of article V of the State Constitution provides for 19 civil departments in the State Government. Section 3 provides that "No new departments shall be created hereafter, but this shall not prevent the legislature from creating temporary commissions for special purposes". The commission is a temporary one and the functions, powers and duties thereunder are "special purposes" within the meaning of section 3 of article V of the State Constitution.

3. Section 7 of the statute (L. 1958, ch. 989) provides that, in any investigation or hearing conducted by the commission relating to any claim with respect to which, by express statutory provision, a competent authority is authorized to confer immunity, immunity may be conferred by the commission in accord with the provisions of section 2447 of the Penal Law "but only after affording the attorney-general and the appropriate district attorney the opportunity to be heard in respect to any objections which they may have to the granting of such immunity." Immunity was properly conferred upon each appellant. Each was informed of the grant and extent of the immunity flowing therefrom (cf. Penal Law, § 2447, subd. 2). The immunity [***5] conferred was not limited to the crimes the commission stated it was investigating. It was a complete immunity, coextensive with their privilege against self incrimination (N. Y. Const., art. I, § 6).

4. The commission was not required to disclose communications had with the Attorney-General and the various District Attorneys in accord with section 7 of chapter 989 of the Laws of 1958 with respect to any objections they might have to the granting of such immunity. Regardless of such communications, the grant of immunity was absolute.

5. The immunity was not invalid because it does not protect appellants from subsequent prosecutions by Federal authorities and the fact that one of the functions of the commission is to "cooperate with departments and officers of the United States government in the investigation of violations of the federal laws within this state" (L. 1958, ch. 989, § 2, par. 5), does not require a different result. The test is whether the immunity gives protection against State prosecution.

6. The commission did not pursue the wrong remedy in bringing these proceedings pursuant to section 406 of the Civil Practice Act. That statute provides that, when a witness [***6] attending before a body such as petitioner herein "refuses without reasonable cause * * * to answer a legal and pertinent question * * * the person issuing the subpoena, if he is a judge of a court of record, or not of record, may forthwith, or if he is not, then any judge of such court may upon proof by affidavit of the facts, by warrant commit the offender to jail, there to remain until he submits to do the act which he was so required to do or is discharged according to law." The distinction between this statute and the provisions of the Judiciary Law (art. 19) is that the latter are punitive in nature whereas the proceeding under section 406 is coercive only. The commission was not required to invoke the punitive provisions as distinguished from the proceeding for coercive relief to compel the witnesses to testify.

7. As to five of the appellants, their summary conviction violated no right. Notice was given to them; a transcript of the testimony in each proceeding was made available to the court and counsel for the witness; a hearing was held. However, the haste with which the proceedings were conducted is not approved. Nevertheless, no prejudice amounting to a denial of due [***7] process is shown because they were denied adjournments so their counsel could examine the law and submit briefs.

8. The other two appellants were also accorded due process.

 

1083 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Thomas v. Central Greyhound Lines, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


6 A.D.2d 649; 180 N.Y.S.2d 461; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3923



December 9, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Judgment so far as appealed from unanimously reversed on the law and on the facts, and in the exercise of discretion, the action is severed as to the defendants, Central Greyhound Lines, Inc., of New York and Lionel Mantel, and a new trial ordered as to said defendants, with costs to the appellants to abide the result of the final judgment in the action.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, bus line and driver, challenged a judgment of the Supreme Court in New York County (New York), in a consolidated action of respondent passengers to recover for injuries sustained by them while they were passengers on a bus owned by the bus line and operated by the driver.


OVERVIEW: The bus in which the passengers were riding collided with a truck. Several actions were instituted by the passengers to recover for the injuries they sustained and those actions were consolidated, resulting in a judgment in favor of the passengers. The court reversed the judgment. It held that the trial court's jury charge, which imposed upon the driver of the bus a higher degree of care than that charged in respect of the operator of the truck, conveyed to the jury that appellants' obligation to the passengers was that of an insurer. Further, it was improper to exclude testimony of an experiment tending to establish the angle of vision of a witness, one of the passengers, whose testimony indicated the northbound bus had entered the southbound lane. The evidence was offered to show, by physical circumstances, the incapacity of the witness to see the centerline of the road from his seat on the bus and it was relevant because, other than the truck driver, the witness was the only one to testify that the bus had deviated from its proper lane and appellants' theory was that the truck entered the bus's lane and collided with the bus.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment entered against appellants in the passengers' suit to recover for personal injuries they sustained while passengers on a bus and granted a new trial.


HEADNOTES

Carriers -- negligence -- standard of care -- plaintiffs were passengers in bus which, traveling in northerly direction on concrete two-lane highway, collided with truck which was proceeding southerly -- charge to jury concerning obligation of owner and operator of bus to passengers tended to convey impression that obligation was that of insurer -- degree of care required is reasonable care -- new trial directed -- verdict legally untenable if based upon Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 56, subd. 1) which has been declared unconstitutional -- evidence of experiment  [***2] conducted to show that passenger could not have seen line in road as he stated was relevant and admissible.

1. Plaintiffs were passengers in a bus, owned by one of the defendants and operated by another, and were injured as a result of a collision between the bus and a truck operated by another defendant. The bus, proceeding northerly on a concrete two-lane highway, collided with the truck, proceeding southerly, at about 6:00 a.m., the weather being misty and the road wet. The court charged that there was a different standard of duty between the operator of the truck and the bus, that the operator of the truck was under a duty to use reasonable care, but that "the bus, as a public conveyance for hire and operated in the business of transporting paying passenger fares, is required to exercise a high degree of care in the operation of the bus for the safety of the passengers. * * * The Greyhound bus driver is bound, therefore, to use more than the ordinary usual caution, but is bound to use a high degree of care, taking into consideration all the conditions prevailing immediately preceding and at the time of the accident." The imposition upon the operator of the bus of a higher [***3] degree of care than that charged with respect to the operator of the truck tended to convey to the jury that the owner's and operator's obligation to the passengers of the bus was that of insurer. The degree of care is always the same and that is ordinary care, reasonable care, or the care which a reasonably prudent person should exercise. Attempts to characterize the degree of reasonable care required, depending on the circumstances, tend to confuse, particularly when more than one vehicle is involved and one of them is a common carrier of passengers.

2. Under the charge, it cannot be determined whether the verdict against the owner and operator of the bus was predicated on subdivision 1 of section 56 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which provides: "No person shall operate a motor vehicle or a motor cycle upon a public highway at such a speed as to endanger the life, limb or property of any person, nor at a rate of speed greater than will permit such person to bring the vehicle to a stop without injury to another or his property." That subdivision has been declared unconstitutional. ( People v. Firth, 3 N Y 2d 472.) Where a general verdict is rendered in a liability case [***4] submitted on multiple theories of liability, the verdict may not stand if one of them is legally untenable.

3. One of the plaintiffs, seated near a window on the left side of the bus, testified that immediately prior to the accident he observed the center line of the highway 6 to 12 inches left of the left side of the bus, and that he lost sight of the center line immediately prior to the collision, implying that at, or immediately prior to the accident, the bus had entered the southbound lane. It was improper to exclude testimony of an experiment tending to establish the angle of vision of that plaintiff, to establish his incapacity, by reason of physical circumstances, to see a line 6 to 12 inches from and parallel with the left side of the bus. The evidence was relevant, and relevant facts derived from experiments are admissible. That the circumstances at the time of the accident may have varied in some respects from those at the time the experiment was made affects the weight, but is not a basis for its exclusion.

4. A new trial is directed.

 

1084 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Grove Hill Realty Co. v. Ferncliff Cemetery Asso.


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, SECOND DEPARTMENT


7 A.D.2d 736; 180 N.Y.S.2d 767; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3979



December 8, 1958 - Decided

 

1085 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Sawyer v. Southport


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


6 A.D.2d 553; 179 N.Y.S.2d 897; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4043



December 2, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with $ 10 costs to plaintiff-respondent.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant county appealed a decision by the Supreme Court at Special Term, Chemung County (New York), which denied the county's motion to dismiss the first of two causes of action filed by plaintiff complainant, who assisted an officer of defendant town in making an arrest and was injured in the process. The complainant sought damages. The officer was also the sheriff of the county. The town was not a party to the county's motion.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Penal Law § 1848 declared that it was a misdemeanor to refuse to aid an officer in making an arrest and that, if such aid was given and the person obeying the command was injured, the person could obtain damages from the municipal corporation by which the officer was employed at the time that the command was obeyed. The county contended that § 1848 was unconstitutional as applied to the county because § 1848 allegedly violated that portion of N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 5 that read that the county could never be made responsible for the acts of the sheriff. On appeal, the court affirmed the trial court's refusal to dismiss the first cause of action. The court found that the New York Legislature intended to include the sheriff, as well as other police officers, within the coverage of N.Y. Penal Law § 1848 because the county was a municipal corporation and the Legislature had knowledge of N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 5 when the statute was written. To extend art. IX, § 5 to prohibit a beneficial statute that could not have conceivably been in the minds of those who passed the New York Constitution would have been to adopt a narrow and unwarranted view of the New York Constitution.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's refusal of the county's motion to dismiss the complainant's first cause of action.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- liability for injury while aiding officer -- section 1848 of Penal Law, which declares it misdemeanor to refuse to aid officer in making arrest and provides cause of action against municipal corporation where injury or damage arises out of and in course of aiding officer in arresting person, does not violate New York Constitution (art. IX, § 5), which provides that "County shall never be made responsible for the acts of the sheriff" -- motion to dismiss cause of action against county in action by one who was allegedly injured in course of obeying command of Deputy Sheriff properly denied.

Plaintiff was ordered by one who was an officer of defendant town and a Deputy Sheriff of defendant county to assist in making an arrest and, according to the complaint, was injured in the course of obeying the command of the officer. Section 1848 of the Penal [***2] Law declares it to be a misdemeanor to refuse to aid an officer in making an arrest, and further provides: "Where such a command is obeyed and the person obeying it is killed or injured * * * and such death, injury or damage arises out of and in the course of aiding an officer in arresting or endeavoring to arrest a person * * * the person or employer so injured * * * shall have a cause of action to recover the amount of such damage or injury against the municipal corporation by which such officer is employed at the time such command is obeyed." The New York Constitution (art. IX, § 5) provides that "But the County shall never be made responsible for the acts of the sheriff." Section 1848 of the Penal Law is not unconstitutional as applied to the county and does not violate the quoted constitutional provision. The statute is remedial in character and should be upheld, if possible, without doing violence to the Constitution. The origin and meaning of the constitutional provision are obscure. To declare the statute contrary to the constitutional provision would be to adopt a narrow and unwarranted view of the Constitution. Accordingly, a motion to dismiss the cause of action against [***3] defendant county was properly denied.

 

1086 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of S. S. Silberblatt, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


6 A.D.2d 603; 180 N.Y.S.2d 210; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4045



December 2, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with $ 10 costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner contractor appealed an order from the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York) which denied the contractor's request for a refund of a mortgage recording tax the contractor paid.


OVERVIEW: The contractor was awarded a bid to construct housing from the United States Military. The subsequent contract was a complicated agreement which provided that the contractor was to lease the property from the United States. Upon completion of the structures, the contractor was ordered to pay a mortgage recording tax. The contractor asserted that he was exempt from paying the tax and that the tax imposed was unconstitutional because it imposed a tax on the United States government. The lower court denied the contractor's request. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment. First, the court held that the mortgage recording tax was not a property tax. The court held that this was significant because the exemption provided in the Housing Act of 1956, 42 U.S.C.S. § 1594, which exempted from taxation leased property from the United States government, was inapplicable to the mortgage recording act. Next, the court stated that mortgage recording tax was not unconstitutional because the tax did not impose any obligations on the United States government.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment denying the contractor's request for a refund of a mortgage recording tax paid because the tax was not a property tax and the contractor was not exempt from paying the tax. In addition, the court held that the tax was not unconstitutional because the tax did not impose any obligation on the United States government.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- mortgage recording tax -- mortgage recording tax ( Tax Law, § 253) applicable to recording of mortgages procured for construction of family housing units at Plattsburgh Air Force Base by corporations which were formed by petitioner and which leased site of project from United States and entered into housing contract with United States -- mortgage recording tax is not property tax and exemption (Housing Act of 1956, § 511) not applicable -- mortgages and indebtedness secured thereby not direct obligations of United States nor instrumentalities of Government employed to perform governmental functions of borrowing money and providing for common defense.

1. Petitioner became the contractor for the construction of family housing units at Plattsburgh Air Force Base. In accordance with the statute [***2] (U. S. Code, tit. 42, § 1594 et seq.) and pursuant to a letter issued by the Department of the Air Force, petitioner formed five Delaware corporations, each with a paid-in capital of $ 1,000, petitioner being the sole stockholder. Each of the corporations then leased from the United States certain lands within the base which together constituted the site of the project. The rental provided by each lease was a lump sum of $ 1,000, and the term in each case was 55 years, terminable by the United States on 60 days' notice at any time after completion and acceptance of the project. Petitioner and the five corporations entered into a housing contract with the United States. The five corporations entered into building loan agreements with a bank and executed and delivered to the bank their several notes secured by mortgages of the leased premises. A commitment for insurance of each of the mortgage notes was indorsed thereon by the Federal Housing Commissioner and payment was guaranteed by the United States. All of the capital stock of the five corporations was assigned in blank and deposited with the mortgage bank in escrow for delivery to the Department of the Air Force upon [***3] completion of the project and final indorsement of the mortgage notes by the Federal Housing Commissioner. The construction period provided by the contract was two years and the first principal payments became due on the notes after the termination of that period. Upon presentation of the mortgages for recording, payment of the mortgage tax under section 253 of the Tax Law was properly demanded.

2. The objection that petitioner is not a proper party petitioner because it is not a party to the mortgages was not raised by way of defense (cf. Civ. Prac. Act, §§ 1291, 242). In any event, the objection is of doubtful validity and, in view of the determination on the merits, the objection is academic.

3. The exemption provided in section 511 of the Housing Act of 1956 refers to property taxes upon the leasehold interests. The New York mortgage recording tax is not a property tax and the exemption is therefore inapplicable.

4. The mortgages and the indebtedness secured thereby did not constitute direct obligations of the United States within the provisions of statute exempting from State or local taxation stocks, bonds, treasury notes and other obligations of the United States (U.  [***4] S. Code, tit. 31, § 742).

5. These obligations are not instrumentalities of the Government, employed to perform the governmental functions of borrowing money and providing for the common defense, such as would put them beyond the taxing power of the State under the doctrine of McCulloch v. Maryland (4 Wheat. [17 U.S.] 316).

 

1087 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Holliday v. Weaver


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


7 A.D.2d 665; 179 N.Y.S.2d 312; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4307



November 10, 1958 - Decided

 

1088 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Harrison Ridge Associates Corp. v. Sforza


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, SECOND DEPARTMENT


6 A.D.2d 1051; 179 N.Y.S.2d 547; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4569



October 20, 1958 - Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporation sought review of an order of a trial court (New York), which denied its petition for an order directing: (1) a building inspector of respondent town to issue a building permit for the construction of a one-family dwelling on a specified lot; (2) respondent town board to act on the corporation's application for an extension of a sewer district; and (3) a determination of the amount of a bond to be furnished to the town.


OVERVIEW: The corporation's principal contention was that it was entitled to a building permit for the particular plot mentioned, 10,000 square feet in area, because an amendment to a zoning ordinance, which rezoned the district from one permitting a minimum plot of 10,000 square feet to one requiring a minimum of one acre, either had not become effective at the time the application for the permit was made or was illegal and unconstitutional. On appeal, the court assumed, without deciding, that the amendment to the ordinance did not become effective until four days after the corporation filed its application for the building permit, as the corporation contended. The court was of the opinion that the trial court properly refused to direct the issuance of the permit because its issuance would have been a futility in view of the change in the ordinance forbidding the use sought by the corporation, and in view of the absence of the acquisition by the corporation of any vested rights prior to such change.


OUTCOME: The court unanimously affirmed the order, with costs, and without prejudice to such further proceedings for the same or similar relief as the corporation might be advised, in connection with the development of its property in accordance with the provisions of the zoning ordinance and other applicable statutes.

 

1089 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Davis v. Board of Elections


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


6 A.D.2d 390; 178 N.Y.S.2d 465; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4599



October 14, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Order unanimously affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant candidate sought review of an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term in New York County, which denied his petition to declare valid an independent nominating petition and affirmed respondent city board of election's action declaring void the signatures of those persons who had signed the petition without registering in the last general election, as required by N.Y. Elec. Law § 138.


OVERVIEW: The candidate had been nominated for public office by independent petition pursuant to § 138. The board declared void the signatures of those persons who had not registered in the last general election, and Special Term denied the candidate's petition to declare valid the independent nominating petition. The candidate argued that the requirement that a signer must have registered in the last general election was unconstitutional, and the court affirmed the lower court. The court held that the requirement was not an unreasonable one, as it tended to prevent fraud and to make more certain the good faith of the persons seeking to present to the voters independent candidates for office. The court held that one who failed to exercise his right to register at the previous general election, thereby preserving his privilege to sign a petition for an independent nomination during the following year, had no right to complain that he did not take advantage of the opportunity. The court reasoned that voting was not only a privilege, but a duty, and a voter was not permitted to make capital of his own delinquency.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order denying the candidate's petition.


HEADNOTES

Elections -- independent nominating petitions -- constitutional law -- requirement of section 138 of Election Law that name of person signing independent nominating petition shall not be counted if he was not registered at time of last preceding general election as qualified voter, not unreasonable with respect to voters who had opportunity to register for general election of preceding year, but is discriminatory as to those who were not qualified to register for general election in preceding year -- however, record does not indicate that those whose names were stricken out in present case were in latter class.

1. The requirement of section 138 of the Election Law that "The name of a person signing such a petition (an independent nominating petition) for an election * * * shall not be counted if such person was not registered at the time of the last preceding general election as a qualified voter" is not an unreasonable one [***2] with respect to voters who had an opportunity to register for the general election of the preceding year.

2. The statute is discriminatory as to those who are not qualified to register for the general election in the preceding year.

3. However, the record does not indicate that those whose names were stricken from the petition in the present case were in the latter class. On the contrary, the petition states that each of the signers was registered to vote at the time of the last preceding general election. The board of elections found that statement to be untrue and it was within its power to declare void the signatures of those persons who had not registered.

 

1090 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Board of Education v. Allen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


6 A.D.2d 316; 177 N.Y.S.2d 169; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4993



July 31, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Order of the Special Term modified to vacate that part thereof which annuls and sets aside the petition for the election and the election and to deny the petitioners' application in these respects; and as thus modified the order is affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, board and taxpayers, sought review of an order of the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which denied their application to annul the order of appellee commissioner, which laid out a central school district. The commissioner sought review from that portion of the order that annulled an election, the petition, and notice to organize the central school district.


OVERVIEW: The commissioner issued an order for the creation of one central school district, which would effectively combine three existing school districts. The board and taxpayers filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding in which they sought to annul the order. The trial court denied their application, but it annulled an election and the petition and notice to organize the school district. The commissioner, board, and taxpayers appealed. On appeal, the board and taxpayers argued that as it had no substantial need for high school facilities because most of its students went to private school, their tax burden would have been unduly increased without substantial benefit to them or the needs of their children. However, the court held that a local inequity was not necessarily a general injustice and, further, that the board and taxpayers did not make out a case of constitutional discrimination for which a law court was able to afford redress. The board and taxpayer further argued that the law was unconstitutional. However, the court held that the statute was not invalid for a failure of prescription of more detailed standards for the guidance of the administrative action of the commissioner.


OUTCOME: The order denying the board's and taxpayer's application to annul the commissioner's order was affirmed; the order annulling the election and the petition and notice was vacated.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- central school district -- State Commissioner of Education may constitutionally lay out central school district consisting of several large union free school districts and one small but relatively wealthy one, despite latter's dissent (Education Law, § 1801) -- central school district was laid out along lines of said union free school district;  [***2] latter embraced about 1/3 of one village and about 1/10 of another village; voters residing in portions of villages not within school district are not to be counted (Education Law, § 1802, subd. 1, par. a).

1. Under the Education Law ( § 1801), the State Commissioner of Education may constitutionally lay out a central school district consisting of several large union free school districts and one small one, even though such layout is contrary to the wishes, autonomy and tax interests of the small and relatively wealthy district and of said one district's taxpayers.

2. The standard required of the State Commissioner of Education by the statute, that he "shall include only territory of suitable size conveniently located for the attendance of pupils and having a sufficient number of pupils for the establishment of a central school" (Education Law, § 1801, subd. 2), is administrative and sufficiently detailed, and is valid and constitutional. Such standard is only the bare minimum of size and number. The commissioner may and should and did consider also a wide range of questions and data as to sound educational policy and needs for the future; and his determination to lay out [***3] this central school district is affirmed.

3. The Education Law ( § 1802, subd. 1, par. a) further provides: "When an order laying out a central school district has been made and entered as provided in section eighteen hundred one * * * a petition may be presented by persons qualified to vote at school district meetings asking for the organization of a central school district * * *. * * * signed by at least one hundred of such qualified voters or by a number of such qualified voters equal to at least ten per centum of the pupils of said central school district as determined by the last school census, whichever shall be less. If such territory includes one or more * * * villages having a population of one thousand or more, then such petition shall be signed by at least one hundred of such qualified voters residing within each said * * * village, or by a number of such qualified voters residing within each said * * * village equal to at least ten per centum of the pupils of the school district residing within said * * * village as determined by the last school census, whichever shall be less; and shall also be signed by at least one hundred of such qualified voters residing in said [***4] district outside of any * * * village or by a number of qualified voters residing in said district outside of any * * * village equal to at least ten per centum of the pupils of the school district residing outside of any * * * village, as determined by the last school census, whichever shall be less." The proposed central school district follows the lines of petitioners' present union free school district, embracing about 1/3 of the Village of Brookville and about 1/10 of the Village of Old Brookville; and presumably each village has a population of over 1,000. But the last, long sentence of the above-statute (§ 1802, subd. 1, par. a) cannot be construed to apply to this case. Only the qualified voters residing in the school district are to be counted; those residing in the village but not in the school district are not to be counted.

 

1091 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Utica v. Water Pollution Control Board


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


6 A.D.2d 340; 177 N.Y.S.2d 47; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4999



July 31, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with $ 50 costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of a decision of the Supreme Court at Special Term in Albany County (New York), which dismissed its petition in a proceeding in the nature of a prohibition brought under N.Y. R. Civ. Prac. art. 78 to restrain respondent State Water Pollution Control Board from proceeding without or in excess of jurisdiction in conducting a hearing in respect to alleged violations by the city of N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1220.


OVERVIEW: The city filed a petition to prohibit the board from conducting a hearing in respect to alleged violations by the city of N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1220. The city allegedly discharged or permitted to be discharged from its municipal sewers into the waters of a river and a canal, sewage and wastes that caused pollution of those waters in violation of the standard of purity promulgated therefor by the board. The city argued that N.Y. Pub. Health Law art. 12 constituted an unconstitutional delegation of legislative powers. The trial court dismissed the city's petition. On appeal, the court affirmed the trial court's order and determined that N.Y. Pub. Health Law art. 12 contained definite and sufficient standards to guide the board. The court found that under N.Y. Pub. Health Law art. 12 the classification of waters and the standards of quality and purity formulated by the board could only be adopted after public hearing with notice to the municipalities and others concerned and that the board's action was subject to judicial review. The court found that the legislature recognized that no single standard of quality or purity of water could be adopted for all the waters of the state.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's dismissal of the city's petition, in favor of the board.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- delegation of legislative power -- Water Pollution Control Board -- article 12 of Public Health Law under which State Water Pollution Control Board proposes to conduct hearing with respect to alleged discharge of sewage and waste by City of Utica into waters of Mohawk River and Barge Canal not unconstitutional as constituting invalid delegation of legislative power -- statute definite and standards sufficient to guide and control board in exercise of discretion committed to it.

The State Water Pollution Control Board proposes to conduct a hearing in respect to alleged violations by the City of Utica of section 1220 of the Public Health Law in discharging or permitting to be discharged sewage and wastes from its municipal sewers into the waters of the Mohawk River and the Barge Canal, causing pollution of those waters in violation of the standards of purity promulgated therefor by the board, pursuant [***2] to article 12 of the Public Health Law. Said article 12 is not unconstitutional as constituting an invalid delegation of legislative power in violation of the State Constitution which provides (art. III, § 1) that "The legislative power of this State shall be vested in the Senate and Assembly." Water pollution control is a proper subject of legislation under the police power of the State. Section 1202 (subd. g) of the Public Health Law defines "standard" or "standards" as meaning "such measure of purity or quality for any waters in relation to their reasonable and necessary use, as may be established by the board pursuant to section one thousand two hundred nine herein."
