Section 1209, entitled "Classification of waters and adoption of standards", recognizes (subd. 1) "that, due to variable factors, no single standard of quality and purity of the waters is applicable to all waters of the state or to different segments of the same waters." The statute (subd. 2) directs that the board, after study and after public hearings upon notice, "shall group the designated waters of the state into classes * * * in accordance with considerations of best usage in the interest of the public" and [***3] with regard to the considerations mentioned in the next succeeding subdivision. The factors so to be considered are numerous and varied. They include the physical nature and characteristics of each area of water, the character of the district bordering it in the various respects enumerated, the uses being made of the waters for any of the purposes stated, the extent of their present defilement and additional factors relating to the extent to which enumerated substances, expressed in terms of their physical, chemical or biological properties, shall be permitted in establishing standards. The classification of waters and the standards of quality and purity thereof formulated by the board are to be adopted only after public hearing, on notice to the municipalities and others concerned (subd. 7) and the board's action thereon is subject to judicial review (§ 1244). Like safeguards surround the board's powers of enforcement. The statute is definite, and sufficient standards are set further to guide and at the same time to control and limit the board in the exercise of the discretion committed to it.

 

1092 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gillman


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, SECOND DEPARTMENT


6 A.D.2d 899; 177 N.Y.S.2d 623; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5060



July 21, 1958 - Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed his conviction and sentence for a violation of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 643a-9.0 in failing to comply with an order issued by the Commissioner of Housing and Buildings of the City of New York, entered in the Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York, Borough of Queens (New York). Defendant challenged the propriety of the Commissioner's order.


OVERVIEW: The Commissioner ordered defendant to discontinue using certain real property in a city borough as a trailer camp and to remove two trailers, which were being used without a certificate of occupancy as required by municipal zoning laws. Defendant refused to comply with the order. He was subsequently convicted for his noncompliance and sentenced to pay a fine or serve a 5-day and a 30-day sentence, with execution of the 30-day sentence suspended upon compliance with the order by a certain time. Defendant paid the fine and then appealed the Commissioner's order. The court held that the appeal mandated dismissal because the court had no power to review the propriety of the Commissioner's administrative order within the context of the criminal prosecution; defendant had to seek review of the order from the city's board of standards and appeals. However, the court found that the sentence imposed was excessive in light of defendant's dilemma by reason of conflicting municipal zoning laws; the court thus reduced the fine, eliminated the jail sentences, and held that defendant should be given a chance to remove the trailers or take such action as was needed to validate their use.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed defendant's appeal regarding the propriety of the Commissioner's order. However, the court modified the trial court's order on the facts by reducing the fine imposed on defendant and by eliminating his two jail sentences; the court otherwise affirmed as to defendant's conviction for noncompliance with the order.

 

1093 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Berkshire Fine Spinning Associates, Inc. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


6 A.D.2d 252; 176 N.Y.S.2d 77; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5206



July 3, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Order and judgment reversed on the law, the motion of the plaintiff for summary judgment is denied and the cross motion of the defendants for a dismissal of the complaint is granted, with costs to appellants.

Settle order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city appealed from an order of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which granted summary judgment for plaintiff corporation in the corporation's action for a declaratory judgment for a refund of the tax assessments, paid under protest, and held that the corporation was exclusively engaged in interstate commerce and that its local activity was de minimis.


OVERVIEW: The city imposed a gross receipts tax for the privilege of doing business in the city. The corporation was incorporated in Massachusetts and sold textiles, the manufacturing of which was provided outside of the city. However, the corporation maintained two separate offices in city. The corporation filed a protest for a refund and the trial court granted its motion for summary judgment. The court reversed, holding that the corporation's local business operations extended substantially beyond the sale and promotion of its products. Its designs were prepared in the city, after study of the local market. The directions for the manufacturing of goods for future sales and delivery, the checking of credits, the approval or withholding of shipments after sales were made, and the maintenance of records occurred in the city. The corporation's business was a local activity that went beyond the solicitation of business exclusively in interstate commerce because it included services rendered to its customers before and after shipment of the goods. Thus, the corporation's local activities were substantial and separable from those in interstate commerce and it was subject to the tax.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's grant of summary judgment to the corporation and granted the cross motion for summary judgment filed by the city.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- New York City General Business and Financial Tax -- local functions of foreign corporation which sold textiles manufactured by it in out-of-State plants through two offices in New York City not merely incidental to corporation's activities in interstate commerce but were, as matter of law, of such character as to enable corporation to establish itself in and hold community market, thereby subjecting corporation to gross receipts tax imposed for privilege of doing business in New York City; in action by corporation for judgment declaring tax unconstitutional as applied to its activities  [***2] in New York City and for money judgment in refund of taxes paid, motion for dismissal of complaint should have been granted -- local activities, though merely incidents in transacting of interstate business, could not properly be isolated from total, where all local activities were either necessitated by or designedly planned for purpose of vying with local competitors -- burden to establish invalidity of tax rested on taxpayer -- even if allocation formula applied to corporation arbitrary and discriminatory, court could not in plenary action afford corporation relief; appropriate remedy by protest to comptroller and proceeding under article 78 of Civil Practice Act.

1. The local functions of a Massachusetts corporation, authorized to do business in New York, which sold textiles consisting of greige goods, finished fabrics, curtain materials and curtains, all of which it manufactured in plants located in Rhode Island, Massachusetts and Vermont, were not merely incidental to the corporation's activities in interstate commerce but were, as a matter of law, of such character as to enable the corporation to establish itself in and hold the community market, thereby subjecting the corporation [***3] to the gross receipts tax imposed for the privilege of doing business in New York City (Administrative Code of City of New York, § B46-2.0, subd. a). The corporation maintained two offices in New York City, one catering to the curtain trade, and the other dealing with cotton goods, supervised by three vice-presidents. The local activities included acceptance, modification or rejection of orders; checking and determination of credit; maintenance of records concerning sales and processing of perpetual inventory records, including all data of goods in process of manufacture and in transit, and record control of shipments, in part comprising directions to the plants as to the time and place of shipments to customers; billing of finished goods, comprising the bulk of the corporation's business; maintenance of bank accounts wherein payments for merchandise sold were deposited and upon which employees of the local office were authorized to draw; exercise of substantial control over production in the out-of-State plants, including purchase and development of designs for printed textiles and the making of decisions with respect to dyeing, printing and other methods of finishing goods and [***4] estimating and determining future production requirements, all of which were influenced by a study of the local market; handling of customer complaints and claims of merchandise defects or nonconformance with samples; and advertising and promotional activities. Upon appeal by defendants, the City of New York and others, in an action by the corporation for a judgment declaring that the New York City General Business and Financial Tax was unconstitutional and void as applied to the corporation's activities in New York City and for a money judgment in refund of taxes paid under protest, a judgment granting summary judgment in favor of plaintiff and an order denying defendants' motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint were reversed on the law, the motion of plaintiff for summary judgment denied and the cross motion of defendants for a dismissal of the complaint granted.

2. While it might reasonably be argued that some of the corporation's local activities were merely incidents in the transacting of interstate business, they could not properly be isolated from the total. It was a fair inference that all of the local activities were either necessitated by or designedly planned [***5] for the express purpose of vying advantageously with local competitors. Where the local activities of a vendor are merely incidental to conduct or transactions essentially in interstate commerce and forming an unbroken process of interstate commerce, then the imposition of the local tax is tainted with illegality; conversely, however, if the vendor, as in the case at bar, engages in activities designed essentially and exclusively for the local buyer then an apportioned tax is permissible. A consideration of the corporation's operations made it clear that its local activities rendered integrated services of which the manufacturing of textiles was merely a part. By channeling business through its New York office, the corporation gained the advantage of a local business. That was a local activity which went beyond the solicitation of business exclusively in interstate commerce for it included services rendered to its customers before and after shipment of the goods.

3. The burden to establish the invalidity of the tax rested on the taxpayer. That requirement is reasonable, since the taxpayer is in better position than the agency empowered to impose the tax to establish the factual [***6] proof with respect to the operative factors involved in the conduct of the business. Moreover, the Administrative Code of the City of New York (§ B46-3.0) places the burden of proof on the taxpayer.

4. Assuming, as contended by the corporation, that the allocation formula applied to it was arbitrary and discriminatory and for that reason invalid, the court could not, in the plenary action at bar for declaratory judgment, afford it any relief. The appropriate remedy for relief from an allocation formula promulgated by the city comptroller in levying the New York City General Business and Financial Tax is by protest to the comptroller, and upon his refusal to give relief, by the commencement of a proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act. That the abbreviated time limitation for the commencement of an article 78 proceeding barred plaintiff from relief, furnished no justifiable reason for the courts to sanction a plenary action in the absence of express legislation.

 

1094 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Austin v. Board of Higher Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


5 A.D.2d 664; 174 N.Y.S.2d 511; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5713



May 27, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Judgment and order reversed upon the law, with costs to the appellants, and the motion of defendant to dismiss the complaint for legal insufficiency is denied, with $ 10 costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff former professors sought review of an order from the Supreme Court at Special Term in New York County (New York) granting a motion to dismiss the complaint and from the judgment entered thereon, in an action brought against defendant board of higher education (board) after the professors were dismissed from their positions in city colleges.


OVERVIEW: The former professors sought to recover salaries accrued from the time of their dismissals to the commencement of the action. The dismissals occurred following the pleading by the former professors of their privilege against self incrimination in hearings before a United States Senate Subcommittee. The dismissals were pursuant to the provisions of New York, N.Y., City Charter § 903. The trial court dismissed their complaint. On appeal, the court reversed the order and judgment and denied the motion to dismiss. The dismissals were automatic, involving neither an act of discretion nor a quasi-judicial determination and the complaint was not time-barred. At the time of the motion to dismiss, the allegations were taken as true and the complaint should not have been dismissed on the basis that the former professors did not seek reinstatement before seeking accrued salaries. The former professors would have eventually had to establish the facts asserted in their pleading and sustain their right. There were other matters of defense that may have eventually served to defeat or diminish the former professors' recovery, but with such possible issues there was no present concern.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order and judgment from the trial court and denied the board's motion to dismiss, in an action brought by the former professors alleging that they were unlawfully dismissed following the pleading by them of their privilege against self incrimination in hearings before a United States Senate Subcommittee, and seeking to recover salaries accrued from the time of their dismissals to the commencement of the action.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- teachers -- dismissal for claiming privilege against self incrimination -- plaintiffs unlawfully dismissed from positions in New York City colleges pursuant to section 903 of New York City Charter, which provides for termination of employment in event employee claims privilege against self incrimination -- plaintiffs may recover accrued salary without first having been reinstated -- no discretion or quasi-judicial determination involved in plaintiffs' dismissal -- charter provision self-executing.

1. According to the complaint, plaintiffs were unlawfully dismissed from their positions in the New York City colleges under the Board of Higher Education of the City [***2] of New York pursuant to the provisions of section 903 of the New York City Charter. The dismissals occurred in 1953, following the pleading by plaintiffs of their privilege against self incrimination in hearings before a United States Senate Subcommittee. Since then the United States Supreme Court, in the case of Slochower v. board of ' Educ. (350 U.S. 551), has held that the statute in its application to another person, similarly situated, constituted a violation of due process and was, therefore, unconstitutional. Section 903 of the New York City Charter provides that a city employee's employment shall, in the event he claims the privilege against self incrimination, terminate and the employment shall be vacant. The dismissals of plaintiffs did not involve any act of discretion or quasi-judicial determination. The statute provides for a self-executing forfeiture. No further action is required. No further action was taken by defendant except to dismiss in response to the clear and unqualified mandate of the statute. No hearings were required and none were held; no charges were placed; nor any findings made. Accordingly, the complaint should not have been dismissed.

 [***3] 2. Plaintiffs need not first have obtained reinstatement to their positions from which they had been illegally dismissed before they seek to recover accrued salary. A proceeding in the nature of mandamus is not the exclusive remedy for one illegally removed. An action at law may lie to recover accrued salary so long as only a clear legal right was involved, uncomplicated by an act of administration discretion or quasi-judicial determination.

 

1095 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


American Chicle Co. v. State Tax Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


5 A.D.2d 318; 172 N.Y.S.2d 389; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6429



March 27, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Determination confirmed, with $ 50 costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petition foreign corporation sought review of a determination of respondent State Tax Commission of the State of New York, which sustained an assessment of a recomputed license fee imposed under N.Y. Tax Law § 181 upon the corporation for doing business in the state.


OVERVIEW: The recomputed license fee was assessed against the corporation when 432,825 shares without nominal or par value, but having a stated value of $ 10 per share, were changed into 1,298,475 shares, without nominal or par value, having a stated value of $ 3.33 1/3 per share. The Commission upheld the assessment, and the court confirmed the Commission's decision. The court rejected the corporation's contention that only a dollar increase was taxable under § 181, as it was clear from the language of § 181 that a change in the corporation's capital share structure included the increase in the number of shares which resulted from the stock split-up. Since the basis of the tax imposed when a corporation first entered the state had been approved, there was no ground for constitutional inhibition of the recomputed tax applied according to the same measure. The fact that the corporation had been authorized to do business in the state for more than five years but was not permitted the credit allowed by N.Y. Tax Law § 180 to New York corporations did not render N.Y. Tax Law § 181 discriminatory because the provision of N.Y. Tax Law § 180 was not in effect with the tax liability accrued.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the Commission's determination.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- corporation -- tax where change made in capital share structure of corporation -- tax properly recomputed and increased tax imposed on New Jersey corporation doing business in New York when 432,825 shares, without par value, having stated value of $ 10 per share, were changed into 1,298,475 shares, without par value, having stated value of $ 3.33 1/3 per share -- not necessary that dollar increase occur in order to be taxable (Tax Law, § 181) -- statute not unconstitutional.

1. Section 181 of the Tax Law provides that: "Every foreign corporation * * * doing business in this state, shall pay a license fee of one-eighth of one per centum on its issued par value capital stock employed within [***2] this state and six cents on each share of its capital stock without par value employed within this state for the privilege of exercising its corporate franchises or carrying on its business in such corporate or organized capacity in this state" and, further: "In any case where a change is made in the capital share structure of a corporation, or the amount of capital stock employed in this state is increased, the fee shall be recomputed on the basis of such change or increase, and there shall be credited against the fee, as recomputed, the amount of any fee that may have been previously paid". The tax was properly recomputed and an increased tax imposed on petitioner, a New Jersey corporation doing business in New York, when 432,825 shares, without par value but having a stated value of $ 10 per share, were changed into 1,298,475 shares, without par value, having a stated value of $ 3.33 1/3 per share. Since "a change * * * in the capital share structure" resulted, it was not necessary that a dollar increase occur in order to be taxable. A change by way of increase in dollar capital -- the "amount of capital stock employed in this state" -- is taxable under the alternative provision [***3] appearing in the quoted portion of the statute.

2. The statute under which this tax was imposed is not unconstitutional.

 

1096 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


La Porte v. State


Claim No. 33115


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


5 A.D.2d 362; 172 N.Y.S.2d 249; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6435



March 27, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, on the law, and the motion to amend the decision granted, without costs.

Judgment modified accordingly, and as so modified, affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In respondent landowners' claim for damages for the appropriation of their property, appellant State challenged an order from the Court of Claims (New York), which denied its motion to amend the claims court's judgment to limit the award of interest thereon from June 1, 1953 to December 1, 1953 and from April 7, 1955 to the date of entry of the judgment.


OVERVIEW: The landowner's property was appropriated, pursuant to N.Y. High. Law § 347, which provided that title passed to the State upon the filing of the description of the premises and a map thereof in the county clerk's office. Thereunder, title passed to the State on June 1, 1953. The landowners, however, did not file their claim for compensation until nearly two years later. The claims court awarded the landowners compensation, with interest from June 1, 1953 to the date of the entry of its judgment. The State's motion to amend the judgment to limit the interest awarded thereon was denied. The court reversed the order denying the motion and modified the judgment accordingly. Section 19(1) of the Court of Claims Act suspended interest from a period beginning six months after a claim accrued and ending when the claim was filed. Although the landowners were not personally served with the description and map, the filing thereof in the county clerk's office was constructive notice of the taking, and the landowners could have filed a claim immediately. Moreover, § 19(1) was, in effect, only a time limitation, and did not deprive the landowners of just compensation.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the claims court's order and granted the State's motion to amend. Therefore, the court modified the judgment of the claims court by limiting the interest awarded to the landowners, and as so modified, affirmed the judgment.


HEADNOTES

Court of Claims -- award -- interest -- under Court of Claims Act ( § 19, subd. 1), where claim is not filed until more than six months after accrual thereof, no interest may be allowed for period between expiration of six months from time of accrual to time of filing claim -- motion to amend decision of Court of Claims to allow interest in conformance with statute granted -- statute does not offend due process clause of Federal Constitution -- property not taken without full compensation -- claimants either had actual knowledge of taking and could have filed claim to insure continuous interest, or use and enjoyment of property was not disturbed.

 [***2] 1. Claimants' land was appropriated for Thruway purposes, pursuant to section 347 of the Highway Law which provided that title shall pass to the State upon the filing of a description of the premises and a map thereof with the clerk of the county in which the land is situated. Under that law, title to and right to possession of the premises vested in the State on June 1, 1953. A copy of the description and a map were not served upon claimants until April 22 and April 26, 1955. The claim was verified February 15, 1955 and was filed on April 7, 1955. Claimants were awarded compensation, with interest from June 1, 1953 to the date of entry of judgment without interruption. The Court of Claims Act ( § 19, subd. 1) provides that "If a claim which bears interest, is not filed until more than six months after the accrual of said claim, no interest shall be allowed between the expiration of six months from the time of such accrual and the time of the filing of such claim." A motion to amend the decision to allow interest only from June 1, 1953 to December 1, 1953 and from April 7, 1955 to the date of entry of the judgment should be granted. The statute suspends the payment of interest [***3] from a period beginning six months after the date when the claim accrued, which was June 1, 1953, and ending when the claim was filed.

2. The statute does not offend the due process clause of the Federal Constitution because the description and map were not personally served upon claimants until after the six months' period from the accrual of the claim had expired. The filing of the description and map was constructive notice to all that the State had taken the property. A claim could have been filed immediately without regard to personal service. A statute which provides a reasonable limitation on interest is not unconstitutional where full compensation for the land taken is provided for and a method of enforcing collection is provided with reasonable time limitations.

3. Claimants either had actual knowledge of the taking and could have filed a claim to insure continuous interest, or, if they had no such knowledge, their use and enjoyment of the property was not disturbed. They are not entitled to both possession and interest on the award.

4. The property was not taken without just compensation.

 

1097 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Gray-Lewis v. Gray-Lewis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


5 A.D.2d 238; 171 N.Y.S.2d 364; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6652



March 11, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Order so far as appealed from unanimously modified on the law so as to grant the motion to set aside service of the supplemental summons and amended complaint in its entirety, and, as so modified, affirmed, with $ 20 costs and disbursements to the appellant.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant wife sought review of the order of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which denied in part her motion to set aside the service of summons and complaint made by plaintiff former wife on defendant husband. The husband had been married to the former wife and was now married to the wife. The former wife filed suit against the wife and the husband seeking to be declared the husband's legal wife.


OVERVIEW: The former wife and the husband were divorced pursuant to a Nevada decree obtained by the husband. Subsequently, the husband and the wife were married. The former wife filed suit against the husband and the wife and sought to be declared the wife of the husband and to have an annulment of the marriage of the former and the wife, and to nullify the separation agreement the former wife had with the husband. The wife moved to contest the jurisdiction of the trial court on the ground that the service was insufficient, improper, invalid, and beyond the scope of N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act §§ 232 to 235. The trial court granted the motion as to the first count of the former wife's complaint but denied it as to the last two counts. On appeal, the court modified the decree of the trial court and held that the motion should have been granted in full Under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 1165-a. The wife was not within the jurisdiction of the trial court because she lived outside of the state and had no contact with the trial court in any of the other actions between the former wife and the husband.


OUTCOME: The order appealed from was modified on the law so as to grant the motion in its entirety and as so modified was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Marriage -- annulment -- service of process -- complaint in action by plaintiff wife against defendant husband and his second wife in which plaintiff wife seeks annulment of said second marriage should be dismissed as against husband's second wife, who was served personally with process in Connecticut where she lives; defendant husband and second wife were married in Nevada and have since resided as husband and wife in Connecticut -- statutes (Civ. Prac. Act, §§ 232, 235, 1134, 1165-a, subd. 3) cannot confer jurisdiction over stranger to proceeding who does not live within State, whose marriage was not consummated here, and where she and claimed offending  [***2] spouse never lived together in this State as man and wife.

1. Plaintiff wife and defendant husband lived in New York, and in 1951 entered into a separation agreement. In that same year defendant husband obtained a Nevada decree of divorce in an action in which plaintiff wife did not appear. In 1955 defendant husband married defendant-appellant in Nevada, and they have since resided and continued to reside as husband and wife in Connecticut. In the present action in which plaintiff wife seeks, as part of the relief demanded, an annulment of defendant husband's second marriage, defendant-appellant was served personally with process in Connecticut where she lives. Upon her special appearance the court at Special Term should have dismissed the complaint.

2. Section 232 of the Civil Practice Act provides that an order for service by publication may be made where the complaint demands judgment annulling a marriage. Section 235 of the Civil Practice Act provides, in part, that "A defendant in any case specified in section [232], or a defendant domiciled in the state, may be served with the summons without an order, without the state in the same manner as if such service were made [***3] within the state." Those sections cannot apply to defendant-appellant who is a domiciliary of Connecticut and was never domiciled in New York.

3. Section 1134 of the Civil Practice Act which provides that "An action to annul a marriage upon the ground that the former husband or wife of one of the parties was living, the former marriage being in force, may be maintained by either of the parties during the life-time of the other, or by the former husband or wife", cannot confer jurisdiction over a nonresident who is not otherwise amenable to process.

4. Subdivision 3 of section 1165-a of the Civil Practice Act provides for the right of a party to maintain an action for annulment "Where the parties were married without the state, and either the plaintiff or the defendant is a resident of the state when the action is commenced, and has been a resident thereof for at least one year continuously any time prior to the commencement of the action." This section applies where the marital res is that of the plaintiff and his or her spouse. It cannot confer jurisdiction over a person of a third party who is a stranger to the proceeding and does not live within the State, and whose marriage [***4] was not consummated here, and where the third party and the claimed offending spouse never lived together in this State as man and wife.

 

1098 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Cluett, Peabody & Co. v. J. W. Mays, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


5 A.D.2d 140; 170 N.Y.S.2d 255; 1958 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7328



January 6, 1958 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed on the law, with costs, and complaint dismissed, with costs. The findings of fact are affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff manufacturer and defendant retailer appealed an order of the Supreme Court of Kings County (New York), which enjoined the retailer from advertising, offering for sale, or selling at retail certain articles of the manufacturer's clothing at a price less than stipulated in the manufacturer's fair-trade contract with another retailer.


OVERVIEW: The manufacturer filed an action against the retailer to enjoin the retailer's discount sales and advertising of the manufacturer's shirts in violation of a fair-trade contract between the manufacturer and another retailer. The trial court granted an injunction enjoining the retailer from selling such merchandise below the prices fixed in the manufacturer's fair-trade contract, except that it allowed the retailer to offer the shirts to the manufacturer at cost, and if the manufacturer declined the offer, the retailer was at liberty to sell the shirts without regard to the agreement. The manufacturer appealed the provision of the offer of sale, and the retailer appealed the entire judgment. The court reversed the issuance of the injunction, holding that the retailer's advertising and sale of the shirts in question, without knowledge of the resale restrictions contained in the manufacturer's fair-trade agreement, did not amount to unfair competition within the meaning of § 369 of the General Business Law. The court held that the retailer established a complete defense to the manufacturer's action for an injunction.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgement enjoining the retailer from advertising, offering for sale or selling at retail certain articles of the manufacturer's clothing or wearing apparel at a price less than stipulated in the manufacturer's fair-trade contract with another retailer.


HEADNOTES

Trade-marks, trade names and unfair competition -- violation of fair-trade agreement -- General Business Law ( § 369-b), declaring that willfully and knowingly advertising, offering for sale or selling commodity at less than prices in fair-trade agreement is unfair competition, is not violated where merchandise so sold was acquired without knowledge that it was subject to fair-trade agreement.

 [***2] 1. Plaintiff entered into a fair-trade agreement with a New York City department store retailer, other than defendant, providing for minimum prices for the sale in New York State at retail of some of its varieties of men's shirts. More than two years after the execution of the fair-trade agreement, defendant purchased approximately 147 dozen of men's shirts manufactured by plaintiff, of the varieties covered by plaintiff's fair-trade agreement, and put them on sale and advertised them at prices less than the minimum price stipulated in plaintiff's agreement. The trial court found that, at the time of its purchase of the shirts, defendant did not know that they were subject to a fair-trade agreement. It had such knowledge when it sold them. Section 369-b of the General Business Law provides: "Wilfully and knowingly advertising, offering for sale or selling any commodity at less than the price stipulated in any contract entered into pursuant to the provision of section three hundred sixty-nine-a, whether the person so advertising, offering for sale or selling is or is not a party to such contract, is unfair competition and is actionable at the suit of any person damaged thereby."  [***3] The Referee improperly ruled that defendant could sell the shirts in question at any price if plaintiff refused to buy them back at the cost to defendant. If in fact the law is violated by the sale of fair-traded merchandise, with knowledge at the time of sale that it is so price-fixed, such a decision would frustrate the statutory purpose.

2. The statute is not violated where defendant acquired the merchandise without knowledge that it was subject to a fair-trade agreement although it had such knowledge at the time the goods were offered for sale. Section 369-b does not prohibit the mere advertising, offering for sale or selling of a commodity at less than the price stipulated in a fair-trade agreement. It is the doing of these things knowingly and willfully which is declared to be unfair competition.

3. It must be presumed that the Legislature intended no unjust or unreasonable result in the enactment of a statute. Moreover, the statute must be construed, if possible, not only to avoid the conclusion that it is unconstitutional, but also to avoid grave doubts that it may be so. To construe the statute other than to require knowledge at the time of purchase by persons not parties [***4] to the contract would cast doubt on the constitutionality of the statute.

4. The shirts have been disposed of and the questions have become abstract. Nevertheless, the questions are important and are likely to arise with frequency and should be decided by the courts. Defendant's motion to dismiss the appeal is denied.

 

1099 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Sunshine Book Co. v. McCaffrey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


4 A.D.2d 643; 168 N.Y.S.2d 268; 1957 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3759



December 3, 1957 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously modified and, as so modified, affirmed. Settle order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff publisher appealed from a judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which dismissed the publisher's complaint against defendant commissioner of licenses seeking declaratory judgment and injunctive relief preventing the commissioner from sending notices to the publisher's customers ordering them to remove and not sell the publisher's magazines.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff published and distributed magazines claimed to be official publications of nudist organizations. The commissioner sent notices to the publisher's customers ordering them to discontinue selling plaintiff's publications and to remove the publications. The publisher filed a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief action arguing that the commissioner's actions violated its constitutional right of freedom of speech and of press, and that the commissioner's actions constituted a prior restraint on publications, which set up censorship of the press. The trial court dismissed the publisher's complaint, and it appealed. The court affirmed but modified the judgment finding that the commissioner's letters constituted a prior restraint against future publications and violated the publisher's constitutional rights. The court held that the trial court should have directed the commissioner to recall the letter and to instruct the customers to whom it was sent to disregard it. The court found that the real impact of the letter was to compel obedience by the customers, and to some extent was effective in curtailing and preventing the sale of future copies of the publisher's magazines.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed but modified the trial court's judgment dismissing the publisher's complaint against the commissioner seeking declaratory judgment and injunctive relief preventing the commissioner from sending notices to the publisher's customers ordering them to remove and not sell the publisher's magazine.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- censorship -- prior restraint -- action of Commissioner of Licenses of City of New York in causing notice to be delivered to newsdealers cautioning them to discontinue sale of certain named magazines and to remove them from display constituted prohibited prior restraint -- censorship in advance of publication is unconstitutional.

1. The Commissioner of Licenses of the City of New York caused a copy of a notice to be delivered to newsdealers licensed by the Department of Licenses cautioning them to discontinue the sale of certain named magazines and to remove them from display, and notifying them that otherwise steps would be taken for the suspension or revocation of their licenses. This action constituted a prohibited [***2] prior restraint. Section 8 of article I of the New York State Constitution and the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution make the rights of free speech and freedom of the press wholly immune from prior restraint or abridgement. Censorship in advance of publication constitutes an unconstitutional and illegal prior restraint.

2. The commissioner of licenses should be directed to recall the letter and to instruct the newsdealers to whom it was sent to disregard it.

 

1100 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Revona Realty Corp. v. Wasserman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


4 A.D.2d 444; 166 N.Y.S.2d 960; 1957 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4418



October 3, 1957 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with $ 10 costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant mortgagee challenged an order from the Sullivan County Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which denied his motion for an order vacating an order permitting respondent owner substituted service of summons on him and a default judgment. The trial court held, in effect, that because of the long period during which the mortgagee knew of the existence of the judgment against him he was barred by laches from the relief he sought.


OVERVIEW: The mortgagee asked the court to determine the judgment's validity, requesting as alternative relief that the judgment be set aside and the matter litigated in a New York City Municipal Court. The court explained that the usual practice would indicate that the affirmative relief the mortgagee sought addressed to the judgment or the action's underlying merits might be severed and sent to the Third Judicial District, but the trial court was not required to do this unless a party requested it, and the mortgagee made no such request and was bound by the procedure he adopted. The court held that the mortgagee should have asserted within a reasonable time a lack of jurisdiction based on showing his purported nonresidence, but he did nothing, and the claim was waived, so the adverse decision was binding on the mortgagee against the present motion to vacate it and became conclusive. To the extent that the mortgagee sought affirmative relief directing a trial on the merits in municipal court, in which admission of personal jurisdiction was implicit in the relief sought, he was deemed estopped from asserting that there was no jurisdiction over him. The order was affirmed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's order authorizing substituted service of summons on the mortgagee and establishing personal jurisdiction.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- jurisdiction -- objection to jurisdiction of person -- waiver and estoppel -- default judgment entered on substituted service; objection that no jurisdiction of person acquired waived by subsequent acts of defendant; defendant estopped from asserting objection.

1. In an action in the Supreme Court, Sullivan County, an order authorizing substituted service of the summons was granted, defendant defaulted and judgment was entered by the clerk in August, 1953. Defendant had personal knowledge of the judgment against him within four months after its entry. Plaintiff moved at the New York County Special Term, in March, 1956, for an order directing certain third-party corporations to turn over on account of the judgment assets owned by defendant. Defendant appeared generally upon that application by an attorney and raised objections going beyond the narrow merits of the application [***2] in supplementary proceedings and asked as affirmative relief that the court order a reference for the purpose of determining the validity of the judgment or that the judgment be set aside and the matter litigated in the Municipal Court of the City of New York. Defendant's application for such affirmative relief was denied and defendant thereafter moved, in April, 1956, at the Sullivan County Special Term to vacate the judgment, asserting that he was not a resident of New York when the substituted service was made. The Sullivan County Special Term properly denied defendant's motion.

2. The New York State Supreme Court is a single judicial entity, and while the judgment was entered in Sullivan County, the New York County Special Term having entertained a proceeding supplementary to execution would have power to deal with the judgment itself upon application of a party in interest. The New York County Special Term was not required to follow the usual practice of severing and sending to the Third Judicial District that part of the affirmative relief sought by defendant addressed to the judgment or the underlying merits of the action unless a party requested that that be done. Defendant [***3] was bound by the procedure he adopted.

3. An objection that no jurisdiction of the person has been acquired may be waived by subsequent acts of the party affected or he may be estopped from asserting the objection.

4. Assuming that the service of process followed due form of law and that the court had before it in proper form proof which would support personal jurisdiction of defendant by substituted service, the objection that no such jurisdiction had been acquired or, otherwise stated, that the facts as proved before the court were not true facts, could be waived. The prior course of conduct or of procedural policy of the party asserting absence of personal jurisdiction may estop its assertion. Both elements existed in the case at bar.

5. If the jurisdictional objection was not deemed to have been waived by resting on knowledge of the entry of judgment, defendant would be deemed to have waived it or to have been estopped from its assertion by the course of proceeding followed by him at the New York County Special Term. To the extent that the application in that court might be deemed to have been made by defendant upon jurisdictional grounds to vacate the judgment, the adverse [***4] decision was binding on defendant against the later motion to vacate it and, in the absence of appeal, had become conclusive against him.

6. To the extent that defendant sought affirmative relief by an order of the Supreme Court directing a trial on the merits in Municipal Court, or by favor of the court in relieving him of default in pleading, in both of which situations admission of jurisdiction of the person lay implicit in the relief sought, defendant would be deemed estopped from asserting that there had not been obtained jurisdiction over his person.

7. Decision did not rest upon a retroactive vesting of personal jurisdiction on the basis of waiver or estoppel, but on the fact there was sufficient valid proof of essential jurisdictional facts presented to the court before the summons went out to justify its taking jurisdiction, and that the course of policy and procedure elected to be followed by defendant foreclosed him from litigating those facts. The facts accepted by the court in taking jurisdiction were no longer left open to dispute. The objections to procedural steps in the entry of judgment were likewise waived by defendant or were without substance.

 

1101 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hotaling v. Hurd


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


4 A.D.2d 339; 164 N.Y.S.2d 955; 1957 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4678



July 24, 1957 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, on the law and the facts, and a final order granted, dismissing the petition, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents, the Director of the Budget of the State of New York and associated individuals, appealed an order from the Supreme Court at Special Term, Albany County (New York), which granted a motion by petitioner, a State Employee, for an order pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act. art. 78 directing respondents to restore the employee to the position of principal statistics clerk following a downward reclassification.


OVERVIEW: The employee's job was reclassified downward from principal statistics clerk, with a civil service grade of G-11, to senior statistics clerk, with a pay grade of G-8. The downward classification was made retroactive to April 1 pursuant to 1954 N.Y. Laws 307. As a result, the employee sought an order directing respondents to restore her to her former position. The trial court found in favor of the employee and held that the reclassification of the employee's position was arbitrary and unlawful. On appeal, the court reversed. The court held that the merits of the administrative decision to classify the employee's position in a lower grade could not be challenged because it was required to accept the reclassification as justified. The employee failed to pursue her administrative remedy by obtaining a review of the Director's decision to reclassify her position. Also, because downgrading was proper and justified, it was not arbitrary simply because similar downgrading did not occur for other civil service positions. Further, the retroactive reclassification was not unconstitutional. The employee had a right to an earned salary, but she did not have a right to hold a public job.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order and granted a final order dismissing the petition.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- reclassification of positions -- petitioner's State job was, pursuant to statute authorizing reclassification, reclassified downward from principal statistics clerk to senior statistics clerk on October 1, 1954, retroactive to April 1, 1954, and placed in grade with maximum lower than petitioner had been receiving -- such reclassification may not be challenged in court, where petitioner failed to pursue remedy before Director of Classification and Compensation Division and Classification and Compensation Appeals Board (L. 1954, ch. 307, § 11).

1. Whether the reclassification downward of petitioner's job in the State Department of Agriculture and Markets from principal statistics [***2] clerk to senior statistics clerk and placement of it in a grade with a lower maximum salary than petitioner had been receiving, was reasonably justified, cannot be challenged in court and is conclusively established against petitioner, where such classification was made by the Director of the Classification and Compensation Division pursuant to chapter 307 of the Laws of 1954 (effective March 30, 1954) and petitioner had the right, which she did not pursue, to review the classification before said director and could have appealed from his decision to the Classification and Compensation Appeals Board before January 1, 1955 (L. 1954, ch. 307, § 11).

2. The failure of the administrative officers charged with the duty of classification to effect a similar downgrading in other departments or bureaus where intervening seniority rights had accrued under the Civil Service Law, was not, as a matter of law, such arbitrary action as would warrant judicial interference.

3. The downward classification, made on October 1, 1954, effective retroactive to April 1, 1954, was not a violation of petitioner's right to be paid the salary, without reduction, after doing the work. Before petitioner occupied [***3] the position or did any work for the period from April 1 to October 1, the statute which permitted retroactive reclassification, including downgrading, had been enacted. Moreover, subdivision 5 of section 8 of chapter 307 of the Laws of 1954 provided that no "incumbent" shall receive "less" than "the gross annual rate of compensation received" by him at a time referable back to April 1.

 

1102 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Kingsley International Pictures Corp. v. Regents of University


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


4 A.D.2d 348; 165 N.Y.S.2d 681; 1957 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4679



July 24, 1957 



DISPOSITION: Determination annulled, with $ 50 costs, and the matter remitted to the license division with a direction to license the film.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner motion picture company sought review of the decision of respondent, the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York, which refused a license for the exhibition of a motion picture film.


OVERVIEW: The motion picture company applied for a license to show "Lady Chatterley's Lover." The license was denied by the board, on the ground that it was immoral, under N.Y. Educ. Law § 122, as modified by N.Y. Educ. Law § 122-a. On appeal, the court reversed. The court held that the definition of "immoral" in N.Y. Educ. Law § 122 violated the Fourteenth Amendment because it left open to discretion in the eye of a censor what constituted immorality under the statute. The court concluded that the addition of other defining words that were similarly open to interpretation in N.Y. Educ. Law § 122-a did not render the standard constitutional and constituted a prior restraint.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the board's denial of a license to the motion picture company.


HEADNOTES

Licenses -- motion pictures -- statutory standard for denial of license for motion picture -- presentation of adultery or similar "immoral" acts "as desirable, acceptable or proper patterns of behavior" (Education Law, § 122-a, subd. 1) not permissible standard under United States Constitution for prior restraint -- license to exhibit motion picture "Lady Chatterley's Lover" unconstitutionally denied.

Subdivision 1 of section 122-a of the Education Law provides that "For the purpose of section one hundred twenty-two of this chapter, the term 'immoral' and the phrase 'of such a character that its exhibition would tend to corrupt morals' shall denote a motion picture film or part thereof,  [***2] the dominant purpose or effect of which is erotic or pornographic; or which portrays acts of sexual immorality, perversion, or lewdness, or which expressly or impliedly presents such acts as desirable, acceptable or proper patterns of behavior." The Board of Regents determined that the entire motion picture "Lady Chatterley's Lover" was immoral on the ground that the picture presents "adultery as a desirable, acceptable and proper pattern of behavior." The standard set up by the statute, namely, the presentation of adultery or similar "immoral" acts "as desirable, acceptable or proper patterns of behavior", is not a permissible standard under the United States Constitution for prior restraint. Nor can the picture be considered "obscene". Accordingly, a license to exhibit the picture was unconstitutionally denied.

 

1103 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lloyd Harbor v. Huntington


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


4 A.D.2d 763; 165 N.Y.S.2d 705; 1957 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4819



July 8, 1957 

 

1104 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Church of Holy Trinity v. Melish


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


4 A.D.2d 256; 164 N.Y.S.2d 843; 1957 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4944



June 24, 1957 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed on the law and the facts, with costs, and judgment directed to be entered in favor of plaintiffs, without costs. Findings of fact, insofar as they may be inconsistent with the opinion herein, are reversed and new findings are made as indicated therein.

Submit orders for settlement on or before 12 o'clock noon on June 26, 1957.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant parishioners challenged the judgment of the Supreme Court, Kings County (New York), which held that an election sanctioned by a church bishop to select a new rector was not lawful. Respondent clergymen challenged the election, claiming that a quorum was not present for the election. The parishioners appealed the judgment.


OVERVIEW: The trial court evaluated the election under N.Y. Relig. Corp. Law § 42 and found that a quorum of the parish was not present for the election. The court disagreed, finding that the civil statute should not have been used to resolve a controversy over an ecclesiastical matter. The court did not adopt the bishop's decision sanctioning the election because that decision was neither pled nor proved by the parishioners. The court determined that the canons of the church included vestrymen in the body of members needed for a quorum and that since 6 of the 11 members of the vestry were present at the meetings in question, that is, two churchwardens and four vestrymen, a majority was present and there was compliance with the governing requirement for a quorum. The six members voted in favor of the rector elected and the election was valid.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment.


HEADNOTES

Religious corporations -- election of rector -- rector of Protestant Episcopal Church validly elected at meeting of Parish vestry attended by 2 churchwardens and 4 vestrymen -- 6 of 11 members of vestry were present and constituted quorum -- Canon 11 (§ 2) of Canons of Protestant Episcopal Church provides that majority of vestry constitutes quorum -- Religious Corporations Law ( § 25) in accord.

1. As a result of action taken at meetings of the Parish [***2] vestry, plaintiff Herman S. Sidener became the rector of the Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn, an unincorporated Protestant Episcopal Church and a subordinate member of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States of America, referred to as the General Church. Defendant William Howard Melish who was the Assistant Minister was discharged at another meeting of the vestry. At the meetings at which action was taken with reference to Dr. Sidener's election, two wardens and four vestrymen were present. The three vestrymen who are defendants in this action were absent. Two offices of vestrymen were vacant. At the meeting at which it was resolved that Mr. Melish's services were terminated, there were in attendance the 2 wardens and the same 4 vestrymen who had attended the two earlier meetings, Dr. Sidener as rector, and two other persons who were purportedly elected to the vacant positions of vestrymen early in the meeting. Since 6 of the 11 members of the vestry were present at the meetings in question, that is, 2 churchwardens and 4 vestrymen, a majority was present and there was compliance with the governing requirement for a quorum. All 6 voted for Dr. Sidener's [***3] election as rector. Accordingly, judgment should be entered in favor of plaintiffs and adjudging that he had been lawfully elected as rector.

2. Section 2 of Canon 11 of the Canons of the General Church provides: "In all cases in which a Canon of the General Convention directs a duty to be performed, or a power to be exercised, by a Standing Committee, or by the Clerical members thereof, or by any other body consisting of several members, a majority of said members, the whole having been duly cited to meet, shall be a quorum; and a majority of the quorum so convened shall be competent to act, unless the contrary is expressly required by the Canon." This section governs as to the matter of a quorum at the meetings of the vestry with regard to the election of a rector. A vestry is included in the expression "by any other body consisting of several members". The fact that General Canon 11 is entitled "Of Standing Committees" and that much of it is concerned with such committees in every diocese, does not require a contrary construction of section 2.

3. This view finds support in section 25 of the Religious Corporations Law. It provides that "No provision of this chapter [The Religious [***4] Corporations Law] authorizes the calling, settlement * * * of a minister, or the fixing or changing of his salary, and a meeting of a church corporation for any such purpose shall be called, held, moderated, conducted, governed * * * not as required by any provision of this chapter but only according to the aforesaid laws and regulations, practice, discipline, rules and usages of the religious denomination or ecclesiastical governing body, if any, with which the church corporation is connected." The quorum provisions of section 42 of the Religious Corporations Law which defendants contend governs as to what constitutes a quorum for a meeting of church vestry, and which would require at least a majority of the vestrymen in addition to the 2 churchwardens, is not applicable to meetings held for the election of a rector.

4. This does not mean that the provisions of section 42 have no useful purpose. They are applicable to all meetings of the vestry insofar as they do not deal with purely ecclesiastical matters.

5. When there is before a civil court for determination a dispute between factions of a religious congregation concerning an ecclesiastical matter, and the congregation in [***5] question is a subordinate member or part of a general church organization in which there are superior ecclesiastical tribunals with a general and ultimate power of control over the whole membership of that general organization, and the questions of discipline, or of faith, or ecclesiastical rule, custom, or law have been decided by the highest of these church judicatories to which the matter has been carried, the legal tribunals must accept such decisions as final and as binding on them, in their application to the case before them. The pronouncement by the Bishop at the institution of Dr. Sidener that there is no valid objection, either ecclesiastical or otherwise to his institution, constituted an ecclesiastical decision which could have been asserted successfully by plaintiffs in this action as having binding effect upon the court. However, the fact of the decision was not pleaded in the supplemental complaint and therefore, even though it was proved at the trial, it may not be considered as determinative of the issue of Dr. Sidener's election. It was never indicated at any time during the trial that plaintiffs relied on the Bishop's pronouncement as binding on the court. No [***6] motion to conform the pleadings to the proof was made, and it does not appear that the Official Referee gave any consideration to that theory.

6. Although the court's decision may not be grounded on the Bishop's pronouncement that Dr. Sidener was properly elected, it may regard the pronouncement as evidence of what the church law is in a situation such as this in the same manner that evidence of the law of another jurisdiction is accepted. As evidence it fortifies the court's independent conclusion that the church law required a quorum of only a majority of the vestry.

 

1105 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Malmud


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


4 A.D.2d 86; 164 N.Y.S.2d 204; 1957 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5255



June 3, 1957 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, motion to dismiss the information denied and respondent required to plead to the information at a term of the Court of Special Sessions at a time to be provided in the order to be entered hereon.

Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state sought review of the decision of the Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York (New York), which sustained defendant's demurrer and dismissed the information charging defendant with failing to comply with the lawful orders and directions given by the bridge and tunnel authority (authority).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with a willful violation of § 3 of article 4 of the rules adopted and promulgated by the authority. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the information against him on the ground that it failed to state a prima facie case of the commission of a crime by him. The court reversed the trial court's decision granting the defendant's motion to dismiss. The court held that the rule was not an unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority in violation of N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1. Provisions of title 3 of article 3 of the Public Authorities Law clearly indicated that the agreements with the bondholders referred to in N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 553 had nothing to do with the regulation of traffic on the project under the authority's control. Although a traffic infraction was not a crime, the rule that defendant allegedly violated was not a provision of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, nor was it a provision of a local law or ordinance. Although the legislature could not delegate to the authority the power to define crimes and to prescribe the punishment therefor, there was no such delegation, however, by § 553.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's order sustaining defendant's demurrer and dismissing the information charging defendant with failing to comply with the lawful orders and directions given by the authority. The court further directed that defendant be required to plead to the information.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- violation of rule of Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority -- motion to dismiss information charging that defendant violated rule of Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority in that he failed to comply with directions given by officer directing traffic at Brooklyn Plaza of Brooklyn Battery Tunnel and refused to proceed into proper traffic lane, improperly granted.

1. Defendant was charged with a willful violation of section 3 of article 4 of the rules adopted and promulgated by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority for the regulation of the use of its project at the Brooklyn Plaza of [***2] the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel, in that he failed to comply with the directions given by a bridge and tunnel officer, then directing traffic at said place, and refused to proceed into the proper traffic lane when directed to do so by the officer. The rule alleged to have been violated requires all persons upon vehicular crossings controlled by the Authority to comply with lawful orders and directions given by employees of the Authority, and was promulgated pursuant to subdivision 5 of section 553 of the Public Authorities Law, which empowers the Authority "To make by-laws for the management and regulation of its affairs, and subject to agreements with bondholders, rules for the regulation of the use of the project and the establishment and collection of tolls thereon", and provides that "Violation of such rules shall be a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not exceeding fifty dollars or by imprisonment for not longer than thirty days, or both". A motion to dismiss the information was improperly granted.

2. The statutory provision does not constitute an unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority (N. Y. Const., art. III, § 1) in that it authorizes the making of rules having [***3] the force of law by the bondholders and the Authority and not in accordance with the independent judgment of the Authority. The statute gives the Authority alone the power to adopt rules and does not require that they shall be approved by the bondholders. The agreements with the bondholders referred to in the statute are those made for the protection of the financial security of the holders of bonds and have nothing to do with the regulation of traffic.

3. Section 553 of the Public Authorities Law is not invalid for the failure of the Legislature to give the Authority standards for its guidance in the exercise of the delegated power to adopt rules. It is that statute enacted by the Legislature and not a rule adopted by the Authority which defines the substantive criminal offense and makes a violation of the Authority's rules a misdemeanor.

4. The Authority has been given the power to adopt rules and regulations reasonably adapted to carry out the purposes and objects for which it was created, and such a grant of power is not an improper delegation of legislative authority.

5. The information, which concededly purports to accuse defendant of the commission of a misdemeanor, was [***4] not properly dismissed on the ground that the violation would constitute, at most, a traffic violation. The rule alleged to have been violated is not a provision of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, nor is it a provision of the local law or ordinance (cf. Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 2, subd. 29). It is a rule promulgated by the Authority acting pursuant to a State statute which provides that a violation of the rule shall be a misdemeanor and which, in any event, prevails over any inconsistent provision of the Vehicle and Traffic Law ( Public Authorities Law, § 571).

6. The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority is not a local authority as defined in the Vehicle and Traffic Law ( § 2, subd. 19), and, consequently, section 54 thereof, which prohibits the passage by local authorities of any ordinance, rule or regulation excluding the operator of a motor vehicle from the free use of the public highways, and provides that any such ordinance, rule or regulation contrary to or inconsistent with the provisions of the Vehicle and Traffic Law shall have no effect, is not applicable.

7. Moreover, section 54 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law provides that nothing therein contained shall impair the [***5] validity or effect of traffic regulations adopted pursuant to law in a city of the first class.

8. The order appealed from is an order of the court dismissing an information on a ground other than the insufficiency of evidence adduced at a trial and is consequently appealable pursuant to the provisions of subdivision 3 of section 518 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

 

1106 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Civil Service Forum v. New York City Transit Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


4 A.D.2d 117; 163 N.Y.S.2d 476; 1957 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5412; 40 L.R.R.M. 2385; 32 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P70,744



May 20, 1957 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, without costs, motions to dismiss the complaint denied, and judgment directed for respondents declaring that the resolutions, election, agreements, and policy statement attacked by appellants are valid, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, union, union members, and hourly paid employees, challenged the order from the Supreme Court at Special Term of Kings County (New York), which dismissed appellant's complaint against respondents, transit authority and union, for a declaratory judgment that a certain collective bargaining agreement entered between respondents was valid.


OVERVIEW: Appellants' complaint alleged that the collective bargaining agreement entered into between respondents was illegal and void because it granted exclusive collective bargaining rights to certain unions. Upon respondents' motion, the trial court dismissed the complaint finding it was insufficient on its face. This appeal followed. The court reversed the order dismissing the complaint but directed a judgment for respondents declaring that the agreement was valid. Under the broad powers granted to the transit authority by N.Y. Pub. Auth. § 1804, the transit authority had the power to enter into the agreement. Thus, the agreement was valid and constituted no abridgement of the statutory or constitutional rights of the hourly paid employees who were not members of certain unions. The agreement did not grant exclusive collective bargaining rights to one union. The agreement preserved the right of all employees to present their grievances, and all employees were treated alike. Based on respondents' implied request, this was a proper case for directing a judgment in accordance with the views expressed herein.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order dismissing appellants' complaint. However, the court directed a judgment for respondents declaring that the collective bargaining agreement at issue herein was valid.


HEADNOTES

Labor unions -- power of Transit Authority to contract for collective bargaining rights -- New York City Transit Authority had power to enter into agreement with Transport Workers Union and Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway & Motor Coach Employees of America, AF of L, concerning wages, hours, working conditions and grievance procedures, and providing for representation of employees by such unions, following election held for selection of labor union by hourly paid employees.

1. The complaint alleged that, pursuant to resolutions of the New York [***2] City Transit Authority, an election was held for the selection by its hourly paid employees of a labor union in each of several groups to be the employees' exclusive representative for presentation and processing of grievances. Transport Workers Union was elected such representative in all the groups except two, in which Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway & Motor Coach Employees of America, AF of L was successful. Effective as of July 1, 1954, the Authority entered into a written agreement with TWU and Amalgamated concerning, among other things, wages, hours, working conditions and grievance procedures, and providing for the exclusive representation of employees by such unions. It is also alleged that, since July 1, 1954, the Authority has implemented and given effect to the resolutions, election and agreements by refusing to permit other unions to represent employees in grievance matters, has refused to discuss wages, hours and working conditions with appellants, and has otherwise discriminated against them and exceeded its statutory authority. The agreement of July 1, 1954, names various unions, including TWU, Amalgamated and appellant Civil Service Forum and [***3] any other union representing hourly paid employees, as parties to the agreement, but provides that the agreement shall inure to the benefit of only such of the named unions or organizations as affix their signatures to and become parties to the agreement. Article VIII regarding grievance procedure recites that TWU and Amalgamated are designated as the exclusive union representatives for presenting and processing employee grievances for hourly paid employees in the named divisions and that "nothing herein shall deprive any individual employee or employees from presenting and processing his or their own grievances through the procedures provided in this Article." Detailed provisions are then made for the processing and settling of grievances which may be presented by any employee personally or through the union elected as the exclusive union representative of employees in that group. It is also provided that nothing contained therein "shall be construed to deny to any employee his rights under § 15 of the New York Civil Rights Law or under applicable Civil Service laws and regulations." The court at Special Term granted motions to dismiss the complaint under subdivision 4 of rule [***4] 106 of the Rules of Civil Practice and stated that there was nothing in the statute creating the Authority, in the Constitution or in any other applicable statute which interdicts the execution of a collective bargaining agreement by the Authority with unions and that, under the broad powers granted the Transit Authority, it could properly enter into the agreement in question. The order is reversed, the motion to dismiss the complaint denied, and judgment should be directed declaring that the resolutions, election, agreements and policy statement attacked by appellants are valid.

2. A proper case of declaratory judgment is presented and it may be that orderly procedure should require the service of answers, and a determination of merits of the controversy thereafter upon appropriate motions. However, the conceded facts are before the court as fully and as completely as though answers had been served and appropriate motions for affirmative judgments had been made. There being no issue of fact, a declaratory judgment may appropriately be directed.

3. The powers conferred upon the Authority by section 1804 of the Public Authorities Law are sufficient to include the power to enter [***5] into the agreement of July 1, 1954. The agreement could be entered into validly under the Authority's power to maintain and operate the transit system, to enter into contracts, and to do all things necessary or convenient for the exercise of the express powers granted.

4. It is unnecessary to determine whether the Authority may legally enter into an exclusive collective bargaining agreement with a union since the agreement here involved is not of that character. The contract could have been signed by any and all the employees' labor organizations which were willing to fulfill its covenants.

5. In matters affecting employees' grievances, the exclusive rights to represent employees is given to those unions which prevailed in the election held for that purpose as is the right to discuss the method of picking jobs within a classification and proposed new work schedules. However, those provisions, or the provision giving such unions the right to be informed of grievances affecting other employees or a basic provision of the contract do not constitute the agreement an exclusive collective bargaining contract for one which the Authority has no power to make. The employee in [***6] every case has the right to present grievances personally, and his rights as a civil service employee are further expressly reserved by the provision that nothing contained therein "shall be construed to deny [him] his rights under § 15 of the New York Civil Rights Law or under applicable Civil Service laws and regulations."

6. The agreement does not violate the employees' constitutional and statutory right to petition for the redress of grievances.

7. There is no statute in this State applicable to government employees supporting the argument that an employee may not be deprived of his right to designate a representative or a minority union to prosecute his grievances.

8. The factual allegations of the complaint, which indicate that the agreement made may have been breached, do not establish the invalidity of the agreement itself.

9. Appellants, who are not parties to the agreement, have no right to attack it for want of consideration or the unilateral right of the Authority to terminate it.

 

1107 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Plachte v. Bancroft, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


3 A.D.2d 437; 161 N.Y.S.2d 892; 1957 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5701



April 30, 1957 



DISPOSITION: Order unanimously affirmed, with $ 20 costs and disbursements to the respondent.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs sought review of a decision from the Supreme Court at Trial Term, New York County (New York), which denied plaintiffs' motion for an order to direct the clerk of court to place the plaintiffs' personal injury action against defendant in a on the trial calendar with other cases placed on the calendar at the same time.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs filed a personal injury action against defendants and subsequently filed a motion for an order to direct the clerk of court to place plaintiff's action on the trial calendar with other cases placed on the calendar at the same time. They contended that New York County, N.Y., Sup. Ct. Trial Term R. V(5), which provided a preference in actions to recover for personal injuries if the injuries result in "permanent or protracted disability", or in wrongful death actions brought under of N.Y. Decedent Estate Law § 130, was unconstitutional. The trial court denied plaintiffs' motion to direct the clerk to set their case on the calendar so that it would be reached for trial, and sustained the validity of Rule V(5). On appeal, the court affirmed because courts have an inherent power over the control of their calendars.
