The court noted that Rule V(5) was an appropriate use of judicial discretion, given the crowed status of court dockets, for which there was no better alternative.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court decision.


HEADNOTES

Trial -- preference -- rule V of New York County Supreme Court Trial Term Rules, which provides for preference in trial of actions, is constitutional.

Rule V of the New York County Supreme Court Trial Term Rules, which provides for preference in the trial of actions, is constitutional.

 

1108 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Hengel v. John Frederici & Sons


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


3 A.D.2d 885; 161 N.Y.S.2d 461; 1957 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5911



April 10, 1957 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Decision and award affirmed, with costs to respondent Special Disability Fund.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, an employer and its carrier, sought review of a decision of respondent Workmen's Compensation Board (New York), which denied reimbursement to appellants from respondent Special Disability Fund under N.Y. Workers' Comp. Law § 15(8), on the sole ground that the claim for reimbursement was not timely filed.


OVERVIEW: Respondent employee suffered an industrial accident in April 1947, and was off work for one week. Thereafter he worked intermittently. The employer had full knowledge of the employee's accident and intermittent work. Disability awards were made and the first award covered a period commencing in August 1947. In June 1949, within 104 weeks from August 1947, appellants filed a claim for reimbursement. On appeal, the court affirmed the Board's decision and awarded costs to the Fund. The court determined the date of disability was fixed at April 1947. Therefore, the court reasoned that the claim for reimbursement was not filed within 104 weeks of the date of disability as required by § 15(8). The court reasoned that there was substantial evidence to support the finding of the Board that the date of disability was April 1947, and that the claim for reimbursement was made more than 104 weeks thereafter and consequently was not timely under § 15(8)(f). The court found that the employer was aware of the disability, and it noted that if the results were deemed unfair, the only remedy was legislative.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision and award, with costs to the Fund.

 

1109 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Excelsior Pictures Corp. v. Regents of University of State of N. Y.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


2 A.D.2d 941; 156 N.Y.S.2d 800; 1956 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3967



November 14, 1956 



DISPOSITION: Determination annulled and the matter remitted to the license division with direction to license the film, with $ 50 costs to petitioner.

 

1110 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


McCall Corp. v. Gerosa


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


2 A.D.2d 358; 156 N.Y.S.2d 111; 1956 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4140



October 23, 1956 



DISPOSITION: Final determination, insofar as it imposes penalties of 5% plus 1% per month for the delay in payment of the tax imposed, unanimously annulled, and the matter is remitted to the comptroller for the exercise of his discretion in conformity with the directions contained in the opinion herein and, in other respects, confirmed. Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Through a proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 78, petitioner taxpayer challenged the final determination of respondent Comptroller of the City of New York (New York), which assessed against the taxpayer a New York City business tax deficiency for a certain period, together with penalties and interest. The final determination was made on a remand from the court that prescribed the appropriate allocation formula for the imposition of the tax.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was assessed a business tax deficiency. After a remand from the court as to the proper allocation formula, the assessment was reduced. The comptroller's final determination not only assessed the deficiency but also imposed penalties at the maximum rate of five percent, plus one percent for each month of delay. The taxpayer challenged the determination, and the court annulled that part of it as to the imposition of the penalties and remitted the matter to the comptroller. The court held that the penalties totalled more than 60 percent of the entire assessment, yet the final determination contained no statement on the basis for the imposition of the penalties. The court concluded that it could evaluate the propriety of the comptroller's determination only from the reasons that he gave. However, on the record, the court could not determine what consideration, if any, was given to the taxpayer's protest with respect to the comptroller's refusal to remit any part of the penalties. If an appropriate protest was duly made, the taxpayer was entitled to be heard and the comptroller should state the reason for his decision that the delay in payment was not excusable.


OUTCOME: The court annulled that part of the comptroller's final determination that imposed penalties on the tax assessment against the taxpayer. The court remitted the matter to the comptroller for the exercise of his discretion in hearing the taxpayer's protest of the imposition of the penalties, and directed the comptroller to state the basis or reason for the imposition of any penalties.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- New York City general business tax -- remission of penalties -- judicial review of administrative discretion -- there was express statutory provision for review by courts of final determination by comptroller of City of New York assessing general business tax deficiency; where comptroller's final determination stated no  [***2] reason for imposing penalties on taxpayer at statutory maximum rate despite taxpayer's due protest thereto, and for not exercising his statutory discretion to remit such penalties "if satisfied that the delay was excusable", that portion of final determination which imposed such penalties was annulled and matter remitted to comptroller for exercise of his discretion.

1. The final determination by the comptroller of the City of New York, assessing an alleged deficiency in the city's general business and financial tax, imposed penalties at the statutory maximum rates of 5% plus 1% for each month of delay, and totalling more than 60% of the entire sum assessed against the taxpayer. The final determination contained no statement or reason for the imposition of such penalties, although the comptroller, "if satisfied that the delay was excusable" was empowered to "remit all or any part of such penalty" (General City Law, art. 2-B, § 24-a [§ 13, subd. a]; Administrative Code of City of New York, §§ R41-14.0, RR41-14.0), and "in his discretion, to remit penalties" (Administrative Code, § RR41-11.0), and although the taxpayer had sought remission of the penalties and protested with [***3] respect thereto. In a proceeding to review the comptroller's determination, so much of said determination as imposed such penalties was annulled and the matter remitted to the comptroller for the exercise of his discretion.

2. There was express statutory provision (General City Law, art. 2-B, § 24-a [§§ 6, 7]) for refund of any "penalty erroneously, illegally or unconstitutionally collected" by the comptroller, and the statute further provided that the comptroller's determinations "shall be reviewable for error, illegality, unconstitutionality or any other reason whatsoever" by proceedings under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act.

3. Failure to state the basis for the rejection of the taxpayer's protest prevented the taxpayer from deciding whether there was merit to his grievance, and impeded the court in its review. The court was not required to speculate as to the reason for the administrative ruling and although it did not hold that the comptroller abused his discretion in refusing to remit part or all of the penalties imposed, it could not determine upon the record what consideration, if any, was given to the protests.

 

1111 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Trio Distributor Corp. v. Albany


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


2 A.D.2d 326; 156 N.Y.S.2d 912; 1956 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4366



September 24, 1956 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed on the law and the facts and complaint dismissed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city sought review of an order by the Supreme Court, Trial Term, Albany County (New York) in favor of plaintiff vendor.


OVERVIEW: A city ordinance required vendors of products from vehicles in the public streets, around which vehicles children gathered for the purpose of making purchases, to be accompanied by an attendant whose sole duty was to protect children from the hazards of street vehicle traffic by maintaining a lookout and warning children. The court found that the ordinance was within the power of the city to enact for the safety and welfare of its inhabitants. The court concluded that the ordinance was reasonable as applied to plaintiff, a vendor of ice cream from vehicles on city streets. The failure of the ordinance to specify in minute detail the duties of an adult guard on a public street did not make the regulation invalid in respect of adequate standards. Neither did the ordinance prohibit plaintiff ice cream vendor's business. The court dismissed the vendor's complaint, which attacked the ordinance as unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court and dismissed the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- ordinances -- ordinance of city requiring vendors of products from vehicles in public streets, around which vehicles children gathered, to be accompanied by attendant whose duty was to protect children from hazard of street traffic, was reasonable and constitutional.

An ordinance of the City of Albany required vendors of products from vehicles in the public streets, around which vehicles children gathered for the purpose of making purchases, to be accompanied by an attendant whose sole duty was to protect children from the hazards of street vehicle traffic by maintaining a lookout and warning children. Such ordinance was within the power of the city to enact under section 30 of the Second Class Cities Law, which authorizes the common council of a city to enact ordinances for the safety and welfare of its inhabitants. The ordinance [***2] was reasonable as applied to plaintiff, a vendor of ice cream from vehicles on city streets. The failure of the ordinance to specify in minute detail the duties of an adult guard on a public street did not make the regulation invalid in respect of adequate standards. Neither did the ordinance prohibit plaintiff ice cream vendor's business. The complaint in this action attacking such ordinance as unconstitutional should be dismissed.

 

1112 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Cutler v. Herman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


2 A.D.2d 782; 154 N.Y.S.2d 576; 1956 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4568



July 23, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners sought review of a decision of the town board (New York), which denied an application for consent to a petition for the annexation of certain territory.


OVERVIEW: The petitioner brought a proceeding to review a determination of the town board, which denied an application for the consent by the town board to a petition for the annexation of certain territory. The court annulled the determination and the board was directed to execute their consent to the petition within 30 days after the entry of the order hereon. There was no basis in the record for such determination and the court was of the opinion that it was sufficiently established that the signers of the petition were properly qualified and sufficient in number and with respect to ownership of property within the territory, as required by the statute.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the decision of the town board and ordered it to give consent to the annexation petition.

 

1113 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


City Title Ins. Co. v. Orgel


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


2 A.D.2d 250; 154 N.Y.S.2d 751; 1956 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4570



July 18, 1956 



DISPOSITION: Order entered March 19, 1955 modified by striking therefrom the second and third ordering paragraphs, and by substituting in lieu thereof the following: "Ordered, that on such re-hearing and after full consideration of all the papers before the court, and due deliberation thereon, respondent's motion to dismiss the [***2] petition herein is granted, and it is further". As so modified, order, insofar as appealed from, unanimously affirmed, with $ 10 costs and disbursements to appellant.

Appeal from order entered June 9, 1954 dismissed, without costs.

Order entered April 9, 1954 unanimously affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city register sought review of three orders by the Supreme Court at Special Term, Kings County (New York), in an N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding. Order No. 1 granted leave to intervene. Order No. 2 directed the city register to record an instrument upon payment of a mortgage tax and denied its motion to dismiss. Order No. 3 granted the city register's motion for a rehearing, adhered to an original decision, and denied reargument.


OVERVIEW: The petition sought a determination that the correct amount of tax on a certain instrument which respondent had presented to the city register for recording was a certain amount. The city register had refused to record the instrument unless a higher amount was paid as mortgage tax. The instrument in question had reference to a mortgage on certain real property. An individual was the mortgagor and the intervenor was the mortgagee. When the principal debt had been reduced, the intervenor advanced to the mortgagor, upon her request, an additional sum of money. The court found that there was an intention to amend the mortgage so as to increase the amount of the secured indebtedness and to render the mortgage an open-end mortgage under which all loans by the mortgagee to the mortgagor or subsequent owner of the mortgaged premises would be secured by the mortgage. The court found that the proper interpretation of relevant statutory law required a tax on the difference between the amount of the unpaid balance of the original indebtedness and the stated possible maximum amount.


OUTCOME: The court modified trial court order No. 3 by granting respondent's motion to dismiss the petition. As modified, trial court order No. 3 was affirmed. The court dismissed the appeal from trial court order No. 2. The court affirmed trial court order No. 1.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- recording of mortgage -- review -- proceeding to determine correct amount of tax on mortgage presented for recording must be brought first before State Tax Commission -- if court had present jurisdiction to determine amount of tax, it would determine that mortgage recording tax must be paid on difference between unpaid balance of original indebtedness and stated possible maximum under readvance agreement, even though total amount readvanced did not reach maximum.

1. A proceeding to determine the correct amount of tax on a mortgage presented for recording must be first brought before the State Tax Commission (Tax Law, § 251; Civ. Prac. Act, § 1285, subd. 4). The review procedure provided in the Tax Law ( § 251) is not inadequate. Accordingly, the parties are relegated to the proceeding under the Tax Law.

2. A mortgage to secure the principal indebtedness of $  [***3] 7,000 was made and recorded in 1944. At a time when the principal debt had been reduced to $ 3,298.71, the mortgagee advanced to the mortgagor an additional $ 2,701.29 and at the same time they entered into an agreement providing that the maximum amount for which the mortgage could stand as security by virtue of the readvance instrument was $ 7,000. The provisions of sections 250, 253, 255 and 256 of the Tax Law, when read together, require a tax on the difference between the amount of the unpaid balance of the original indebtedness ($ 3,298.71) and the stated possible maximum ($ 7,000) or $ 3,701.29. Accordingly, if the court had present jurisdiction to determine the controversy on its merits, it would determine that the correct tax base would be $ 3,701.29, and the tax, accordingly, would be $ 18.50. With the $ 6 recording fee, the correct amount which the city register of the City of New York would be entitled to require for recording the instrument would be $ 24.50.

 

1114 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Swanson v. Fitzsimmons


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


2 A.D.2d 235; 153 N.Y.S.2d 772; 1956 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4631



July 11, 1956 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed on the law, without costs, and writ sustained without prejudice to the right of the officials of the demanding State to renew the application to the Governor of this State.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator challenged an order of the County Court of Jefferson County (New York) that dismissed a writ of habeas corpus and directed that relator be turned over to the duly authorized officer of the State of Minnesota on a warrant of extradition under N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 829. The opposing party was respondent, county sheriff.


OVERVIEW: In the underlying extradition papers, no claim was made that relator had committed a crime in Minnesota and fled. Instead, the request plainly stated that relator had committed acts in New York that intentionally resulted in the crime of abandonment of his minor child in Minnesota. There were two kinds of extradition. N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 829 provided for extradition of persons who were charged with crimes in another state and who fled from justice and the governor and courts had limited review. N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 834 provided for extradition of persons of persons who had not fled from justice and were not in the demanding state at the time of the commission of the alleged crime. The governor was given permissive power to grant the request. Here, the extradition request was made under N.Y. Code Crim. Proc. § 829 and the Governor of New York mistakenly issued a fugitive warrant under that section. There was no evidence that the Governor exercised any discretion in reviewing the request. The court held that relator could not be transported to Minnesota as a person who committed a crime in Minnesota and fled from justice. The court reversed the order.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order and sustained the writ without prejudice to the rights of the officials of the demanding state, Minnesota, to renew the application for extradition to the Governor of New York.


HEADNOTES

Extradition -- mandatory and permissive extradition -- abandonment of children -- request from Minnesota for extradition of relator showed, not that he had fled from justice, but that he had committed acts in New York which resulted in abandonment of his minor children in Minnesota; warrant of arrest issued thereon by New York Governor showed that he had deemed warrant mandatory and had not considered discretion; writ of habeas corpus sustained, without prejudice to renewal of extradition application by Minnesota.

1. The Uniform Criminal Extradition Act (Code Crim. Pro., §§ 827-860) provides (a) for mandatory extradition of a fugitive from justice (§ 829),  [***2] pursuant to the requirements of the United States Constitution (art. IV, § 2, 2d par.) and the United States Code (tit. 18, §§ 3182, 3194), and (b) for permissive extradition of a person who has not fled from justice and who was not, at the time of the commission of the alleged crime, in the State which demands his surrender, but who is charged with committing an act, in this State or in a third State, intentionally resulting in a crime in the demanding State, when the act "would be punishable by the laws of this state" (Code Crim. Pro., § 834). In the case of permissive extradition, the warrant issued by the Governor of New York State "must substantially recite the facts necessary to the validity of its issuance" (Code Crim. Pro., § 835). Also, in such case, the Governor of New York State has discretionary power to make surrender conditional on an agreement by the executive authority of the demanding State that the person so surrendered will be accorded certain rights as set forth in said section 834.

2. In this case, the request from the Governor of Minnesota and the underlying papers made no claim that relator had committed a crime in Minnesota and fled therefrom; in fact,  [***3] the request stated that he had committed acts in New York State which intentionally resulted in the crime of abandonment of his minor child in Minnesota. Extradition was therefore merely permissive and discretionary; but the warrant of arrest issued by the Governor of New York State failed to recite the facts necessary to its validity and failed to show that he had considered the request or had exercised any discretion, and on the contrary showed that he had treated the request as one upon which he was mandated to issue a warrant of arrest. Accordingly, a writ of habeas corpus should be sustained, without prejudice to the right of the demanding State to renew its application to the Governor of New York State.

 

1115 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


A. S. Rampell, Inc. v. Hyster Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


2 A.D.2d 739; 153 N.Y.S.2d 176; 1956 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4754



July 3, 1956 



DISPOSITION: Order modified in accordance with memorandum and, as so modified, affirmed. Settle order on notice.

 

1116 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Four Maple Drive Realty Corp. v. Abrams


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


2 A.D.2d 753; 153 N.Y.S.2d 747; 1956 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4801



July 2, 1956 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landlord sought review of a decision of a New York trial court which dismissed its petition brought under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 challenging the order of respondent State Rent Administrator that upheld the determination of local rent administrator denying the landlord's application for an adjustment of maximum rents pursuant to § 4 of the State Residential Rent Law.


OVERVIEW: The landlord asserted in its application that it was entitled to a net 6 percent return of the assessed valuation of its rental property. The local rent administrator held that the ratio which such assessed valuation bore to the full valuation as determined by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment to be applied was 100%. On appeal, the court affirmed, holding that if the statute and regulation were unconstitutional, substantial injustice would be inflicted upon a landlord if he were required to obtain a judgment declaring them unconstitutional in an action instituted solely for that purpose before he would be entitled to an order of the administrator adjusting the maximum rents on a basis that the statute and regulation were unconstitutional. With the issue of unconstitutionality squarely raised in the protest and in the petition, the court considered the proceeding as one in the nature of mandamus.


OUTCOME: The order upholding the denial of the landlord's application for an adjustment of maximum rents was affirmed.

 

1117 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lerner v. Casey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


2 A.D.2d 1; 154 N.Y.S.2d 461; 1956 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4853



June 25, 1956 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with $ 50 costs and disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employee challenged an order of the Supreme Court in Kings County (New York), which granted respondent employers' motion to dismiss the employee's action that challenged his dismissal under the Security Risk Law (law), 1951 N.Y. Laws ch. 233.


OVERVIEW: The employee worked as a conductor in the New York subway system and was subject to the provisions of the state civil service law. When asked questions regarding his political affiliations, the employee asserted his rights under the Fifth Amendment. After his suspension for failure to answer the questions, the employee was given a chance to show why he should have been reinstated. The employee failed to give any evidence and he was terminated. The employee's action seeking reinstatement was dismissed and the court affirmed that decision. The court held that the law was constitutional because it bore a substantial relation to the permitted objective without unreasonably interfering with personal rights. The court found that the law provided the employee with an opportunity to present evidence and a procedure for review of his termination. The court noted that the employee did not have an unqualified right to work for the state on his own terms. The employee was not discharged without evidence because court was required to accept the employee's claim that the answers to the questions propounded might have incriminated him.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision to dismiss the employee's claim against the employer, which challenged his dismissal for failing to answer questions about his political affiliations.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- removal -- subway conductor who invoked constitutional privilege against self incrimination and refused to answer questions as to whether he was Communist party member was properly discharged as security risk by New York City Transit Authority pursuant to State Security Risk Law (L. 1951, ch. 233).

1. Appellant, employed by respondent New York City Transit Authority as a conductor on the city subway system, upon three separate occasions declined, in reliance upon his constitutional privilege against self incrimination, to answer under oath questions by a deputy commissioner of investigation of the city concerning his political affiliations, particularly whether he was a member of [***2] the Communist party. Thereafter, pursuant to the State Security Risk Law (L. 1951, ch. 233), the Transit Authority suspended him by resolution reciting that reasonable grounds existed for the belief that, because of his doubtful trust and reliability, his employment as a conductor would endanger the security and defense of the nation and State. Subsequently the Transit Authority discharged appellant by a similar resolution further reciting that he had not within 30 days after his suspension submitted statements, as provided by the Security Risk Law, to show why he should be restored to duty. In a proceeding brought by him under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act to secure his reinstatement, the petition was properly dismissed.

2. The Transit Authority, an agency created by the State and performing a governmental function, was subject to the provisions of the Security Risk Law. The Civil Service Commission was required by the statute to make a determination, reviewable by the courts, that an agency or position affected the security of the State or nation. Such security agency, charged with the duty of determining whether an employee was of doubtful trust and reliability from [***3] a security standpoint, properly inquired into such matters, and was empowered to find that the employee's refusal to answer such inquiries, in and of itself, furnished reasonable grounds for the belief that he was not a good security risk, although the statute (§ 5) made no specific reference to a refusal to answer. Appellant's membership in the Communist party may not be inferred from his assertion of privilege against self incrimination, but his statement that answers to the questions propounded might have tended to incriminate him must be accepted as truthful.

3. It cannot be said that there is no presumption of constitutionality of a statute duly enacted by a State, although where rights protected by the First Amendment to the Federal Constitution are involved, the evil which the Legislature sought to remedy will be more closely scrutinized before the courts sustain the validity of legislation impinging on those rights than in a case involving property rights protected only by the Fourteenth Amendment.

4. The subject of the legislation here involved was one on which the Legislature was permitted to act.

5. The Security Risk Law bore a real and substantial relation to the permitted [***4] objective without unreasonably interfering with personal rights. There was no arbitrary exclusion of an employee irrespective of his guilty knowledge or intent, remoteness in time, or mistake or inadvertence, but a finding, after an opportunity had been given him to submit statements or affidavits giving reasons for reinstatement, that reasonable grounds existed for believing him to be a security risk.

6. Provisions of the Civil Service Law ( § 22) governing the procedure to be followed in removals for misconduct or incompetency, were inapplicable (Civil Service Law, § 22, subd. 3).

 

1118 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Capitol Enterprises, Inc. v. Regents of University of State


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


1 A.D.2d 990; 149 N.Y.S.2d 920; 1956 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5806



April 5, 1956 - Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant film company challenged the decision from respondent, the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York, which sustained the refusal of its motion picture division to license a film deemed "indecent" under N.Y. Educ. Law § 122. The film company contended that the decision was an unconstitutional prior restraint.


OVERVIEW: The film in question was a biological film showing a live human birth. On appeal, the court annulled the decision of the Board of Regents. The statute in question required the division to license a film unless it fell into several categories, including being indecent or obscene. Under recent United States Supreme Court case law, the court reasoned that the film was not indecent and the refusal of the license was a prior restraint. While the court would not go as far as to say that the denial of a license under similar circumstances was always a prior restraint, the division had a heavy burden of justifying the denial.


OUTCOME: The determination of the Board of Regents was annulled and the matter remitted with directions to issue a license.

 

1119 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Mercury Machine Importing Corp. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


1 A.D.2d 337; 149 N.Y.S.2d 900; 1956 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5847



March 29, 1956 



DISPOSITION: Judgment and order unanimously reversed, with costs to the appellant, and the motion to dismiss the complaint denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff corporation sought review of an order from the Supreme Court at Special Term in New York County (New York), which granted defendant city's motion to dismiss plaintiff's plenary action to recover from defendant the money that plaintiff had erroneously paid defendant in taxes.


OVERVIEW: The corporation had erroneously paid the city certain taxes because of its accountant unawareness that transactions in foreign commerce were not subject to a city tax. The comptroller had denied the corporation's application for a refund. The corporation, instead of appealing the comptroller's denial, had filed a plenary action to recover the money that it had erroneously paid in taxes. The lower court had granted the city's motion to dismiss the corporation's plenary action, and the corporation appealed. The court issued a decision that denied the city's motion to dismiss. The fact that the corporation chose not to seek a review of the comptroller's decision pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 78 did not bar the corporation from seeking its claim against the city. Also, the city had no greater right than an individual to retain moneys to which it was not rightfully entitled. Further, the comptroller's decision did not constitute as a bar to the plenary action because there was no determination on the merits. Finally, the court held that in a plenary lawsuit for mistake a distinction between a mistake of law and mistake of fact was wholly immaterial.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower court's order, and denied the city's motion to dismiss the taxpayer's plenary action to recover from the city the money that the taxpayer had erroneously paid the city in taxes.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- plenary action against municipality for tax refund -- corporation which was not subject to municipal business tax paid such tax by mistake of law, and was denied refund by city comptroller who had no statutory authority to make refund of tax not paid under protest; taxpayer is not limited to "exclusive" remedy of fruitless proceeding under article 78 of Civil Practice Act to review comptroller's denial within thirty days (Administrative Code of City of New York, §§ B46-7.0, B46-9.0), but may maintain plenary action against city for unjust enrichment.

1. A corporation which imported machines in foreign commerce, paid the New York City [***2] general business tax on gross receipts (Administrative Code of City of New York, § B46-1.0 et seq.) through a mistake of law, since its accountant was unaware that its transactions were not subject to the tax. Upon application made a year later, the comptroller refused to make a refund. He had no authority to make a refund, since the statute authorized refunds of taxes paid "under protest" (Administrative Code, § B46-7.0) and his regulations (art. 122) dispensed with the necessity for a protest in cases of "pure mistake of fact" only. A review proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act (Administrative Code, § B46-7.0) would have been ineffectual, since an official cannot be directed to perform an act beyond the powers delegated to him. Prescribed procedures for review are not exclusive when the jurisdiction of the taxing officer is challenged or where the statute by its own terms does not apply in a given case. Accordingly, the taxpayer may maintain this plenary action against the City of New York to recover the money, on the ground of unjust enrichment.

2. A governmental unit has no greater right than an individual to retain moneys to which it is not entitled.

 [***3] 3. The lack of a protest at the time of the mistaken payment was not a waiver.

4. If, as the comptroller asserts, the court should rule that protests are necessary in all cases in order to give the comptroller sufficient notice for making budgetary adjustments, then taxpayers would file protests as a matter of course in all cases and thus throw the budget into greater, rather than less, confusion.

5. The taxpayer's initial choice of the administrative remedy -- an application to the comptroller for a refund -- does not bar him from a plenary action where the comptroller had no power to consider the refund application on the merits.

6. The comptroller's denial of the application for a refund for want of jurisdiction or for mistake in the form of remedy chosen does not constitute res judicata of this plenary action.

7. Relief may not be denied in a plenary action merely because the mistake is one of law rather than one of fact. (Civ. Prac. Act, § 112-f.)

 

1120 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Murtha v. Monaghan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


1 A.D.2d 178; 148 N.Y.S.2d 615; 1956 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6350



February 14, 1956 



DISPOSITION: Order unanimously reversed, with $ 20 costs and disbursements to the appellant, and the petition dismissed. Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Commissioner of the Harness Racing Commission of the State of New York sought review of an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term in New York County (New York), which directed the commissioner to issue to respondent license applicant a license to act as a mutuel clerk.


OVERVIEW: The applicant filed a license to act as a mutuel clerk. When the commissioner denied such license, the applicant sought review. The trial court entered an order directing the commissioner to issue the license, and the commissioner sought review. Under N.Y. Unconsol. Law § 7 (1926), the commissioner was authorized to issue licenses to applicants desiring to hold running races or steeple chases. The court found that the commissioner was given permissive power to license drivers and other persons participating in the race that met the commissioner's prescribed rules, pursuant to N.Y. Unconsol. Law § 8 (1953). The court determined that the commissioner was prohibited from issuing a license to any public employee unless he earned less than $ 5,000 per year. The court found that, because the applicant was such an employee, the commissioner was not authorized to issue him a license. The court reversed the order of the trial court and dismissed the applicant's petition.


OUTCOME: The court reversed an order of the trial court, which directed the commissioner to issue to the applicant a license to act as a mutuel clerk. The court dismissed the applicant's petition.


HEADNOTES

Horse racing -- harness racing -- prohibition against licensing of public employees -- statutory construction -- (1) school teacher whose annual compensation as such public employee exceeded $ 5,000 was properly denied license by State Harness Racing Commission to accept employment by licensed pari-mutuel harness raceway as mutuel clerk (Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law, § 63, subd. 1, par. [c]; subd. 6) -- (2) ban of section 63 as to "public employee" (subd. 1, par. [c]; L. 1954, ch. 514) was removed as to local public employees who earned less than $ 5,000 and who were authorized by their local governing board (subd. 6; L. 1954, ch. 515); if latter enactment  [***2] denies equal protection of laws, this employee is not aggrieved since prior enactment (L. 1954, ch. 514) bars him -- (3) this public employee was employed by raceway prior to 1954 as mutuel clerk, but was not qualified to receive such license since his public compensation exceeded $ 5,000; hence he was not benefited by subdivision 7 of section 63 (L. 1955, ch. 815), insofar as such subdivision removed ban against licenses for employees who were properly qualified before 1954.

1. A school teacher whose compensation as such "public employee of a political subdivision" was more than $ 5,000 per annum, and whose governing board or local legislative body had not passed any resolution or ordinance authorizing him to accept employment from a corporation or association or firm licensed by the State Harness Racing Commission to conduct pari-mutuel racing, was properly refused a license by the commission to serve as a mutuel clerk (Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law, § 41-a; § 63, subd. 1, par. [c]; § 63, subd. 6 [L. 1940, ch. 254; L. 1953, ch. 391, § 8; L. 1954, chs. 514, 515]).

2. The school teacher, as a public employee, is barred from harness racing employment by paragraph (c) of subdivision [***3] 1 of section 63 (L. 1954, ch. 514). The bar of that paragraph was removed as to local public employees whose compensation was less than $ 5,000 per annum and who had authorization from their governing board or legislative body (subd. 6, added by L. 1954, ch. 515). The school teacher urges that the latter enactment (subd. 6) unconstitutionally fails to provide equal protection of the laws; but, if so, the prior enactment (subd. 1, par. [c]) stands and prohibits his employment. Thus he is not a person aggrieved by subdivision 6 and therefore he lacks the standing to challenge its constitutionality.

3. Section 63 of the Pari-Mutuel Revenue Law, in another paragraph (subd. 1, par. [a]; L. 1954, ch. 514), originally completely prohibited any "public officer, public employee or party officer" from holding any license from the State Racing Commission or from the State Harness Racing Commission; and the bar of said paragraph was subsequently removed as to any such persons who were qualified to hold such a license on or prior to April 6, 1954 (§ 63, subd. 7; L. 1955, ch. 815). A reading of section 41-a and all of section 63, and a consideration of the legislative history of horse [***4] racing and of harness racing, shows that subdivision 7 was intended to have two effects: one, to remove the bar as to such owners and drivers and other "participants" who were qualified on or before April 6, 1954, as distinguished from "employees"; and two, to make sure that any "employees" as to whom the commission had not theretofore exercised its power to require a license should not be prohibited from getting a license if they were qualified to receive one before April 6, 1954. The school teacher, although he had actually been employed prior to 1954 as a mutuel clerk by a licensed harness racing corporation or association, was not qualified to receive such an employee's license (under § 63, subd. 1, par. [c]; subd. 6); hence he was not benefited by the enactment in 1955 of subdivision 7 of section 63.

 

1121 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rawe v. State Bd. of Equalization & Assessments


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


1 A.D.2d 49; 147 N.Y.S.2d 297; 1955 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3705



December 23, 1955 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.

Application for stay heretofore made denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant county board of equalization sought review of a decision by the Supreme Court at Special Term, Albany County (New York), which dismissed the petition in a proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 78 for an order in the nature of prohibition.


OVERVIEW: The county board filed an action to obtain an order (1) prohibiting respondent, the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, from reviewing the equalization rates established for the board's county, and (2) prohibiting a mayor and a supervisor from continuing to seek a review of the rates. The Special Term dismissed the petition. The mayor and the supervisor, being dissatisfied with the rates, filed complaints with the State Board, pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law § 176-a, claiming that the equalization rates were unjust and inequitable and requesting that they be annulled and new rates be fixed. Neither the mayor nor supervisor obtained the consent of any other public official to the filing of the complaints. The county board argued that a review pursuant to § 176-a was not available to the mayor and the supervisor and that the appeal provision contained in the special act creating the county board was the only method available. The court disagreed and affirmed the decision, finding that the legislature intended to have § 176-a apply to rates of equalization fixed by the county board.


OUTCOME: The decision was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- assessments -- county equalization rates -- review -- (1) State Board of Equalization and Assessment has jurisdiction of application by Mayor of Buffalo and supervisor of Town of Tonawanda to review equalization rates fixed by Erie County Board of Equalization; Tax Law ( § 176-a) not impliedly repealed by special Erie County act -- (2) although Tax Law ( § 176-a) provided that review application be filed "within ten days after the delivery of the tax-roll to the collector", earlier filing was not untimely -- (3) provision that "legislature shall prescribe the manner by which such ratio shall be determined" (N. Y. Const., art. VIII, § 10) inapplicable; it refers to State, not county, equalization rates.

1. The Tax Law ( § 176-a, added by L. 1915, ch. 317) empowered the State Tax Commission -- which power has been temporarily transferred [***2] to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment -- "on complaint to review the equalization fixed by the board of supervisors of any county or other lawfully constituted authority." The words "on complaint" and "or other lawfully constituted authority" were much broader than the existing language of section 175 of the Tax Law which provided for appeals by certain officials only and from equalizations fixed by boards of supervisors only. The Legislature did not intend to repeal such broadening when it specially created an Erie County Board of Equalization and provided that its decisions might be appealed to the State Tax Commission by a Mayor with the consent of a majority of the city councilmen or by a town supervisor with the consent of a majority of the town board (L. 1919, ch. 304, § 6). Such appeal provisions in such special act did not repeal by implication the additional procedure for review provided by section 176-a of the Tax Law. Under section 176-a, any aggrieved taxpayer or the chief executive officer of any affected tax district may seek review. Accordingly, the State Board of Equalization and Assessment has jurisdiction of a complaint by the Mayor of Buffalo and [***3] by the supervisor of the Town of Tonawanda for review of equalization rates established for Erie County for 1955 by the Erie County Board of Equalization.

2. The Tax Law ( § 176-a), as it read at the time, provided that a complaint for review shall be filed with the State Tax Commission "within ten days after the delivery of the tax-roll to the collector." In this case the Erie County Board of Equalization fixed its rates for 1955 on October 29, 1954, and the County Board of Supervisors then adopted its budget on November 23, 1954, but, owing to clerical work, the tax roll for 1955 was not delivered until January 1, 1955. Meantime, the Mayor and supervisor had filed their complaint for review on November 26, 1954. As a practical matter, such filing was timely. The statute merely fixed a time limitation beyond which a complaint might not be filed.

3. The State equalization provisions of the State Constitution (art. VIII, § 10) are meant for the purpose of determining average full real estate valuation for the operations of constitutional tax limitations, and not for county equalization rates; hence a provision in that section that "The legislature shall prescribe the manner by [***4] which such ratio shall be determined" does not apply to the review in this case.

 

1122 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Vanderbilt v. Vanderbilt


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


1 A.D.2d 3; 147 N.Y.S.2d 125; 1955 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3791



December 20, 1955 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs. Settle order on notice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant wife sought review of an order from the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which adjudged that a Nevada decree of divorce in favor of appellant husband was a bar to the wife's cause of action for a separation.


OVERVIEW: The wife challenged an order determining that a Nevada decree of divorce in favor of the husband was a bar to a cause of action for a separation and the husband challenged a judgment awarding the wife maintenance and counsel fees and costs. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment and held that the wife, in addition to having established residence in New York before the divorce, and the constructive matrimonial domicile, had also sufficiently established contacts with New York to merit relief under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 1170-b.


OUTCOME: An order of the lower court in a divorce action involving the husband and the wife was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Husband and wife -- maintenance of wife where divorce previously granted on nonpersonal jurisdiction -- (1) in wife's action for separation, relief was denied under Civil Practice Act ( § 1161) because of existence of valid prior Nevada divorce obtained without personal jurisdiction over wife, and alternative relief was granted under section 1170-b of Civil Practice Act, authorizing direction for  [***2] maintenance of wife "as justice may require" in such circumstances; judgment affirmed -- (2) wife, who has never before obtained judicial provision for support, may by virtue of section 1170-b maintain action resulting in direction for maintenance, following divorce in action by husband in which she was not served personally within jurisdiction and in which she did not appear or defend -- (3) section 1170-b constitutional; statute is legislative extension of concept of "divisible divorce" -- (4) wronged wife brought constructive marital domicile to New York when she moved here while still undivorced -- (5) New York law determinative of wife's marital status -- (6) section 1170-b does not, by necessary implication, require matrimonial domicile in New York as condition to relief -- (7) contention that section 1170-b was designed to assist "New York wife" not valid -- (8) New York remedies not indiscriminately available to migrant spouses -- (9) limitations in application of statute considered; wife sufficiently established marital contacts with New York -- (10) before maintenance may be ordered under section 1170-b, wife must establish elements of standard matrimonial causes of action  [***3] -- (11) Nevada divorce valid -- (12) husband did not subject himself to in personam judgment after special appearance, by intercession in action (Civ. Prac. Act, § 237-a) -- (13) allowances for maintenance and counsel fees adequate.

1. In a wife's action for a separation, relief was denied under section 1161 of the Civil Practice Act because of the existence of a valid prior decree of divorce in favor of defendant husband, obtained in Nevada without personal jurisdiction over the wife, and alternative relief was granted under section 1170-b of the Civil Practice Act which authorizes a court in a matrimonial action to direct maintenance for a wife "as justice may require" where the court is barred from granting a divorce, separation or annulment by reason of the prior granting of a judgment or decree for divorce or annulment in an action in which personal jurisdiction was not obtained over the wife. The judgment was affirmed.

2. By virtue of section 1170-b, a wife, who has never before obtained judicial provision for her support, may maintain an action resulting in a direction for maintenance, following a divorce in an action brought by the husband and in which she was not served [***4] personally within the jurisdiction and in which she did not appear or defend.

3. Section 1170-b of the Civil Practice Act is constitutional. That statute is a legislative extension of the judicial concept that a divorce based on constructive service alone is divisible; that the marital status between the parties may be severed, but that, despite such severance, the husband's economic marital obligation may survive.

4. The wife became a resident of New York before the husband obtained the Nevada decree of divorce in his favor. As a wronged wife, still undivorced, the wife brought the marital domicile with her, even if it were only a constructive matrimonial domicile.

5. Where the wife was divorced in Nevada by virtue of constructive service alone while she was a wife resident in New York, New York law would determine her marital status, whether "unitary" or "divisible".

6. Section 1170-b of the Civil Practice Act does not, by necessary implication, require a matrimonial domicile in New York as a condition to relief under it.

7. Defendant husband contended that the statute was designed to assist only a "New York wife". But, given the concept of "divisible divorce", plaintiff was [***5] still a wife for the purpose of obtaining enforcement of the husband's in personam financial obligations. The wife was in New York and had been there for the required one year (Civ. Prac. Act, § 1165-a, subd. 3). The statutory requirements to sue were satisfied.

8. However, New York remedies are not to be considered indiscriminately available to migrant spouses for the purposes of lawsuits. The phrase "as justice may require" was designed not to create a right as of course. Rather, those words confer power and obligation upon a court of jurisdiction to render directions that serve the public policy of the State and protect its residents in proper cases.

9. In applying the statutory standard, a distinction will be made between an actual matrimonial domicile and a constructive marital domicile. If there be no actual matrimonial domicile in New York, it will be incumbent upon the wife to establish other equally significant circumstances before she merits relief under the statute. In the case at bar there was no actual matrimonial domicile in New York, but there were other circumstances which suggested that discretion might be exercised in the wife's behalf. The husband was [***6] a man of many residences, temporary and permanent, and his family and economic ties with New York were great. The parties frequently sojourned at the husband's maternal home in New York, the bulk of the husband's sources of income, while the parties lived in marriage, had a situs in New York, and the wife was receiving welfare assistance through the City of New York. Thus the wife, in addition to having established residence in New York before the divorce, and the constructive marital domicile, also sufficiently established contacts with New York to merit relief under section 1170-b of the Civil Practice Act.

10. Before maintenance may be ordered under section 1170-b, the wife must establish all the elements of the standard matrimonial causes of action. The wife's testimony sufficiently established acts of cruelty and failure to support.

11. Defendant husband established that he had resumed an earlier domicile in Nevada and the court properly found that the Nevada divorce was valid.

12. By virtue of section 237-a of the Civil Practice Act, once Special Term had overruled defendant's objection, made on special appearance, to the jurisdiction of the court, with leave to raise the [***7] defense in his answer, defendant had the opportunity to defend on the merits without jeopardizing his right to raise on appeal the jurisdictional issues tendered, and even though he failed to sustain, on appeal, his attack on the court's jurisdiction over his person, he was not subject to an in personam judgment.

13. Allowances for maintenance and counsel fees were adequate and justified by the record.

 

1123 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Goodwin v. State Tax Com.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


286 A.D. 694; 146 N.Y.S.2d 172; 1955 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4121



November 23, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer challenged the decision of respondent New York State Tax Commission (commission), which affirmed the assessment of additional personal income taxes under subdivision 11 of § 360 of the Tax Law.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer, a non-resident, took deductions for real estate taxes, mortgage interest, and other expenses that were not associated with his business in state. The commission disallowed the taxpayer's claimed deductions and assessed additional taxes. The taxpayer filed suit on grounds that New York's distinction between residents and non-residents for purposes of these deductions violated U.S. Const. art. IV, § 2. The court held that the taxes were properly assessed because the distinction between residents and nonresidents was a reasonable one based upon valid independent reasons. The court found that the factor of residence had an obvious connection with the allowance of the deductions of a personal character and that the claimed deductions were properly associated with the place where the taxpayer resided.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the decision of the commission, which had denied certain personal deductions of the taxpayer and had assessed additional taxes.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - personal income tax - deductions by nonresidents - constitutionality of disallowance of nonresident's nonbusiness deductions - (1) lawyer, all of whose income was earned in New York, but who lived in New Jersey was properly disallowed deductions on his New York personal income tax return for taxes and mortgage interest on his New Jersey home, and for medical expenses and life insurance premiums - (2) Tax Law ( § 360, subd. 11) constitutionally disallows nonresident's deductions which are not connected with income derived from sources within State (U.S. Const., art. IV, § 2).

1.A lawyer who resided in New Jersey but all of whose income was earned in New York was allowed deductions on his New York personal income tax return for expenses connected with the production of his income,  [***2] such as bar association dues, legal periodicals, car expense and entertainment connected with production of such income, and also certain charitable contributions, but was properly disallowed the following nonbusiness deductions: real estate taxes on his home in New Jersey, interest on the mortgage on said home, medical expenses, and life insurance premiums.

2. The Tax Law ( § 360, subd. 11) validly provides that "In the case of a taxpayer other than a resident of the state the deductions allowed in this section * * * shall be allowed only if, and to the extent that, they are connected with income arising from sources within the state and taxable under this article to a nonresident taxpayer". This does not offend the provision of the Federal Constitution (art. IV, § 2) that "The Citizens of each State shall be entitled to all Privileges and Immunities of Citizens in the several States." Just as a State has no jurisdiction to tax the income of a nonresident except to the extent that such income is derived from sources within the State, so a State need not accord a nonresident a deduction, in computing his net income, for expenses not connected with income derived from sources within [***3] the State. Moreover, in allowing personal, nonbusiness deductions, a State may validly and constitutionally distinguish between its residents and nonresidents. The nonresidents' personal activities must be deemed to take place in the State of his residence.

 

1124 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Powers v. Taylor


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


286 A.D. 575; 146 N.Y.S.2d 194; 1955 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4094



November 16, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term in Albany County (New York), which dismissed his motion for an order pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 that would have declared 1950 N.Y. Laws 526 unconstitutional, and that would have directed respondent, the New York Civil Service Commission, to classify the position of workmen's compensation referee in the competitive class of classified civil service.


OVERVIEW: The amendments of 1950 N.Y. Laws 526 provided that workmen's compensation referees were included in the exempt class of the classified civil service. Appellant claimed that provision violated N.Y. Const. art. V, § 6, which indicated that appointments and promotions in the state civil service shall be made according to merit and fitness to be ascertained, as far as practicable, by competitive examination. The legislation did not alter any long-standing or well-recognized policy of the Commission. When the title of referee was first used in 1921, the Commission placed the referees in the exempt class. However, a competitive examination was held in 1932 and appointments were made from that list. Three of the 51 referees were in the competitive class at the time that 1950 N.Y. Laws 526 was enacted. Hence, the policy lacked consistency and needed legislative direction. The personal qualities of fairness, patience, common sense, and judgment required of referees could not be determined by any objective test. N.Y. Const. art. V, § 6 contemplated that civil service positions existed for which examinations were not practicable. Clearly, the position of referee was of such a nature.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment in favor of the Commission.


HEADNOTES

Civil service - exempt class - workmen's compensation referees - (1) Workmen's Compensation Law ( § 150), providing that position of workmen's compensation referee shall be in exempt class of classified civil service, does not violate direction of State Constitution (art. V, § 6) that appointments in civil service shall be made as far as practicable upon competitive examination; petition in proceeding (art. 78) for order directing respondents to classify such position in competitive class properly dismissed - (2) Legislature did not act arbitrarily in placing position in exempt class and in impliedly determining that no examination supplies practicable test of fitness therefor - (3) where nature and character of duties of position had been defined by Legislature,  [***2] not essential that Legislature hold hearings as to whether it was practicable to hold competitive examination - (4) other enumerated positions for which Civil Service Commission determined it practicable to hold competitive examinations not, in functions and importance, essentially same as workmen's compensation referees; at least Legislature and Civil Service Commission had right to so determine.

1. Section 150 of the Workmen's Compensation Law (as amd. by L. 1950, ch 526), which provides that the position of workmen's compensation referee shall be in the exempt class of the classified civil service, does not violate the direction of the State Constitution (art. V, § 6) that "Appointments and promotions in the civil service of the state * * * shall be made according to merit and fitness to be ascertained, as far as practicable, by examination which, as far as practicable, shall be competitive". The petition in a proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act for an order directing respondents, the State Civil Service Commission and others, to classify such position in the competitive class, was properly dismissed.

2. It has been cemented into our law by legislative [***3] enactment that workmen's compensation referees are quasi-judicial officers, with power to hear and determine compensation claims and with the concomitant authority to preside over proceedings, arrange calendars, sift and evaluate evidence and render decisions on controverted claims. In view of the well-established nature and character of the duties of workmen's compensation referees, the Appellate Division is unable to conclude that the Legislature acted arbitrarily in placing them in the exempt class and in impliedly determining that no examination supplies a practicable test of fitness for the position. No objective test would be practicable to determine such personal qualities essential to the position as fairness, patience, common sense and judgment.

3. Where the nature and character of the duties of the position were themselves defined by the Legislature, it was not essential that the Legislature hold hearings as to whether it was practicable to hold a competitive examination. The finding of impracticability was necessarily implied in the exemption and was not required to be expressly stated.

4. While the Civil Service Commission had determined it practicable to hold [***4] competitive examinations for unemployment insurance referees, motor carrier referees, motor vehicle referees and hearing officers, those positions are not in their functions and importance essentially the same as workmen's compensation referees, or at least the Legislature and Civil Service Commission had the right to so determine.

 Matter of Powers v. Taylor, 207 Misc. 465, affirmed.

 

1125 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Commissioner of Welfare v. Richter


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


286 A.D. 1068; 145 N.Y.S.2d 617; 1955 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5170



November 7, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant mother sought review of an order of the Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York in New York County (New York), which denied her application for an extension of an order of filiation and terminated the probation of respondent father.


OVERVIEW: The mother argued that her application for an extension of an order of filiation should be granted because her 16-year-old son, for whom she sought continued support, was completing his high school education. The court indicated that the provisions of N.Y. City Crim. Ct. Act § 69(2), which provided that support could be ordered after a child reached 16 years of age for good cause shown, required that an unusual or exceptional circumstance had to be demonstrated, which supported such an order. The court viewed the continuance of the youth's high school education as an ordinary circumstance, which did not justify such an order.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's denial of the mother's application.

 

1126 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Seltzer v. Yonkers


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Second Department


286 A.D. 557; 145 N.Y.S.2d 664; 1955 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4090



October 31, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant developers sought review of an order of the Supreme Court in Westchester County (New York), which entered judgment in favor of plaintiff city. The city's action sought to enjoin the developers from building an apartment house on grounds that the city had adopted a zoning ordinance, after the developer's plans were filed, changing the district where the land was located to one where the planned use was not permitted.


OVERVIEW: The city's zoning ordinance, City of Yonkers, N.Y. Zoning Ordinance 24-1953, provided that it would not require any change in the plans, construction or designated use of a building for which completed plans had been filed, or for which a building permit had been issued, provided that the construction of the building began within 90 days after the building permit was issued. This exception was twice amended to extend the time within which construction had to begin. The developer's building permit was not issued until after the ordinance became effective. Construction did not begin until more than 90 days later but within the extended period. On appeal, the court held that the clear intention of the exception was to exempt structures for which the plans had been filed prior to the effective date of the ordinance, even if the building permit was not granted until after the ordinance, as long as construction was started in a timely fashion. Even if the time limit was construed to apply only to building permits issued before the ordinance, that reading created a conflict within the ordinance that would be resolved by adopting the construction that was clearly intended.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment in favor of the city on the law, with costs. The court dismissed the city's complaint against the developer without costs. The court affirmed the trial court's findings of fact.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations - zoning ordinance - statutory construction - saving provision - (1) after plans filed to erect six-story apartment house, new zoning ordinance changed such district to one where such structure not permitted; ordinance further provided that it should not require change in plans theretofore filed "or" for which building permit theretofore issued, provided construction was actually begun in 90 days; permit issued two weeks later; four months later, "90 days" was amended to "150 days", and, two months later, to "210 days of the date of issue of such permit, heretofore legally issued"; construction, actually begun about five months after original enactment, legal; action for injunction dismissed - (2) literal reading of last amendment, which would restrict it to permits issued before original enactment, would defeat purpose of legislation - (3) amendments constitutional exercises of city's power to amend its zoning ordinance.

1. After plans had been legally filed to erect [***2] a six-story apartment house in a district wherein the city's zoning ordinance permitted such a structure, a new zoning ordinance was adopted in which the district was designated as one wherein such a structure was not permitted. However, a section of the new zoning ordinance provided that nothing in the ordinance should require any change in plans theretofore legally filed "or" for which a building permit had been theretofore issued, provided that in either case, the construction of such building should have been actually begun within 90 days of the date of issue of such permit. The permit was issued about two weeks after the effective date of the amendment. Construction was not begun until about five months after the effective date of the amendment. But, about four months after such effective date, the "90 days" was amended to "150 days"; and, about six months after such original effective date, it was further amended to "210 days of the date of issue of such permit, heretofore legally issued". Under such amendments, the proposed six-story apartment house was legal, since the plans were filed before the effective date of the new zoning ordinance and construction was begun within [***3] 210 days after the issuance of the building permit. A complaint seeking to restrain the construction should be dismissed.

2. The intention of the saving provision was clarified, if it needed any clarification, by the last amendment to the section, in which the words "heretofore legally issued" should be construed to mean permits legally issued before the date of such last amendment. It would defeat the general purpose of the legislation, and would lead to unreasonable consequences, to construe the amendment so literally as to restrict it to permits issued before the originally effective date of the section.

3. The amendments were valid and constitutional exercises of the city's power to amend its zoning ordinance.

 

1127 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


De Matteis v. Hempstead


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Second Department


286 A.D. 1025; 145 N.Y.S.2d 256; 1955 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5052



October 17, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a causes of action for a declaratory judgment and one under N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 51, appellant property owner sought to enjoin the condemnation of his property on the ground that the applicable provisions of the Nassau County Administrative Code were unconstitutional and void and the condemnation proceedings were illegal. He appealed from an order dismissing the complaint for failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: The property owner's contentions, in substance, were that the statute was illegal because of its failure to provide for personal service of the notice to condemn or the condemnation petition on a property owner, and that the proposed taking of his land was unnecessary and was not for a public purpose. The court found that the statute was not invalid merely because no provision was made for personal service of notice of the proceedings on the property owner. The absence of any provision in the Nassau County Administrative Code bringing the factor of necessity of the taking within judicial consideration showed that the legislature had delegated its power to the town board to determine necessity. The determination of that question, therefore, was a legislative function and not a judicial one. While the question of whether or not a proposed condemnation was for a public purpose was a judicial question, the court held that the complaint failed to plead facts indicating that the asserted use was not a public one. The purpose of the acquisition was to obtain access to property which the town had previously purchased.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed.

 

1128 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Horoch v. State


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


286 A.D. 303; 143 N.Y.S.2d 327; 1955 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4035



July 7, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant state sought review of an order by the Court of Claims (New York), which denied the state's motion to implead appellee personal injury claimant's (claimant) employer in the claimant's action to recover for injuries that he sustained while working on a state-owned jobsite. The state argued that it was entitled to indemnification from the employer under negligence principles and a hold harmless clause between the state and the employer.


OVERVIEW: The claimant filed suit against the state with the court of claims to recover for injuries that he sustained at a state worksite. Thee state moved for an order from the Ct. Cl. Authorizing it to bring in the claimant's employer in order to assert a claim for indemnification against the employer on the basis of common law negligence and under the terms of a hold harmless clause allegedly contained in the contract between the state and the employer. The court of claims denied the motion, and the state sought review. The court affirmed the denial of the state's motion, holding that N.Y. Ct. Cl. Act § 9(6) did not authorize the state to implead or bring in a third party against whom it may have asserted a claim over. In the practice of impleader there were no adverse claims against a party under an alleged obligation. Pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act. § 193-a, impleader was the means by which the primary liability of the original defendant and the alleged "liability over" of a third party were to be settled in one action. The impleader of a third party for the purpose of allowing the state to assert a claim against such party was not authorized.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the court of claims denying the state's motion to implead the claimant's employer in the claimant's personal injury suit.


HEADNOTES

Court of Claims - impleader of third party in action against State - (1) State not entitled to bring in additional party against whom State may seek judgment over in event State is held liable in claim pending against it in Court of Claims - (2) State may, by means of separate action in court of general jurisdiction, enforce any right to indemnification from third party.

1. The State is not entitled, under the Court of Claims Act and the State Constitution, to bring in an additional party against whom the State may seek judgment over in the event the State is held liable in a claim pending against it in the Court of Claims. Subdivision 6 of section 9 of the Court of Claims Act does not authorize the State to implead or bring in a third party against whom it may assert a claim over, although it does allow interpleader.

2. The State may, however, by means of a separate action in a court of general jurisdiction, enforce any right to indemnification from a third party.

 

1129 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New York Tel. Co. v. Public Service Com.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


286 A.D. 28; 142 N.Y.S.2d 68; 1955 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3978



May 24, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner telephone company sought review of a determination of respondent Public Service Commission of the State of New York, denying petitioner's application for an increase in telephone rates.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner telephone company applied for a rate increase. Respondent Public Service Commission refused to receive evidence of the alleged present value of petitioner's property used in the public service. Respondent denied the rate increase. On appeal, the court annulled the determination and orders of respondent and remitted the matter to respondent. The court held that exclusion of evidence material to the computation of present fair value rate basis was reversible error. Under N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law § 97, respondent was required to adopt a present fair value rate basis in passing upon petitioner's request for a rate increase. Fairly construed, the statute could only mean present value. That the statute referred to the value of property actually "used" in public service did not refer merely to the past in any grammatical or logical sense. Thus, respondent erred in excluding the evidence.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the determination and orders of respondent public service commission which denied petitioner telephone company's application for a rate increase. Respondent committed reversible error by refusing to receive evidence of the alleged present value of petitioner's property used in the public service.


HEADNOTES

Public utilities - rates - evidence - present value - (1) upon application of telephone company for increase in telephone rates, Public Service Commission should have received evidence of alleged present value of property actually used in public service (Public Service Law, § 97, subd. 1) - (2) reproduction cost less depreciation is indispensable ingredient to be considered in fixing present value - (3) statute is mandatory - (4) Legislature has apparently treated gas and electric companies differently for rate-making purposes from railroad and telephone companies (§§ 49, 72, 97).

1. Upon the application of the New York Telephone Company for an increase in telephone rates, the Public Service Commission should have received evidence of the alleged present value of the property actually used in the public service. The Public Service Law ( § 97, subd.  [***2] 1) provides that a determination of the rates should be made "with due regard, among other things, to a reasonable average return upon the value of the property actually used in the public service". The words "value of the property actually used in the public service" were used with deliberate intention and design when the statute was enacted in 1910 and re-enacted in 1921. Under Smyth v. Ames (169 U.S. 466) a public utility was entitled to have its rates based on present fair value. The statute (§ 97) used language so closely paralleling the language of Smyth v. Ames that the only conclusion that can be drawn is that it adopted the Supreme Court concept. Those words continued with the same force and effect after the United States Supreme Court abandoned the concept of present fair value as a constitutional requirement for a rate base ( Federal Power Comm. v. Hope Natural Gas Co., 320 U.S. 591 [1944]) and left the Legislature free to disregard it, but did not bar its use. The failure of the Legislature to act after the Hope case was decided in 1944 is of decisive importance. Fairly construed, the words "value of the property actually used in the [***3] public service" can only mean present value.

2. Accordingly, reproduction cost less depreciation is an indispensable ingredient to be considered in fixing the present value of property actually used in the public service. Reproduction cost can only be shown by opinion evidence.

3. The language of section 97 is mandatory. The commission undoubtedly has rather wide discretionary power, but it could not give "due regard" to the value of property actually used in the public service if some proof of that measure were not before it.

4. The Legislature has apparently treated gas and electric companies (Public Service Law, § 72) differently for rate-making purposes from railroad and telephone companies (§§ 49, 97).

 

1130 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Fink v. Cole


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


286 A.D. 73; 140 N.Y.S.2d 708; 1955 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3980



May 10, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:
