PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee horse owner brought an action in the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York) against appellant, the State Racing Commission (the Commission) and claimed the Commission arbitrarily and wrongfully denied the horse owner's application for an owner's racing license. The trial court ordered the Commission to reconsider the horse owner's application and the Commission appealed.


OVERVIEW: The horse owner was previously licensed to race but his license application was later denied through a ruling of a joint board which the New York Supreme Court later deemed null and ineffective. The horse owner later applied again for a license to race but the Commission denied his application relying largely on the prior information and ruling handed down by the joint board. The horse owner challenged the Commission ruling as arbitrary and capricious and the trial court ordered the Commission to reconsider the horse owner's application. On appeal, the court affirmed and held that the Commission action could only be described as arbitrary and capricious. The evidence in the 1949 proceeding as well as the decision of the joint board lost all vitality by virtue of the ruling of the state court. That prior proceeding was improperly used by the Commission as the basis for the present decision, as there was no other proof in the record, and the Commission should not have relied on such information.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court ruling and ordered the Commission to reconsider the horse owner's application.


HEADNOTES

Administrative law - reviewable record required even where formal hearing not required - horse racing license - proceeding against body or officer - (1) Jockey Club, acting under power unconstitutionally delegated to such private corporation without statutory standards, denied petitioner's application for race horse owner's license; Court of Appeals annulled determination as one made under void statute; Legislature enacted new statute empowering State Racing Commission to grant or deny licenses if it "shall find" any of several stated standards met or not met; five years after first denial, petitioner again applied and was refused on basis of former hearing and decision; proceeding properly remanded to commission for further consideration - (2) commission's determination arbitrarily disregarded constitutional invalidity enunciated [***2] by Court of Appeals - (3) although new statute does not expressly provide for hearing, commission must enunciate its finding and basis for its finding, and must use proof and provide record which court can review for arbitrariness - (4) although court cannot apply substantial evidence rule where statute does not require hearing, court may determine whether there is clear proof that commission exercised its discretion arbitrarily.

1. In section 9-b of the act pertaining to the State Racing Commission (L. 1926, ch. 440, as amd. by L. 1934, ch. 310), the Legislature purported to empower the Jockey Club, a private corporation, to license owners of horses at races. The club denied petitioner a license for the years 1949 and 1950. Petitioner, while protesting the unconstitutionality of such delegation of licensing power, demanded a hearing before a joint board consisting of the State Racing Commission and two stewards of the club (§ 9-b, as amd. by L. 1947, ch. 196). The joint board sustained the denial, in "the best interest of racing", a standard set by the rules of the club. The statute itself set no standards. The Court of Appeals annulled the determination, on the grounds that [***3] section 9-b was an unconstitutional relinquishment of legislative power and that, even if the licensing power had been delegated to a governmental agency, such delegation would be void for lack of proper standards ( Matter of Fink v. Cole, 302 N.Y. 216). The Legislature thereupon enacted a new section 9-b (L. 1951, ch. 324) empowering the State Racing Commission to grant licenses and to deny licenses if it "shall find" that any of a number of stated standards is or is not met by the applicant (§ 9-b, subd. 2). Subsequently, petitioner applied for a license for the year commencing April 1, 1954. The commission, without a hearing, denied this application for "failure to meet the standards set" by the new section 9-b, but did not specify which standard.In this review proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act, the commission stated that it "considered anew the proof in the [prior] proceeding * * * and reaffirmed the said decision". This was an arbitrary and capricious disregard of the constitutional principle enunciated by the Court of Appeals. This proceeding was properly remanded to the commission for further consideration.

2. It would amount to nullification [***4] of a constitutional principle to say that, although the prior proceeding and decision were ruled out of legitimate consideration, the evidence could be lifted out and, without more, become the entire basis of a like decision five years later.

3. Although the new section 9-b (subd. 2) does not expressly provide for a hearing, there must be some enunciation by the commission of its finding and the basis for its finding, and it must be based on something resembling proof, and must be made upon such a record as can be reviewed by a court in order to decide whether the determination was arbitrary.

4. Since the determination made in this case was not made "as the result of a hearing held, and at which evidence was taken, pursuant to statutory direction" (Civ. Prac. Act, art. 78, § 1296), the reviewing court in this proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act cannot use the so-called "substantial evidence" rule. But petitioner seeks an order not only annulling the determination but also directing the issuance of a license; hence the court may inquire whether there is clear and convincing proof that the commission exercised its discretion arbitrarily or capriciously.

 

1131 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Janowsky v. Parsons


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Fourth Department


285 A.D. 601; 139 N.Y.S.2d 676; 1955 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5548



April 13, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owners in certain school districts challenged a decision from the Supreme Court at Special Term of Steuben County (New York), which granted the motions of defendant members of the board of education of a city school district for dismissal of the owners' complaints on the grounds of insufficiency, lack of subject matter jurisdiction, and lack of capacity to sue.


OVERVIEW: The owners alleged the New York Commissioner of Education made an order purportedly pursuant to N.Y. Educ. Law § 1526 consolidating 61 school districts. The owners argued that § 1526 was unconstitutional and void in that it delegated legislative powers to the Commissioner and in that did not permit a vote by the voters of one of the school districts. The owners alleged the Commissioner illegally created the enlarged, consolidated school district. The owners sought judgments that would enjoin the consolidated district and its board of education from assessing the owners' real property. On appeal, the court affirmed, holding that: (1) § 1526 did not offend the Constitution either because the voters of a certain school district were not permitted to vote or because there was an unconstitutional delegation of legislative powers to the Commissioner; (2) the area meeting, which was neither a city school district meeting nor a district meeting, was not subject as to time, place, or methods of voting to any provisions of the Education Law except as set forth in § 1526; and (3) where all provisions of § 1526 were fully complied with, the meeting and vote taken thereat were legal and valid.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the dismissal of the owners' action.


HEADNOTES

Schools - consolidated school district - (1) Education Law ( § 1526), pursuant to which Commissioner of Education created enlarged city school district by consolidating with it sixty-one school districts in contiguous area, sets standards on powers thus delegated to commissioner and is [***3] constitutional - (2) section 1526, requiring vote of contiguous area voters, validly requires only consent of board of original city school district; no constitutional right to vote on such consolidation - (3) qualified voters at area meeting (§§ 1526, 2012, 2603) voted at time and place and by method prescribed in section 1526 (art. 31); different provisions as to "district meetings" and elections in "city school districts" (arts. 41, 53) inapplicable; hence, unnecessary to decide whether a district in area was city school district - (4) no violation of constitutional rights of plaintiffs, who are property owners and voters in other districts in area.

1. Section 1526 of the Education Law, pursuant to which the State Commissioner of Education created an enlarged city school district by consolidating with it sixty-one school districts in the contiguous area, which in this case lay in three counties, sets limitations and standards on the powers delegated to the commissioner, and therefore the statute is not an unconstitutional delegation of legislative powers.

2. Section 1526 of the Education Law provides for a vote by the qualified voters of the contiguous school district areas [***4] to be consolidated with the city school district and for a consenting resolution by the board of education of the city school district (subd. 4). This is valid. There is no constitutional right inthe voters of the city school district to vote on such consolidation.

3. The State Commissioner of Education duly called a "special meeting of the qualified voters within each such area" (Education Law, § 1526, subd. 5). The time, place and method of voting provided in section 1526 were complied with. Section 1526 (subd. 6) further provides that "Any person qualified to vote in any school district wholly or partly within the area laid out by the commissioner and who resides whthin such area shall be qualified to vote at such meeting." Section 2012 of article 41 states the qualifications of voters at district meetings. Section 2603 of article 53 states the qualifications of voters in a city school district in a city of less than 125,000 inhabitants. These were complied with. Since this was an area meeting (art. 31, § 1526), the provisions as to time, place and method of voting in articles 41 and 53 governing "district meetings" and elections in "city school districts" respectively,  [***5] were not applicable. Hence it is unnecessary to determine whether one of the districts in the area was a city school district, and if so, whether section 2037 of article 41 applies to it.

4. Plaintiffs-appellants in these actions for a declaratory judgment were resident owners of real property in districts outside of the original city school district and outside of the particular district which they assert was a city school district. No constitutional right of theirs was violated.

 Janowsky v. Parsons, 207 Misc. 107, affirmed.

 Johnson v. Parsons, 207 Misc. 107, affirmed.

 

1132 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Onondaga County Water Authority v. New York Water Service Corp.


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FOURTH DEPARTMENT


285 A.D. 655; 139 N.Y.S.2d 755; 1955 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5560



April 13, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Public Service Commission (commission) sought review of the final order of the County Court of Onondaga County (New York), which confirmed the report of commissioners of appraisal appointed in a proceeding to condemn properties of respondent New York Water Service Corporation (water service), and denied a motion made by the commission pursuant to N.Y. Condemn. Law § 18 for abandonment and discontinuance of the proceeding.


OVERVIEW: Respondent Water Authority authorized the acquisition of the water service's plant. The commissioners of appraisal made their report and after entry of the final order by the state court, the commission filed a motion to abandon and discontinue the order, which was denied. The other parties challenged the commission's right to bring the action. The court reversed the final order and held that the commission was a proper party to the proceeding. The commission argued that the award was grossly excessive and was not supported by the evidence upon any theory of valuation, that the appraisers did not give adequate consideration to the result attained by capitalization of the earnings of the corporation as a regulated public utility, and that an erroneous principle was adopted by the appraisers in that the award was made on the basis of condemnor's ability to pay rather than the value of condemnee's properties being condemned. The court agreed and held that regardless of the principle of valuation adopted, the question of just compensation was not to have been determined by the value to the government which takes, but the value to the individual from which the property was taken.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the final order and remanded to the commissioners of appraisal for a new appraisal. The court dismissed the commission's appeal from the order denying its motion for abandonment and discontinuance of the proceeding.


HEADNOTES

Eminent domain - award - public utilities - public authorities - (1) in proceeding by public authority to condemn property of public utility, commissioners of appraisal shall give "due regard" to Public Service Commission's certification of rate base and rate of return and anticipated annual net earnings; and if final award does not capitalize such earnings or is so excessive as to be not in public interest, commission shall ask court to discontinue proceeding; commission is party for all purposes (Condemnation Law, §§ 5-a, 14, 15, 18, as amd.); commission needs no order to intervene, and also may appeal from award and from [***2] court's refusal to direct that proceeding be abandoned - (2) Legislature stated it was not "attempting to mandate the basis of valuation"; amendments constitutional (N.Y. Const., art. I, § 7) - (3) award was based, not on value of property to be taken, but on what public authority could afford to pay - (4) due regard was not given to anticipated annual earnings; legislative direction merely stated decisional law - (5) matter remitted to commissioners for new appraisal.

1. The Condemnation Law (as amd. by L. 1952, chs. 508, 515) provides that a copy of a petition to condemn the property of a person or corporation subject to the jurisdiction of the Public Service Commission must be served on the Public Service Commission, which must then, after a hearing, certify to the court and to the commissioners of appraisal (1) the annual net earnings which the utility system involved might reasonably be expected to continue to produce in the hands of the condemnee, and (2) the rate base and rate of return from which that estimate is derived (Condemnation Law, § 5-a); that the commissioners of appraisal shall determine the compensation with "due regard * * * to the anticipated earnings of [***3] such company as certified" (§ 14); that the Public Service Commission "shall be a party to such proceedings for all purposes" (§ 15); and finally, that if the final order of confirmation directs payment of an amount which is (1) not a capitalization of the certified earnings of the system, or (2), in the opinion of the Public Service Commission, is so excessive or insufficient as to be not in the public interest, the commission shall ask the court to exercise its discretionary power to order that the proceeding be abandoned and discontinued (§ 18). Under the above-quoted section 15, the Public Service Commission needs no order permitting it to intervene (Civ. Prac. Act, § 193-b). It is a party "for all purposes", including the right of appeal (Condemnation Law, § 19).

2. Such 1952 amendments to the Condemnation Law do not usurp the jurisdiction of the courts and the commissioners of appraisal to determine the just compensation (N.Y. Const., art. I, § 7). The Legislature pointed out (L. 1952, ch. 508, § 1) that it was not "attempting to mandate the basis of valuation to be followed".

3. In this proceeding by the Onondaga County Water Authority (Public Authorities Law,  [***4] art. 5, tit. 6; L. 1951, ch. 675) to acquire the Syracuse water-distributing plant of respondent public utility, the Public Service Commission certified, after a hearing, that the anticipated annual net earnings were $ 237,000, being a 6% return upon a rate base of capital actually expended of $ 3,950,000. This was placed in the record by the commissioners of appraisal, without comment. Their report formally stated that they had considered it. The utility's principal witness testified that the reproduction cost new less depreciation was $ 12,700,000; but $ 4,700,000 of this was his valuation of intangible water rights, which was a double valuation based on duplicating and expanding the existing supply structures and should not have been considered. The value to be appraised is the present system, and not that which the condemnee expects to build. Similarly, the Authority's principal witness fixed $ 8,650,000, not as the value of the present system, but as what the Authority "can afford to pay". Furthermore, he based this on the Authority's prospective earnings on an expanded system; also, he improperly gave to the condemnee the capitalized benefit of tax-free operation by the Authority.  [***5] The Authority, too, presented no evidence of the present economic value to the owner. Its petition had alleged that the value was $ 8,500,000; and the commissioners of appraisal found that - plus additions and betterments and work in progress which they found precisely in the form stated in the Authority's estimate - the total value was $ 8,650,000. On this appeal by the Public Service Commission, the condemnee appeared merely as a respondent, joining with the Authority in arguing in favor of the award and against appellant Public Service Commission. The record does not contain evidence from which the fair value of the property could be correctly determined, and the award was apparently based on what the condemnor could afford to pay.

4. The Legislature had found that condemnation awards to privately owned public utilities often were "not based upon the damage to the private owner but upon the benefit to the condemnor" (L. 1952, ch. 508, § 1), and it directed that "due regard" be given to the anticipated annual net earnings. This was only an expression of what had long been decisional law. There is no evidence in this case that the commissioners gave any real consideration [***6] to the expressed will of the Legislature.

5. Therefore, the final order confirming the award should be reversed and the matter remitted to the same commissioners for a new appraisal.

 

1133 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Congregation Beth Israel West Side Jewish Center v. Board of Estimate


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


285 A.D. 629; 139 N.Y.S.2d 645; 1955 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5555



April 12, 1955 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant parking corporation sought review of the decision of the Supreme Court at Special Term, New York County (New York), which denied its motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint filed by plaintiff religious school seeking an injunction restraining the parking corporation from applying for any building permit or from proceeding to construct the proposed garage.


OVERVIEW: The parking corporation maintained an open parking lot. The parking lot was immediately adjacent to the structure occupied by the religious school. The parking corporation applied, pursuant to New York City, N.Y., Zoning Resolution § 21-F, for approval of the erection of a garage designed to hold 450 cars. New York City, N.Y., Zoning Resolution § 21-A prohibited the operation of garages having a vehicular entrance within 200 feet from an entrance or exit of a school maintained by an established religious group. Defendant city planning commission unanimously passed a resolution approving the application. Defendant board of estimate confirmed the approval even though the religious school was within the proscribed distance from the projected garage. However, at the time application was approved, it had no pupils or teachers. The school filed an action seeking to restrain the parking corporation from proceeding on the garage. The trial court denied the parking corporation's motion for summary judgment. The court reversed and held that the amendment to § 21-A. which permitted the garage to be built, was a reasonable legislative act and was required to be followed.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and granted the parking corporation's motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations - zoning - public garages - (1) 450-car garage on site in restricted zone was approved after public hearings by city planning commission and board of estimate (New York City Zoning Resolution, § 21-F), on condition there be no facilities for repairing or gasoline or oil service; at that time section 21-A prohibited garage within 200 feet of religious school, but commission and board found plaintiff's school was not in operation; meantime, six-month study and hearings had been going on, from which planning commission found city-wide need for more provision for off-street parking; board of estimate then approved and enacted commission resolution amending section 21-A so as to exclude only garages which sell gasoline and oil; this was about three months after defendant had received such special approval; action to declare amendment unconstitutional and to enjoin garage, dismissed on motion for summary judgment - (2) section 21-A as amended, and section 21-F,  [***2] constitutional - (3) plaintiff did not sustain burden of showing that amendment not justified by any reasonable interpretation of facts - (4) section 21-A must be applied as amended, not as it read when application was approved - (5) power of board of standards and appeals to grant variances, which might have achieved same result for defendant, does not exclude general legislative provision such as section 21-F for specific authorizations by planning commission and board of estimate - (6) Special Term erred in refusing summarily, on ground that preliminary questions of fact existed, to adjudge well-precedented constitutionality of section 21-F and amendment to section 21-A.

1. The New York City Zoning Resolution (§ 21-F) provides that an application for approval of a public garage to be erected on a site which is within a restricted zone - in this case it was a retail use district - may be approved by resolution of the city planning commission, subject to appropriate conditions, and that such approval takes effect when further approved by the board of estimate, and that nothing in this section divests the board of standards and appeals of its jurisdiction to permit variances of [***3] the zoning resolution. Defendant owner of a parking lot on a busy mid-town street was granted such approval for a 450-car garage, on condition that no facilities should be provided for gasoline service or oil selling or repairing of vehicles. Section 21-A of the zoning resolution at that time prohibited a gagage with a vehicular entrance within 200 feet of a school maintained by an established religious group - such as plaintiff. However, plaintiff's school had recently had only ten pupils, and more recently it was in what plaintiff called a temporary suspension of operation. The planning commission and the board of estimate found that plaintiff was not operating a school within the contemplation of section 21-A. The parking garage was approved after public hearings at which plaintiff appeared. Meantime, the city planning commission had been conducting a six-month study and public hearings, from which it found that, throughout the city as well as in this neighborhood, there was insufficient provision for off-street accommodation of motor vehicles, and, as a result of which, the board of estimate approved and enacted a resolution of the planning commission which amended section [***4] 21-A generally, by narrowing the restriction against garages so as to exclude only garages selling gasoline and oil. This general amendment to section 21-A was enacted about three months after defendant had been given such special permission. Plaintiff, asserting that the special permission and the subsequent zoning amendment were "spot zoning" and "tailor-made" for defendant, sued to enjoin the authorized garage and to have the amendment declared unconstitutional. Plaintiff also joined the board of estimate and the planning commission as defendants. Summary judgment should be granted dismissing the complaint.

2. Section 21-A as amended, and section 21-F, are valid and constitutional.

3. The burden of showing that an ordinance is not justified under governmental police power by any reasonable interpretation of the facts is on those who assail it. There is no proof to support any claim that the approval of defendant's projected garage was based on incorrect motives or was special legislation for the benefit of defendant alone. The hearings before the planning commission and the board of estimate show that the city-wide amendment to section 21-A was enacted after careful [***5] study of its effect upon thousands of schools and hospitals as contrasted with its effect upon a critical city-wide off-street parking problem. Such balancing of relative harm, benefit and convenience is peculiarly a legislative function.

4. Section 21-A must be applied as it now reads, not as it read when defendant's application was first approved.

5. Section 21-F does not conflict with the discretion of the board of standards and appeals to grant individual variances in hardship and other cases authorized by the zoning resolution (New York City Charter, § 666, subd. 5). A zoning regulation, such as section 21-F, which provides that the board of standards and appeals may grant a variance from it, may be amended or repealed (New York City Charter, § 200). The variance-granting power of the board of standards and appeals stems in the first instance from the powers granted to the board of estimate (L. 1917, ch. 601). The fact that defendant might have been granted substantially the same result by the board of standards and appeals does not mean that the legislative zoning scheme could not be amended. The courts have sustained, as a valid exercise of the legislative zoning [***6] power rather than a grant of a variance, zoning provisions such as section 21-F, whereby a general enactment withholds blanket approval beforehand and requires subsequent separate authorizations for specific uses.

6. Special Term erred in refusing to adjudge summarily the constitutionality of section 21-F and section 21-A as amended, on the stated ground that there were preliminary questions of fact as to whether the school existed and as to whether the board of estimate acted for the benefit of defendant only. The substance or counterparts of this type of zoning legislation had previously been held to be constitutional in analogous situations. Since sections 21-A and 21-F of the zoning resolution are valid and constitutional both as enacted and as they bear upon the facts in this case, and since such holding leaves no issue of fact to be determined, summary judgment should be granted dismissing the complaint.

 

1134 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Defiance Milk Products Co. v. Du Mond


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


285 A.D. 337; 136 N.Y.S.2d 619; 1954 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3324



December 28, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant state commissioner of agriculture and markets (commissioner) sought review of an order from the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which declared that N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 64(2), prohibiting the sale of evaporated skimmed milk in containers of less than 10 pounds avoirdupois net weight, was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Respondent Ohio dairy products manufacturer challenged the constitutionality of § 64(2). The commissioner alleged that the statute was necessary to prevent fraud and deception in the sale of evaporated skimmed milk in containers similar to those used in the sale of evaporated milk. The trial court granted summary judgment for the dairy products manufacturer, and the commissioner appealed. The court held that although the legislature had the authority to protect the public from fraudulent substitutes, there was no evidence that evaporated skimmed milk could be considered a fraudulent substitute for anything else and that there was no other reason justifying the legislation. The court held that even if the statute had been valid at its enactment in 1922, conditions had changed greatly, making the enforcement of the statute unreasonable and arbitrary. The court noted that the product sold by the dairy products manufacturer was not adulterated milk, as defined in N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 46.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment declaring that the New York statute prohibiting the sale of evaporated skimmed milk in containers of less than 10 pounds of avoirdupois weight was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - milk control - (1) judgment declaring unconstitutional that part of 1922 statute which prohibited sale of evaporated skimmed milk unless in ten-pound containers and which thus in effect barred such product from retail sales, affirmed; continued exercise of police power against milk product now widely recognized as nutritive, unreasonable - (2) evaporated skimmed milk with vitamins added is not "adulterated".

1. Subdivision 2 of section 64 of the Agriculture and Markets Law of this State provides that "No person shall sell * * * any condensed or evaporated skimmed milk, except it be in containers or packages containing ten pounds avoirdupois net weight or more * * * distinctly labeled * * * in block letters not [***2] less than one-half inch in height * * * 'Condensed Skimmed Milk' or 'Evaporated Skimmed Milk'". This statute was originally enacted thirty-two years ago. Today, the nutritional values and uses of skimmed milk and condensed or evaporated skimmed milk are widely recognized by experts and by the retail buying public. Where the milk is labeled as provided in the above subdivision, there is no reason to fear that the public will be confused and deceived. The ten-pound-container requirement is, today, a disservice to those who wish to buy this product in the same conveniently small containers as those in which they usually buy evaported whole milk or skimmed fluid milk. Whether or not the ten-pound requirement was a reasonable police regulation thirty-two years ago, in present times it is arbitrary, discriminatory, unreasonable, unconstitutional and void. The judgment, in an action by a manufacturer and distributor of evaporated skimmed milk, declaring that that part of the subdivision which prohibits the sale of evaporated skimmed milk except in containers holding ten pounds or more is void, should be affirmed.

2. Skimmed milk is milk "from which part or all of the cream has been [***3] removed", and, if "sold for and as skimmed milk", it cannot be classified as "adulterated milk" (Agriculture and Markets Law, § 46, par. 7 and also unnumbered paragraph; § 50; § 64, subd. 1). Nor has plaintiff's product been "diluted with water or any other fluid" (§ 46, par. 8). Vitamin A has been added in the form of a concentrated oil, and vitamin D[3] in the form of a concentrate already mixed with milk. These do not constitute such a "foreign substance" (§ 46, par. 8) as renders the milk corrupt or debased or "adulterated". Nor is plaintiff's product "filled milk", the sale of which is prohibited by a Federal statute which defines "filled milk" as "any milk * * * or skimmed milk * * * to which has been added, or which has been blended or compounded with, any fat or oil other than milk fat, so that the resulting product is in imitation or semblance of milk" (U.S. Code, tit. 21, § 61, subd. [c]).

 Defiance Milk Products Co. v. Du Mond, 205 Misc. 813, affirmed.

 

1135 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Ross v. Wilson


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


284 A.D. 522; 132 N.Y.S.2d 760; 1954 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3436



July 8, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, Commissioner of Education of the State of New York, N.Y., challenged a judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term in Albany County, (New York), which, in a suit by respondent disgruntled bidder, annulled a determination of the Commissioner. The Commissioner had sustained a contract made by respondent board of education to sell the real property of a discontinued school to a church rather than to the bidder.


OVERVIEW: The board called a special meeting of qualified voters of to consider a vote upon a proposition to close the school and to sell the school property. In the notice of the meeting, the propositions included: (1) should the school be closed; and (2) should the school property be sold to the church for a certain amount. At the meeting, these two proposals were carried by a majority vote. The bidder made an oral offer in an amount higher than any other bid, but a majority of the qualified voters present at the meeting decided to accept the offer made by the church. Thereafter, the board entered into a contract to sell the property to the church. The Commissioner upheld the board's decision. The trial court annulled and set aside the Commissioner's determination. On appeal, the court reversed and dismissed the bidder's petition, holding that: (1) under N.Y. Educ. Law § 310, Commissioner's decision was final and binding unless it was arbitrary, which it was not; (2) under N.Y. Educ. Law §§ 1520, 1804, the board had normal discretionary power to deal with the matter of the sale of school property; and (3) the board's action did not violate N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 1.


OUTCOME: The trial court's order was reversed, and the petition was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Schools - sale of property and site of discontinued school - (1) voters of common school district which had been included in central school district voted to close their school and to sell such real property to church for $2,000, as against offer by grange of $3,000 proposed and offer by one of petitioners, private individuals, of $4,000; Commissioner of Education sustained contract; commissioner's determination is conclusive (Education Law, § 310), unless purely arbitrary or unconstitutional - (2) property of pre-existing common school district may be dold by board of education on majority vote of qualified voters of district (§ 1804, subd. 6); further provision that net proceeds shall be distributed among taxpayers [***2] was not intended to deprive voters of normal discretion; voters may authorize sale of former site and building at price and terms they deem proper (Education Law, § 402, subd. 1) - (3) commissioner's interpretation of statute not contrary to State Constitution (art. VIII, § 1), since sale for substantial price is not gift - (4) no violation of due process of law as to those taxpanyers who are not voters; they had no vested right in the property - (5) commissioner's action not arbitrary or wholly lacking in rationality; petition dismissed.

1. At a duly called meeting of the qualified voters of a common school district which had been included in a central school district, it was decided by a majority vote to close heir schoolhouse and to sell such real property to a neighborhood church for $2,000, as against an offer by the local grange of $3,000, and as against a proposed offer of $4,000 by one of the petitioners in this proceeding, who are private individuals. Pursuant to such a vote, the board of education of the central school district entered into a contract to sell the property to the church. Petitioners chose to appeal to the State Commissioner of Education instead of to [***3] the courts, and the commissioner sustained the making of the contract. In such case the commissioner's determination is conclusive (Education Law, § 310), unless it is so arbitrary that no reasonable man could reach such result, or unless the commissioner's interpretation of a statute would produce an unconstitutional result.

2. The property of a pre-existing common school district may be sold by the board of education upon a majority vote of the qualified voters of the district (§ 1804, subd. 6). The further provision in said subdivision 6 that the net proceeds of the sale shall be distributed among the taxpayers of such district was not intended to deprive the voters of normal discretionary power. In the absence of a specific statutory provision, the board of a municipal or other public corporation is not required to use competitive bidding in selling its property. Furthermore, "Whenever the site of a schoolhouse shall have been changed * * * the inhabitants of a district entitled to vote, lawfully assembled at any district meeting, shall have power, by a majority of the votes of those present and voting, to direct the sale of the former site or lot, and the buildings thereon [***4] and appurtenances or any part thereof, at such price and upon such terms as they shall deem proper" (§ 402, subd. 1).

3. A bona fide sale for a substantial price is not a gift prohibited by the State Constitution (art. VIII, § 1).

4. The commissioner's decision and interpretation of the statutes does not result in depriving the minority of the voters, and the taxpayers who are not residents of the district and who are therefore not entitled to vote, of any interest in property without due process of law. The taxpayers have no vested interest in the property. The Legislature could, if it wished, have directed that the proceeds of the sale be turned over to the central school district instead of being distributed among the taxpayers of the common school district. As a matter of fact, the Legislature has provided for that disposition of the proceeds of sales under subdivision 6 of section 1804, upon approval by a majority of the voters of the district, in the case of sales taking place after March 31, 1954 (L. 1954, ch. 362); and under the present statute, too, the taxpayers had no right to the proceeds, except to the extent that the Legislature gave it to them.

5. The commissioner's [***5] action was not arbitrary or wholly lacking in rationality. Accordingly, an order of Special Term annulling the commissioner's determination should be reversed and the petition dismissed.

 Matter of Ross v. Wilson, 205 Misc. 295, reversed.

 

1136 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


International Harvester Credit Corp. v. Goodrich


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


284 A.D. 604; 132 N.Y.S.2d 511; 1954 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3450



July 8, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff vendor filed an action against defendant New York Tax Commission and challenged the validity of the Commission's assessment of highway use tax against vehicles that the vendor had repossessed.


OVERVIEW: The vendor sold three tractors to a carrier, which was subject to the highway use tax pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law art. 21. The carrier defaulted on its payments and the vendor repossessed the tractors. The Commission then asserted a lien against the tractors for unpaid taxes. The vendor filed an action against the Commission and challenged the validity of the lien. The court found that the Commission had lien priority regarding the unpaid taxes. The court reasoned that the tax was imposed on the carrier for its use of the State's highways. Furthermore, if the tax went unpaid then the Commission was entitled to seek recourse against the property. Therefore, the court found that the Commission's lien had priority.


OUTCOME: The court found in favor of the Tax Commission.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - highway use tax - priority of lien - constitutional law - (1) tax on carriers using highways attaches at "time of operation of any motor vehicle" and is "paramount to all prior liens * * * and to the rights of any holder of the legal title in or to any such motor vehicle" (Tax Law, art. 21, § 506); such sovereign priority of lien is constitutional - (2) title of assignee of conditional vendor, which repossessed vehicles, is subject to lien of such taxes incurred by conditional vendee - (3) such lien includes taxes incurred by vendee in its operation of other vehicles both before and after it bought vehicles which were eventually repossessed; also included are taxes assessed after such repossession for periods prior to such repossession - (4) but statute does not impose lien on vehicle for taxes of vendee accruing after repossession by vendor - (5) statute constitutional despite provisions for seizure and sale without notice of tax deficiencies and secrecy of tax returns and failure to provide for notice of assessment of tax deficiencies.

1. The highway use tax on carriers using [***2] motor vehicles on the highways (Tax Law, art. 21) has been declared constitutional (Mid-States Frgt. Lines v. Bates, 304 N.Y. 700, certiorari denied 345 U.S. 908). Likewise constitutional and within the sovereign prerogative is the provision of section 506 (in art. 21) that the tax "shall constitute a lien upon all motor vehicles * * * of such carrier" and that such "lien shall attach at the time of operation of any motor vehicle * * * of such carrier within this state and * * * shall be paramount to all prior liens or encumbrances * * * and to the rights of any holder of the legal title in or to any such motor vehicle".

2. Thus, the title of the assignee of a conditional vendor, which, after the conditional vendee defaulted in payments under such sales contracts, repossessed such motor vehicles, is subject to the lien of the State for unpaid taxes, penalties and interest due from the conditional vendee.

3. Such lien includes (1) taxes incurred by the vendee as a result of its operation of the repossessed vehicles, (2) taxes incurred by the vendee as a result of its operation of other vehicles purchased from the same vendors or from other vendors, (3) taxes incurred by [***3] the vendee both prior and subsequent to its purchase of the trucks which were eventually repossessed, and (4) taxes for periods prior to such repossession, including any taxes assessed therefor after such repossession.

4. But the statute does not impose a lien on a motor vehicle for taxes accruing against the conditional vendee after the conditional vendor has repossessed the vehicle.

5. The statute is not to be adjudged unconstitutional on the ground that some hardship may result from its failure to provide for notice of assessment of tax deficiencies, its provisions for seizure and sale of vehicles without notice, and its provisions for secrecy of tax returns. It is not reasonable to assume that the tax authorities will administer the law in such manner as to produce unnecessary inequities.

 

1137 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


KANSAS PACKING CO. v. CITY OF NEW YORK


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


284 A.D. 398; 1954 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3412



June 15, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of a decision of the Supreme Court at a Special Term, New York County (New York), which decreed that respondent packaging company was entitled to declaratory judgment, declared New York City, N.Y., Sanitary Code § 140a was unconstitutional, void, and could not be enforced against the company's products in interstate commerce, and enjoined the city from so enforcing § 140a against the company and its products.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to New York City, N.Y., Sanitary Code § 140a, it was unlawful to "bring into" the city or to "keep" in the city corned beef briskets containing added water greater than 10 percent of the weight of the meat. A certain percentage of the company's products were procured in the city and sold in the city where the company had its establishment. The trial court found that § 140a conflicted with the Meat Packing Act, 21 U.S.C.S. § 87, which permitted 20 percent of water, and infringed on a federal policy so far as interstate commerce was concerned. The trial court declared New York City, N.Y., Sanitary Code § 140a unconstitutional and enjoined the city from enforcing it against the company. On appeal, the court held that the city had in its police power the right to regulate the quantity of water in corned beef briskets insofar as its regulation affected solely intrastate commerce. The court noted that Congress did not intend completely to occupy the field involved, but that the Meat Packing Act expressly made an exception with regard to persons who transported or sold meat in a state in which the establishment was located.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment so as to strike down the statute as void only insofar as it violated the company's rights and privileges in interstate commerce and, and as so modified, affirmed the judgment.


HEADNOTES

Commerce - interstate and intrastate - city and Federal meat regulations - Federal Meat Packing Act excepts those who transport or sell meat in State in which their establishment is located; Federal regulation allows 20% increase [**2] in weight of beef briskets by curing, whereas New York City Sanitary Code (§ 140a) allows only 10%; in action by packing company whose establishment is located in New York City, judgment should declare that city's requirement is void as to plaintiff's products in interstate commerce but is valid as to corned briskets of beef which plaintiff buys in State and sells in city.

The Meat Inspection Regulations of the Department of Agriculature were amended in 1952 (Code of Fed. Reg., tit. 9, § 17.8, subd. [c], par, [52] so as to require that the curing of beef briskets should not increase the uncured weight by more than 20%. The Sanitary Code of the City of New York (§ 140a) forbids bringing into the city or keeping therein any processed beef containing added water greater than 10% of the weight of the beef. The Federal Meat Packing Act (U.S. Code, tit. 21, § 87) expressly excepts persons who transport or sell meat in a State in which their establishment is located. Accordingly, in this action by a packing company whose establishment is located in New York City, judgment should be granted declaring that the city's requirement is void insofar as it applies to plaintiff's products [**3] in interstate commerce, but is valid as to all corned briskets of beef which plaintiff purchases in the State and sells in the city.

Kansas Packing Co. v. City of New York, 204 Misc. 1077, modified.

 

1138 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Guardian Life Ins. Co. v. Bohlinger


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


284 A.D. 110; 130 N.Y.S.2d 705; 1954 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3356



May 18, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant insurance company sought review of an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which denied the insurance company's motion for an order under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 78 to annul a determination of appellee Superintendent of Insurance (superintendent) that denied the insurance company's application for approval of a purchase of real estate.


OVERVIEW: The insurance company proposed to use part of certain real property they had acquired for its own use, which required the superintendent's approval under N.Y. Ins. Law § 81(7). After an approval hearing, the superintendent denied the insurance company's application to purchase real estate where they intended to erect their home offices. The insurance company sought judicial review of the determination, pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 78, but the trial court denied their motion. The court affirmed on appeal. The court ruled that when the right to judicial review under § 78 was not specifically granted, it was not available. The court held that the only instance in which a determination of the superintendent would have been annulled was where he had misconceived or exceeded his grant of authority under § 81(7). The court held that the fact that the superintendent had not misconceived nor exceeded its statutory grant of authority in combination with the fact that the legislature was silent on whether the court had the power to review the superintendent's determination, led to the court's decision that the superintendent's decision could not be annulled in these circumstances.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the trial court that denied the insurance company's motion to annul the decision of the superintendent that denied their application for the purchase of real estate.


HEADNOTES

Insurance - acquisition by insurance company of real estate - decision of Superintendent of Insurance denying application of insurance company for approval of purchase of real estate as requisite for company's convenient accommodation in transaction of its business was neither arbitrary nor capricious and was supported by evidence adduced on hearing; even if decision were reviewable on such review it would be determined that such decision not arbitrary or capricious; Special Term properly refused to annul such decision.

Petitioner insurance company applied to respondent Superintendent of Insurance, pursuant to the Insurance Law ( § 81, subd. 7, par. [b]), for approval of the purchase of real estate by petitioner in the city of White Plains as "requisite for its convenient accommodation in the transaction of its business". Petitioner [***2] owned a twenty-story building in New York County in which it occupied thirteen floors and rented the remaining seven floors. The seven rented floors contain sufficient space for petitioner's expansion purposes. Since 1946, petitioner has spent $400,000 in modernizing this building and, in addition, respondent, some years ago, approved the acquisition of an adjoining building to provide room for expansion. Petitioner's contemplated move to the city of White Plains, where it intends to erect a two-story office building and to occupy it in whole or in part, was planned as a temporary expedient. The superintendent, in denying petitioner's application, held that the proposed White Plains building was not "requisite" for the convenient accommodation of petitioner's business, and found that petitioner failed to demonstrate that its present quarters were inadequate for the convenient transaction of its business or that economies in the best interests of policyholders would flow from such acquisition. The superintendent further found that the proposed building was purely an interim measure, that the cost of the project would be upwards of $1,300,000, that plans for the actual use of the [***3] proposed building by petitioner had not been crystallized, and that petitioner was still endeavoring to find a proper location for a new home office building. Even if the court had power to review the decision of the Superintendent of Insurance, on such review it would be determined that his decision was neither arbitrary nor capricious, and that it had a reasonable basis and was amply supported by the evidence adduced on the hearing, and, accordingly, Special Term properly denied petitioner's application under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act to annul the superintendent's determination.

 

1139 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Jelke


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


284 A.D. 211; 130 N.Y.S.2d 662; 1954 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3374



May 18, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Court of General Sessions of the County of New York (New York) upon a verdict convicting defendant, on two counts, of the crime of compulsory prostitution of women.


OVERVIEW: The court found that an examination of the record disclosed sufficient evidence to sustain the verdict of the jury; however, the court found that defendant was deprived of a fair and impartial trial. The court found that the trial court's investigations of two different jurors on successive days relating to their qualifications to serve impartially was improper. There was no evidence of any improper conduct on the part of either juror, nor untruthful statements by either juror during voir dire. The court also found that the trial court's act of closing the trial to both public and press during the presentation of the people's case and conducting a public trial during the presentation of the defense was improper because it deprived defendant of a public trial in violation of two New York statutes, N.Y. Jud. Law § 4 and N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 8, which guaranteed to an accused a public trial. The court found that the judgment of conviction had to be reversed on the basis that defendant was denied a public trial for which prejudice to defendant was presumed.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and granted a new trial.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - right of accused to public trial - jurors - (1) judgment convicting defendant of compulsory prostitution of women should be reversed and new trial granted, since trial court examined two jurors as to their impartiality after trial was under way, and since it excluded press and general public during People's case and then let them in during defendant's case; such actions tended to intimidate jurors and witnesses and prejudiced defendant's right to fair trial - (2) during trial, jurors should not be questioned as to their qualifications based on matters preceding their acceptance - (3) also, improper for Trial Judge to talk with juror in absence of counsel for all parties - (4) trials, with certain exceptions inapplicable here, must be "public" (Code Crim. Pro., § 8; Civil Rights Law, § 12; Judiciary Law, § 4) - (5) Federal decisions construing Sixth Amendment to Federal Constitution do not apply to such New York statutes -  [***2] (6) error of totally excluding press and public during People's case was compounded by letting them in during defendant's case; effect was to shield People's witnesses from publicity and to expose defendant's witnesses.

1. Judgment on a verdict convicting defendant of compulsory prostitution of two women (Penal Law, § 2460) was sustained by sufficient evidence; but defendant did not have a fair trial and a new trial should be granted, because (a) after the jury had been accepted (Code Crim. Pro., §§ 371, 374) and during the evidence-taking part of the trial, the court examined two jurors several times as to their impartiality, and (b) the court excluded the general public and the press during the presentation of the People's case, contrary to Judiciary Law ( § 4), Code of Criminal Procedure (§ 8) and Civil Rights Law ( § 12), and then compounded the error by admitting the public and the press to the presentation of the defendant's case. Although the trial court deemed these actions to be in the interests of justice and morals and against the dissemination of obscenity, the effect on the trial was to intimidate jurors and witnesses who might honestly have been for the defendant [***3] and to protect any possibly dishonest witnesses for the People.

2. After a jury has been accepted and sworn and testimony has begun, there is generally no place in our procedure for renewed questioning of a juror as to his qualifications based on matters preceding his acceptance. there was no showing that either juror had concealed any facts or made any untruthful statement upon his voir dire examination. Furthermore, although the two jurors were questioned separately and not in the presence of the other jurymen, the latter knew that the others were being retained in court from time to time after they had departed.

3. Also, a private conversation, not in the presence of counsel for all parties, between the Trial Judge and a juror in whose mind doubts had arisen as to his ability to be impartial, was improper.

4. The traditional Anglo-American distrust of secret trials was reflected in the adoption of the Sixth Amendment to the Federal Constitution. When the courts decided that the amendment did not apply to State courts, and it was realized that out State Constitution contained no similar sefeguard, our Legislature provided in the Revised Statutes of 1829 that "the [***4] accused has a right to a * * * public trial" and that "The sittings of every court within this state, shall be public, and every citizen may freely attend the same". The firstquoted provision is now found in the Code of Criminal Procedure (§ 8) and also in the Civil Rights Law ( § 12). The second-quoted provision is now in the Judiciary Law ( § 4), to which has been added: "except that in all proceedings and trials in cases for divorce, seduction, abortion, rape, assault with intent to commit rape, sodomy, bastardy or filiation, the court may, in its discretion, exclude therefrom all persons who are not directly interested therein" - which amendment does not apply to this case.

5. Federal decisions construing the Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution do not control our courts' interpretation of these broad, New York statutes, except as the determination may be violative of the due process clause of the Federal Constitution.

6. A trial court has inherent power to exclude particular individuals if good order requires it or to clear the courtroom of spectators for a limited time to preserve order, or to exclude children, or to limit the number of spectators in an [***5] overcrowded courtroom. But it may not exclude the press and the general public during the People's case and then compound that error by admitting them to the defendant's case. A witness who testifies glibly and falsely in the secrecy of a grand jury room will often refuse or be reluctant to give the same untrue testimony upon the trial in open court, where he knows that there may be persons who can and will come forward to testify to the true facts. The ruling of the trial court in this case was, in effect, that a witness for the People would be shielded from publicity but a witness for the defense would have to testify in the pitiless glare of press and public. In such circumstances, it must be presumed that the defendant's rights to a fair trial were prejudiced.

 

1140 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Comereski v. Elmira


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


283 A.D. 556; 128 N.Y.S.2d 913; 1954 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4730



March 24, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Supreme Court, Chemung County (New York) denied a motion to dismiss for failure to state a cause of action that was filed by defendants, city and parking authority, in plaintiff taxpayer's action to void an agreement between defendants. The city and parking authority appealed the order.


OVERVIEW: The city agreed to pay to the parking authority the amount of the authority's estimated yearly deficit from the net revenues of city parking meters, so long as bonds of the parking authority remained outstanding. The taxpayer argued that the agreement was an unconstitutional gift or loan of the city's credit. The court reversed the order that denied defendants' motion to dismiss the taxpayer's complaint. N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 1 did not prohibit the city from giving or loaning money to a public corporation. The bonds were the liability of the parking authority, and did not become the obligation of the city because of the city's promise of money. The title to the money transferred to the parking authority and any payment made on the bonds was from the funds of that authority. The pledge of parking meter revenues was not a gift or loan of the credit of the city.


OUTCOME: The order denying the motion to dismiss filed by the city and parking authority was reversed and the taxpayer's complaint was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Public authorities - city parking authority - municipal corporations - traffic regulation - (1) to provide parking areas to decrease traffic congestion, City of Elmira Parking Authority Act empowered city to give real or personal property to Authority, and latter to accept loans or contributions from city and to issue bonds on which Authority alone would be liable; city charter was amended by local law to authorize contract whereby city agreed to pay any deficits of Authority up to $25,000 annually out of net revenues of existing city parking meters, total number of which should not be substantially reduced during life of agreement; agreement valid and taxpayer's action dismissed - (2) municipality cannot give its credit but it can give or lend its own money to public corporation (N.Y. Const., art. VIII, § 1) - (3) city could use its own parking meter revenues for city parking project under General Municipal Law ( § 72-j), and should be able [***2] to do so even when it uses Authority - (4) police power to use parking meters was continued, not surrendered, by agreement.

1. The City of Elmira Parking Authority is a public benefit corporation whose purpose is to provide parking areas so as to decrease traffic congestion in the city. (Public Authorities Law, art. 7, tit. 9, § 1482 et seq.) The statute provides that the city may give real to personal property to the Authority; the latter may accept grants, loans or contributions from the city; bonds or other obligations of the Authority are to be payable out of the Authority's own funds or revenues; and the Authority is to continue for five years and thereafter until all its bonds and liabilities have been paid. The Elmira City Charter (§ 73), as amended by Elmira Local Law No. 5 of 1949, permits the city council to authorize a contract whereby the city pledges to the Authority the net revenues from the city's street parking meters for as long as the bonds of the Authority might remain outstanding but in no event for longer than thirty years. Such a contract was executed when the Authority authorized issuance of its bonds in the amount of $500,000. The contract provided,  [***3] in part, that the city should pay to the Authority the amount of the latter's estimated deficit, if any, not exceeding $25,000 in any year, such payments to be made from the net revenues of existing city parking meters but not from meters later installed except as substitutes. The city further agreed that it would not substantially reduce the number of meters during the existence of the agreement, but that it nevertheless could abandon or change their sites. The agreement was valid. The complaint in this taxpayer's action to void the agreement should be dismissed.

2. The State Constitution (art. VIII, § 1) provides that a municipality shall not give or loan its money or property to or in aid of any individual or private corporation, and shall not give or loan its credit to or in aid of any individual or public or private corporation. It does not prohibit a gift or loan of moneys to a public corporation where the municipality does not borrow the money. Pledges of net meter revenues would not be gifts or loans of credit. The city is not liable on the Authority's bonds. The contract provisions are valid under title 9 of article 7 of the Public Authorities Law,  [***4] the Elmira local law, and the constitutional power of cities to regulate their property (N.Y. Const., art. IX, § 12).True, the pledge would benefit bondholders, but the city would benefit from its pledge by reason of the assurance to it of clear title to the parking project when the bonds were paid in full.

3. If the identical project had been undertaken by the city itself under section 72-j of the General Municipal Law, there would be no doubt of the city's power to use its parking meter revenues. It should not be assumed that the Legislature intended to prohibit the same thing if done through an Authority.

4. The police power of the city to regulate automotive traffic, insofar as parking meters are concerned, was not surrendered but was continued by the agreement.

 

1141 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Gulf Oil Corp. v. Joseph


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


283 A.D. 309; 127 N.Y.S.2d 684; 1954 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4671



February 16, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer sought review, under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78, of a final determination of respondent, Comptroller of the City of New York, which denied the taxpayer's application for refund of gross receipts taxes.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer had an extensive interstate and intrastate business and sought a refund of the amount of gross receipts taxes imposed by the Comptroller for certain years for the privilege of doing business in the city. The taxpayer argued that the allocation ratios employed to determine the appropriate percentage of interstate sales subject to the tax were unconstitutional because they required a minimum of 33 1/3 percent. The court confirmed the Comptroller's denial of a refund. The court noted that the apportionment ratios did not have to be mathematically perfect, but only needed to be a rough approximation to satisfy constitutional requirements. Because the taxpayer's percentages were close to the minimum, the court concluded that the taxpayer could not claim that the ratios worked a hardship. In addition, the court determined that taxpayer could have applied for the use of a different method under the regulations of the Comptroller, but did not do so.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the determination of the Comptroller denying a refund.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - taxation - New York City gross receipts tax - (1) petitioner engaged in interstate oil business not entitled to refund of New York City gross receipts taxes for privilege of doing business in New York City - (2) allocation formula established, pursuant to Administrative Code, by city comptroller to allocate percentage of interstate sales subject to tax resulted in computations of 32.2%, 30.85% and 31.9%; under formulae, average of percentages then raised to 33 1/3% which is not arbitrary - (3) since petitioner did not avail itself of opportunity to apply for different method of allocation, pursuant to comptroller's regulations, it may not now have such relief.

1. Petitioner, a Pennsylvania corporation doing an extensive interstate and intrastate oil business, is not entitled to [***2] a refund of gross receipts taxes paid during certain years for the privilege of doing business in New York City (Administrative Code, ch. 41, tit. RR). The statute provides that where receipts cannot be taxed in their entirety by reason of the Federal Constitution, the city comptroller shall establish rules and methods of allocation so that only such part of the receipts which are attributable and allocable to the doing of business in the city shall be taxed.

2. The allocation three-factor formula, established by the city comptroller pursuant to the statute, seeks to allocate the appropriate percentage of interstate sales subject to tax by striking ratios between, first, the value of the taxpayer's property in the city and the value of the property elsewhere in the United States, and, second, between the wages paid locally and elsewhere in the country. For the third factor the comptroller has devised a purported basis for computing a proper percentage of gross receipts. The three percentages thus obtained are then averaged. If the result exceeds 66 2/3%, it is reduced to that figure; if it is less than 33 1/3%, it is increased to that amount. The resultant computation becomes [***3] the percentage of interstate commerce allocated to the gross receipts tax. The computations under the three-factor formula in this case were 32.2%, 30.85% and 31.9% in the three years that the minimum requirement was used, scarcely a shocking margin in the application of formula that at best is calculated to produce approximate figures.

3. Since the petitioner did not avail itself of the opportunity to make application for a different and more appropriate method of allocation which it had the right to request under the comptroller's regulations if "any of the prescribed allocation formulae works unfairly or inequitably" to a taxpayer, it may not now have such relief.

 

1142 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Williams v. Aircooled Motors, Inc.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Fourth Department


283 A.D. 187; 127 N.Y.S.2d 135; 1954 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4645; 24 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P68,076



January 6, 1954 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff employee appealed an order of the County Court of Onondaga County (New York), which affirmed a judgment of the Municipal Court of the City of Syracuse, which granted a motion by defendant employer for summary judgment dismissing the employee's complaint in his action to recover overtime claimed to be due under the provisions of N.Y. Elec. Law § 226, relating to time allowed employees to vote.


OVERVIEW: The employer's contract with the union required compensation according to time and one-half for hours in excess of eight in any one day and forty in any one week. The employer had also contracted to comply with the requirements of the New York State Election Law in allowing time off with pay to vote. Section 226 provided that on Election Day any voter could be absent for two hours while the polls were open and that no deduction could be made from the usual salary or wages of the voter. The two hours the employee spent voting in addition to the seven hours worked that day equaled nine hours, and the employee sought overtime for the ninth hour. The court reversed the trial court's order, which dismissed the employee's complaint. The court held that § 226 required that the employee be paid on Election Day precisely what he would have earned had he remained on the job for nine hours. The court held further that the normal work day determined the employee's usual salary or wages from which a deduction was prohibited.


OUTCOME: The court reversed on the law and granted summary judgment in favor of the employee.


HEADNOTES

Elections - compensation for time off for voting - (1) employee was paid $17.10 for his usual nine-hour day, eight hours at straight time of $1.80 and $2.70 for ninth hour at time and one-half; employee worked seven hours on Election Day and was given succeeding two hours off to vote; employee should have been paid at time and one-half for second hour off so as to receive "usual salary or wages" within Election Law (§ 226) - (2) statute constitutional even if construed to require overtime for hours not worked.

1. An employer's usual operations included a nine-hour day and forty-five-hour week, with overtime being paid for each hour in excess of eight in any one day. Plaintiff employee's compensation was $1.80 per hour for straight time and $2.70 per hour for overtime so that he earned $17.10 per day. Where the employee worked seven hours on Election Day and the employer [***2] gave him the succeeding two hours off with pay to vote, as provided by section 226 of the Election Law, he should have been paid time and one-half for the second of the two hours. By paying the employee at straight time for the ninth hour, the employer did not give the employee $17.10 per day, which was his "usual salary or wages" within the meaning of section 226 of the Election Law. The "usual salary or wages" is the amount received on a typical working day, and cannot be construed to indicate the usual hourly rate of wages.

2. The statute is constitutional even if construed to require the payment of overtime for hours not actually worked.

 

1143 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Mancuso v. Board of Education


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


282 A.D. 1097; 126 N.Y.S.2d 537; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5907



December 22, 1953 

 

1144 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Gibbs v. Wallin


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


282 A.D. 578; 125 N.Y.S.2d 699; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4527



November 20, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner physician appealed an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Albany County (New York), dismissing an application for an order under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 directing respondents, the members of a state university board of regents (regents), to stay all proceedings in a pending disciplinary proceeding to revoke petitioner's medical license on the grounds that N.Y. Educ. Law § 6514(2) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The physician challenged the supreme court's order denying his application for an order in the nature of prohibition to prevent the regents from going forward to consider allegations that he was insane, that he was a drug addict, and that he was guilty of fraud and deceit in the practice of medicine by reason of a mental affliction or illness. The physician also claimed that N.Y. Educ. Law § 6514(2), which authorized the proceeding, was unconstitutional. The court affirmed the order denying relief. Noting that prohibition was an extraordinary remedy which should only be utilized when there was no other appropriate remedy, the court held that N.Y. Educ. Law § 6515(5) expressly provided for review of any disciplinary determination of the regents and that claims of unconstitutionality were cognizable therein. As for the constitutional challenge, however, the court held that N.Y. Educ. Law § 6514(2) was constitutional because the legislature had the power to authorize the regents to determine an issue of insanity with relation to the right of a physician to practice medicine without invading the physician's personal or property rights under either the state or federal constitutions.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the supreme court dismissing the physician's application for an order staying any proceedings by the regents on a pending disciplinary matter.


HEADNOTES

Physicians and surgeons - Board of Regents - prohibition - constitutional law - prohibition will not lie to halt proceedings by Board of Regents to revoke physician's license for fraud, addiction or insanity; determination, including constitutionality, reviewable by proceeding to review (Education Law, § 6514, subd. 2; § 6515, subd. 5); statute giving Board of Regents power to determine licensee's sanity not unconstitutional. 

The Board of Regents may revoke a physician's license on the ground that he is guilty of fraud in medical practice or that he is a drug addict or that he has become insane, and its determination is reviewable by the court. (Education Law, § 6514, subd. 2; § 6515, subd. 5.) Such a determination of insanity would [***2] apply only to the right to practice medicine and not to the physician's personal or property rights. With such limitation the statute giving the Board of Regents the power to determine insanity is not repugnant to any constitutional provision. In any event, the question of constitutionality could be determined in the proceeding to review and the instant application for an order in the nature of prohibition against further steps by the board was properly dismissed.

 

1145 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Broadway Angels, Inc. v. Wilson


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


282 A.D. 643; 125 N.Y.S.2d 546; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4544



November 18, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: On transfer from the Supreme Court, Special Term, Albany County (New York), the court reviewed in a N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 proceeding the determination of respondents, the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York and Commissioner of Education of the State of New York, refusing to license petitioner applicant's film about a teenage drug addict upon the ground that the public exhibition would corrupt morals and incite crime.


OVERVIEW: The applicant sought to license a motion picture entitled "Teenage Menace" that depicted the brief life span of a teenage drug addict from his first marijuana cigarette to his death from a poisoned heroin fix. Finding that the film was viciously immoral and that its public showing would tend to corrupt morals and incite crime, the Regents affirmed a determination of respondent state official and refused to license the film for public exhibition pursuant to N.Y. Educ. Law § 122. Upon review, the court annulled the Regents' determination against the applicant by finding that, although § 122 validly delegated the power of licensing motion pictures to the Regents as a proper exercise of the state's power to deem motion pictures offensive to public morals, the findings that the immoral film would tend to corrupt morals and incite crime were not sustained by the evidence. Although the film was a sordid and dismaying picture of mental and physical misery, despair, degradation, and health, the film portrayed nothing visually or orally having to do with sex or sexual immorality, and the Regents' predictions that viewers would possess and use illegal drugs were purely speculative.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the Board of Regents' determination against the applicant with $ 50 costs and disbursements to the applicant.


HEADNOTES

Theatres and shows - censorship - motion picture story of teenage drug addict - (1) court annuls refusal of Board of Regents to license motion picture showing misery and death of teenage addict of heroin injections, since such picture does not "incite to crime" (Education Law, § 122) - (2) other words of statute, "to corrupt morals", mean sexual morals only.

1. A determination of the Board of Regents, refusing to license a motion picture which depicts how a teenager is lured by his friend into smoking a marijuana cigarette and then into injecting heroin, first intramuscularly and later into his arteries, and how instead of experiencing exaltation he experiences misery and a desperate and mounting need for more heroin, and how the drug peddler is compelled to give him more heroin by threats of exposure [***2] to the police, and how the teenager dies after injecting himself with some of the drug which the peddler had poisoned, is annulled. It does not "incite to crime" (Education Law, § 122).

2. Nor does the picture "tend to corrupt morals" since those words in the statute have been limited, for constitutional purposes, to mean sexual morals only.

 

1146 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Defiance Milk Products Co. v. Du Mond


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


282 A.D. 977; 125 N.Y.S.2d 533; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5610



November 12, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff company sought review of an order of a supreme court of Albany County (New York) that denied the company's motion under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 113 to strike out the answer of defendant Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets of the State of New York and for summary judgment, in the company's action to declare N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 64(2) unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The company manufactures and sells evaporated skimmed milk. When the company was advised that its sale of such milk in small containers in New York violated § 64(2), which restricted such sales to containers of 10 pounds or more, it brought the present action. The court ruled that the lower court properly declined to resolve the constitutionality of § 64(2) by affidavits. While the constitutionality of a statute could have been tested in a declaratory judgment action, such an issue often could not have been resolved by affidavits.
