In the present case, the answer contained substantial denials, and the answering affidavits raised the issue that the statute was a reasonable exercise of police power. Specifically, the court noted that a fair inference of legislative intent was that the statute was passed to protect consumers from mistakenly believing that they were purchasing evaporated whole milk, rather than evaporated skimmed milk. The court observed that evaporated whole milk commonly was marketed in small containers. Because the reasonableness of a statute arguably involving an exercise of the State's police power was raised, the action was properly not decided on affidavits.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the supreme court's order. The court also assessed costs against the company.

 

1147 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Bailey v. American Soc. for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


282 A.D. 502; 125 N.Y.S.2d 18; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4503



October 27, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a non-profit society, appealed an order from the Supreme Court of New York County (New York), which denied the society's motion to dismiss for failure to state a cause of action, or in the alternative for summary judgment, plaintiff members' action for a judgment declaring certain by-laws of the society void and for a judicial determination of the rights of the parties.


OVERVIEW: The members claimed that there was an unlawful usurpation of power by the board of managers of the society in various respects to the injury and deprivation of the members' rights and that that the bylaws were adopted unlawfully. On appeal, the court ruled that: (1) the members' claim that the bylaws were in conflict with the Membership Corporation law was meritless because N.Y. Membership Corp. Law § 2 excluded the Society from its provisions; (2) there was no present justiciable issue as to whether the bylaws were illegally or improperly adopted because the bylaws were ratified by members of the Society almost 50 years before the members' action; (3) the claims that the board unlawfully usurped too much power to itself with respect to acceptance of new members and expulsion of present members and in respect to self-perpetuation of control by selection of successors to the board were meritless because there was no allegation that particular applicants or members were rejected or expelled, and the board's election of successors did not infringe the members' rights; and (4) the issue regarding the size of a quorum provided for in the bylaws was not ripe for adjudication.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the members' complaint.


HEADNOTES

Corporations - membership corporations - (1) complaint of minority of members of American Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, that by-laws were illegally adopted and that board of managers had usurped excessive power to accept or expel members and to select their own successors in office, dismissed - (2) procedural irregularities in adoption of by-laws in 1900 and 1907 were waived by members' ratification; no allegation that anyone excluded or expelled; after fifty years, no justiciable issue - (3) by-laws giving board of nonprofit corporation control of election of successors do not infringe enforcible rights of members - (4) Membership Corporations Law (§ 2) excludes corporations created by special act, such as defendant - (5) no present need for judicial declaration as to whether quorum of five is sufficient in board of managers, under General Corporation Law (§ 27).

1. The [***2] American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals was incorporated by special act (L. 1866, ch. 469), which authorized the society to adopt by-laws not inconsistent with the laws of the State. Plaintiffs, a small minority of the society, complain that amendments to the by-laws were illegally adopted in 1900 and 1907 and that the board of managers had usurped excessive powers with respect to acceptance and expulsion of members of the society and self-perpetuation of the board by control of selection of its successors. The complaint should be dismissed.

2. The amendments appear to have been adopted or ratified at meetings of the members of the society and apparently the members waived any procedural irregularities in the steps preliminary to the introduction of amendments. It is not alleged that any persons have been improperly excluded or expelled. After approximately fifty years, and at least as to members who joined the society after 1907, there is no justiciable issue; but even if there were, defendant would be entitled to summary judgment.

3. Provisions in the by-laws of charitable or nonprofit corporations under which the board controls the election of its successors [***3] do not infringe on any enforcible rights of ordinary members.

4. The Membership Corporations Law (§ 2) excludes from its requirements corporations such as this, created by special act.

5. The by-laws were lawful when adopted. Perhaps the provision that five members of the board constitute a quorum runs counter to the present requirements of the General Corporation Law (§ 27); but there is no present need for a judicial declaration as to that point, since there is no allegation that defendant has adopted any resolutions by a vote of only five.

 

1148 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Kluczynski v. Hospital Service Corp.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


282 A.D. 276; 123 N.Y.S.2d 183; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4455



July 2, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employer sought review of the decision of respondent, the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board, in an action by respondent employee for disability benefits for an injury out of the course of the employee's employment.


OVERVIEW: The employee was engaged with the employer, who was a nonprofit hospital service corporation. The employee was injured out of the course of her employment and filed a claim for disability benefits under N.Y. Workmen's Comp. Law art. 9. The employee's claim was allowed and benefits awarded. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that the employer was not exempt from contributions to disability benefits by virtue of its non-profit status. The court determined that the use of the word "contribution" in N.Y. Workmen's Comp Law did not encompass the word "tax" or the word "tax" would have been used by the New York State Legislature. The court concluded that under N.Y. Ins. Law § 251(3), the exemption from tax did not include the liability of the employer for contributions to its employee's disability benefits.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the entry of an award in favor of the employee.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - employees' disability benefits - taxation - "taxes" and "contributions" - (1) nonprofit hospital service corporation "exempt from every state, county and municipal tax" (Insurance Law, § 251) but not from "contributions" under Disability Benefits Law (Workmen's Compensation Law, art. 9) - (2) such law, providing for contributions with which to pay benefits for disabilities not connected with employment, is constitutional,

1. A nonprofit hospital service corporation is "exempt from every state, county and municipal tax" (Insurance Law, art. 9-C, § 251, subd. 3), but not from "contributions" for disability benefits under article 9 of the Workmen's Compensation Law. Such "contributions" are not the usual taxes paid to State, county or municipality for its own purposes.

2. The Disability Benefits Law (Workmen's Compensation Law, art. 9), providing for contributions from employees and employers with which to pay benefits to employees for disabilities not connected with their employment, is a valid exercise of [***2] the police power of the State for the public welfare.

 

1149 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Adler v. Wilson


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


282 A.D. 418; 123 N.Y.S.2d 655; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4485



July 2, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant former teachers sought review of a decision by the Albany County Supreme Court, Special Term (New York), which dismissed a proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 to review determinations of respondents, a board of education and the Commissioner of Education of the State of New York, suspending the teachers from their positions.


OVERVIEW: The teachers were suspended for their refusal to answer questions regarding their membership in the Communist party. The teachers appealed their suspensions to the Commissioner, who dismissed the appeals. A proceeding was then instituted for an order under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 to review the Commissioner's decision. The trial court dismissed the petition. On appeal, the court affirmed the trial court's decision. The court held that the board had the authority to question the teachers as to their Communist party membership. The court noted that N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 26-a prohibited asking any employees in the civil service their political affiliations as a test of their fitness to hold office. The court stated, however, that § 26-a did not prohibit questioning concerning Communist party membership because the statute did not envision a condition in which a group dedicated to the doctrine of the overthrow of democratic government, by force and violence if necessary, would assume the form of a political party. The court determined that the power to question the teachers as their affiliations was vested not solely in the state, but in the various boards of education as well.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the trial court.


HEADNOTES

Schools - teachers - membership in Communist party - (1) board of education adopted declaration of policy requiring teachers to answer inquiries by superintendent of schools as to their past or present membership in Communist party; teachers who refused to answer questions were suspended; proceeding to review decision of Commissioner of Education dismissing teachers' appeals properly dismissed - (2) right of board and superintendent to question teachers as to Communist party membership and obligation of teachers to answer conclusively established - (3) Feinberg Law (L. 1949, ch. 360) provisions that Board of Regents conduct inquiries and list subversive organizations not exclusive; law not intended to limit local boards' right to examine - (4) board's declaration of policy not invalid as inconsistent with Feinberg Law or other statutes - (5) provisions in Civil Service Law ( §§ 25, 26-a) prohibiting asking political opinions [***2] or affiliations of employees of State or its subdivisions do not prohibit questioning as to Communist party membership.

1. The New York City Board of Education adopted a declaration of policy which stated that a member of the Communist party is not qualified to continue as a teacher or employee in the school system, that past membership in the party may establish present membership, and that, on inquiry by the superintendent of schools, the failure of any teacher to make full disclosure as to past and present participation should be regarded as an insubordinate act. Five teachers employed by the board refused to answer questions as to past and present membership in the Communist party, and another, who denied present membership, refused to answer as to past membership. The teachers, who were thereupon suspended, appealed from such disciplinary action to the Commissioner of Education who dismissed their appeals. The decisions of the commissioner were not contrary to law and were neither arbitrary nor capricious. A proceeding to review the commissioner's decisions was properly dismissed.

2. The right of the board and the superintendent to question teachers as to their past [***3] or present membership in the Communist party and their obligation to answer such questions has been conclusively established. ( Garner v. Los Angeles Bd., 341 U.S. 716, followed.)

3. The Feinberg Law (L. 1949, ch. 360, adding § 3022 to the Education Law) which directed the Board of Regents to adopt rules for the better enforcement of existing statutes (Education Law, § 3021; Civil Service Law, § 12-a), to list organizations found, after inquiry and hearing on notice, to be subversive, and to make rules that membership in any such organization shall constitute prima facie evidence of disqualification for appointment or retention in any public school position, subtracted nothing from the substantive and procedural provisions of existing law. It is not exclusive in its application to an inquiry of the nature here considered. The rule of evidence fixed by the law as to a rebuttable presumption of disqualification for public school employment because of membership in a certain type of organization related to the power of dismissal which is not at issue here. The function of the law was that of implementation and no legislative intent to limit the local school authorities'  [***4] right and performance of a duty to examine into the very matters of which the Legislature was complaining may be read into the law.

4. The board's declaration of policy stated a policy but purported to add nothing to the power of inquiry and investigation already resident in local school authorities. Moreover, after taking official notice of applicable Federal and State statutes, including the Feinberg Law, the declaration explicitly reserved all safeguards to any teacher accused of subversive activity and allowed such teacher to controvert any evidence of Communist party membership. The declaration is not invalid as inconsistent or incompatible with the Feinberg Law.

5. Sections 25 and 26-a of the Civil Service Law, which forbid questioning relating to the political opinions or affiliations of any person having to do with the civil service of the State or its subdivisions, do not prohibit questioning as to the Communist party membership of public school teachers.

 Matter of Adler v. Wilson, 203 Misc. 456, affirmed.

 

1150 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Rockland County Anti-Reservoir Ass'n v. Duryea


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


282 A.D. 457; 123 N.Y.S.2d 445; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4490



July 2, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner association filed a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 to review and annul a determination of respondents, Water Power and Control Commission (commission) and its officers, that had approved an application by a water company subsidiary for the construction of a reservoir that was alleged to have excess capacity so as to benefit the parent company.


OVERVIEW: After the commission approved an application by a water company subsidiary for the construction of a water reservoir, the association filed a proceeding under § 78 to review and annul that determination. The association contended that the reservoir was to be built with excess capacity intended for the sole benefit of the parent company. The court confirmed the commission's decision to approve the application, holding that the commission based its decision upon sufficient evidence. The requirements of N.Y. Conserv. Law § 523 were satisfied because the plans made fair and equitable provision for the determination and payment of any legal damages to persons and property. Further, the commission's findings upon the subject of public necessity were adequate and the commission was not required to make any findings as to the comparative costs of wells and the reservoir. Finally, the provision of § 396 that allowed the commission members to delegate their authority to a subordinate was constitutional and the legislature did not overstep its powers in enacting such a statute.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the determination of the commission to approve the application by a water company subsidiary for the construction of a reservoir.


HEADNOTES

Public utilities - water supply - (1) Water Power and Control Commission made determination approving water supply company's application to construct reservoir; objections to sufficiency of commission's findings are without merit; determination confirmed - (2) commission's findings complied with requirement (Conservation Law, § 523) that plan be shown to provide for fixing and payment of damages to persons affected by project; objections alleging inadequate assurance of payment for damages are without substance - (3) commission's findings adequate as to public necessity for project; no need for findings as to its cost compared with that of drilling additional wells which commission found unacceptable method of augmenting company's water supply - (4) commission not required [***2] to make findings as to effect of project on consumers' water rates; determination of rate bases reflecting proportionate costs of project to company and its parent company to be made only by regulatory commissions - (5) provision (Conservation Law, § 396) that regular members of commission may appoint deputies or subordinate employees to act on commission in their stead and may appoint substitutes not unconstitutional delegation of legislative power; section is valid and constitutional.

1. The State Water Power and Control Commission approved an application by a water supply company to construct an impounding reservoir on the Hackensack River. The commission found that, in view of the steady growth of communities served by the company and the expanding needs of its industrial consumers, the acquisition of additional sources of supply was necessary inasmuch as the company was meeting current demands by overpumping its wells, its only source of supply. The commission also found on the basis of substantial evidence that, although the reservoir would provide a supply in excess of the company's current requirements, an additional source of such magnitude was essential to assure an [***3] adequate supply for present and future needs. It further found that although the reservoir, by regulating water flow in the river, would benefit downstream owners, including the water company's parent company which supplies water to northern New Jersey communities from its New Jersey reservoirs on the river, such benefit was a necessary and incidental effect of the reservoir project. Objections to the sufficiency of the commission's findings are without merit and its determination is confirmed.

2. The commission's findings, based on substantial evidence, were adequate to comply with the requirement (Conservation Law, § 523) that it make findings as to whether the plans "make fair and equitable provisions for the determination and payment of any and all legal damages to persons and property" affected by the project. In addition to making such statutory finding in the language of the statute, the commission found that an intercompany plan between the water supply company and its parent company provided for sufficient funds to pay all costs of the project including acquisition of necessary lands. Inasmuch as such financing plan requires approval of the Public Service Commission [***4] and the New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners, the Water Power and Control Commission's decision, providing that its approval of the reservoir construction would not become effective until the regulatory commissions had approved the financial plan, was a sensible, if not the only possible, method of dealing with the problem. Objections that this solution does not afford adequate assurance of payment of all legal damages to owners of lands to be taken are without substance since no lands will be taken until the financing plan is approved.

3. The commission's findings as to the public necessity for the project were adequate. Inasmuch as it had found, on substantial evidence, that drilling additional wells was not an acceptable method of supplying the water company's needs, no findings as to the comparative costs of such wells and of the reservoir were necessary to enable the commission to reach a fair determination as to the public necessity for the reservoir.

4. There was no need for the commission to make any findings as to the effect of the reservoir upon the water rates payable by the company's consumers. The commission had no power to determine what portions [***5] of the cost should be reflected in the rate bases of the water supply company and of its parent company. Such determinations may be made only by the regulatory commissions.

5. Section 396 of the Conservation Law provides that the regular members of the Water Power and Control Commission (the Conservation Commissioner, the Superintendent of Public Works and the Attorney-General) may designate deputies to act as members of the commission in place of their principals. The further provision in the section that, in case both a regular member and his alternate are unavailable on any occasion, the member may designate any suitable employee of his department to act for him involves no unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority. The Legislature may constitutionally vest the power of decision in the first instance in holders of designated offices, and then authorize them to redelegate or subdelegate such power to other officers or employees selected by them. Section 396 is valid and constitutional.

 

1151 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Black River Regulating Dist. v. Adirondack League Club


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Fourth Department


282 A.D. 161; 121 N.Y.S.2d 893; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4424



May 27, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, river regulating district and others (district), sought review of the order and judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which granted defendant club's motion for summary judgment and dismissed the district's declaratory judgment action pursuant to N.Y. R. Civ. Prac. 113.


OVERVIEW: The district's plan for constructing a reservoir was disposed of by the Stokes Act, 1950 N.Y. Laws 803, which amended N.Y. Conserv. Law § 445. The Stokes Act prohibited reservoirs in the area where the district had planned such construction. The district filed an action, seeking a declaration that Stokes Act was void as impairing the obligation of the bonds that were issued to finance the construction, and a declaration that it was entitled to condemn the club's property and complete the reservoir project. On appeal, the court reversed the trial court's order and judgment that granted the club's motion for summary judgment and dismissed the district's action. The court ordered that bondholders within the jurisdiction were conditionally necessary parties, which should have been brought in as parties to the action. The court held that removal of the district power to issue bonds and levy taxes to retire the bonds gave the district an independent interest separate and apart from their status as agents of the state. Thus, the district was to test the validity of the Stokes Act. The state was not an indispensable party, thus the trial court did not lack subject matter jurisdiction.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment that dismissed the district's declaratory judgment action by granting the club's motion for summary judgment. The court ordered that persons in the jurisdiction who held bonds for the district's planned reservoir construction project were to be brought into the declaratory judgment action, as they were conditionally necessary parties.


HEADNOTES

Declaratory judgments - constitutionality of law prohibiting river regulating district from constructing reservoir - conditionally necessary parties - State forest preserve - effect of Court of Appeals decision - (1) river regulating district sold bonds to public to pay for work done preliminarily to condemning defendant's lands, contructing reservoir, and then levying taxes on benefited areas to pay bonds; Legislature amended Conservation Law (§ 445) to prohibit reservoir in that area; district asserts it cannot pay bonds; district may maintain action against defendant for judgment declaring amendment unconstitutional - (2) Court of Appeals, in dismissing petition of defendant to review determination of district board to build reservoir, did not pass on constitutionality of amendment - (3) if amendment now be declared invalid, defendant may apply to Court of Appeals for reargument - (4) although district is [***2] public corporation, it may question validity of statute - (5) State cannot be made party, but it is only conditionally necessary (Civ. Prac. Act, § 193) - (6) owners of bonds are conditionally necessary parties; those within jurisdiction should be joined.

1. The Black River Regulating District, a public corporation (Conservation Law, art. VII), determined after a public hearing to construct a Panther Mountain Reservoir to regulate the flow of the Moose River. The plan, approved by the State Conservation Commission, required the use of approximately 1,500 acres of the Adirondack Forest Preserve owned by the State and about 3,500 acres of land owned by a corporation called the Adirondack League Club. On the club's petition to review the determination (Conservation Law, § 454), the Appellate Division confirmed the determination. Then the Legislature declared (L. 1950, ch. 803, amdg. Conservation Law, § 445) that "No reservoirs for the regulation of the flow of streams * * * shall be hereafter constructed * * * on * * * the Moose River by any river regulating board." The Court of Appeals thereupon decided (301 N.Y. 219) that the issues had become moot and directed that the review [***3] petition of the club be dismissed. The district may now maintain this action against the club, in which the complaint alleges that the district and incurred an indebtedness of $203,000 for work preliminary to the construction of the reservoir and had sold its bonds in that amount to the public, that it now has no means of paying the bonds except through condemning the club's property, completing the reservoir, and then levying taxes on the properties benefited, and that judgment should be rendered declaring the amendment to section 445 void as impairing the obligation of the district's bonds.

2. The Court of Appeals did not pass upon the constitutionality of the amendment.

3. If that amendment should be declared invalid in this action, the issues would no longer be moot, and then the club, if it still wished to have a further judicial review of the board's determination, could apply to the Court of Appeals for reargument of the dismissal of its review proceeding.

4. Although in general a public corporation or State agency cannot question the validity of an act of the Legislature, this district has an independent interest sufficient to entitle it to do so, since its bonds [***4] were apparently not guaranteed by the State.

5. The State, because of its immunity, cannot be made a party to this action for a declaratory judgment. However, it is only a conditionally necessary party and not an indispensable party (Civ. Prac. Act, § 193). The Attorney-General, pursuant to section 71 of the Executive Law, has filed a brief in support of the constitutionality of the act and has orally argued every conceivable interest of the State. Although, nevertheless, the judgment will not bind the State, it appears unlikely that the State will litigate further. The district should not be left without a remedy. The court should exercise its discretion to assume jurisdiction of this action for a declaratory judgment.

6. The owners of the bonds issued by the district are conditionally necessary parties. Such of them as are within the jurisdiction of the court should be brought in as parties.

 Black Riv. Reg. Dist. v. Adirondack League Club, 201 Misc. 808, reversed.

 

1152 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


New Rochelle v. Seacord


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Second Department


281 A.D. 1039; 121 N.Y.S.2d 558; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4260



May 18, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owner challenged an order of the trial court (New York), which granted respondent city's motion for partial summary judgment, denied the owner's cross motion to amend the answer, and entered a judgment in the tax lien foreclosure action.


OVERVIEW: The court ruled that the motion for summary judgment was properly granted, reasoning that the city complied with the notice requirements of N.Y. Tax Law art. VII-A, tit. 3, by filing an annual list of property that had tax liens. Moreover, the court noted that the statute had been held constitutional. Finally, where the owner did not show any facts or other proof to overcome the presumption that the assessment was valid under N.Y. Tax Law § 165-g, summary judgment was appropriate.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

1153 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


United Air Lines, Inc. v. Joseph


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


282 A.D. 48; 121 N.Y.S.2d 692; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4396



May 12, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer, an airline, challenged the decision of respondent comptroller (New York) to impose a gross receipts tax, contending that the tax interfered with interstate commerce.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was an airline based in Illinois that did business in New York City as part of its interstate transportation of passengers. The court annulled the comptroller's decision to assess a gross receipts tax pursuant to New York City, N.Y. Admin. Code § RR 41-2.0 because it interfered with interstate commerce in violation of the Commerce Clause, all of the taxpayer's activities with the city were incidental to its interstate business, and related intrastate activities were de minimis. The court noted that the taxpayer did pay the gross receipts tax on income it received from other airlines for service and parts.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the comptroller's decision, and ordered a refund of the gross receipts taxes paid by the taxpayer for a period of three years.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - gross receipts tax - interstate commerce - (1) New York City gross receipts tax for privilege of doing business in city not applicable to allocated receipts of air line corporation's revenues from air transport in and out of city; activities of corporation in city constitute necessary extension of its interstate air transportation; tax is local tax on interstate commerce forbidden by Federal Constitution; assessment of tax annulled and refund of taxes paid directed - (2) principle of de minimis applied to air line's revenues from sales of tickets for intrastate passage in other air lines and from sales of airplane parts and service in city; fair apportionment of corporation's traffic revenues between intracity and interstate receipts impossible [***2] as corporation not engaged in intrastate or intracity air transportation.

1. An air line corporation, chartered in Delaware and having its principal offices in Illinois and its chief maintenance base in Wyoming, operates in many States, from coast to coast and also beyond the continent. It carries no intrastate traffic in this State and, of its authorized route mileage of about 3,000 miles, only about nineteen miles are in New York City. The corporation maintains one of its chief terminals, including three traffic offices, a hangar, a parts and supplies stockroom and a repair and maintenance shop, and employs about 300 persons including a district traffic manager, in New York City. Its annual sales of passenger tickets in the city averaged over $2,000,000 and an equal amount is sold outside the city for transportation thereto. Such activities in New York City are a logical, continuous and necessary extension of the corporation's interstate transportation. Therefore, the gross receipts tax for the privilege of doing business within the city (Administrative Code, ch. 41, tit. RR) imposed by the city on a portion of the allocated receipts of the corporation derived from passenger,  [***3] mail and freight carriage between the city and out-of-State points, regardless of where contracted, is a local tax on interstate commerce forbidden by the Federal Constitution. The determination of the city comptroller assessing such tax on a minimum of one eight of the corporation's allocable receipts from air transportation is annulled and a refund directed of taxes paid for three years.

2. The corporation's sales of airplane parts and service for other air lines in the city, producing an average annual return of $12,000, and its sales, as a member of an air lines clearing house, of tickets of other air lines for passage between points in New York State are activities which are perhaps intrastate in form and therefore separable and distinct from the large principal interstate operations of the corporation. However, these matters are de minimis and not a sufficient justification to subject millions of dollars of interstate receipts to taxation and apportionment by the city. Moreover, the corporation pays a city gross receipts tax on the $12,000 average income received for parts and service. In any event, the corporation does not engage in intrastate and intracity commerce [***4] or activity so far as air transportation is concerned and accordingly there is no possible ratio between intracity and interstate receipts from air transportation and no formula of apportionment of traffic revenues can be fair.

 

1154 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


United Piece Dye Works v. Joseph


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


282 A.D. 60; 121 N.Y.S.2d 683; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4397



May 12, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner company brought a proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 to review and annul a determination of respondent Comptroller of the City of New York, which denied the company's claims for refunds of taxes imposed by the City.


OVERVIEW: The City imposed the gross receipts tax on an apportioned basis of the revenue of the company. The company resisted the payment on the ground that its revenues were derived exclusively from interstate activity. The court annulled the Comptroller's determination. The court determined that the activities of the company were exclusively in interstate commerce, and that the incidental services rendered in the City were insubstantial insofar as they did not directly relate to the company's interstate operations. The court explained that almost entirely the services rendered in the City were directly promotional or otherwise incidental to the company's interstate operations. The court noted that at the Lodi, New Jersey plant, the company employed over 1,100 persons, occupied 507,000 square feet of floor space, did the processing, and made the contracts. The court concluded that the New York office, employing 13 persons, was devoted to soliciting and to promoting the company's services. The court determined that where one was in one state, the mere selling of merchandise or services in another state did not subject one to tax jurisdiction in the other state.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the determination of the Comptroller and directed a refund of the taxes paid for the years 1947 and 1948. The court confirmed the determination with respect to the taxes paid for the year 1946.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - gross receipts tax - interstate commerce - (1) foreign corporation maintains plants for dyeing greige goods in other States; goods owned by others; no plants maintained in New York City except office to service accounts; bulk of direct customers of corporation are in New York City; corporation not subject to apportioned tax on gross receipts for privilege of doing business in New York City - (2) activities of corporation are exclusively in interstate commerce - (3) determination of city comptroller assessing apportioned tax on receipts annulled and refund directed for years 1947 and 1948 - (4) taxpayer having failed to make protest, no return of 1946 taxes ordered.

1. A corporation maintains plants in other States wherein it renders the service of dyeing greige goods and [***2] "sizing" of yarns, which goods and yarns are owned by its customers. After processing, the goods are reshipped pursuant to the instructions of the customers. The reshipments are in part to New York City, where the bulk of the direct customers of the corporation are. The corporation has an office in New York manned by thirteen employees wherein it services its accounts by advice, sales promotion, advertising and claim handling. The City of New York may not impose upon said corporation a gross receipts tax (Administrative Code, ch. 41, tit. RR; ch. 46, tit. B) for the privilege of doing business in New York City on that portion of its receipts from customers in New York City.

2. The activities of such corporation are exclusively in interstate commerce and the incidental services in rendered in New York City are insubstantial insofar as they do not directly relate to its interstate operations. Almost entirely the services rendered in New York City are directly promotional or otherwise incidental. A foreign corporation is not subject to tax jurisdiction in this State by the mere selling of merchandise or services. The advice and promotion that it gives in New York City to attract [***3] customers for its customers in New York City is not a local activity separate and distinct from its interstate operation.

3. Accordingly, a determination of the city comptroller assessing a tax on an apportioned basis should be annulled and a refund directed on taxes paid for the years 1947 and 1948.

4. With respect to taxes paid for the year 1946, the determination should be confirmed, the taxpayer having failed to make timely or proper protest.

 

1155 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Zacharakis v. Bunker Hill Mut. Ins. Co.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


281 A.D. 487; 120 N.Y.S.2d 418; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3074



March 31, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, resident of New York, appealed from an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term, New York County (New York), which denied defendant's motion to set aside service of complaint on defendant, Pennsylvania insurance company, on ground that court did not have jurisdiction of defendant as N. Y. Ins. Law § 59 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff, resident of New York and owner of New Hampshire hotel, obtained insurance policy from defendant, Pennsylvania carrier not authorized to do business in New York. After fire in hotel, plaintiff sent complaint to New York Superintendent of Insurance, which was forwarded to defendant. Defendant appealed from order denying its motion to set aside service of complaint as court did not have jurisdiction. Defendant contended N.Y. Ins. Law § 59-a was unconstitutional. Court denied motion to vacate process, and defendant appealed. N.Y. Ins. Law § 59-a provided that Superintendent of Insurance was appointed by foreign insurer as attorney for service of process in New York by performance of certain acts in New York, whether effected by mail or otherwise, including delivery of insurance contracts and collections of premiums. Court determined that when defendant mailed its insurance contract to resident of New York, and collected a premium by mail sent from New York, it came within terms of statute. Court determined N.Y. Gen. Constr. Law § 35 stated that words in plural would be construed to include singular and one policy of insurance would apply even though statute used plural.


OUTCOME: Order affirmed where court did have jurisdiction of defendant and law was not unconstitutional when acts performed within the state of New York, whether effected by mail or otherwise, were established.


HEADNOTES

Process - constructive service on foreign insurance company - constitutional law - (1) Pennsylvania insurance carrier unauthorized to do business in New York and had no office, address, agent or bank account in State; carrier issued fire insurance policy on New Hampshire hotel owned by New York resident; transaction conducted through insurance broker's New York office; policy mailed to and premium collected from New York; in action by hotel owner against carrier following fire, delivery of summons and complaint to State Superintendent of Insurance and his forwarding same to carrier constituted valid service of process on carrier - (2) Insurance Law ( § 59-a) under which service made applicable to carrier; transaction came within statutory definition of acts operating to designate superintendent as service agent - (3) use of plural terms in statute construed to include single transaction between carrier [***2] and hotel owner (General Construction Law, § 35) - (4) statute accords carrier due process.

1. An insurance carrier incorporated in and a resident of Pennsylvania was not authorized to do business in New York State. It had no office, mailing address, agent or bank account in New York and had never issued an insurance policy in this Sate. At the instance of an insurance broker the carrier issued a fire insurance policy on a New Hampshire hotel owned by a New York resident. The transaction involved telephone and mail communications between the carrier and the broker's New York office. The policy, addressed to New York, was mailed to the broker and the premium therefor was sent from New York. Subsequently a fire occurred and thereafter the summons and complaint in the hotel owner's action against the carrier were delivered to the New York State Superintendent of Insurance and forwarded by him by mail to the carrier at its Pennsylvania address. The carrier's motion to vacate the service of process on the ground no personal jurisdiction had been obtained was properly denied.

2. Section 59-a of the Insurance Law, pursuant to which the service was made, provides that "delivery [***3] of contracts of insurance to residents of this state", "collection of premiums * * * for such contracts" or "any other transaction of business" in this State "effectuated by mail or otherwise" by an unauthorized or foreign insurer operates to appoint the Superintendent of Insurance as its "true and lawful attorney" for the service of process upon it in this State. The carrier, by mailing the insurance contract to a New York resident addressed to a New York broker, by collecting the premium sent from New York and by corresponding in and out of New York as to the terms and conditions of the policy, came literally within the statute. 

3. Although the statute uses plural terms in referring to delivery of "contracts" to "residents" and collection of "premiums" for "such contracts" the singular transaction also is brought within the effect of the plural words by other portions of the statute. Moreover, practical difficulties stand in the way of any construction which would make the statute never operative unless the acts were plural and the general rule of construction is that "words * * * in the plural number include the singular" (General Construction Law, § 35). Consequently the [***4] legislative plural words are read to include the singular and the carrier's issuance of a single policy of insurance falls within the terms of the statute. 

4.The statute accords due process to the insurance carrier. The validity of constructive designation of a public officer to receive process has long been accepted in the case of an operator of a motor vehicle whose operation on the highways of a State results, by statute, in such designation. There is little perceptible difference between designation in the case of motor vehicle operators and designation occasioned by mailing a contract of insurance into the State, by receiving therefrom a premium for the policy, or by corresponding across the State line in relation to its issuance. The insurance carrier is not compelled to send its policy into, or collect its premiums from, the other State and it is not unreasonable that if these acts are engaged in they should result in the designation which the statute imposes.

 

1156 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Peters v. Robin Airlines


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Second Department


281 A.D. 903; 120 N.Y.S.2d 1; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3734



March 23, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant airline sought review of a denial by the trial court (New York) of its motion to set aside service of summons and complaint issued by respondent decedent's intestate in a suit for wrongful death.


OVERVIEW: The intestate's decedent was a paying passenger of the airline and was to fly from one state to another, the latter being where the airline was incorporated. The plane crashed in the other state before reaching its destination. The intestate brought a wrongful death action against the airline and had the state of departure's Secretary served with a summons and complaint. The airline entered a special appearance and filed a motion to have the summons and complaint set aside. The trial court denied the motion and the airline appealed. The court found that the statute, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 250, under which the complaint was filed was unconstitutional because it violated the airline's due process rights. The court reversed the prior denial of the airline's motion.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the prior denial of the airline's motion to set aside the summons and complaint.

 

1157 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Franklin Nat'l Bank


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Second Department


281 A.D. 757; 118 N.Y.S.2d 210; 1953 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3201



January 12, 1953 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff People of the State of New York brought an action against defendant national bank for a permanent injunction restraining the bank from violating N.Y. Banking Law § 258(1). The People appealed from a judgment of a trial court (New York) dismissing the complaint on the merits after trial.


OVERVIEW: The bank admitted it violated § 258(1), which prohibited all but state mutual savings banks from using the terms "saving" or "savings" in a banks name. On appeal, the court held that the trial court erred when it found the statute was unconstitutional because (1) the statute was a valid exercise of police power aimed a preventing public deception, (2) the terms at issue had become synonymous with mutual savings banks, (3) the presumption of constitutionality was not overcome, and (4) the establishment of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation did not vitiate § 258(1), as it did not eliminate the need upon which the law was based. Further, the court held that § 258(1) did not conflict with Federal law because it did not unduly interfere with the operation of national banks. Section 258(1) applied equally to all commercial banks in similar circumstances and operating under the same conditions, so it was not constitutionally impermissible class legislation. Section 258(1) did not forbid the use of the expressions that were formerly permitted by the State Banking Department.


OUTCOME: The judgment was reversed. Judgment was directed for the People. The bank, its officers, agents, servants, and employees were restrained from advertising or using the word "saving" or "savings" in relation to its banking or financial business in its dealings with the public, and from soliciting or receiving deposits as a savings bank. Inconsistent findings of fact were reversed and new findings were made as indicated by the court.

 

1158 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


SANFORD v. STATE TAX COMMN.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


280 A.D. 687; 117 N.Y.S.2d 217; 1952 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3556



November 17, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff executrix appealed from an order of the Special Term of the Supreme Court, Montgomery County (New York), which order entered in St. Lawrence County (New York), granting defendant New York State Tax Commission's motion to dismiss the executrix's complaint for a declaratory judgment restraining the Commission from collecting an additional tax that was assessed against the deceased after his death.


OVERVIEW: The facts showed that the deceased paid income taxes for the year before he died. Shortly after the deceased paid the tax, he died. The Commission later assessed an additional income tax for that same tax year against the deceased's estate. The executrix argued that the additional assessment was illegal, erroneous, and contrary to law on the grounds that the Commission had to comply with the provisions of the N.Y. Surr. Ct. Act art. 12, which required that claims for debts against an estate had to be made to the executors. On appeal, the court held that the trial court properly dismissed the executrix's complaint for failure to state a cause of action. The court ruled that art. 12 did not apply to assessments of taxes imposed by the State. The court determined that the executrix had an adequate remedy in the supreme court for review of the assessment under N.Y. Tax Law §§ 199, 375. The court concluded that the executrix was entitled to an administrative hearing and review in the first instance without paying the tax or filing a bond, however, penalties and interest on the contested assessment might accrue unless the assessment was declared void.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's order, with costs.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - personal income tax - additional assessment against estate of deceased taxpayer - review - (1) decedent filed income tax return and paid tax; after decedent's death State Tax Commission assessed additional tax, with interest and penalties if tax not paid within thirty days; complaint in action for judgment restraining collection of tax and declaring commission's sole remedy against estate was under Surrogate's Court Act properly dismissed - (2) statute (Surrogate's Ct. Act, art. 12) requiring claim against estate to be made to executor not applicable to taxes imposed by State - (3) estate not deprived of property without due process of law by enforcement of tax laws; statute (Tax Law, §§ 199, 375) provides for administrative and judicial review of tax assessments - (4) requirement (Tax Law,  [***2] § 373) that notice of additional assessment be mailed to taxpayer's last address inapplicable when taxpayer dead - (5) where judgment entered, improper to appeal from order.

1. Decedent had filed a State income tax return for a specified year and had paid the tax. Subsequently, the State Tax Commission assessed an additional tax for that year against decedent's estate, together with interest and penalties to be imposed if the tax were not paid within thirty days. In an action for judgment restraining the commission from collecting the assessment and declaring that its sole remedy at law is that provided to creditors of an estate by article 12 of the Surrogate's Court Act, the complaint was properly dismissed for failure to state a cause of action.

2. The provisions in article 12 of the Surrogate's Court Act which require claims for debts against an estate to be made to the executor, who is given the power to reject the claims and put claimants to their proof, apply only to claims which must be established, if contested, by action and not to assessments of taxes imposed by a sovereign State.

3. Enforcement of the tax laws will not deprive decedent's estate of property without [***3] due process of law in violation of the State and Federal Constitutions. The Tax Law (§§ 199, 375) provides for review of any tax assessment both on the law and facts by the administrative agency and in the Supreme Court. Moreover, under section 374 of the Tax Law the penalties and interest which may accrue if the tax is ultimately paid will not be imposed if the additional assessment is declared void.

4. The requirement in section 373 of the Tax Law that the notice of additional assessment be mailed to the taxpayer at the address given in his last return does not apply inasmuch as the taxpayer was dead. In any event, mailing the notice to another address was such technical lapse as cannot invalidate the additional assessment.

5. The court calls attention to the fact that it is not good practice to appeal from an order granting a motion to dismiss the complaint when a judgment has been duly entered.

 

1159 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Fidler


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


280 A.D. 698; 117 N.Y.S.2d 313; 1952 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3559



November 17, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants sought review of their convictions from the Broome County Court (New York) for resisting an officer in the discharge of his duty in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 1851.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were a truck driver and his employees. The prosecution alleged that all defendants were driving trucks loaded with crushed stone. Police officers stopped the trucks and attempted to weight them on a portable scale. Defendants refused to drive the trucks onto the scales and refused to turn the truck keys over to the police. On appeal, the court found that the refusal to drive the trucks on the scales, together with the shutting off of the motors, the removal and retention of the ignition keys, and the locking of some of the cab doors, in their totality presented a factual pattern of events upon which a jury might be warranted in finding resistance and obstruction to the performance of public duty. However, the trial court erred in instructing the jury. The trial court in its jury charge gave an instruction on traffic law. There was an indissoluble merger of the two offenses in the instructions to the jury and one had no application at all to the case. In other parts of the instructions this merger was reiterated. The effect of this error upon the verdict could not be avoided and could not be disregarded.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendants' convictions from the trial court.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - motor vehicles - resisting public officer who is inspecting truck for overloading - (1) State police, pursuant to duty to inspect motor vehicles on highways to detect inadequate equipment or overloading or other violations ( Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 69) stopped heavily loaded trucks and ordered owner and drivers to drive onto weighing scales; said defendants refused, took keys out of ignition, locked doors, and refused to deliver keys; question for jury whether defendants guilty of resisting public officer in discharge of his duties ( Penal Law, § 1851) - (2) on these facts, section 69 of Vehicle and Traffic Law does not unconstitutionally authorize unreasonable searches - (3) however, order which defendants disobeyed was not traffic order ( Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 88, subd. 6); trial court's charge erroneously permitted jury to convict defendants solely for refusing to drive onto scales, without necessarily considering evidence of affirmative [***2] obstruction; new trial ordered.

1. Pursuant to section 69 of the Vehicle Traffic Law, which provides that the superintendent of State police shall cause inspection to be made of the motor vehicles operating on the public highways to detect inadequacy of equipment, overloading and other violations of law governing the use of the public highways, State police stopped five trucks and told the drivers to drive the trucks on a portable scale. Each truck was heaped high with crushed stone. Two weeks before this occurred, they had been similarly loaded and found overweight. Defendants refused, took the keys out of the ignition switches, locked some of the doors of the cabs, and refused to deliver the keys to the police. The owners, who had been summoned by telephone, also refused to deliver the keys or direct the drivers to drive the trucks on the scales. On this evidence it was proper to submit to the jury the question whether the drivers and owner were guilty of resisting a public officer in the discharge of his duty ( Penal Law, § 1851).

2. On these facts, section 69 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law has not unconstitutionally authorized an unreasonable search.

3.However, the [***3] trial court's charge in this case erroneously permitted the jury to convict defendants solely for disobedience of the order to drive onto the weighing scales, as if they had disobeyed an "order of a peace officer engaged in the direction of traffic" ( Vehicle and Traffic Law, § 88, subd. 6). Section 69 does not say that motor vehicle operators must drive onto weighing scales; rather, it requires the police to inspect the vehicles. Defendants could be convicted of resistance under section 1851 of the Penal Law only if their disobedience, plus their affirmative acts of taking the keys out of the ignition and retaining them and locking the cab doors, were factually found by the jury to be such resistance and obstruction. Judgments of conviction should be reversed and a new trial ordered.

 

1160 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Blackport Estates, Inc. v. McGoldrick


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


280 A.D. 329; 113 N.Y.S.2d 579; 1952 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3469



June 18, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landlord sought review of a decision by the Supreme Court at Special Term, New York County (New York), which dismissed the landlord's petition in a proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 to review an order made by respondent, the State Rent Administrator (New York). The Administrator granted the landlord an increase in rent, but the Administrator did not use the assessed valuation alleged by the landlord.


OVERVIEW: The landlord contended that it was entitled to a percentage of return based upon a particular assessed value of the apartment house. The Administrator refused to accept that valuation and instead relied on his statutory authority to make a valuation different from the assessed valuation under N.Y. Residential Rent Law § 4, which outlined the situations in which, and the formulae by which, the Administrator could determine valuations other than assessed values. The landlord complained that it was not permitted by the Administrator to submit evidence of the many facts bearing upon the actual value of the building. The landlord challenged the constitutionality of the statute under which the Administrator acted, asserting that the statute lacked adequate standards for guiding the Administrator's action. The court found that, although the statute was in order, there was no warrant in the Administrator's refusal to consider the facts in the individual case and in choosing to rely entirely upon a formula drawn from a statistical study of other cases. Although those studies could be informative, the landlord was entitled to an individualized valuation of his property.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's dismissal of the landlord's petition. The matter was remitted to the Administrator to make a determination in accordance with the court's opinion.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant - rent regulation - method of determining valuation for computing landlord's return - (1) Rent Administrator computed basis for return to which landlord was entitled by applying formula resulting from statistical study; matter remitted to Rent Administrator with direction to accept and consider evidence offered by landlord bearing on fair value of property for housing purposes and to make determination on individual facts - (2) statutory authority to make valuation different from assessed valuation where relation between valuation of land and buildings is not reasonable, is not unconstitutional. 

1. In a proceeding by the owner of an apartment house to secure an increase in rents, the Rent Administrator refused to accept assessed valuation of the property as the basis for computing the return to which the landlord was entitled. Instead, he fixed [***2] the valuation at five times the annual rent roll - a formula resulting from a statistical study occasioned by the fact that in some cases the assessed valuation of land is so greatly in excess of the assessed valuation of the building that the land is presumably under-improved. The Rent Administrator should not have refused to consider evidence which landlord sought to submit bearing upon the actual value of the building, including the fact that the assessed valuations did not reflect a proper relation between land and buildings. The Rent Administrator should take all relevant evidence bearing upon the fair value of the property for housing purposes and make a determination on the individual facts. The matter is remitted to the Rent Administrator to make a new determination.

2. The statutory authority to make a valuation different from the assessed valuation "where the valuation of the land without the buildings thereon does not bear a reasonable relationship to the valuation of the buildings themselves" (State Residential Rent Law, § 4, subd. 4, par. [a]; L. 1946, ch. 274, as amd.) is not unconstitutional.

 

1161 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Commercial Pictures Corp. v. Regents of University of N. Y.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


280 A.D. 260; 114 N.Y.S.2d 561; 1952 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3448



June 13, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 78, petitioner motion picture corporation sought review of a determination of respondent Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York, which affirmed a refusal to license a motion picture film. The action was transferred to the court by an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term in Albany County (New York).


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to N.Y. Educ. Law § 122, the education department refused to license the exhibition of a French film on the ground that the film was immoral and would tend to corrupt morals. The Board affirmed the education department's decision. The motion picture company requested that the court annul the Board's decision on the ground that it was unreasonable and arbitrary and issue a license. On appeal, the court held that there was no sufficient ground that warranted interference with the Board's judgment that the film was immoral. The court found that a committee reviewing the film for the Board determined that promiscuity was the central theme of the film and that prostitution and sex indulgence was the end result. The court found that when reviewing an administrator's decision, the court had to place itself in the administrator's place.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the Board's determination.


HEADNOTES

Theatres and shows - license to show motion picture - scope of judicial review of administrative decision - insufficient ground shown in this case for judicial reversal of refusal of Board of Regents to license "immoral" motion picture (Education Law, § 122); determination of board confirmed.

A determination of the Board of Regents which affirmed a determination of the motion picture division of the State Education Department, refusing to license a French film entitled "La Ronde" on the ground that the film is "immoral * * * or is of such a character that its exhibition would tend to corrupt morals" (Education Law, § 122), should be confirmed. Sufficient ground has not been shown, according to standards set by disciplined legal tradition for judicial review of administrative judgments, to warrant the court in overruling the [***2] judgment of the Regents.

 

1162 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of WEIL


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


280 A.D. 100; 111 N.Y.S.2d 828; 1952 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3400



April 15, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant trust company sought review of a decree of the New York County Surrogate's Court (New York), which denied its application for the issuance of letters of administration on the estate of the deceased and issued letters of administration to respondent Public Administrator of the County of New York.


OVERVIEW: The trust company applied for the issuance of letters of administration on the estate of the deceased. The surrogate's court denied its application and issued letters of administration to the Public Administrator instead. Upon the trust company's appeal, the court reversed the decree. The court held that, pursuant to N.Y. Banking Law § 100-a(2), as amended by 1948 N.Y. Laws 221, any trust company could be appointed guardian, trustee or administrator, with or without the will annexed, on the application or consent of any person acting as such or as an executor or entitled to such appointment irrespective of whether such person would himself be disqualified from acting by reason of his being an alien or non-resident of the State of New York, and in the place and stead of such person, or such trust company could be joined with any person so acting or entitled to such appointment.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decree of the surrogate's court.


HEADNOTES

Executors and administrators - appointment of trust company as dministrator on application of alien nonresident - trust company may be appointed administrator upon application of one who would be entitled to act as administrator except that he is both alien and nonresident (Banking Law, § 100-a, subd. 2, par. [a]).

In 1948 the Banking Law (§ 100-a, subd. 2, par. [a]) was amended to provide that a trust company might be appointed to act as administrator "on the application or consent of any person acting as such * * * or entitled to such appointment irrespective of whether such person would himself be disqualified from acting by reason of his being an alien or non-resident of this state". Prior thereto one who was disqualified as an alien nonresident could not appoint a trust company to act as administrator. An application [***2] be one who would be entitled to act as administrator, except for the fact that he is an alien nonresident, for the appointment of a trust company to act as administrator, should be granted. Since neither the fact that a person was an alien alone nor that he was a nonresident alone would disqualify him from acting as administrator or appointing a trust company (Surrogate's Ct. Act, § 94), the intent of the 1948 amendment was to extend the power to designate trust companies to persons who are both alien and nonresident. Any other interpretation would render the amendment meaningless.

 

1163 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Avon Dairies, Inc.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


280 A.D. 116; 111 N.Y.S.2d 272; 1952 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3404



March 19, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets (New York) challenged an order of the Supreme Court, Monroe County Special Term (New York), which denied the Commissioner's motion to dismiss the petition in a proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 to review his denial of petitioner corporation's application for a milk dealer's license.


OVERVIEW: The Commissioner appealed from the trial court's order, which denied his objections to the jurisdiction of the trial court to hear the petition of the corporation to review, under art. 78, a determination of the Commissioner. The Commissioner's objection to the jurisdiction of the trial court was founded upon his interpretation of N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 1287, which, it was urged, by its requirement that the application for review be made to in the third judicial district, left the trial court without jurisdiction of either the person or the subject matter. The court determined that § 1287, insofar as it referred to proceedings against the Department of Agriculture and Markets, was intended to refer also to the Commissioner. The court explained that the requirement of § 1287 that the proceeding be brought in the third judicial district, was a matter of venue, not jurisdiction. The court noted that matters of venue could have been waived, but jurisdictional matters could not have been waived. The court concluded that the proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 should not have been dismissed, but the Commissioner could have applied for a change of venue, if so advised.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the trial court, but not upon the grounds set forth by the trial court, with leave to the corporation to make proper application for a change of venue, if so advised.


HEADNOTES

Proceeding against body of officer - venue - (1) requirement of section 1287 of article 78 of Civil Practice Act, that proceeding against Department of Agriculture and Markets should be brought in third judicial district, is merely matter of venue, not jurisdiction - (2) proceeding against Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets should not be dismissed although brought in wrong district; commissioner may move for change of venue - (3) proceeding against Department of Agriculture and Markets includes proceeding against Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.

1. Section 1287 of article 78 of the Civil Practice Act entitled "Where proceeding to be brought" provides that where relief is applied for against the Department of Agriculture and Markets, the proceeding should be brought in the third judicial district.  [***2] This provision should be contrued, not as a possibly unconstitutional attempt to limit the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court (N.Y. Const., art. VI, § 1), but as a matter of venue only.

2. The distinction is substantial. For example, matters of venue may be waived but jurisdictional matters may not. This proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act against the Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, instituted at Monroe County Special Term of Supreme Court in the seventh judicial district, should not be dismissed. The commissioner may apply for a change of venue, if he is so advised.

3. The statue insofar as it referred to proceedings against the Department of Agriculture and Markets was intended to refer also to the Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets. The commissioner should not be considered as distinct from the department.

 

1164 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Claim of Fiol


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


279 A.D. 963; 111 N.Y.S.2d 288; 1952 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5432



March 12, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employer sought review of a decision of respondent New York Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board which held that respondent employee's voluntary separation from his work with the employer did not disqualify him under N.Y. Lab. Law art. 18 for unemployment insurance benefits.


OVERVIEW: The employer, a steamship corporation, employed the employee as a messman. The employee left his employment with the employer and filed a claim for unemployment insurance benefits. The unemployment insurance appeal board awarded the employee benefits and the employer appealed, arguing that the unemployment insurance appeal board erred in holding as a matter of law that it was required to recognize a union's rule as a statutory good cause for the employee's voluntary relinquishment of employment. The court affirmed the decision, concluding that the employee had good cause as a matter of fact for relinquishing his employment, and that the unemployment insurance appeal board's determination involved no unconstitutional delegation of legislative power.


OUTCOME: The decision awarding benefits to the employee was affirmed.

 

1165 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Cifolo v. General Electric Co.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


279 A.D. 884; 110 N.Y.S.2d 759; 1952 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5198



March 11, 1952 

 

1166 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Mid-States Freight Lines, Inc. v. Bates


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


279 A.D. 451; 111 N.Y.S.2d 578; 1952 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4693



March 10, 1952 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers sough review of an order made at a Special Term of the Supreme Court, Ulster County (New York), which denied the taxpayers' motion for a temporary injunction restraining appellee state tax commission from enforcing article 21 of the Tax Law, which dismissed the taxpayers' petition, granted the commission's motion for judgment on the pleadings, and which declared that the statute was constitutional.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers, freight trucking lines, first argued that they should have received a trial on their claims that the statute under which they were being taxed was unconstitutional. The court disagreed and held that the taxpayers' pleadings alleged no facts except the nature of their business operations and the territorial descriptions of their shipping zones. The rest of the pleading was a description of the statute on its face, accompanied by a conclusion that it was constitutionally invalid. The challenged statute exempted some types of vehicles from taxation and left the tax to be shared by the rest of the inter- and intra-state traffic. The court held that when the state legislature fixed the beginning point of the special use tax on heavy trucks at a certain poundage, its judgment was reasonable and the classification was not discriminatory in the sense that the equal protection of the law was thereby withdrawn from he owners of the heavy vehicles affected by the tax. The court held that the correlation between the weight, speed, and the greatly growing incidence of the heavy truck and deterioration of the roads were subjects well within the range of legislative regulation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower court's order, with costs.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - weight-distance tax on highway motor carriers - (1) judgment which declared valid weight-distance tax on trucks (Tax Law, art. 21) affirmed - (2) on pleadings, Special Term had no issues of fact to decide; properly granted judgment on pleadings on questions of law - (3) statute imposes tax on operation of vehicles of gross weight of over 18,000 pounds on roads of State; tax is based on "gross weight" of truck and is fixed on graduated scale at rates, beginning at six mills for lowest group of weights of trucks, multiplied by miles traveled; tax is not undue burden on interstate commerce - (4) State not required to devote proceeds of highway [***2] use tax entirely to road maintenance - (5) exemptions of enumerated vehicles do not make statute invalid - (6) provision (§ 503, subd. 2) that tax not imposed where vehicle is used exclusively in zone established by Public Service Commission or in city or village, not invalid delegation of legislative power - (7) nor does subdivision 2 of section 503 incorporate another statute by reference.

1. A judgment of the Supreme Court, Special Term, which declared valid the weight-distance tax on trucks as provided by article 21 of the Tax Law (added by L. 1951, ch. 74), and an order denying injunctive relief to restrain the enforcement of article 21, should be affirmed.

2. On the face of the pleadings, Special Term had no issues of fact to decide and therefore properly granted judgment on the pleadings on the problems of law presented.

3. The statute (Tax Law, § 503) imposes a "highway use tax" on the operation of vehicles having a gross wight of over 18,000 pounds on the roads of the State. It exempts from the tax omnibuses and other enumerated classes of vehicles (§ 501, subd. 2; § 503, subd. 2; 504). The tax is based on the "gross weight" of the truck (§ 501, subd. 4; § [***3] 503) and is fixed on a graduated scale at a rate beginning at six mills for the lowest group of gross weights of vehicles (the rate increasing up to the group having the legal maximum weight), multiplied by the number of miles traveled (§ 503). Such tax is not an undue burden on interstate commerce, inasmuch as it falls equally on intrastate vehicles of the same weight and following the same routes as interstate vehicles, and inasmuch as the tax, based on the quantum of highway use, is a reasonable charge.

4. The State is not required to devote the proceeds of a tax for highway use, such as here, entirely to the maintenance of roads.

5. The examption by the statute of some vehicles from its operation, thus leaving the tax to be shared by the residuum of interstate as well as intrastate traffic, does not make the statute invalid if the exemptions are reasonable. The placing by the Legislature of the beginning point of the special use tax on trucks at 18,000 pounds is reasonable and not discriminatory. The question of a tax standard here is legislative and not a judicial question. The exclusion of omnibuses from the tax (§ 501, subd. 2) on the ground of other special taxation,  [***4] and of zonal and local city and village traffic (§ 503, subd. 2) on the ground that their effect on the State highways as a whole is relatively small, is also within the legislative competence and is not unreasonable. Likewise the exemption made in favor of vehicles used by farmers to transport farm products or needed supplies (§ 504, subd. 3) is within the power of the Legislature.

6. A provision (§ 503, subd. 2) that the tax is not imposed where the vehicle is used exclusively within a zone established by the Public Service Commission or used exclusively within a city or village, is not an invalid delegation of legislative power. The statute must be construed as an adoption by the Legislature of an existing territorial arrangement.

7. Nor is there any substance to the contention that subdivision 2 of section 503 incorporates another statute by reference.

Mid-States Frgt. Lines v. Bates, 200 Misc. 885, affirmed.

 

1167 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Garzo v. Maid of Mist S.B. Co.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Fourth Department


278 A.D. 508; 106 N.Y.S.2d 4; 1951 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3850



July 11, 1951 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff shareholders sought review of a judgment from the Supreme Court in Erie County (New York), which dismissed their complaint against defendant corporation on the merits. The shareholders sought the dissolution and liquidation of the corporation and the distribution of its assets because the corporation had not extended its existence prior to the expiration of its term.


OVERVIEW: The articles of the corporation provided for a term of existence of 50 years. The term expired before the corporation extended its term, but the corporation continued to do business until it filed a certificate of revival, pursuant to N.Y. Gen. Corp. Law § 49. The shareholders brought an action against the corporation for its dissolution and liquidation, and sought their pro rata share of the assets. The trial court dismissed the complaint and the shareholders sought review. The court held that: (1) after the expiration of the corporate term, there was no statutory authority for the corporation to revive its corporate existence until 1944; (2) the reserved power of the legislature to alter, suspend and repeal a corporate charter was provided under N.Y. Const. art. X, § 1; (3) the legislature had the power to ratify and confirm, by retroactive statutes, any act which it might lawfully have authorized in the first instance, where the defect arose out of the neglect of some legal formality; and there was no evidence of fraud or bad faith by the corporation that provided a basis for equitable relief.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that dismissed the shareholder's action against the corporation to compel the corporation's dissolution and liquidation.


HEADNOTES
