Corporations - expiration of charter - revival - (1) complaint in action to dissolve corporation which filed certificate of revival after original charter had expired properly dismissed - (2) statute permitting corporation to file certificate of revival (General Corporation Law, § 49) applies to corporations whose existence expired prior to passage of statute - (3) Legislature, under its reserve power (N.Y. Const., art, X, § 1), had power to enact statute and make it retroactive - (4) minority stockholders had no implied statutory right to appraisal of stock - (5) minority stockholders have shown no equitable right to appraisal of stock.

1. A corporation, incorporated in 1892 for fifty years, failed, before [***2] the fifty-year term expired, to file a certificate extending its term of existence. It continued to do business to 1947, when it filed a certificate of revival (General Corporation Law, § 49, eff. April 6, 1944). In an action to procure a dissolution of the corporation upon the assumption that its existence had terminated, the complaint was properly dismissed.

2. The statute (General Corporation Law, § 49) permitting a corporation to file a certificate of revival was intended to apply to corporations whose existence had expired prior to the passage of the statute. 

3. The Legislature, under its reserve power, had the power to enact the statute and to make it retroactive (N.Y. Const., art. X, § 1) and could alter or repeal general or special laws relating to incorporation, and could ratify and confirm any act which it might have authorized in the first instance ( Stott v. Stott Realty Co., 288 Mich. 35, followed). That power to enact the statute is superior to the right of stockholders to require a dissolution of the corporation.

4. The fact that the statute was given retroactive effect did not give the minority stockholders an implied statutory right to have their [***3] stock appraised.

5. Nor have the minority stockholders shown an equitable right to such appraisal. There is in the record no evidence of fraud or bad faith on the part of the majority stockholders. Dividends have been declared and paid regularly on all the stock and it has not been shown that any valuable rights have been lost. Prior to the time when the corporation filed a certificate of revival, the minority stockholders accepted their dividends and participated as stockholders in the affairs of the corporation. They did not become aware that the corporate charter had expired until the revival proceedings had been instituted.

 

1168 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Bergerman v. Murphy


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


278 A.D. 388; 105 N.Y.S.2d 642; 1951 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3821



June 20, 1951 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, police pension trustees and retirees, appealed a judgment of the Supreme Court Special Term (New York), which ordered the trustees to annul pensions awarded to the retirees and restrained the trustees from giving effect to New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § B18-4.0(f), in plaintiff citizens union's action against the police pension trustees and the retirees.


OVERVIEW: The retirees, two police officers, were appointed police commissioners after more than 20 years of service. The day the retirees were appointed they applied for retirement at the annual rate of a police commissioner. Their applications were made pursuant to New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § B18-4.0(f), which provided that an officer appointed as a police commissioner could retire without any prerequisite length of service in that position. The citizens union brought an action against the retirees and the police pension trustees challenging the pensions awarded. The trial court held that the statute was unconstitutional as authorizing a gift of public funds. The police pension trustees and retirees appealed. The court found that the statute was constitutional because its terms created a valid pension. The pension was a prospective award or deferred compensation for services not fully recompensed as rendered. The statute was intended to entice qualified officers to accept a high-ranking, exempt position. However, the court found that the pension awards were illegal and invalid because the retirees never actually served or performed tasks in the role of commissioner.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment insofar as it declared the statute unconstitutional but affirmed the judgment in all other respects.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - municipal corporations - police - validity of pension provisions covering deputy police commissioners - (1) awards of pensions as deputy police commissioners to members of police pension fund who serve on force for twenty years and then serve as deputy police commissioners (Administrative Code of City [***2] of New York, § B18-4.0, subd. f) are constitutional and not gifts of public funds (N.Y. Const., art. VIII, § 1) - (2) but, where detectives who had served as Mayor's bodyguard and who would have received $3,000 pensions were briefly appointed deputy police commissioners and did not actually serve as such and were thereafter retired on pensions of $6,000, trustees of police pension fund directed to rescind such fraudulent pensions and to retire them on their lawful pensions.

1. The provision of the Administrative Code of the City of New York (§ B18-4.0, subd. f, enacted March 29, 1940), that a member of the police pension fund who shall have performed duty on the force for a period of twenty years "and who subsequently shall serve as police commissioner or deputy police commissioner, shall be retired and placed upon the pension roll of such pension fund and granted the pension allowed to a chief inspector in such department", is valid and does not violate the constitutional prohibition against gifts of public funds (N.Y. Const., art. VIII, § 1). Pensions are not gratuities but are deferred compensation. The legislative intent in enacting subdivision f in 1940 was to offer members [***3] of the police force an incentive to qualify for promotion to the exempt position of chief or deputy commissioner since police officers who had tenure might be unwilling to seek promotion to an exempt position without an increased inducement.

2. In this case, however, pensions were fraudulently awarded to favored appointees and such pensions should be annulled. In 1950, two patrolmen who had served for over twenty years and who had acted as bodyguard and chauffeur for the Mayor, resigned from their positions of first grade detective (at a salary of $5,175 annually, under which they would have received pensions of about $3,000 annually), accepted appointments as deputy police commissioners, and immediately applied for retirement. After forty-four days and sixty-seven days, respectively, their applications were granted and they were retired as deputy commissioners at annual pensions of $6,000. Upon the trial of this action at Special Term, it was established that they did not perform the duties of deputy police commissioner as defined in the police manual of procedure, during their short and nominal term of office. The board of trustees of the police pension fund should be directed [***4] to rescind their $6,000 pensions and to retire them on such pensions as they may be lawfully entitled to receive as retired patrolmen.

 Matter of Bergerman v. Murphy, 199 Misc. 1008, modified.

 

1169 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Froehlich v. Norton


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Second Department


278 A.D. 952; 105 N.Y.S.2d 157; 1951 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5347



June 11, 1951 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action in ejectment that was brought by respondent landlord, appellant tenant challenged a decision of a trial court (New York), which denied her motion to dismiss the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The tenant came into possession of the subject premises under a written lease for the term of her life. The landlord alleged that the tenant violated the covenant in the lease prohibiting the tenant from assignment or subletting. In reversing the decision of the trial court and granting the motion to dismiss, the court found that the complaint failed to allege that the respective notices required to be given by a landlord under N.Y. State Residential Rent Law § 12(1)(a) (1950) and N.Y. Temporary State Housing Rent Comm'n Rent and Eviction Regs. §§ 52, 53 were given by the landlord to the tenant. The fact that the statute and regulations did not become effective until subsequent to the occurrence of the alleged violation and the giving of a notice by the landlord as required by the provision of the lease did not render the statute and regulations unconstitutional in that respect. The statute and the regulations applied regardless of the fact that the nature of the action was ejectment and that the term of the lease was for the period of a lifetime rather than for a fixed term.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the trial court and granted the motion to dismiss.

 

1170 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Suppus v. Bradley


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


278 A.D. 337; 105 N.Y.S.2d 48; 1951 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3806



June 5, 1951 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action alleging the State Residential Rent Law, L. 1946, ch. 274 as amended by L. 1950, ch. 250, was unconstitutional, plaintiff landlords appealed from an order of the Supreme Court of Bronx County (New York) that denied their motion for judgment on the pleadings and granted a cross motion by defendant State Rent Administrator (administrator) dismissing the complaint for failure to state a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: The landlords brought this action against the administrator alleging that the State Residential Rent Law (law), L. 1946, ch. 274 as amended by L. 1950, ch. 250, was unconstitutional. The supreme court denied their motion for judgment on the pleadings and granted a cross motion by the administrator dismissing the complaint for failure to state a cause of action. The landlords appealed, and the court affirmed. Contrary to the landlords' contentions, the regulations enacted pursuant to the law to implement its provisions provided for withdrawal of housing accommodations from the rental market. Furthermore, the regulations expressly required that a certificate would be issued in the landlords' favor when the landlords established that he sought in good faith to recover possession because of compelling necessity and undue hardship, and with the intention permanently to withdraw the accommodations from housing and nonhousing rental markets without any intention to sell.


OUTCOME: The decision of the supreme court that denied the landlords' motion for judgment on the pleadings and granted a cross motion by the administrator dismissing the complaint for failure to state a cause of action was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - landlord and tenant - rent regulation - withdrawal of housing from market - (1) State Residential Rent Law (L. 1950, ch. 250, § 9, subd. 4; L. 1951, ch. 443, § 10, subd. 4) requires approval of State Housing Rent Commission to withdraw housing accommodations from market, if such withdrawal requires eviction of tenant; regulation (§ 59) provides for such approval when landlord establishes that, because of compelling necessity and undue hardship, he seeks in good faith to withdraw accommodations from housing and nonhousing rental and sales markets; statute and regulation are constitutional and valid - (2) landlords must apply to commission, whose decision may then be reviewed [***2] under article 78 of Civil Practice Act.

1. The State Residential Rent Law (L. 1950, ch. 250, § 9, subd. 4 [now in L. 1951, ch. 443, § 10, subd. 4]) provides that it shall not be construed to require any person to offer any housing accommodations for rent, but that housing accommodations already on the rental market may be withdrawn only after prior written approval of the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission, if such withdrawal requires that a tenant be evicted from such accommodations. The commission's regulations (§ 59) provide that such approval shall be issued when a landlord establishes that, because of compelling necessity and undue hardship, he seeks in good faith permanently to withdraw occupied housing accommodations from both the housing and nonhousing rental markets without any intention to rent or sell them. The statute contains a legislative finding of a serious public emergency in housing. The above provisions are constitutional and valid.

2. Landlords must first apply to the commission. The findings and conclusions of the commission refusing a certificate of necessity and the regulation may then be reviewed under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act [***3] on the ground that such regulation or its application to a particular state of facts is arbitrary, illegal or unconstitutional.

 

1171 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Joseph Burstyn, Inc. v. Wilson


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


278 A.D. 253; 104 N.Y.S.2d 740; 1951 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3788



May 9, 1951 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78, appellant licensees challenged a determination of respondents, the members of the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York, which rescinded the licensees' licenses for the public exhibition of a motion picture on the ground that the motion picture was sacrilegious. The application of N.Y. Educ. Law § 132 was dispositive of one of the issues raised on appeal.


OVERVIEW: The Board rescinded licenses for the public exhibition of the motion picture in question on the ground that it was sacrilegious. The licensees contended that censorship of motion pictures constituted an unconstitutional previous restraint on freedom of speech and freedom of the press, that N.Y. Educ. Law § 122, which barred the licensing of a motion picture deemed sacrilegious, was unconstitutional, and that the Board was without power to rescind the licenses. The court stated that motion pictures had been judicially declared to be entertainment spectacles and not part of the press or organs of public opinion, and hence subject to State censorship. Section 122 was not an unconstitutional exercise of legislative power. The State had the power to exercise a previous restraint as to motion pictures that could be fairly deemed sacrilegious to the adherents of any religious group. The exercise of such power was directly related to the public peace and order, and unless clearly in conflict with a constitutional prohibition it should not be denied. The Board clearly had the power under N.Y. Educ. Law § 132 to correct or rescind any illegal action taken by its motion picture division.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the Board's determination.


HEADNOTES

Theatres and shows - revocation of license of motion picture film - constitutional law - (1) determination by Board of Regents rescinding license granted by motion picture division for picture "The Miracle" after finding by board that picture was sacrilegious, confirmed - (2) motion pictures deemed entertainment spectacles and State censorship thereof no restraint on freedom of speech or press - (3) board found picture sacrilegious to Christians but State may bar picture though profanation not common to all sects - (4) exercise by State of restraint as to motion pictures deemed sacrilegious to any group directly related to public peace and order - (5) right to full inquiry and free discussion [***2] as to any religious doctrine not affected since motion pictures for entertainment alone not within category of inquiry and discussion - (6) while statute authorizes review in case of denial of license but makes no provision for review of license once issued, Board of Regents has power to rescind illegal action taken by its subordinate body, motion picture division - (7) Legislature did not intend to leave authorities helpless where film illegally licensed by motion picture division; power to correct inherent in statute - (8) court cannot say that determination made by board was one no reasonable mind could reach.

1. A motion picture entitled "The Miracle", which was produced in Italy, depicts a demented peasant girl who was seduced by a bearded stranger whom she imagined to be St. Joseph. She referred to her pregnancy as "the grace of God" and, subsequently, gave birth to a child in the basement of a church. The motion picture division of the State Education Department issued two different licenses for the picture, but on receipt of many protests against its exhibition on the ground that it was sacrilegious, an order was issued requiring the licensees to show cause why the license [***3] should not be revoked. At the hearing a committee of the Board of Regents recommended that the board, as a committee of the whole, view the picture and, after due consideration, the board found it to be sacrilegious and voted to rescind the licenses therefor. The determination should be confirmed.

2. Motion pictures have been judicially declared to be entertainment spectacles and not a part of the press or public opinion and, hence, subject to State censorship.

3. The Board of Regents based its revocation solely on the ground that the picture was sacrilegious, that it parodied in effect the Immaculate Conception and the divine birth of Christ as set forth in the New Testament. By millions of Christians these doctrines are held sacred and any profanation thereof held as a sacrilege, although there are other groups which do not accept these beliefs. The State may bar such a picture (Education Law, § 122) even though the profanation is not common and universal to all groups.

4. The term "sacrilege" means the violation or profanation of sacred things. The Legislature used the term in its widest sense and it was intended to apply to all recognized religions, not merely one [***4] sect alone. The exercise by the State of a previous restraint as to motion pictures that may fairly be deemed sacrilegious to the adherents of any religious group is directly related to public peace and order and, unless clearly in conflict with a constitutional prohibition, it should not be denied.

5. While full inquiry and free discussion, even to the point of attack, may be had with regard to the doctrines of any religion, including Christianity, by nonbelievers, motion pictures staged for entertainment purposes alone are not within the category of inquiry and discussion. The statute does not muzzle either free speech or a free press. All it purports to do is to bar a visual caricature of religious beliefs held sacred by one sect or another and such a bar is not a denial of religious freedom.

6. The Education Law ( §§ 120-132) indicates that the motion picture division is a subordinate body of the Education Department under the control of the Board of Regents and that the latter has the power to correct or rescind any illegal action taken by its motion picture division (Education Law, § 132). If the motion picture division was an independent body, the grant of an express [***5] power to review where a license was denied would negative a power by implication to review in a case not specified but the subordinate position of the motion picture division and the supreme responsibility of the regents to enforce the statute preclude such result.

7. Furthermore, it seems most unlikely from a practical viewpoint that the Legislature intended to leave the authorities helpless in a case where, through some misconception or inadvertence on the part of the motion picture division, a film was illegally licensed. The regents could not then correct the situation nor would a criminal prosecution be possible because the film had been licensed. Such a situation raises the belief that the Legislature gave no specific grant of power to the regents for a review when a license was granted because none was considered necessary. The power to correct was inherent in the statute. 

8. As to whether the regents acted arbitrarily and capriciously, the issue becomes one of judgment to be resolved by the administrative body which has it in charge. The text and content of the picture, together with the complaints received, constituted substantial evidence upon which the regents [***6] could act. The court cannot say that the determination made was one that no reasonable mind could reach.

 

1172 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Russo


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


278 A.D. 98; 103 N.Y.S.2d 603; 1951 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3750



March 27, 1951 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York of New York County (New York) that convicted him of unlawfully possessing a firearm in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 1897.


OVERVIEW: Defendant claimed that there was insufficient evidence to support the determination that he was in possession of the pistol in his automobile and that the presumption created by N.Y. Penal Law § 1898-a (as amended by 1936 N.Y. Laws 390) violated U.S. Const. amend. XIV and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6, and was unconstitutional. The court determined that defendant had admitted that he knew the pistol was in the car and that he knew how it got into the car. The court held that defendant's admissions and the fact that officers found the pistol in the car were sufficient in the absence of an explanation by defendant to support his conviction. The court also held that the presumption created by N.Y. Penal Law § 1898-a was rebuttable and defendant failed to offer in evidence to rebut the presumption, which was not a violation of due process and did not shift the burden of proof to defendant.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - crimes - firearms - validity of statute creating presumption of possession from finding of pistol in automobile in which accused is found - (1) appellant's guilt of unlawfully possessing firearm in violation of Penal Law (§ 1897) proven beyond reasonable doubt - (2) presumption in Penal Law (§ 1898-a) of illegal possession by all persons in car of gun also found in same car, rebuttable; evidence that appellant knew gun was in car and that it lay on ledge of automobile within his immediate reach and therefore in his "possession" disclosed appellant's constructive possession thereof - (3) section 1898-a of Penal Law is constitutional - (4) statutory presumption of section 1898-a merely assumes that, in absence of some explanation, occupants of automobile in which pistol is found are in illegal possession thereof.

1. Where,  [***2] immediately prior to appellant's arrest, he and his codefendants were together in an automobile, in which a pistol was also found, appellant's guilt of unlawfully possessing a firearm in violation of section 1897 of the Penal Law was proven beyond a reasonable doubt. The testimony of police officers sustained this view and appellant admitted it as did his codefendants. Even an incompetent statement of a fourth man upon which appellant relied placed appellant and the weapon in the automobile at the same time.

2. Subdivision 4 of section 1897 of the Penal Law prohibits the unlicensed possession of a pistol, and section 1898-a provides that the presence in an automobile of a pistol "shall be presumptive evidence" of its illegal possession by all persons found in such automobile at the time the pistol is found. The statutory presumption of illegal possession of a gun by all persons found in the automobile is a rebuttable one, and the evidence here, far from rebutting the presumption, served to confirm it. The evidence that appellant knew the gun was in the car and that it lay on the back ledge of the automobile within the immediate reach and control of appellant and therefore in [***3] his "possession" as that word is used in connection with penal provisions relating to weapons, disclosed a constructive possession of a loaded revolver by appellant.

3. Section 1898-a of the Penal Law is constitutional. It does not conflict with the Fourteenth Amendment of the Federal Constitution and section 6 of article I of the State Constitution which provide that no person shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself, nor deprived of life, liberty or property without due process of law. Statutes such as 1898-a which provide that certain facts are presumptive evidence of one or more of ultimate facts in issue are not unconstitutional, as here, there is a rational connection with the facts proved and the conclusion presumed and where the presumptions themselves are neither conclusive nor arbitrary.

4. All presumptions arising from the facts cast upon the defendant the burden of overcoming them. Here the statutory presumption merely assumes that in the absence of some explanation the occupants of an automobile in which a pistol is found are in illegal possession of the pistol. If the persons in the automobile have no actual knowledge of its presence,  [***4] there cannot be a conviction and the burden of establishing beyond a reasonable doubt their possession of the gun is nevertheless with the People.

 

1173 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Zorach v. Clauson


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Second Department


278 A.D. 573; 102 N.Y.S.2d 27; 1951 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3993



January 15, 1951 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners appealed an order from the trial court (New York), which granted intervenor's motion to dismiss a proceeding to have respondents, a board of education and a commissioner of education, ordered to discontinue a program of released time for religious education and to rescind regulations that authorized the program.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to N.Y. Educ. Law § 3210(1)(b), the commissioner of education established regulations for a program of released time for religious education. The board of education thereafter also established regulations. Petitioners instituted a proceeding in which they sought an order for respondents to discontinue the program and to rescind the regulations that they had promulgated. The trial court granted intervenor's motion to dismiss the proceeding on the ground that the petition failed to state facts that were sufficient to constitute a cause of action. On appeal, the court affirmed the trial court's order. The court concluded that N.Y. Educ. Law § 3210(1)(b) was not unconstitutional. The statute merely provided that absence from attendance on required instruction should be permitted for specified religious purposes under rules that were to be established. The court also concluded that petitioners had failed to allege facts that were sufficient to establish any invasion of their constitutional rights by the adoption of the regulations or the operation of the released time program.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order against petitioners.

 

1174 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Utica Transit Corp. v. Feinberg


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


277 A.D. 464; 100 N.Y.S.2d 916; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3088



November 15, 1950 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, a railway corporation, commenced a proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 to review a determination of respondents, members of the Public Service Commission of the State of New York, which required the corporation to extend bus service from a village to a college campus.


OVERVIEW: The Commission directed the corporation to extend one of its bus lines to include service to a college campus one and one half miles from its terminus. On review, the court confirmed the Commission's determination. The court found that the corporation's claim that there was no necessity for service and that the route was too hazardous involved issues of fact. The court found no reason to conclude that the Commission's conclusions on those issues were not supported by substantial evidence. The court determined that the extension directed was not a new venture beyond the corporation's commitments because the Commission's determination indicated that the extension was not a new venture, but rather an extension of service within an area the corporation was already committed to serve. The court noted that from a geographic and economic perspective, the entire area involved should have been treated as one community. The court concluded that the fact that the corporation had no local franchise to go beyond the center of the village was irrelevant because the only franchise required for the extension ordered was the Commission's certificate of public convenience and necessity.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the Commission's determination.


HEADNOTES

Carriers - extension of bus line - (1) carrier ordered by Public Service Commission to extend bus line from center of village to campus of college, 1.5 miles distant; order confirmed - (2) charge that order unreasonable because service unnecessary and route hazardous involves issues of fact; since findings of commission are supported by evidence, judicial interference unwarranted - (3) carrier not ordered to undertake new venture, which would be unconstitutional, but only to extend service in area already served by carrier - (4) commission has statutory authority to extend termini of omnibus corporation - (5) local franchise for extended service not needed - (6) charge that order confiscatory premature.

1. A street railway [***2] corporation furnishing transportation wholly by omnibuses in substitution for street cars pursuant to section 50-a of the Public Service Law was ordered by the Public Service Commission to extend a bus line running from a railroad station in a large city to the center of a small village (a distance of 9.35 miles) to the campus of a college (a distance of 1.5 miles from the present terminus) except during the summer months. Such order should be confirmed.

2. The carrier charges that the order is unreasonable in that there is no necessity for service on the extension and in that the route is too hazardous for safe operation. These charges involve issues of fact concerning which the record reveals conflicting evidence. There is no basis for judicial interference where the determination of the commission is supported by substantial evidence.

3. A State Public Service Commission may not require the extension of existing lines beyond the scope of a carrier's commitment to the public service because such a requirement would constitute the taking of property in violation of the due process clause of the Federal Constitution. There is no specific finding to the effect that the extension [***3] here directed was not a new venture, but rather an extension of service within an area which the carrier was already committed to serve. Since it is the carrier's obligation to serve this area, there is no constitutional inhibition against the commission's order for the extension of service therein.

4. The commission is authorized by subdivision 13 of section 61 and sections 63-a and 63-b of the Public Service Law to modify the routes or stated termini of an omnibus corporation.

5. That the carrier has no local franchise to go beyond the center of the village is not decisive for neither the town nor the villege requires the consent of local authorities for the operation of an omnibus line and hence the only franchise required is the commission's certificate of public convenience and necessity.

6. An argument that the order is confiscatory is prematurely raised.

 

1175 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Potter v. Heffernan


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


277 A.D. 331; 99 N.Y.S.2d 653; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3049



September 19, 1950 


HEADNOTES

Elections - time for filing independent nominating petitions - constitutional law - (1) independent nominating petitions for general election of November 7, 1950, must be filed by September 9th (Election Law, § 314, subd. 11, enacted [***4] by L. 1950, ch. 329); Mayor resigned on September 2d; time between September 2d and 9th is not so unreasonably short as to render statute unconstitutional; election of new Mayor in 1950 will not be enjoined - (2) portion of Special Term order which extended time to September 16th deleted; provision of Election Law (§ 143, subd. 12) that independent petition may be filed within fourteen days "where a vacancy occurs after the last day for the filing", inapplicable.

1. A Mayor of the City of New York elected for a term expiring December 31, 1953, filed his resignation on September 2, 1950. The Election Law (§ 314, enacted by L. 1950, ch. 329) provides that "Notwithstanding the times fixed by the provisions of this chapter * * *, the time fixed for the nomination * * * of candidates * * * for the * * * general election for the year nineteen hundred fifty, shall be as follows: * * * 11. A petition for an independent nomination for an office to be filled at the general election shall be filed * * * not later than September ninth". The time thus allowed in this case by section 314 for obtaining and filing independent nominating petitions (from September 2d to September 9th) was reasonable [***5] and constitutional, and accordingly the Board of Elections will not be enjoined from taking steps for the election of a Mayor on November 7, 1950.

2. Another section of the Election Law (§ 143, subd. 12) provides that "A vacancy occurring before September twentieth of any year in any office authorized to be filled at a general election * * * shall be filled at the general election held next thereafter" and that "where a vacancy occurs after the last day for filing of an independent petition * * *, an independent petition may be filed for the said office within fourteen days after the vacancy occurs." However, on the law applicable to the facts of this case, Special Term should not have extended to September 16th the time expressly fixed as September 9th by subdivision 11 of section 314 for the filing of independent nominating petitions; and such portion of its order should be deleted.

 

1176 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People v. Turner


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Fourth Department


277 A.D. 317; 98 N.Y.S.2d 886; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3044



July 13, 1950 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed judgments of the Children's Court of Erie County (New York) convicting them of violating N.Y. Educ. Law § 3212(2) in not causing their children to attend school.


OVERVIEW: The court found that New York State required that every minor from seven to 16 years of age should attend full time day instruction and that N.Y. Educ. Law § 3204(1) provided that such a minor could attend at a public school or elsewhere. The court further found that there was no provision in the Education Law which prohibited instruction of children at home, nor was there any provision requiring certification of a parent by the Commissioner of Education before she could teach her children at home. The court also found that the object of a compulsory education law was to see that children were not left in ignorance, that from some source they would receive instruction that would fit them for their place in society, and that, provided the instruction given was adequate and the sole purpose of nonattendance at school was not to evade the statute, instruction given to a child at home by its parent, who was competent to teach, should satisfy the requirements of the compulsory education law. The court concluded that defendants' proof of the nature and type of instruction received at home by the children and of the competency of defendants to teach them should not have been excluded.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgments of conviction of both defendants and granted them a new trial.


HEADNOTES

Schools - compulsory education of children - place of instruction - conviction of parents of children for violating compulsory education law (Education Law, § 3212, subd. 2) reversed and new trial ordered where evidence as to type of instruction given children at home by mother and mother's competency to instruct them excluded; such evidence admissible; Education Law does not prohibit instruction at home nor require certification of parent as teacher by Commissioner of Education.

The Education Law (§ 3204) requires the instruction of children of compulsory school age at a public school or elsewhere. There is no provision in the statute which prohibits instruction of children at home nor is there any provision requiring certification of a parent by the Commissioner of Education before she may teach her children at home. Provided the instruction given is adequate and the sole purpose of nonattendance at school is not to evade the statute, instruction [***2] given to a child at home by its mother who is competent to teach should satisfy the requirements of the compulsory education law. In this case defendants' offer of proof of the nature and type of instruction received at home by defendants' children and of the competency of the mother to teach them should not have been excluded. Defendants were improperly convicted of violating subdivision 2 of section 3212 of the Education Law in not causing said children to attend school. A new trial should be ordered.

 

1177 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Grow System School v. Board of Regents


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


277 A.D. 122; 98 N.Y.S.2d 834; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3010



June 27, 1950 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner school owner, citing N.Y. Educ. Law § 5001, appealed an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term in Albany County (New York) dismissing on the merits a proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 for an order directing respondent Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York to renew the school owner's license to conduct a trade school.


OVERVIEW: The Commissioner of Education had disapproved of the school owner's practice of charging students for lockers, notebooks, and certificates in addition to regular tuition. The school owner contended on appeal that N.Y. Educ. Law § 5001 was unconstitutional insofar as it made approval by the Commissioner of the tuition to be charged a requisite for the issuance of a license. The court reversed the order. The court noted that it might well be that the power to regulate certain phases of private school operation was a necessary and indispensable corollary to the State's supervisory jurisdiction over education in general. The court observed that what the embryo technician, be he hair stylist or masseur, dentist or doctor, might have paid for his education was purely a personal matter between himself and the school of his choice. The court stated that in the absence of any showing whatsoever that tuition in trade schools was a matter of great public concern or affected with a public interest, any attempt on the part of the legislature to fix the rates thereof was an unnecessary and unwarranted interference with individual liberty and hence unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the trial court dismissing the school owner's proceeding against the Board and directed the Board to issue to the school owner a renewal of its trade school license.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - schools - private trade schools - tuition - (1) Education Law (§ 5001) authorizes Commissioner of Education to approve tuition paid by students at private trade schools; renewal of license to operate beauty culture school denied on ground petitioner had improperly charged for lockers, notebooks, etc., in addition to regular tuition; renewal of license directed - (2) in absence of showing that such tuition affects public interest section 5001 is unconstitutional. 

1. With respect to private trade schools, section 5001 of the Education Law provides that no license shall be issued until the Commissioner of Education has approved "the tuition to be paid and the method of collecting tuition". Acting under such section the Commissioner of Education has refused to renew petitioner's license [***2] to operate a beauty culture school until it has discontinued charges made to students for lockers, notebooks and various certificates in addition to the regular tuition. In this proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act respondent Board of Regents is directed to issue to petitioner forthwith a renewal of its license to operate a trade school.

2. Section 5001, in the absence of any showing in the statute or in the record that tuition in trade schools is a matter of great public concern or affected with a public interest, is an unconstitutional attempt on the part of the Legislature to fix tuition rates and constitutes an unnecessary and unwarranted interference with individual liberty.

 

1178 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Consolidated Edison Co. v. Moore


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


277 A.D. 245; 98 N.Y.S.2d 973; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3034



June 27, 1950 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer challenged the decision of the Supreme Court of New York at Special Term which granted a motion by respondent comptroller for an order striking from the taxpayer's petition objecting to a tentative valuation and equalization rate fix, allegations attacking the constitutionality of 1949 N.Y. Laws 346.


OVERVIEW: Under 1949 N.Y. Laws 346, a state board of equalization and assessment was created as a temporary state commission for special purposes. The questions on review were the constitutionality of ch. 346 and the validity of the designation of the comptroller as a member of the board. The court affirmed. The court found that the duties, powers, or functions to be performed by the state department of taxation were left entirely in the discretion of the legislature and ch. 346 did not provide for the creation of a new department of the state government, either in terms or in effect. The court determined that ch. 346 did create a temporary commission for special purposes and simultaneously, and incidentally it did modify or diminish powers and functions formerly performed by the department of taxation. The court determined that N.Y. Const. art. V, § 3 provided explicit constitutional authority for both steps and was satisfied that the legislative disposition was in accord with constitutional requirements. The court was also convinced that the appointment of the comptroller as a board member did not violate N.Y. Const. art. V, § 1.


OUTCOME: The grant of the comptroller's motion to strike allegations attacking the constitutionality of a certain law related to equalization and assessment was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - temporary State commission - (1) act creating State Board of Equalization and Assessment (L. 1949, ch. 346) constitutional - (2) board not new department banned by Constitution but temporary commission for special purpose - (3) statute not vague and indefinite in specifying jurisdiction and duties delegated to board - (4) no unlawful delegation of legislative power and no incorporation of other statute in act - (5) provision of Constitution (art. V, § 1) prohibiting Legislature from assigning to Comptroller administrative duties, excepting such as may be incidental to performance of his assigned functions, not violated by his appointment to board - (6) no new duties as Comptroller assigned, only duties as member and chairman of board.

1. Chapter 346 of the Laws of 1949, which created the State Board of Equalization and Assessment as a temporary State commission for special purposes,  [***2] is constitutional.

2. Section 3 of article V of the State Constitution provides that, other than the State departments therein provided for, no new State departments shall be created. The section specifically states, however, that this provision shall not prevent the Legislature from creating "temporary commissions for special purposes". Chapter 346 does not provide for the creation of a "new department" of the State Government, either in terms or in effect. It does create a "temporary commission for special purposes" which expires on April 1, 1952, and simultaneously it does, as authorized by section 3, "modify or diminish * * * powers and functions" formerly performed by the Department of Taxation and Finance. The two purposes to be accomplished by the commission - review and revision of the equalization rate and publication and submission of recommendations to the Legislature for the permanent assignment of the jurisdiction, powers and duties which it temporarily controls - are "special purposes" (Matter of People [Westchester Tit. & T. Co.], 268 N.Y. 432, followed.)

3. The statute is not vague and indefinite in its specification of the jurisdiction, functions,  [***3] powers and duties delegated to the board. The act transfers all the duties of the state tax commission, the state board of equalization and the department of taxation and finance, pertaining to or connected with the assessment and taxation of real estate". The matters transferred are itemized in the act.

4. Chapter 346 does not constitute a prohibited delegation of legislative power and does not incorporate other statutes contrary to section 16 of article III of the State Constitution. It provides for the devolution upon said Board of Equalization and Assessment of carefully itemized and specified functions, powers and duties of three existing administrative agencies of the State Government pertaining to assessment and taxation of real estate and it does require reference to previously enacted statutory provisions which conferred that jurisdiction upon those predecessor agencies in order to determine the method of exercising the powers conferred, the procedure involved and the precise limitation upon the scope thereof. In that there is no violation of the letter, intent or spirit of the Constitution.

5. Section 1 of article V of the State Constitution provides for the [***4] election of a State Comptroller and that the Legislature shall define the scope of his duties prescribed by the Constitution. The section provides that the Legislature "shall assign to him no administrative duties, excepting such as may be incidental to the performance of these functions." The appointment of the State Comptroller as a member of the Board of Equalization and Assessment did not violate the terms or purposes of this provision of the Constitution. Nothing in the Constitution disqualifies the incumbent of said office from performing other public functions not incompatible with that of Comptroller.

6. Moreover, the Legislature assigned no administrative duties to the Comptroller, but assigned the duties to the equalization board, to which the Comptroller was subsequently appointed by the Governor in his individual capacity as member and chairman.It was in that capacity that the Governor bestowed administrative responsibility upon him.

 Matter of Consolidated Edison Co. of N.Y. v. Moore, 197 Misc. 628, affirmed.

 

1179 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Natanson


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


276 A.D. 745; 98 N.Y.S.2d 155; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4960



May 23, 1950 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landlords challenged the order of the Supreme Court at Special Term in New York County (New York), which fixed the total rent permitted from commercial space occupied by respondent tenants, declared that landlords were receiving a fair and reasonable rental from each of the tenants, and dismissed the petition to fix the rents, upon the merits.


OVERVIEW: The landlords leased commercial space to tenants. The landlords instituted a proceeding pursuant to the additional alternative method provided in N.Y. Comm. Rental Law § 4 to fix the fair rental value per square foot of commercial space. The trial court enforced the language of the statute relating to the alternate method strictly and literally. The court held that the income from the entire premises was in excess of the amount permissible by application of the statutory formula and therefore, the landlords were receiving a fair and reasonable return. The trial court, thus, deemed it unnecessary to apply the optional square foot rule. The court rejected literal interpretation of the statute and held that the square footage of the respective rental spaces had to be weighted or adjusted in proportion to their relative rental value. The landlord was entitled to recover from each statutory tenant the amount of the rent apportioned to him regardless of how much income was received from the rest of the building.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order from which the appeal was taken.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant - rent regulation - reasonable rent - (1) under square-foot alternative method of fixing reasonable rent under section 4 of Commercial Rent Law (as amd. by L. 1949, ch. 534), statutory tenant must pay rent based on square footage as weighted in proportion to relative rental value, regardless of how much income landlord receives from rest of building - (2) accepting concessions of fact stipulated on appeal, Appellate Division fixes square footage and value of tenant's space - (3) but such increase of rent is now limited to 15% (L. 1950, ch. 327, amdg. Commercial Rent Law, § 4, subd. 2); amendment applies to pending proceedings; phrase includes cases on appeal - (4) appellate court grants motion for [***2] judgment which Special Term should have granted (Civ. Prac. Act, § 584) - (5) rent as so fixed and limited is payable as of date landlord made application.

1. In a proceeding to fix a reasonable rent pursuant to the additional alternative method provided by a portion of section 4 of the Commercial Rent Law (added by chapter 534 of the Laws of 1949), the square footage of the respective rental spaces in the building must be weighted or adjusted in proportion to their relative rental value and the landlord is entitled to recover from each statutory tenant the amount of rent apportioned to him regardless of how much income is received from the rest of the building. (Matter of Barry Equity Corp. [Marcia Hat Co.], 276 App. Div. 685, followed.)

2. In this proceeding, the Appellate Division accepts the concessions of fact stipulated by both sides on appeal and fixes the value of the tenant's 10,505 square feet of space at $2.21 per square foot as a total of $23,216.05.

3. However, subdivision 2 of section 4 of the rent act (amended, as to an alternative square-foot proceeding by L. 1950, ch. 327, eff. March 31, 1950) expressly limits any increase to a landlord in any [***3] one year to an amount not "in excess of fifteen per centum greater than the amount of the rent being paid by the tenant". The amount being paid is the emergency rent of $13,800. Fifteen per cent of that is $2,070. Accordingly, the sum of $15,870 is fixed as respondent tenant's rent. The 15% limitation was expressly made applicable to "pending" proceedings. The Legislature did not adopt a recommendation of the Temporary Commission to Study Rents and Rental Conditions that the amendment should not include cases on appeal.

4. The Civil Practice Act (§ 584) provides that the appellate court, unless it affirms the judgment, "shall so far as practicable, grant the motion for judgment which the court below ought to have granted." The order of Special Term is modified accordingly to fix the tenant's rent at $15,870.

5.The rent as so fixed is payable as of the date the landlord's application was made.

 

1180 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re GUARANTY TRUST CO.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


276 A.D. 651; 97 N.Y.S.2d 171; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4938



April 25, 1950 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant estate administrator challenged the decision of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which held in favor of respondent trust and beneficiaries that Florida's tax apportionment statute was unconstitutional as applied to a decedent's inter vivos revocable trust, and held that the trustee was to make no payments on federal and Florida estate taxes until assets of the estate in Florida were depleted.


OVERVIEW: The trustee for an inter vivos revocable trust established in New York by the decedent, and the trust's beneficiaries through a guardian ad litem, contended that the retroactive application of 1949 Fla. Laws ch. 25435 to the trust was unconstitutional. Decedent had perished prior to the statute's enactment. The estate administrator argued that the trust was liable for its pro rata share of federal and Florida estate taxes. The court modified the trial court's decision because the trustee and beneficiaries failed to prove the unconstitutionality of the Florida statute, holding that the statute was constitutional because the statute was merely a declaration of the existing public policy of the state, retroactivity did not make it unconstitutional, and the policy was in line with the law and policy of other states, including N.Y. Decedent Est. Law § 124. Given the Florida statute's constitutionality, the court ordered the trustee to pay its pro rata share of federal and Florida estate taxes.


OUTCOME: The court modified the decision of the trial court in favor of the trustee and beneficiaries, and against the estate administrator, and instructed the trustee to pay its pro rata share of both the federal and Florida estate taxes, together with interest.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - estate taxes - apportionment - constitutionality of retroactive Florida statute - (1) decedent established, with funds and trustees in New York, revocable inter vivos trusts in 1923 and 1929 and died intestate in 1948, resident of Florida; Federal and Florida estate taxes, imposed on total of intestate estate plus trust estates, will exceed intestate estate; Florida statute providing for apportionment [***2] of Federal and Florida estate taxes in manner similar to section 124 of New York Decedent Estate Law, was enacted in 1949 retroactive to 1948; retroactivity constitutional - (2) New York Supreme Court has jurisdiction of accounting proceedings brought by trustees under article 79 of Civil Practice Act - (3) Florida Legislature properly determined that Florida statute was declaratory of existing public policy - (4) those attacking statute must show that it changed existing law - (5) retroactive succession taxes constitutional - (6) as long as estate is in process of administration, revocable inter vivos trust is constitutionally treated for tax purposes as part of decedent's estate - (7) statute requiring estate beneficiaries to share estate tax proportionately prevents unjust enrichment - (8) inter vivos trustees required to pay their prorata share of Florida and Federal estate taxes as determined by Florida court - (9) trustees also instructed as to extent to which interest on taxes should be paid from income or principal of trust funds.

1. A resident of Florida died intestate in 1948, leaving his five children as distributees. The administrator, appointed in Florida, filed a [***3] Federal estate tax return on June 6, 1949, showing a gross estate of $782,623. Such gross estate included an amount of $528,973 constituting the corpus of two inter vivos trusts established by decedent in 1923 and 1929, which were revocable by decedent, and under which the income was payable to decedent for his life and then to his five children for their lives, with remainders over to their issue. The trust funds are in New York and the trustees are three banking institutions located in New York. In the course of current administration of the estate in Florida the net estate distributable by the administrator before estate taxes was shown at $180,571. The total Federal estate tax, including the inter vivos trusts, amounted to $190,532, and the Florida estate tax amounted to $20,198. The administrator paid the Florida estate tax in full and made a payment on account of Federal estate tax. Then, on June 13, 1949, a Florida statute (Laws of Florida of 1949, ch. 25435 [No. 439]) became law and provided for the equitable apportionment of both Federal and State estate taxes among the persons interested in the estate in a manner substantially identical with section 124 of [***4] the New York Decedent Estate Law. However, while the New York statute applies only to estates of persons who died after the statute became effective, the Florida act by its terms applies to estates of persons dying after January 1, 1948, or to payments of estate taxes or death taxes made, or required to be made, after June 13, 1949. In this situation the Florida statute is validly and constitutionally retroactive.

2. The New York Supreme Court has jurisdiction to grant the relief sought (accounting and instructions) by the inter vivos trustees in this proceeding under article 79 of the Civil Practice Act. The trust fund is in New York, the proceeding is basically in rem, and the Florida court could not exercise jurisdiction over the trustees in the absence of the latter's consent.

3. The apportionment statute involved no retroactive change in Florida law, but was simply declaratory of the law of that State as it existed at the time of the death of decedent. In section 5 the Florida Legislature declared that it "considers the equitable principles of this Act as merely declaratory of the existing public policy of this State". Such a legislative declaration should be given [***5] full effect in the courts of a foreign jurisdiction, especially since that declaration is in no way inconsistent with court decisions in Florida.

4. Those attacking the statute have failed to show - and that burden was upon them - that the apportionment statute changed the existing law of Florida.

5. The statute does not violate an obligation of contract merely because it operates on an inter vivos trust created prior to its enactment. Retroactive succession taxes, or retroactive increases, modifications or redistributions thereof enacted after a decedent's death, are constitutional.

6. So long as a decedent's estate is in process of administration, the rights of the beneficiaries thereof, including beneficiaries of property constituting part of the gross taxable estate, although not in the probate estate, are not completely fixed and ascertained; during such period the property constituting the gross taxable estate remains within the State's taxing power and within the State's power to control the ultimate impact of the tax burdens thereon. For all tax purposes, property in an inter vivos trust, revocable by the settlor up to the date of his death, is treated as [***6] the settlor's own property - no gift tax is payable upon the transfer, the income is taxed to the settlor, and on his death the property is included in his gross estate for estate taxes.

7. The purpose of an apportionment statute is to correct unjust enrichment of one beneficiary at the expense of another. Otherwise, in the absence of a specific direction by the decedent, the residue would have to bear the entire tax burden on property received by another. Such a result would be particularly inequitable where, as in the present case, includible inter vivos transfers give rise to estate taxes in excess of the value of the distributable estate. To require such proportional sharing of the burden of estate taxes with respect to an estate in process of administration is not so arbitrary or unreasonable as to violate constitutional prohibitions.

8. Accordingly, the trustees of each of the inter vivos trusts should pay from principal its prorata share of both the Florida and Federal estates taxes as such share is determined by the county court in Florida according to the laws of Florida.

9. Any interest on the estate taxes payable from each trust fund should be paid by [***7] said trustees from income to the extent that income was earned on that part of the trust fund used to pay estate taxes from the respective dates such taxes were due, the balance of such interest to be charged to the principal of the trust fund.

 Matter of Gato, 197 Misc. 462, modified.

 

1181 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Application of Barry Equity Corp.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


276 A.D. 685; 96 N.Y.S.2d 808; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4944



April 25, 1950 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord challenged a judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term in New York County (New York), which fixed rental from respondent tenant at the date of judgment rather than the date of commencement of the proceeding. The tenant cross-appealed the judgment granting a motion by the landlord to fix the rent of space occupied by tenant at a reasonable rate in excess of the emergency rent pursuant to N.Y. Commercial Law § 4 (1949).


OVERVIEW: The tenant alleged that § 4 was unconstitutional in that it required all tenants in a building to pay the same amount of rent per square foot regardless of the actual value of the portion leased by them. The court reversed and held as follows: (1) the statute was not unconstitutional because the legislative intent was not to require all tenants to pay the same rent in excess of the emergency rent regardless of the actual value of the rental property; (2) providing for all of the floor space in the same building as of equal value was a fortuitous and unintended consequence of the wording of § 4; (3) inasmuch as evidence was not taken on the trial of relative values of floor space within the building, a new trial was necessary; and (4) the reasonable rent was to be determined as of the date of the landlord's application to the trial court.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the trial court and ordered a new trial.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant - emergency rent law - reasonable rental - (1) in "alternative proceeding" under chapter 534 of Laws of 1949 (amdg. L. 1945, ch. 3) involving single tenant occupying loft space in building in New York City, order reversed and new trial ordered - (2) amendment adopted to require payment by statutory tenants of reasonable rental values of floor space occupied regardless of return from building as whole - (3) language used, if literally construed, might require valuation of all floor space at same figure regardless of value or position in building - (4) draftsman of law failed to consider operation thereof where floor space is of unequal value but mistake must not be permitted to defeat object of amendment - (5) proper manner stated of ascertaining rental of several rental spaces [***2] in building - (6) reasonable rent in such proceeding to be determined as of date of application therefor to Supreme Court.

1. In this "alternative proceeding" instituted under section 4 of the Commercial Rent Law (L. 1945, ch. 3), added by chapter 534 of the Laws of 1949, wherein only one tenant who occupies loft space on the eighth floor of the landlord's building in New York City is a party, the order appealed from directed payment of a reasonable rent in excess of the emergency rent and further fixed the rent as of the date of decision instead of the date of the commencement of the proceeding. The order is reversed and a new trial ordered.

2. The amendment was apparently adopted to require statutory tenants to pay the reasonable rental values of floor space occupied by them (computed under the statutory formula), aside from whether or not the landlord receives a reasonable return from the building as a whole. This purpose is disclosed not only by the amendment itself but by a report of the temporary commission which recommended its enactment.

3. The Legislature, however, used language which, if construed literally, might be deemed to require the evaluation of all of the [***3] floor space at the same figure per square foot, regardless of whether it be a choice showroom area on the ground floor or much less desirable loft space. Such a result is not necessary to the accomplishment of the purpose intended by the Legislature.

4. In the hypothetical case of a building in which all of the rentable space is of equal value, the literal terms of the amendment would correctly require each tenant to pay a fair return fo the space occupied. The draftsman of the statute did not consider how it would operate in cases where the floor space in a building is of unequal value. This obvious mistake should not be permitted to defeat the object of the amendment.

5. The total basic return for the building should be divided by the total of the weighted net rental space and the quantity of square footage in the respective rental spaces in the building should be weighted or adjusted in proportion to their relative rental values. After that has been done, the landlord is entitled to recover from each statutory tenant the amount of rent so apportioned to him regardless of how much income is received from the rest of the building.

6. The reasonable rent should be determined [***4] "as of the date of the application to the supreme court". (§ 4.)

 

1182 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Lederman v. Board of Education


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Second Department


276 A.D. 527; 96 N.Y.S.2d 466; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4904



March 27, 1950 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant board of education challenged a judgment of the Supreme Court, Kings County (New York), which found for respondents, a teachers' union president and others, and, pursuant to an order granting judgment on the pleadings under N.Y. R. Civ. Prac. 112, declared that N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 12-a(c) and N.Y. Educ. Law § 3022(2), and N.Y. Board of Regents Rules ch. XV-B, § 254 were unconstitutional and void, and restrained their enforcement.


OVERVIEW: Respondents brought an action challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 12-a(c), N.Y. Educ. Law § 3022(2), and N.Y. Board of Regents Rules ch. XV-B, § 254. The trial court found for them, declared the statutes and rule unconstitutional and void, and restrained the board of education from enforcing them. On appeal, the court reversed the judgment insofar as appealed from, denied respondents' motion for judgment on the pleadings, and dismissed the complaint under N.Y. R. Civ. Prac. 112, with costs. The court held that the wisdom or lack thereof of the challenged statutes and the propriety of their enactment was a legislative rather than judicial problem, that the offenses defined in N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 12-a were crimes under state and federal statutes that had been held to be constitutional, and that a finding pursuant to N.Y. Educ. Law § 3022(2), as to an organization and its listing, bore rational relation to the presumption that a listed organization unlawfully advocated overthrow of the government and that a member had knowledge thereof, and was prospective and provided due process of law. The court declined to consider the validity of the challenged rule.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment in favor of respondents, insofar as appealed from, denied the motion for judgment on the pleadings, and dismissed the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - public schools - teachers and other school employees - subversive activities - (1) subdivision (c) of section 12-a of Civil Service Law forbidding appointment to public position of member in or organizer of society advocating forceful overthrow of government and section 3022 of Education Law (Feinberg Law) implementing same with respect to enforcement in public schools, deemed constitutional - (2) propriety of enactment of statute not [***2] judicial problem - (3) offenses defined in section 12-a are crimes under other statutes which have been found constitutional and so subdivision (c) is valid; no constitutional right to be public employee except on compliance with reasonable conditions such as those found in statute - (4) presumption under section 3022 that organization listed is subversive and that member employee has knowledge thereof not conclusive but rule of dence within power of Legislature; statute prospective in operation and conforms with due process of law - (5) contention that statute (Feinberg Law) bill of attainder without merit since predicated on preamble which is not part of statute. 

1. Subdivision (c) of section 12-a of the Civil Service Law makes ineligible for appointment to any public position one who organizes or helps to organize a society or group advocating the overthrow of the State or National Government by force or is a member therein. Section 3022 of the Education Law (L. 1949. ch. 360), the so-called "Feinberg Law", implements said section 12-a as to enforcement and, among other things, provides for the removal of superintendents, teachers and employees in the educational system who [***3] continue as members of subversive organizations. The statutes are constitutional.

2. The wisdom or unwisdom of these statutes and the propriety of their enactment presents a legislative and not a judicial problem.

3. The offenses defined in section 12-a are crimes under section 161 of the Penal Law and section 2385 of title 18 of the United States Code, both of which have been held constitutional, and hence subdivision (c) of said section 12-a is valid. A constitutional right of free speech may be abridged as a condition of public employment. No one has a constitutional right to be a public employee except on compliance with reasonable conditions which may be imposed by the Legislature under reasonable classifications. Here both the condition and classification are reasonable.

4. A finding pursuant to section 3022 as to the nature of an organization and the listing thereof bears rational relation to the facts to be presumed under subdivision 2 of section 3022, namely, that the organization does unlawfully advocate overthrow of the government and that a member employee has knowledge thereof. The presumption is not conclusive and is a rule of evidence within legislative [***4] competence. The statute is prospective in operation and conforms with due process of law.

5. A contention that chapter 360 of the Laws of 1949 is invalid as a bill of attainder is without merit. It is predicated on language in the preamble which is not part of the statute and, regardless of references therein to the Communist party and its affiliated organizations, section 3022, which provides for a finding after a hearing on notice as to all organizations, is determinative.

 Lederman v. Board of Education of City of N.Y., 196 Misc. 873, reversed.

 

1183 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Thompson v. Wallin


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


276 A.D. 463; 95 N.Y.S.2d 784; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4891



March 8, 1950 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York, challenged an order of the Supreme Court, Albany County Special Term (New York), which granted the motion of plaintiffs, officers of a voluntary association known as the Communist Party of the State of New York, for judgment on the pleadings declaring 1949 N.Y. Laws ch. 360 unconstitutional, entered judgment thereon, and enjoined the Board from executing its provisions.


OVERVIEW: When the action was brought by the officers, their association was under inquiry by the Board as to whether it was a subversive organization under 1949 N.Y. Laws ch. 360. The officers claimed that the statute had the prohibited effect of a bill of attainder. In reversing the judgment and order, the court held that the officers had unsuccessfully challenged the constitutionality of the statute as to its effect upon them, the association, or anyone else. First, the fact that the legislature used the expression "the communist party" in the statute's preamble did not mean any penalties were inflicted, and even if branded as subversive, the officers and the association could carry on as they chose. Further, the preamble did not form a part of the statute and enacted nothing. Thus, the statute could not be stricken down as a bill of attainder. Second, the statute did not transgress constitutional safeguards of due process because whatever action was taken was subject to notice, a hearing, and judicial review. Finally, the statute did not unwarrantably encroach upon their association's basic freedoms because the only result was that the association could be listed as subversive.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and order on the law, granted the Board's motion for judgment on the pleadings, and dismissed the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - public schools - teachers and other school employees - subversive activities - (1) in action by Communist party, judgment declaring unconstitutional, and enjoining execution of provisions of, section 3022 of Education Law, known as Feinberg Law (relating to removal of disloyal persons), reversed and complaint dismissed - (2) constitutionality of statute subject to attack only by one whose rights are affected thereby; since Board of Regents has noticed plaintiffs' organization for inquiry and board does not question their right to sue and since plaintiffs charge statute is bill of attainder, court may take jurisdiction - (3) charge that statute is bill of attainder dependent on preamble of statute where Communist party alone is mentioned, but preamble forms no part of statute - (4) charge that statute violates safeguards of due process unavailable since it accords right to [***2] association to be heard and to judicial review of determination - (5) no denial to plaintiffs of freedoms of assembly, speech and press since listing of organization as subversive obtains only as incident in maintenance of qualifications of public school personnel - (6) State's exercise of police power in field of education not within operative effect of Federal guarantees of said freedoms - (7) statute may not be held invalid because of envisioned unconstitutional procedures unless prescribed; none such found - (8) rule that membership in listed organization is prima facie evidence of disqualification mere rule of evidence; no vested right exists as to absence thereof.

1. A judgment in favor of plaintiffs (Communist party of the State of New York) declaring unconstitutional and enjoining the Board of Regents from executing any of the provisions of chapter 360 of the Laws of 1949 (Education Law, § 3022) - known as the Feinberg Law - which provides for the removal of subversive persons from employment in public schools should be reversed and the complaint dismissed.

2. One may attack the constitutionality of a statute only if and to the extent that his rights are affected by [***3] it and may not be heard to champion any right but his own. However, the association of which plaintiffs are officers has been noticed for and was under inquiry by the Board of Regents for findings as to whether it was subversive under the act. The Regents do not press the point that plaintiffs have no standing to sue. In view thereof and the further fact that plaintiffs charge that the statute attaints their association, the court will take jurisdiction.

3. In attacking the statute as a bill of attainder, plaintiffs rely on its preamble where the Legislature used the expression "the communist party" as descriptive of one of the "subversive groups" teaching seditious doctrines. However, the references in the preamble are expressly based on hearsay and adjudicate nothing as to the organizations therein mentioned and, even if found and listed as subversive, the statute provides no punishment and prescribes no forfeiture. The association is named only in the preamble which forms no part of the statute and carries no sanctions. Moreover, advocacy of the overthrow of organized government by force is not an essential of the basic doctrine of communism. Accordingly, since as to these [***4] plaintiffs the statute exercises no judicial power and imposes no punishment or penalties, it may not be stricken down as a bill of attainder.

4. Plaintiffs' contention that, in subjecting their organization to inquiry and possible listing, the statute transgresses constitutional safeguards as to due process, fails because appropriate notice and a right to be heard is afforded and judicial review of any determination may be had as regards any justiciable question (Civ. Prac. Act, art. 78). The provision for listing of subversive organizations after "appropriate" notice and hearing as provided in the act demands a full compliance with all the applicable requirements of due process.

5. As to the claim that the statute encroaches on plaintiffs' basic freedoms as to assembly, speech and press, it is to be noted that, after due notice and hearing, the association shall, if the facts warrant, be listed as subversive but that result can obtain only as an incident to the primary aim of the statute in the maintenance of the qualifications of public school personnel. Insofar as the statute can operate, the basic freedoms of the association remain unmolested.

6. It is not contended [***5] that the State may not exclude those who advocate or adhere to the doctrine of criminal anarchy and all relevant criticism is as to the means provided to achieve the statutory aim. Those means are the method of the State's exercise of its police power in a proper field, that of education. They are employed in a matter which is not within the operative effect of the Federal guarantees as originally laid down nor as extended by the Fourteenth Amendment.

7. Assuming that plaintiffs have a standing which permits them to attack the statute, it is doubtful that they may be heard to assail it because of its impact on others. Even if granted full voice in the matter, they are limited to the face of the statute. The statute may not be held invalid because of envisioned unconstitutional procedures unless it prescribes them. None such are to be found.

8. In testing as to qualification for employment in the public school system, all the cardinal elements of due process are provided. The provision that membership in a listed organization is prima facie evidence of disqualification is a rule of evidence and no vested right is deprived by the existence of that rule. The statute is equally [***6] applicable to all employees and all who may seek such employment in a matter which is purely a State concern and which allows the exercise of its police powers.

Thompson v. Wallin, 196 Misc. 686, reversed.

 

1184 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


L'Hommedieu v. Board of Regents


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


276 A.D. 494; 95 N.Y.S.2d 443; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4898



March 8, 1950 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellees, current and retired teachers, sought a determination that N.Y. Educ. Law § 3022 (1949) (chapter 360) was unconstitutional. The Supreme Court at Special Term (New York) granted the teachers' petition and held that chapter 360 was unconstitutional as a bill of attainder and as violative of the due process clause of the United States Constitution. Appellants, school officials, sought review.


OVERVIEW: The court found that under chapter 360, the school officials could, after notice and a hearing, determine if an organization advocated the overthrow of the government by force, violence, or other unlawful means.
