Chapter 360 also provided that membership in such an organization was prima facie evidence of disqualification for teachers. The school officials contended that chapter 360 was not a bill of attainder and that it did not violate due process because it provided notice and a hearing. The court agreed with the school officials and reversed the lower court's order. The court held that chapter 360 was not a bill of attainder because it did not impose any penalty without a hearing. Because hearings were provided and there were several channels of review from the results of these hearings, the court also held that chapter 360 did not violate the guarantees of due process. In addition, the court held that the state legislature could prescribe the qualifications of state employees, including requiring loyalty to the government, and that such loyalty was especially relevant to the qualifications of teachers, who were entrusted with the education of the state's children.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower court's order and dismissed the teachers' petition.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - public schools - teachers and other school employees - subversive activities - (1) order declaring unconstitutional chapter 360 of Laws of 1949 (Education Law, § 3022), known as Feinberg Law, reversed - (2) by section 3022 of Education Law, Board of Regents directed to adopt rules for disqualification of teachers who violate section 3021 of Education Law or are ineligible under section 12-a of Civil Service Law (both directed at disloyalty in public service); board directed, after inquiry and appropriate hearing, to list organizations found to be subversive by reason of teaching overthrow of Government by force; board also directed to provide that membership in any organization so listed shall constitute prima facie evidence of disqualification for position in public schools - (3) full and complete court review available for any determination of board's listing of organization as [***2] subversive and for any determination of board of education finding teacher disqualified under new statute (Cov. Prac. Act, art. 78; Civil Service Law, § 12-a, subd. d; Education Law, § 310) - (4) no constitutional right to be school teacher nor to advocate overthrow of Government by force; disqualification to teach by reason of advocacy of overthrow of Government by force deemed constitutional - (5) in holding statute bill of attainder Special Term improperly relied on contents of section 1 of said chapter 360 which is merely preamble to law and cannot be read into operative provisions of section 3022; elements essential to bill of attainder absent from section 3022 - (6) fact that membership in listed organization is made prima facie evidence of disqualification does not vitiate statute by making new rule of evidence requiring less or different proof; rule invoked available only to ex post facto law - (1) statute not ex post facto law as condemned by Constitution since phrase relates exclusively to criminal or penal statute - (8) as between two possible interpretations, court should adopt construction upholding statute - (9) statute does not violate due process guarantee of State [***3] of Federal Constitutions nor infringe on freedoms guaranteed thereby - (10) finding of denial of due process in that under statute every member of listed organization not entitled to notice of hearing and opportunity to participate, improper - (11) constitutional guarantees of freedom of speech and press not absolute; Legislature needed no public hearings to learn that teachers who are members of subversive organizations imperil life of Government.

1. In a proceeding under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act for a determination directing the Board of Regents to disregard chapter 360 of the Laws of 1949 (known as the Feinberg Law) and to refrain from taking any action for its enforcement, an order declaring the statute unconstitutional is reversed on the law and the petition dismissed.

2. A prior statute (Education Law, § 3021) provides that a person employed in the public schools shall be removed from such position for the utterance of any treasonable or seditious words or the doing of any treasonable or seditious acts and, under section 12-a of the Civil Service Law which applies to all public employees, appointment or retention of any person in public employ is prohibited [***4] if the person by word of mouth or writing willfully teaches the doctrine that the Government of the United States or of any State should be overthrown by force or if he becomes a member of any society so teaching. By the new law (Education Law, § 3022) the Board of Regents is directed to adopt rules and regulations for the disqualification or removal of teachers and others who violate section 3021 or who are ineligible for appointment or retention under section 12-a of the Civil Service Law. The Board of Regents is directed, after inquiry and after such notice and hearing as may be appropriate, to make a listing of organizations found to be subversive in that they teach the doctrine that the Government of the United States or of any State should be overthrown by force or advise or teach propriety of adopting any such doctrine as set forth in section 12-a. The board is further directed to provide in its regulations that membership in any organization listed by it shall constitute prima facie evidence of disqualification for appointment to or retention in any position in the public schools.

3. Full and complete court review of any determination of the Board of Regents' listing [***5] of an organization and of any determination of a board of education finding a teacher disqualified under the Feinberg Law is available. An organization so listed has the remedy provided by article 78 of the Civil Practice Act while a teacher found disqualified pursuant to the Feinberg Law by a board of education has an election of remedies. He may petition for a review under subdivision d of section 12-a of the Civil Service Law and obtain a stay until final judgment on the hearing or he may have a right of appeal or petition to the Commissioner of Education under section 310 of the Education Law and is given an alternative right of review under the provisions of article 78 (Education Law, § 2523, subi. 5). In addition, where constitutional rights of liberty or property are involved, due process entitles one whose rights are invaded to independent judicial determination of the constitutional question involved, the act of the Board of Regents, the delegate here of the Legislature, being reviewable as an act of the Legislature itself.

4. The sole issue in this case is that which makes one activity - membership in an organization advocating the overthrow of Government by force [***6] - prima facie, a disqualification to teach in the public schools. There is no constitutional right to be a teacher any more than there is to be a public official.Nor has one a constitutional right to advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence. The standards for qualification as teachers in the public schools are fixed by the Legislature. It may constitutionally require as qualification and declare as disqualification factors other than scholastic, including as a qualification adherence to the form of Government of the United States and, as a disqualification, advocacy of the overthrow thereof by force. The most important qualification of a teacher is loyalty to the Government. This is not an unconstitutional qualification.

5. In holding that the statute in question is a bill of attainder, Special Term based its decision solely on section 1 of chapter 360 of the Laws of 1949 which is no part of the Education Law ( § 3022) to be administered by the Board of Regents or any officer. It is merely a preamble to the law and cannot be read into the operative provisions of section 3022 nor can it be strained to find in it a directive to the regents to list the Communist [***7] party or to find in it the imposition of punishment upon that party without a hearing. It does not impose (a) any penalty (b) without a hearing and these are the two elements of a bill of attainder. A bill of attainder is a legislative judgment of conviction, an exercise of judicial power by the legislative body, the imposition of punishment by a legislative act and there is no one of these elements in the law. In the body of the act which the Board of Regents must enforce there is no mention of any organization at all by name and a hearing is provided with respoect to any such organization. No penalty is imposed on any organization which, after a hearing, the board shall find advocates the overthrow of the Government by force and the organization has the remedy of review by the courts, while a teacher found to be a member of such organization also has the protection that the Education Law provides, as noted. ( Cummings v. Missouri, 4 Wall. [U.S.] 277; United States v. Lovett, 328 U.S. 303, distinguished.)

6. An argument that, by the provision making membership in a listed organization prima facie evidence of disqualification, the statute is vitiated because [***8] it makes a new rule of evidence whereby less or different proof is required to convict, is without merit because that rule is one applicable to an ex post facto law as regards a criminal or penal statute. Moreover, there is no vested right in a public school employee's retention of position conditioned as it is on the continued possession of prescribed qualifications and there is no vested right in an existing law of evidence.

7. The law in question is not an ex post facto law within the condemnation of the Constitution since that phrase is one that relates exclusively to criminal or penal statutes.

8. Where the validity of a statute is assailed and there are two possible interpretations, the court should adopt the construction which would uphold the statute. 

9. The Feinberg Law does not violate the due process guarantee of the State or Federal Constitutions. Neither does it infringe upon the freedoms guaranteed thereby for it is not a criminal statute and the effect of its application is not criminal punishment.

10. The court below improperly found that there is a denial of procedural due process because every member of an organization as to which the Regents hold a [***9] hearing to determine whether it is to be listed is not required to be given notice of the hearing or opportunity to participate.

11. The constitutional guarantees of freedom of speech and freedom of the press may not be deemed absolute and those who imperil the very existence of Government cannot take shelter therein and make those guarantees the very means of self-destruction. It is a matter of common knowledge that organizations which advocate the overthrow of the Government by force endanger the existence of the country and that, to have members of such organizations as teachers of our children in whose hands will soon rest the fate and existence of the Government, is a peril to its life. The Legislature needed no public hearings to learn that.

 Matter of L'Hommedieu v. Board of Regents, 196 Misc. 686, reversed.

 

1185 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Continental Bank & Trust Co. v. Tanager Constr. Corp.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


276 A.D. 988; 95 N.Y.S.2d 275; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5448



March 2, 1950 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant construction company challenged an order of the Supreme Court at Special Term (New York), which granted a motion by respondent trustee for judgment on the pleadings under N.Y. R. Civ. Prac. 112 and struck out the counterclaims and defenses contained in the answer and from the judgment entered thereon.


OVERVIEW: The record of the mortgage was cancelled and discharged without payment of disputed unpaid interest. On appeal, the court affirmed the trial court's grant of the trustee's motion for judgment on the pleadings under N.Y. R. Civ. Prac. 112 and striking of counterclaims and defenses contained in the answer and from the judgment entered thereon. The court awarded costs to the trustee.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's grant of the trustee's motion for judgment on the pleadings under N.Y. R. Civ. Prac. 112 and striking of counterclaims and defenses contained in the answer and from the judgment entered thereon.

 

1186 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Fullam v. Westchester County Playland Com.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Second Department


276 A.D. 925; 94 N.Y.S.2d 637; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5157



January 30, 1950 

 

1187 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Whitbeck v. Cacioppi


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


276 A.D. 939; 94 N.Y.S.2d 239; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5202



January 18, 1950 

 

1188 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


L'Hommedieu v. Board of Regents


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


276 A.D. 287; 94 N.Y.S.2d 268; 1950 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4847



January 10, 1950 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a university board of regents and others, challenged the order of the Albany Special Term (New York), which determined that the "Feinberg Law," 1949 N.Y. Laws 360, was unconstitutional. Respondents filed motions to strike from calendar, or to adjourn to another term the appeal or to render a pro forma decision and direct that the appeal be heard in the New York Court of Appeals, and to make certain corrections in the record.


OVERVIEW: After respondents brought a proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 to direct the board of regents to desist from taking any action pursuant to the Feinberg Law, the trial court found in favor of respondents by finding that the Feinberg Law was unconstitutional. When the board of regents filed an appeal, respondents filed motions to strike from the calendar or adjourn the appeal to another term, to render a pro forma decision, to direct that the appeal be heard in the Court of Appeals, and to make certain corrections in the record before the special term. The court denied the motions, holding that the adjournment of the matter would unduly delay the matter, and that the delay should be avoided in the interest of an early and ultimate determination of an important constitutional question. Moreover, the court directed waiver of provisions of N.Y. App. Div., 3rd Jud. Dep't Spec. R. 12, 13 as to the time of service of the record and notice of argument and brief. The court noted that it had jurisdiction of the merits of the appeal and had no election or choice in entertaining an appeal. Accordingly, it should not render a pro forma decision.


OUTCOME: The court denied respondents' motions.


HEADNOTES

Appeal - service of record and notice of argument - pro forma decision - (1) motion to strike appeal from calendar on ground record and notice of argument not served in sufficient time before term, or to adjourn appeal to following term, denied; since important constitutional question is involved, rules of court as to time of service are waived - (2) Appellate Division, having jurisdiction of merits of appeal, will not render pro forma decision affirming Special Term and directing that appeal be heard in Court of Appeals - (3) motion that [***2] record be referred to Special Term for correction of errors denied.

1. A motion to strike the present appeal from the calendar, on the ground that the record and notice of argument had not been served in sufficient time before the term of court or, in the alternative, to adjourn the appeal to the next term, is denied. If the case were adjourned, its submission to the Court of Appeals would be delayed. Such delay should be avoided so that there may be an early determination of the important constitutional question involved. Under the circumstances, provisions of the rules of the court as to the time of service of the record, notice of argument and brief, will be waived.

2. A motion that the Appellate Division should render a pro forma decision, affirming the decision at Special Term and directing that the appeal be heard in the Court of Appeals, is denied. The court has jurisdiction of the merits of the appeal and is under a duty to cosider fully, adequately and independently questions properly before it. Moreover, it has no power to direct that the appeal be heard in the Court of Appeals.

3. A motion to refer the record to Special Term for correction of errors is [***3] denied.

 

1189 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Seeth v. Joseph


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


276 A.D. 188; 93 N.Y.S.2d 591; 1949 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3140



December 20, 1949 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner pilot brought a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 to review a determination by respondent, the Comptroller of the City of New York, which assessed a tax on the gross receipts of the pilot for the fiscal years 1941-1943 pursuant to the New York City Business Tax Laws, New York City, N.Y., Local Laws No. 47 (1941), New York City, N.Y., Local Laws No. 27 (1942), New York City, N.Y., Local Laws No. 21 (1943).


OVERVIEW: The receipts held to be taxable by the Comptroller represented pilotage fees for the pilot's services in navigating ships in and out of the port of New York. The ships piloted by the pilot were navigated to or from points on the high seas beyond the territorial limits of the United States. The pilot argued that the tax as applied to him was unconstitutional in several respects. The court held that the tax was in conflict with the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution. The court reasoned that the United States Supreme Court had invalidated taxes imposed under the New York City Business Tax Laws upon gross receipts of stevedores operating in New York harbor. The loading and unloading of a vessel was so essentially a part of commerce as to prohibit a tax on gross receipts derived from the business of stevedoring in connection with vessels engaged in foreign and interstate trade. The piloting of vessels in foreign and interstate commerce was as much a part of commerce as the work of a stevedore. If the imposition of an unapportioned gross receipts tax on the business of stevedoring was repugnant to the Commerce Clause, a like tax on pilotage was open to the same objection.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the Comptroller's determination.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - taxation - local tax on gross receipts of pilot - (1) imposition of tax by City of New York on gross receipts of pilot engaged in navigating, in and out of Port of New York, ships in foreign and interstate commerce conflicts with commerce clause of Federal Constitution - (2) grant of power by Federal Government to States to regulate business of piloting does not empower city to impose tax for general revenue purposes.

1. The City of New York may not - under Local Laws (Local Law No. 47, 1941; Local Law No. 27, 1942; Local Law No. 21, 1943) which provide for a tax payable by persons carrying on any trade, business, profession or commercial activity in the city of New York - impose a tax upon the gross receipts of a pilot for his services in piloting, in and out of the Port [***2] of New York, ships in foreign and interstate commerce. The piloting of vessels in foreign and interstate commerce is a part of such commerce and the imposition of the tax conflicts with the commerce clause of the Federal Constitution.

2. In granting to the States the power of regulation over pilots and piloting (U.S. Code, tit. 46, § 211) Congress did not intend to empower the city to impose this tax. The Local Laws do not attempt to regulate pilots in the Port of New York nor has any such power been conferred on the city by the State. The taxes have been imposed as part of a general revenue system, and not as an incident to exercise of police power. This revenue taxation has no relation to regulation or police power.

 

1190 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Moffett v. Bates


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


276 A.D. 38; 93 N.Y.S.2d 313; 1949 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3107



November 16, 1949 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer brought a proceeding under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 to review and annul a determination of respondents, the Tax Commission of the State of New York, which held the taxpayer subject to assessments of unincorporated business tax under N.Y. Tax Law art. 16-A.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was a consultant in matters of corporate finance and reorganization. The Tax Commissioner held that he was conducting a business rather than practicing a profession and was subject to the unincorporated business tax under N.Y. Tax Law § 386. The taxpayer contended that N.Y. Tax Law art. 16-A, imposing such tax, was unconstitutional, in that it violated the due process and equal protection clauses of the federal and state constitutions. The court did not agree. The power of taxation was coextensive with sovereignty and could be directed against the exercise of personal rights and privileges. The State retained wide discretion in selecting subjects of taxation. The equal protection clause was not offended because no business was exempt. It was not discriminatory to exempt professions. All those conducting unincorporated businesses were in the same taxable category, and the taxpayer was taxed on the same basis as other unincorporated businesses. The taxpayer was not engaged in a profession because his knowledge was not acquired through formal education or special instruction and study.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the decision of the Tax Commission.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - unincorporated business tax - (1) Tax Law (art. 16-A) which imposes tax on income of "any unincorporated business" but exempts professions, is constitutional - (2) petitioner is consultant in corporate finance and reorganization; he is not engaged in profession and his income from such business is subject to tax - (3) record supports further finding of tax commission that petitioner's compensation as director and officer of certain corporations which retained him as consultant was taxable as income in his business as consultant.

1. Article 16-A of the Tax Law, which imposes a tax on the net income of "any unincorporated business", does not violate the due process clause of the United States Constitution (14th Amendt., § 1) or the equal protection [***2] clause of the therefrom, whatever business classifications it deems proper, and so long as all persons similarly situated are treated equally there can be no valid complaint or unconstitutionality. The exemption which the statute, the tax commission and the courts have granted, with qualifications, to professions as distinguished from businesses, is not a denial of "equal protection" of the laws. Furthermore, only those affected by alleged unconstitutionality are in a position to complain. Petitioner is neither a corporation whose unincorporated competitor has been granted exemption, nor is his occupation a profession. Nor is the question of interpretation as to what constitutes a profession so uncertain as to result in a denial of due process.

2. Petitioner is a consultant in matters of corporate finance and reorganization, rendering services to various clients for which he is paid fees. The tax commission properly held that he is conducting a business rather than practicing a profession and is subject to the unincorporated business tax. His preparation and his work are closely akin to those of an investment counselor, a market consultant, and a specialist in office management,  [***3] all of whom have been held to be engaged in businesses rather than in professions.

3. During the tax period involved, petitioner also served as a director and officer of corporations by which he was retained as consultant. The record supports the finding of the tax commission that petitioner's compensation from such employment was in furtherance of and constituted receipts from his regular business as consultant.

 

1191 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Robinson v. Broome County


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


276 A.D. 69; 93 N.Y.S.2d 662; 1949 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3114



November 16, 1949 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and other taxpayers of the county, appealed a decision from the Supreme Court of Broome County (New York), which dismissed their complaint against defendant Town of Union. The taxpayers sought to restrain the Town from withdrawing from the county welfare unit and from constituting itself as a separate welfare district.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers contended that the statutes authorizing the Town to withdraw from the county welfare unit violated the county home rule provisions of N.Y. Const. art. IX (1939). The court found that 1930 N.Y. Laws 197 and 1936 N.Y. Laws 1936 properly authorized any town in Broome County having a population of 30,000 or more to elect to assume the responsibilities of a city in a county public welfare district. At the date the statutes were enacted, the home rule provision had not yet been enacted, and there was no constitutional prohibition for the legislation. Although 1940 N.Y. Laws 619 was enacted without complying with the constitutional conditions, it merely consolidated existing law and was not a new law in violation of the constitutional ban. The taxpayers directed their argument against 1946 N.Y. Laws 200, § 75-a. However, the court found that the statute had nothing to do with counties and only applied to towns and welfare districts. Finally, the court held that a general statute relating to a matter of state concern, that applied to all localities having a given population, was not rendered local by the fact that only a single locality was eligible when it was enacted.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision dismissing the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - special or "local" laws - town welfare districts - (1) section 75-a of Social Welfare Law which provides that town might constitute itself town welfare district is not violative of article IX of State Constitution prohibiting enactment of special or local law or law relating to one county only; constitutional provision does not relate to towns or welfare districts - (2) moreover, constitutional prohibition does not relate to matters of health and welfare - (3) statute not rendered "local" law by fact that only single locality eligible to qualify thereunder.

1. A town having assumed, pursuant to statutory authority (L. 1930, ch. 197; L. 1936, ch. 595; L. 1940, ch. 619; Social Welfare Law, § 55), the responsibilities of a city in a county public welfare district, elected to function as a separate district under [***3] the provisions of section 75-a of the Social Welfare Law (L. 1946, ch. 200), which provides that a town having a population of 50,000 or more and which has already assumed the responsibilities of a city in a county public welfare district, might elect to constitute itself a town welfare district. This provision of the Social Welfare Law does not violate the provisions of article IX of the State Constitution prohibiting the enactment of special or local laws or laws relating to one county only without either the approval of the board of supervisors or a certificate of the Governor and two-thirds vote of the members of the Legislature. The constitutional provision relates to counties and not to towns or welfare districts. Accordingly, the complaint in a taxpayer's action seeking to restrain the Town of Union in Broome County from operating as a separate welfare district was properly dismissed.

2. The constitutional prohibition relates to "the organization and government of counties" and legislation which is concerned with matters of health and welfare is not within the category of special or local laws affecting the organization and government of any county. Accordingly, even [***4] if the statute allowing the town to elect to constitute itself a town welfare district did relate to counties it would not be unconstitutional. 

3. Furthermore, a general statute relating to a matter of State concern and applying to all localities having a given population is not rendered a "local" law by the fact that only a single locality is eligible at the time of its enactment to qualify under it. The classification based on population is not unreasonable or arbitrary.

Robinson v. County of Broome, 195 Misc. 24, affirmed.

 

1192 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Adirondack League Club v. Board of Black River Regulating Dist.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Fourth Department


275 A.D. 618; 92 N.Y.S.2d 256; 1949 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3827



September 28, 1949 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner conservation group requested that the court review a decision by respondent, Board of Black River Regulating District (board), under N.Y. Conserv. Law § 454 and N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, that found that public welfare required the construction of a reservoir on the south branch of the Moose River and directed that construction proceed according to the proposed plans.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner alleged that if the plan was followed, its land would be flooded and it would be deprived of land without due process. Petitioner also argued that the board did not comply with N.Y. Conservation Law art. VII, that the capacity of the proposed reservoir was excessive, and that the construction of the dam and reservoir was not in the public interest. The court affirmed the decision of the board. The court reasoned that respondents were not deprived of land without due process. There was substantial compliance with the provisions of the Conservation Law and that all required steps have been taken. The court found that the state could create an agency for the purpose of carrying out a state duty or function. The legislature acted within constitutional limitations in enacting the Conservation Law, the board was a state agency, the members of the board were state officers, and their acts were the acts of the state and complied with the statute.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the board in the environmental dispute.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - river regulating district as "state" - public authorities - (1) determination by board of river regulating district to construct dam for regulating flow of river requiring taking of private land and use of State forest preserve, confirmed - (2) findings of board as to size and desirability of dam supported by sufficient proof - (3) no deprivation of private property without due process of law involved - (4) substantial compliance with terms of Conservation Law (art. VII) governing river regulation - (5) provisions of said article authorizing river regulating district to construct dam on State forest preserve not violative of article XIV of State Constitution [***2] requiring such reservoirs to be constructed, owned, controlled and operated by "state"; statutory intent was to create State agencies to take over State functions in regulation of rivers and board members are State officers as indicated by necessity of filing oath of office with Secretary of State - (6) clear conflict between statute and Constitution essential to invalidate former - (7) board is State agency and acts of members are acts of "state".

1. In proceedings under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act a determination of respondents to construct a dam and operate a reservoir for the purpose of regulating the Moose and Black Rivers - a project which requires the taking of approximately 3,500 acres of private lands and the use of 1,500 acres of the State Forest Preserve - is confirmed.

2.With respect to contentions that the capacity of the proposed reservoir is excessive and that the construction of the dam and reservoir is not in the public interest, there is sufficient proof from which respondents could make the findings they have made and, although on all the evidence the court might differ with such findings, it may not be said that they were not based upon substantial [***3] evidence.

3. An objection that petitioner, a private corporation, will be deprived of property without due process of law, is overruled. ( Hudson River Regulating District v. Fonda, J. & G.R.R. Co., 249 N.Y. 445, followed).

4. There has been a substantial compliance with the applicable provisions of article VII of the Conservation Law governing river regulation and all the steps have been taken which are required at this stage of the proceedings. Before actual construction of the reservoir is commenced, additional surveys and contract plans will have to be made but such work was not necessary until the determination of respondents was reviewed by the court.

5.It is also contended that the provisions of article VII, authorizing the board of a river regulating district to construct dams and reservoirs on the State forest preserve, are unconstitutional in that article XIV of the Constitution requires such reservoirs to be constructed, owned, controlled and operated by the State and that the board is not "the state". The predecessor of article VII was enacted shortly after the amendment to the Constitution authorizing the use of not exceeding 3% of State forest preserve [***4] lands for the maintenance of reservoirs to regulate the flow of streams under the control of the State and a reading of the statute shows that the Legislature had the constitutional limitations in mind. The districts were to be created by a commission of the State (presently the Water Power and Control Commission). After appointment by the Governor, each member of the board is required to take and file a constitutional oath of office in the Secretary of State's office, a requirement indicating the Legislature's intent to make them State officers ( Public Officers Law, § 10). Title to all real estate acquired by respondent is in the name of the State, the Comptroller is given control over the funds of the district and the acts of the board must have the approval of the commission. It is clear that the legislative intent was to give the commission the power in proper cases to create State agencies to take over State functions to regulate rivers under the supervision of the commission and, although the statute names such agencies public corporations, the board members were to be and are State officers.

6. To justify a court in declaring a statute invalid, the conflict between the [***5] act and the Constitution must be clear and certain. Every presumption favors the validity of the statute. If there is a reasonable doubt, the act should be upheld.

7. The Legislature acted within constitutional limitations in enacting the statute. Respondent is a State agency and the acts of its members are the acts of "the state" and comply with the statute.

 

1193 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Kohn v. Bates


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Fourth Department


275 A.D. 431; 90 N.Y.S.2d 391; 1949 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3788



June 24, 1949 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Supreme Court in Oneida County (New York) granted petitioner executor's motion under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act. art. 78 for an order to annul a determination of respondent Commissioner of Taxation and Finance of the State of New York and directed him to pay a veterans' bonus to the executor. The Commissioner appealed.


OVERVIEW: 1947 N.Y. Laws ch. 547 provided for payment of a bonus to the next of kin of a member of the armed forces who died on active duty between certain dates during World War II. The deceased's father applied for the bonus but died before the claim was approved. The father's executor argued that the bonus should be paid to the estate because the father had acquired a vested right to the payment. The lower court ordered the Commissioner of Taxation to pay the bonus to the executor. The court reversed and confirmed the Commissioner's determination that the executor was not entitled to payment of the bonus. The court found that the bonus was a pure gratuity which the legislature was at liberty to repeal at any time. Thus no vested right existed in favor of any person until the payment had actually been made. The court also held that it could not overlook the interpretation placed on the statute by the Commissioner of Taxation because that interpretation was warranted by the record and had a reasonable basis in the law.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the lower court and confirmed the commissioner's determination.


HEADNOTES

Army and navy - veterans' bonus - (1) veterans' bonus, payable under chapter 547 of Laws of 1947, is gratuity and not property right passing to executor of applicant who died prior to payment - (2) estate of adoptive father of member of armed forces who died while on active duty, who applied as next of kin for payment of bonus but died before payment made, not entitled to payment of bonus - (3) statute indicates intent that surviving next of kin, in order named in statute, should receive payment if person eligible dies - (4) interpretation of statute by Veterans' Bonus Bureau, having warrant in record and basis in law, should not be disturbed.

1.The veterans' bonus provided for by chapter 547 of the Laws of 1947 is a gratuity and not a property right which passes to an executor of an applicant who died prior to payment.

 [***2] 2. The adoptive father of a member of the armed forces who died while on active duty made claim for the bonus as next of kin, but, before the claim had been finally passed upon and before all the necessary date showing that he was next of kin had been submitted, the adoptive father died. The bonus is not payable to the executor of the father's estate. Since the next of kin mentioned in the statute must be alive to receive payment of the bonus, such next of kin could obtain no rights by the filing of an application.

3. The statute provides that in the event an eligible veteran himself makes application for a bonus but dies prior to receiving payment, the proceeds of such bonus go, not to the estate of the applicant, but to the surviving eligible next of kin (L. 1947, ch. 547, § 1, subd. [b]). This and other provisions of the statute indicate that, if the person eligible for payment of the bonus should die before actual payment is made, the surviving next of kin next in line in the order named in the statute would be entitled to receive payment thereof.

4. The Veterans' Bonus Bureau has always taken a corresponding position and its interpretation has warrant in the record,  [***3] a reasonable basis in law, and is not arbitrary or capricious. The courts should not interfere with an interpretation so placed upon the statute by an administrative body.

Matter of Kohn v. Bates, 194 Misc. 833, reversed.

 

1194 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Layton v. A. I. Namm & Sons, Inc.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


275 A.D. 246; 89 N.Y.S.2d 72; 1949 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3752



May 17, 1949 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant store challenged an order of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which denied its motion for summary judgment in plaintiff operator's wife's action for damages after the store removed the operator's equipment and merchandise from the store.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to an agreement, the operator managed an optical department in the store. After the operator died, the licensor gave notice terminating the agreement and then removed the operator's equipment and merchandise from the department. The operator's wife brought an action for damages, claiming protection under various landlord-tenant laws. The trial court denied the store's motion for summary judgment in the operator's wife's action for damages, holding that the agreement provided for more than a license. The court disagreed, reversed the trial court's order, and entered summary judgment for the store. In support of its ruling, the court considered that: 1) the operator's use of the space was limited and the space itself was subject to change and substitution at the will of the store; 2) the operator had only the privilege of conducting the department and not exclusive possession and control as against the store; 3) the operator did not pay rent, which was defined in N.Y. Bus. Rent Law ch. 314, § 2(f), as consideration for the use or occupancy of space, but paid the store 25 percent of the gross receipts for occupancy and the privilege of conducting the department.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's order that denied the store's motion for summary judgment in the operator's wife's action for damages after the store removed the operator's equipment and merchandise. The court granted summary judgment to the store.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant - rent regulation business space - operation of optical department in store - (1) agreement for operation of optical department in department store did not create landlord-tenant relationship - (2) immaterial that Business Rent Law (L. 1945, ch. 314, § 2, as amd.) defines tenant as including licensee - (3) moreover, compensation paid under agreement not rent as defined in Business Rent Law - (4) accordingly, in action to recover damages resulting from exclusion from space in store (L. 1945, ch. 314, § 8, as amd.), complaint should be dismissed.

1. In May, 1939, a department store, described as licensor, and an optician, described as licensee, entered into an agreement for the operation of an optical department in the store. The agreement provided that the licensor leased to the licensee and the licensee hired from the licensor certain space, which was shown on a diagram made part of the agreement. The licensor [***2] reserved the right to remove the department to another place in the store. The sales were to be made in the name of the licensor and receipts were to go through the regular channels of the business of the licensor, and, after deducting the licensor's commissions, the proceeds were to be retained by the licensor in trust for the licensee, who agreed to pay for the privilege of conducting the department 25% of the gross receipts thereof and to spend 8% of the gross receipts on advertising. The licensee was made liable to the licensor for unpaid charge accounts. Selection of employees by the licensee was to be subject to the approval of the licensor. Prices were made subject to regulation by the agreement and final adjustment of disputes with customers was to be made by the licensor. The license could not be assigned and the licensee was forbidden to permit anyone else to occupy the space or transact business therein without consent of the licensor. The original agreement covered the period from April, 1939, to January 27, 1940, subject to continuance at will with the right of either party to cancel on fourteen days' notice. It was specifically provided that the relationship between [***3] licensor and licensee was personal. Such agreement did not create a relationship of landlord and tenant. The licensee was not granted exclusive possession of the space and the agreement provided for such control by the licensor that the licensee had only the privilege of conducting the department. The fact that the space occupied is specific and described by diagram does not effect a landlord-tenant relationship.

2. It is immaterial that the Business Rent Law (L. 1945, ch. 314, § 2, as amd.) defines a tenant as including a licensee. The licensee herein did not have exclusive possession of a rentable area.

3. Moreover, compensation paid under the agreement was not "rent", defined in the Business Rent Law as consideration "for the use and occupancy" of space (L. 1945, ch. 314, § 2, as amd.). The consideration paid under this agreement was, as provided by the agreement, for occupancy "and the privilege of conducting the said department."

4. Accordingly, in an action brought by the optician's widow as his executrix, who had conducted the department for several months and was then excluded from the premises, to recover damages resulting from such exclusion (L. 1945, ch.  [***4] 314, § 8, as amd.), summary judgment dismissing the complaint should have been granted.

 

1195 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Levine v. O'Connell


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


275 A.D. 217; 88 N.Y.S.2d 672; 1949 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3745



May 10, 1949 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner licensee sought review of a judgment of the supreme court (New York), which ruled in favor of respondent State Liquor Authority (authority) in the licensee's N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act art. 78 proceeding for review of a decision of the authority to revoke his license to sell liquor at retail for consumption off the premises.


OVERVIEW: The licensee was found guilty for the third time of cutting prices on sales of liquor in violation of the Fair Trade Law, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law §§ 369-a to 369-e, and the authority's Rule 26, which required the adoption and observance of fair trade contracts fixing resale prices. The court annulled the authority's decision to revoke the licensee's license, holding that: (1) N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law § 17(12)(b) simply granted the authority discretion to prohibit the sale of alcoholic beverages except pursuant to a fair trade contract; (2) whether mandatory price-fixing should be adopted was not a fit subject to be relegated to determination by an administrative board; (3) what the authority did went far beyond anything enacted by the Fair Trade Law, which was intended to protect producers of branded commodities in the ownership of their brand names and which made price-fixing entirely voluntary; and (4) the incorporation of the Fair Trade Law by reference in § 17(12)(b) violated N.Y. Const. art. III, § 16. Thus, both N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law § 17(12)(b) and the authority's Rule 26 respecting mandatory price-fixing were invalid.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the authority's determination revoking the licensee's license and remitted the matter to the authority for suitable action with respect to the other charges against the licensee.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law - intoxicating liquors - Fair Trade Law - delegation of legislative power - incorporation of another statute by reference - (1) mandatory price-fixing provisions of Alcoholic Beverage Control Law ( § 17, subd. 12, par. [b]) and of rule 26 of State Liquor Authority are unconstitutional and void (N.Y. Const., art. III, §§ 1, 16) - (2) Legislature may not delegate discretion to administrative body to determine whether price-fixing of brandname alcoholic beverages shall be mandatory - (3) price-fixing under Fair Trade Law (General Business Law, art. XXIV-A) depends on voluntary contract of owner of brand name, whereas here discretion is delegated to make it mandatory - (4) statute fails to set standard to control discretion of administrative body - (5) statute also unconstitutionally incorporates [***2] Fair Trade Law by reference - (6) revocation by Authority of liquor license annulled and matter remitted for further action in respect of lesser charges.

1. Paragraph (b) of subdivision 12 of section 17 of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law is an unconstitutional delegation of legislative discretion (N.Y. Const., art. III, § 1) to the State Liquor Authority to make mandatory as to alcoholic beverages the provisions of the Fair Trade Law (General Business Law, art. XXIV-A) permitting contracts to be made fixing the prices of brandname commondities. This provision of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law also violates the constitutional prohibition against incorporating another statute by reference (N.Y. Const., art. III, § 16). The provision, as well as rule 26 of the Rules of the State Liquor Authority adopted pursuant thereto, is invalid.

2. The General Business Law (art. XXIV-A, known as the Fair Trade Law) provides that no contract relating to the sale or resale of a commodity which bears the trade-mark, brand, or name of the producer or owner and which is in fair and open competition with commodities of the same general class shall be deemed in violation of law notwithstanding [***3] that such contract prohibits the buyer from reselling except at the price stipulated by the vendor, and notwithstanding that it may require any dealer to agree that he will not resell except at the price stipulated by such vendor or vendee (§ 369-a). Willfully and knowingly advertising, offering for sale or reselling a commodity at less than the price stipulated in such a contract, whether or not by a party thereto, is made unfair competition and actionable at the suit of any person damaged thereby (§ 369-b). Paragraph (b) of subdivision 12 of section 17 of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law purports to authorize the State Liquor Authority "in its discretion" to prohibit "the sale of any or all alcoholic beverages * * * except pursuant to a fair trade contract entered into in accordance with the provisions of article twenty-four-a of the general business law." Whether mandatory price-fixing shall be adopted is not a fit subject to be relegated to determination by an administrative board, under the guise of making regulations to facilitate the accomplishment of its purpose to enforce the liquor laws enacted by the Legislature. Under section 1 of article III of the New York State [***4] Constitution, "The legislative power of this State shall be vested in the Senate and Assembly." This legislative power cannot be passed on to others.

3. What has been done here goes far beyond anything enacted by the Fair Trade Law. Such laws are primarily designed to safeguard the producers of branded commodities in the ownership of their brand names. The purpose here ( Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, § 17, subd. 12) is different, viz., by avoiding price wars, "to foster and promote temperance, and provide for the orderly distribution of alcoholic beverages." This motivation has nothing to do with protecting property rights of producers in brand names. Under the Fair Trade Law, price-fixing depends upon the voluntary act of the owner of the brand name in entering into or refraining from entering into a fair trade contract; in the present case, price-fixing of branded alcoholic beverages is made compulsory by the State Liquor Authority except as it may, in its unlimited discretion, choose to make exceptions. (Rule 26.)

4. The quoted words of subdivision 12 of section 17 of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law do not set a standard by which the action of the Authority is controlled [***5] in determining whether or not there shall be mandatory price-fixing. The statute delegates to the Authority the power to determine the important and delicate question whether price-fixing of branded alcoholic beverages does tend "to foster and promote temperance, and provide for the orderly distribution of alcoholic beverages." The Constitution of the State and the orderly processes of representative government require that the Legislature should make such important decisions itself. Otherwise there is no method by which the people can locate responsibility for such fundamental determinations of public policy.

5. Paragraph (b) of subdivision 12 of section 17 of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law likewise violates section 16 of article III of the New York State Constitution, which provides: "No act shall be passed which shall provide that any existing law, or any part thereof, shall be made or deemed a part of said act, or which shall enact that any existing law, or part thereof, shall be applicable, except by inserting it in such act." Incorporation of the Fair Trade Law by reference in subdivision 12 of section 17 of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, even if it were to take [***6] effect without being subject to the fiat of the Authority, would violate the spirit of this provision of the Constitution, for the significant reason that the Fair Trade Law was adopted for a different purpose, viz., to enable the owner of a brand name to protect such name by fixing resale prices at its own election, whereas it is incorporated in the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law for the purpose of facilitating the enforcement of the liquor laws. The Fair Trade Law is not mandatory on produces, and cannot be made so without being removed from its context and altered in substance. The Legislature is constitutionally forbidden to do that except by inserting the applicable provisions of the old law in the new act.

6. A determination of the State Liquor Authority, revoking petitioner's liquor license because of his violations of said statute and rule, should be annualled and the matter remitted to the Authority for suitable action as to the other charges proven against petitioner. Those other charges - receipt of an unfilled order for an excess quantity of liquor, one actual sale of an excess quantity, and some informalities in books and records - were too unsubstantial to have [***7] warranted complete revocation of license.

 

1196 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Haim v. Chapman


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


274 A.D. 132; 80 N.Y.S.2d 835; 1948 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3025



July 7, 1948 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, petitioners, the surviving directors of a corporate taxpayer, sought review a determination by respondent, the State Tax Commission (New York), which affirmed an assessment of a tax under former N.Y. Tax Law art. 9-A, § 209(3), as enacted by 1944 N.Y. Laws ch. 415.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer challenged the legality of the tax as imposed because § 209(3) was enacted and made effective at a time when the taxpayer was lawfully existing and had paid all franchise taxes theretofore imposed and due, the payment of which, prior to the enactment of § 209(3), had, by law, given sanction to the enjoyment of its franchise for a future period subsequent to the effective date of the § 209(3)'s enactment. The taxpayer claimed that it was granted the right to exist for a future period, which included also the right to cease to exist, or dissolve, during that time without payment of such a franchise tax. In affirming the tax imposed by the Commission, the court ruled that the mere abolishment of the taxpayer's opportunity to take measures to become free of a tax violated no rights. The tax imposed by § 209(3) was not a new tax, but only the time and circumstance that occasioned its becoming due and payable constituted the new arrangement. All that was done was to accelerate the time of payment should dissolution be decided upon, and thus close the door to the old opportunity to escape payment. This was within a valid exercise of the taxing power.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the Commission's determination.


HEADNOTES

 [***2] Taxation - franchise tax - constitutional law - Tax Law (art. 9-A, § 209, former subd. 3, as enacted by L. 1944, ch. 415) constitutionally required corporations, including those incorporated before 1944, to pay on dissolution amount of franchise tax computed on basis of net income to extent to which such base had not been used prior to dissolution and would have been so used under article 9-A except for such dissolution. valid exercise of taxing power.

Former subdivision 3 of section 209 of article 9-A of the Tax Law (as enacted by L. 1944, ch. 415) required a corporation which ceased to exercise its franchise to pay an amount of franchise tax computed "upon the basis of its entire net income * * * up to the date of such cessation, to the extent that such entire net income has not theretofore been used as a basis for any franchise tax under this article * * * but would have been so used except for such cessation." Payment of such tax was validly and constitutionally required of a corporation which was incorporated prior to the 1944 statute and thereafter sought to dissolve. Article 9-A had imposed a corporate franchise tax based on net income but had left an opportunity to escape [***3] payment of part of the tax by dissolving and then reincorporating; and the amendment (L. 1944, ch. 415) simply closed that opportunity to escape. It was a valid exercise of the taxing power.

 

1197 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Mayer Bros. Poultry Farms v. Meltzer


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


274 A.D. 169; 80 N.Y.S.2d 874; 1948 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3035; 22 L.R.R.M. 2315; 15 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P64,615



June 30, 1948 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff kosher poultry wholesaler (wholesaler) challenged the decisions of the Supreme Court (New York), which dismissed the wholesaler's complaint against defendants, union and its officials individually (union), and refused to temporarily enjoin the union from conducting a secondary boycott of the wholesaler's poultry.


OVERVIEW: A wholesaler sought review of the lower court's decisions that dismissed its complaint and refused to issue a temporary injunction prohibiting a union and its officials from conducting a secondary boycott. The court affirmed dismissal of the claims against the officials individually without comment. However, the court reversed dismissal of the complaint against the union and the refusal to enjoin the boycott because the private embargo was not a lawful objective, and even if it were lawful, the union could be enjoined from engaging in a secondary boycott.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed dismissal of the wholesaler's complaint against the officials without comment, but reversed the lower court's dismissal of the wholesaler's action against the union, and reversed the lower court's decision not to temporarily enjoin the boycott.


HEADNOTES

Injunctions - picketing - (1) New Jersey packer sold frozen kosher poultry to kosher stores and frozen food stores in New York City; local union of kosher slaughterers picketed such retailers in order to monopolize city kosher poultry market; temporary injunction granted - (2) no labor dispute involved since plaintiff's employees are members of same parent union as defendant and fact that monopoly would increase piece rate pay of New York City operatives of no moment - (3) private embargo to prevent foodstuffs from entering New York City not lawful objective - (4) Allen Bradley Co. v. Union (325 U.S. 797) distinguished -- (5) ousting of State jurisdiction arises where burden imposed on interstate commerce not where, as here, law prevents burden on all commerce whether interstate or intrastate - (6) section 876-a of Civil Practice Act not [***2] intended to amend State law as to restraint of trade - (7) identification of constitutional protection of right of free speech with immunity to impose private embargoes on foodstuffs entering New York City, unwarranted - (8) section 876-a of Civil Practice Act inapplicable - (9) no intention in Labor Management Relations Act of 1947 to divest State courts of jurisdiction in cases like present.

1. A slaughterer and packer of kosher poultry in New Jersey entered the New York City market where it sold such poultry exclusively to retail kosher butcher stores and frozen food stores. In an action to restrain defendants from interfering with such seller's business the complaint alleges that defendant union - an organization of religious officials qualified to slaughter animals in accordance with the ritual requirements of the Hebrew Orthodox faith - has picketed the New York retailers in an endeavor to monopolize the market for the benefit of operatives in that city. Plaintiff's motion for a temporary injunction should be granted and defendants' motion to dismiss the complaint against the union should be denied.

2. Since plaintiff's poultry is conceded to be kosher there is no religious [***3] question in the case nor is there any labor dispute between the parties for plaintiff's employees are members of locals affiliated with the same parent union as defendant. The purpose of defendants' activities is to keep away from the New York City market all frozen kosher poultry slaughtered elsewhere and to limit the market to poultry slaughtered in the city so as to obtain better wages.

3. A private embargo to prevent foodstuffs from entering New York City is not a lawful objective and is not made so by using procedures which would be legitimate if directed toward the accomplishment of other purposes. In the case of foodstuffs alone the consequences of such embargoes would be disastrous in a city as dependent upon outside sources of supply as is New York. That is the interest of the consuming public in this issue.

4. The case of Allen Bradley Co. v. Union (325 U.S. 797) relied on by defendants, although somewhat similar to the present case on the facts, is distinguishable.

5. The question whether State jurisdiction has been ousted is accustomed to arise where a State has imposed a burden upon interstate commerce not where, as here, the State laws prevent burdens [***4] from being laid upon commerce, whether interstate or intrastate. An intention of Congress to exclude States from asserting their police power must be clearly manifested. While the present case involves interstate commerce, the circumstance is coincidental since the barrier established by defendant union applies equally to all poultry slaughtered in the State of New York elsewhere than in New York City.

6. Section 876-a of the Civil Practice Act was not intended to have the effect of amending the substantive State law, common or statutory, respecting restraint of trade and kindred subjects which the United States Supreme Court ascribed to the Norris-La Guardia Act as amending the Federal Antitrust Law.

7. While picketing has been held to be akin to free speech guaranteed by the Constitution of the United States, in none of the cases considered was the United States Supreme Court dealing with an unlawful objective, one which is not a labor objective at all. The controlling features in the present case are that the purpose of the picketing, the erection of an embargo against the importation of frozen kosher poultry into New York City, is an unlawful objective, that no labor controversy [***5] of any kind is involved; that the information on the signs carried by the pickets, while technically accurate, was actually misleading as indicating that there was a labor dispute whereas none existed, and that the signs were not displayed for the purpose of publicizing any legitimate grievance of the union, but rather as a verbal act in a conspiracy to accomplish an unlawful purpose. To identify the cherished constitutional protection of the right of free speech with immunity to impose private embargoes on foodstuffs entering New York City would be unwarranted.

8. Section 876-a of the Civil Practice Act does not apply since the controversy has no relation to terms or conditions of employment but relates instead to something which cannot even properly be the subject of collective bargaining.

9. The Labor Management Relations Act of 1947, known as the Taft-Hartley Act, is not considered except to note that, in providing for the institution of injunction proceedings thereunder by the General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, it was clearly not intended to divest the State courts of Jurisdiction which they had in cases of this kind before its adoption.

Mayer Bros.  [***6] Poultry Farms v. Meltzer, 191 Misc. 830, reversed.

 

1198 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


In re Central Hanover Bank & Trust Co.


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


274 A.D. 772; 80 N.Y.S.2d 127; 1948 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3272



June 21, 1948 

 

1199 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Bull v. Stichman


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division Third Department


273 A.D. 311; 78 N.Y.S.2d 279; 1948 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4589



March 24, 1948 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff citizen sought review of a decision from the Supreme Court, Erie County (New York), which granted the motion to dismiss the citizen's complaint that was filed by defendants, the New York State Emergency Housing Joint Board, a church-related college, and a construction company, in an action to declare a $ 128,000 allocation to the college by the Board unconstitutional as a violation of N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 4.


OVERVIEW: The citizen sought a declaratory judgment to the effect that a $ 128,000 allocation to the church-related college by the Board was unconstitutional. The trial court dismissed the complaint on the ground that the citizen had no special or peculiar interest in the matter other than that common to all taxpayers, which meant that he lacked legal capacity to bring the action. On appeal, the court sustained that judgment. The court noted that the clear weight of authority in the state was against the alleged power and authority of a court to pass upon the constitutionality of a statute except in an action or proceeding on behalf of a person whose special, peculiar personal rights were affected thereby. Because the citizen had not shown any special rights or interests in the matter, the complaint was properly dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment and order, which dismissed the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Actions - taxpayer's action - (1) taxpayer without capacity to maintain action testing constitutionality of expenditure of State funds for religious educational institution; civil or property rights of plaintiff not particularly affected thereby - (2) if question of capacity to sue not raised and matter of great public exigency, court need not inject issue; but such is not this case - (3) section 51 of General Municipal Law, granting taxpayer right to prevent illegal act by municipal officer, not applicable to actions against State.

1. Plaintiff, as a citizen and taxpayer, sought a judgment declaring that a $128,000 allocation to Canisius College (a religious educational institution) by the Emergency Housing Board was unconstitutional. An individual taxpayer is without capacity to maintain an action for a declaratory judgment to test the constitutionality of an act of the Legislature or the activities of State officers thereunder, unless his civil or property rights are specifically and particularly affected thereby.  [***3] The plaintiff in this action has not shown any special rights or interests in the matter other than those common to all taxpayers and citizens. A complaint which does not show that the plaintiff has the requisite rights or interests to enable him to maintain his action must be dismissed for insufficiency.

2. If the question of capacity to sue is not raised and the matter is of great public exigency concerning which all parties desire an immediate determination on the merits, the court on its own motion need not inject that issue. But those factors are not here present.

3. Section 51 of the General Municipal Law granting a right of action to a taxpayer to prevent an illegal act by an official of a municipality is not applicable to actions against the State.

Bull v. Stichman, 189 Misc. 597, affirmed.

 

1200 of 2939 DOCUMENTS


Molnar v. Curtin


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division First Department


273 A.D. 322; 77 N.Y.S.2d 553; 1948 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4591



March 15, 1948 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landlord challenged the decision of the Supreme Court (New York), which denied the landlord's application for an order under N.Y. Civ. Prac. Act § 78 to compel respondent clerk of court to issue a warrant of dispossess to a tenant.


OVERVIEW: The landlord contended that the clerk's refusal, pursuant to the Sharkey anti-eviction law, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § U41-7.0 (1947), to issue a writ of dispossess to a tenant in an eviction action, was an unconstitutional infringement on the landlord's rights. The court affirmed the trial court's decision in favor of denying the writ because 1948 N.Y. Laws 4 validated New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § U41-7.0 (1947), which did not conflict with the Housing and Rent Act of 1947, 50 U.S.C.S. §§ 1881-1902, and neither the due process nor the impairment-of-contract clauses of the United States Constitution invalidated the anti-eviction law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's decision that denied the landlord's request to compel the clerk to issue a warrant of dispossess to a tenant.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations - legislative power - landlord and tenant - rent regulation - validity of local law restricting evictions - (1) Local Law No. 66 of 1947 of City of New York (Administrative Code, § U41-7.0), as validated by State (L. 1948, ch. 4), requiring landlord to obtain certificate from city rent commission before bringing summary proceedings, is constitutional - (2) local law may be validly adopted by State even if such law originally exceeded city's power - (3) local law expressly applies to pending proceedings; landlord had obtained final order, but his application for order under article 78 of Civil Practice Act to compel municipal court clerk to issue warrant of dispossess was properly denied - (4) immaterial that landlord had obtained, prior to enactment of local law, certificate from former U.S. Office of Price Administration permitting eviction proceedings; Federal Housing and Rent Act of 1947 omits prohibition [***2] against local controls contained in Price Control Extension Act of 1946.

1. Local Law No. 66 of 1947 of the City of New York (Administrative Code of City of New York, § U41-7.0), validated by the State (L. 1948, ch. 4), declares a housing emergency situation in the city and prohibits the institution of proceedings to remove a tenant from an apartment unless the landlord first obtains a certificate from the temporary city housing rent commission. The requirement is constitutional. (N.Y. Const., art. IX, § 12; City Home Rule Law, §§ 11, 31; New York City Charter, § 27.)

2. The State may enact legislation which in effect constitutes an adoption of a local law even if the local law originally exceeded the powers of a municipality.

3. The local law applies "to all pending and future eviction proceedings". The State law provides that "Such local laws shall be deemed effectual as of the date when such local laws purported to take effect and all acts authorized thereby are hereby legalized and confirmed." Said requirement of a certificate therefore applies to a pending summary proceeding, at least until a warrant of eviction has been issued, and even though the landlord has [***3] obtained a final order. An application by the landlord in this case for an order under article 78 of the Civil Practice Act to compel the municipal court clerk to issue a warrant of dispossess was therefore properly denied.

4. The landlord had obtained a certificate from the former United States Office of Price Administration permitting eviction proceedings, and had instituted such proceedings on May 6, 1947, but under said local law, enacted September 17, 1947, he must obtain a certificate from the city rent commission. The act extending the Emergency Price Control Act of 1942 to June 30, 1947, provided that "such housing accommodations shall not be subject to rent control by any State or local government" (U.S. Code, tit. 50, Appendix, § 902; Price Control Extension Act of 1946, Public Law 548, 79th Cong., 2d Sess.), but the Federal Housing and Rent Act of 1947 relaxed Federal controls and omitted such provision. (U.S. Code, tit. 50, Appendix, § 1881 et seq.; Public Law 129, 80th Cong., 1st Sess.) The local law as validated by the State law is not in conflict with the Federal law and can be enforced without clashing. No matter how the rights obtained by the landlord [***4] under the certificate previously issued by the Federal Office of Price Administration may be characterized, the validity of the subsequently enacted legislation by the city and State under the police power is not impaired.
